HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
 Mexico adopted a tough new economic plan that suggests a grim near-term future: recession, job loss and personal hardship as unavoidable in recovering from the financial crisis that has severely reduced the peso's value. Among other things, gasoline prices will jump 35 percent, and the value-added tax is to rise to 15 percent. [Page A1.] 
 The U.S. is struggling over whether to ban American companies from doing business with Iran. Secretary of State Warren Christopher condemned Conoco's $1 billion Iranian energy deal. [A2.]
 
Markets
 The Clinton Administration faces dual currency crises: the dollar's slide and the peso's free fall. [D1.]
 The stock market stabilized, as the dollar steadied somewhat, but traders kept a wary eye on the currency markets. [D4.]
 Price of Treasury securities rose, sending the yield on the long bond down to 7.51 percent. [D13.]
 Gasoline futures prices fell to eight-week lows, but lumber, hogs, orange juice and coffee rose. [D14.]
 
The Economy
 The lead in overhauling communications laws is being taken by Senator Larry Pressler, head of the Commerce Committee. [D1.]
 Previously unregulated derivatives operations will be submitted to the review of Federal regulators. Six big brokerage firms volunteered, apparently hoping to head off Congressional efforts to vote more controls over the securities industry. [D1.]
 A $200 billion, five-year tax cut was proposed by Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. The proposals follow the lines of the Contract With America: tax reduction for families of $500 for each child, a lower capital gains tax, tax cuts for working couples and retirees and a variety of business tax breaks. [A16.]
 
Companies
 Morrison Knudsen named a chief executive. Robert A. Tinstman, a 20-year veteran of the company, will succeed William J. Agee, who resigned under fire a month ago. [D1.]
 The abrupt resignation by W. R. Grace's chief executive, J. P. Bolduc, may have resulted from a dispute over whether the company had made full disclosure to shareholders of questionable financial transactions involving J. Peter Grace Jr., the company's chairman, and his son J. Peter Grace 3d. [D3.]
 Peter S. Lynch, corporate director, has been unable to match the enviable record of Peter S. Lynch, mutual fund wizard. He serves on two boards: Morrison Knudsen and W. R. Grace. [D1.]
 Borland International won a stay of execution as a Federal appeals court overturned a lower court ruling that might have required Borland to pay $100 million to Lotus Development. [D1.]
 The suit itself may be derivative. A Chinese Government company is countersuing Lehman Brothers over derivatives. [D3.]
 Hughes Communications announced a $500 million venture with three Latin American media companies to create a satellite-delivered television service. [D3.]
 Fleet Financial and Shawmut National agreed to bring 1,200 jobs to New England to replace jobs lost in their merger. [B5.]
 Christie's surprised the art world with a new fee schedule intended to bolster its flat profits. [C26.]
 
Today's Columns
 Caremark International could become a big market winner, but with legal woes it could also be a loser. Market Place. [D4.]
 South Korea's Kia Motor is cast as a determined upstart with a sense of fun in two campaigns created by Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco. Advertising. [D13.]

HEADLINE: Yeltsin to Allow a European Rights Mission in Chechnya

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 9

 BODY:
In another gesture to Western opinion, President Boris N. Yeltsin agreed today to allow a human-rights mission from the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe to maintain a presence in the secessionist Chechnya republic.
Meeting the Foreign Ministers of Germany, France and Spain, who came here on a mission from the European Union, Mr. Yeltsin repeated his assurances that Russia is committed to a political settlement of the three-month Chechnya war. 
 On Friday Mr. Yeltsin is to meet with the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, to agree formally on an economic program entitling Russia to a $6.4 billion loan. While Mr. Camdessus must present the loan to the Fund's board for approval, the money should begin to flow to Russia in April.
The loan is another sign of Western willingness to deal with Russia as a great power despite Chechnya. But the Fund, which has seen Russian promises of economic rectitude collapse in the past, has insisted on providing the money monthly, not quarterly, dependent on Russian economic performance.
Three days ago, the European Union froze a wide-ranging trade agreement with Russia because of Moscow's military tactics in Chechnya, which included aerial bombing and extensive artillery attacks on a largely defenseless city, Grozny, the capital.
The visit of the three Foreign Ministers -- Klaus Kinkel of Germany, Alain Juppe of France and Javier Solana of Spain, together with the European Union Commissioner, Hans van den Broek -- was intended to seek assurances from Mr. Yeltsin that human rights would be respected in Chechnya and that a political dialogue would start with the Chechens fighting for independence.
Mr. Yeltsin and his Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, urged the European Foreign Ministers today to carry out the trade deal reached last year. Mr. Kozyrev said with some irritation that ratification of the accord was being "unjustifiably dragged out" because of criticisms about Russian behavior in Chechnya.
But the Europeans have been struggling to find a way to express their concern over human rights violations there without undermining either Mr. Yeltsin or the stability of Russia's borders.
Russian forces continue to use bombs and shells against Chechen villages where secessionist fighters are thought to be sheltering. There have been allegations of human rights abuses -- including mistreatment of prisoners -- from organizations like Amnesty International.
After meeting Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Kinkel said the Russians "said in principle they accept the idea of the O.S.C.E. in Chechnya, but we did not go into details" or settle timing.
The establishment of a human rights mission in Chechnya by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe has also been a demand by Washington, Western diplomats said, suggesting that it was a prerequisite before President Clinton agrees to come to Moscow for a summit meeting, which could be in May or June.
But there are other serious issues between Washington and Moscow, including Russia's plans to sell nuclear reactors to Iran, and it is not yet decided whether Mr. Clinton will come here for the anniversary of the defeat of Nazism on May 9.
In Israel, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he would meet Mr. Kozyrev within two weeks on a "substantial agenda." The United States Ambassador to Russia, Thomas R. Pickering, was told by Washington to break off a trip to the Russian Far East and return to Moscow for consultations "on ongoing matters of significant interest to the two Governments," essentially to help set up the Christopher-Kozyrev meeting, a spokesman for the ambassador said.
Mr. Christopher originally wanted to meet Mr. Kozyrev before returning to Washington from the Mideast, American officials said, but that was not possible. So the men are expected to meet the week of March 20, presumably in Geneva.
The European delegation is the highest-level foreign mission to Moscow since Vice President Al Gore saw Mr. Yeltsin on Dec. 16, five days after the Chechnya operation began.
Before arriving in Moscow, the German Foreign Minister, Mr. Kinkel, said the delegation would not "mince its words over Chechnya." The French Foreign Minister, Mr. Juppe, stressed that isolating Russia was not an option, but that "Russia must respect commitments," including respect for human rights.
The O.S.C.E. groups 53 nations, including the United States, Canada and every European country. Moscow would like it to play a stronger role in European security, subordinating NATO, an idea that Washington rejects.
The organization has sent two previous missions to Chechnya, both of them brief. It has condemned the "disproportionate use of force" by Russia in Chechnya, but does not recognize Chechen claims to independence from Moscow.
The organization's previous missions have been careful and done little offending Moscow. The first mission found violations of human rights on both sides; the second offended many Russian human rights advocates when it agreed to get on a military plane to Chechnya without Mr. Yeltsin's human-rights commissioner, Sergei A. Kovalyov. Mr. Kovalyov has been a fierce critic of the war, and the Russian military refused to let him into the air base, even though he was supposed to travel with the mission.
Mr. Kovalyov is now out of the country and could not be reached for comment.

Russia Presses Attack
 SLEPTSOVSK, Russia, March 9 (AP) -- Russian forces pounded villages in southwestern Chechnya today with artillery shells and rockets, casting doubt on the future of an informal truce reached on Wednesday.
Chechen village leaders and Russian military officials met for a second day but agreed only to reconvene "in the near future" to discuss a cease-fire, the Interfax news agency reported, quoting the Chechen district leader in Samashky, Salam Umalatov.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Chinese Suit Against Lehman

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The latest twist in Wall Street's payments spats with China? You guessed it -- derivatives!
A Chinese Government trading company, the Minmetals International Nonferrous Metals Trading Company, countersued Lehman Brothers Inc. yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, contending that the investment bank induced an employee into making "more than $35 billion in unauthorized derivatives trades unrelated to its business." 
 The suit, which seeks $128 million of damages, contends that Lehman's sophisticated investment bankers seduced the employee, Hu Xiangdong, into making "incredibly complicated derivatives transactions that were impossible for him to understand."
A Lehman Brothers spokesman, Steven H. Faigen, responded: "Their complaint and allegations are simply a smokescreen for not paying their obligations. Portraying the situation as similar to some other derivative-related issues is cynical opportunism and has no relation to the facts."
Derivatives are a generic name for a slew of financial instruments -- including options and futures -- that are priced off, and derive from, the underlying performance of stocks and bonds.
Like many other investment banks, Lehman enthusiastically pursued business with companies in China in recent years as that country's economy grew strongly. But that enthusiasm has soured, leading some firms to make staff cutbacks in Hong Kong and other regional offices.
As relations with the Chinese cooled, Lehman in November sued Minmetals International and its parent company, the China National Metals and Mineral Import and Export Company, in the same court, saying it had $53.5 million in unpaid debts and margin calls. Such calls require investors to put up more cash or collateral to help offset losses on their trading.
Minmetals had until next Monday to answer the Lehman suit, and with the countersuit, the matter is expected to go to trial.
"These were young, pushy investment bankers who weren't being supervised that well," said Aaron Rubinstein, a partner at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, the law firm representing Minmetals. He maintained that Mr. Hu was not authorized to make many of the trades and that Lehman did not disclose to him the full risks of the trading.
Mr. Faigen of Lehman denied this and maintained that Mr. Hu was a sophisticated trader who had made some trades that resulted in losses.
Lehman has been more aggressive lately in seeking to resolve its payment difficulties with Chinese Government companies and has gone to court while many other firms with similar problems are still negotiating with the Chinese. In November it also sued the China International United Petroleum Chemicals Company, seeking $44 million in bills that it said had not been paid.
There have recently been a number of disputes between Wall Street firms and Chinese companies. In a separate matter, the China International Trade and Investment Corporation, a Government-owned investment company, settled payments disputes this month with Merrill Lynch & Company and with Lehman, paying an estimated $14 million to the two firms but leaving outstanding financial disagreements with several other big metals trading companies.
Wall Street is not alone, however, in its payment difficulties with Chinese Government companies. Several foreign banks and financial institutions are seeking several hundred million dollars in unpaid debts from China's state companies.

HEADLINE: Senator Deals Blow to Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Joining the growing political debate over affirmative action, the Senator who is the new head of a centrist Democratic group with close ties to President Clinton said today that preferential policies based on race and sex were "patently unfair" and had helped lead to a breakdown in society.
"You can't defend policies that are based on group preferences as opposed to individual opportunities, which is what America has always been about," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the new chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council. 
 "When we have such policies, we have the effect of breaking some of those ties in civil society that have held us together, because they're patently unfair," he added. "And those who are the victims of them and lose out when choices are made based on group preferences as opposed to individual ability naturally become disaffected from the process."
Mr. Lieberman made his remarks in response to questions from reporters after a speech at the National Press Club, and he emphasized that he was speaking as an individual, "but I think reflecting the point of view of the D.L.C."
Mr. Clinton, who helped start the leadership council when he was Governor of Arkansas, recently ordered aides to review the merits of all Federal affirmative action efforts in the face of Republican pressure to scale back preferential programs based on race and sex. The White House hopes to emphasize programs that benefit working Americans, regardless of race or sex, in an effort to hold onto disgruntled white Democrats that Mr. Clinton lured back to the party in 1992, then apparently lost in the midterm elections last fall.
But in a sign of the sensitivity of the issue, the President met briefly at the White House this afternoon with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other representatives of women's and minority groups who urged him not to abandon efforts to redress past discrimination.
Mr. Jackson has suggested he might challenge Mr. Clinton's re-election if he is dissatisfied with the President's position on the question, and he issued a news release today announcing that he would "convene a meeting" with Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff. But after meeting with Mr. Panetta and other top aides for about an hour, and then with Mr. Clinton himself, he told reporters: "We need not suggest any threat. The concern here is we've come to bring clarity, we've come to bring concerns."
He added, "My appeal to Mr. Clinton is to move more quickly, because the review will show the need to renew, not to retreat."
Mr. Jackson said he had urged Mr. Clinton to hold a White House conference on jobs, affirmative action and other issues.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said later, "We think that might dovetail nicely with our plans for a series of economic conferences" around the country in the coming months. He also said Mr. Jackson and the President had agreed to keep in touch.
The Republicans have vowed to make affirmative action a major campaign issue, and in California, Gov. Pete Wilson and others support a ballot proposition in 1996 that would bar the state from awarding jobs or contracts based on race or sex.
Mr. Lieberman said of that proposal, "I can't see how I would be opposed to it, because it basically is a statement of American values." But he said he was just beginning to review the issue and that the leadership council had not yet taken a position. Democrats in California are discussing an alternative to the Republican proposals.
Mr. Lieberman, who has known Mr. Clinton since the President's days at Yale Law School, said that "this business of deciding by group, in a sense, is the flip side of the argument that has flared up here in the last year about genetics, if you will, and the argument that some make that some groups are genetically less able than others.
"That's an un-American argument," he added. "And it's an un-American argument because it's based on averages, not on individuals. And that's the same when we come to group preferences and quotas. America's about individuals, not about averages or groups."
In a news conference last week, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to explore whether the Government could help disadvantaged people in some cases without preferences based on race or gender, through efforts like expanding preschool programs and college loans, extending tax breaks to working families and providing aid to cities.
"Where we can move ahead based on need, we ought to move forward and we shouldn't move backward," Mr. Clinton said then, sketching out a theme that his advisers say he intends to stress in the coming weeks. "There are still a lot of people who aren't living up to their capacity in this country, and it's hurting the rest of us."
On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton's chief pollster, Stanley Greenberg, warned that "the Democratic coalition cannot be based on social justice claims of some segment of their coalition against other segments of the coalition" if it is to prevail and retain its majority status.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

WEAPON OF CHOICE IN SCHOOLS: BOX CUTTER
 At first, the two dozen or so students milling about outside Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx agreed that schools need to be made safer. But in a few moments, swift as switchblades, the students produced a gleaming assortment of weapons. There was a pearl-handled pocket knife, a pair of brass knuckles and, most favored of all, box cutters. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 

AIRPORTS PLAN SAFETY PADS FOR PLANES
 The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said that it would install foam blocks at the end of some runways at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports, as a kind of flypaper for airplanes that roll too far. B3.
 
PATAKI ASKS JAVITS BOARD TO RESIGN
 Governor Pataki branded conditions at the corruption-tainted Jacob K. Javits Convention Center "intolerable to me and to all New Yorkers," and called for its board to resign. B3.
 
BODY OF SECOND BURNED WOMAN IS FOUND
 Five days after the police found the charred body of a 20-year-old Canarsie woman in the basement of a vacant house, the body of another young woman -- also burned beyond recognition -- was found in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The police said they had no specific evidence to link the two cases but added that there were some similarities. B3.
 
MAYOR'S POPULARITY SUFFERS A DROP
After a year of high approval ratings for Mayor Giuliani, his austere budget proposals have apparently caused his popularity to sag sharply in the last few months, according to a poll. B3.
 
GIULIANI ORDERS REVIEW OF HOSPITALS
 In response to reports of high rates of deaths and injuries for newborns at New York City's public hospitals, Mayor Giuliani and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said that they had begun a review of delivery room care. B2.
 
THOUSANDS HAVE FUND TO THANK
 Thousands of lives were made better this year by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A total of 12,868 donors from Bay Ridge to Bangkok helped raise $4,526,919.95, the third-highest total ever. B2.
 
REGION
 
BANKS PLEDGE TO PRESERVE JOBS
 Under intense pressure from Gov. John G. Rowland, Connecticut's two largest banks announced that they had revised their merger plans to guarantee that the state would not lose jobs. B5.
 
CATSKILLS RESIDENTS RALLY FOR CASINO
 At a standing-room-only meeting of the Sullivan County Board of Supervisors, local residents rallied in support of the Oneida Indian Nation's proposal to build a casino and said they would fight to get approval from the Governor. Without a casino, they said, the Catskills region's economy would continue to slide. B5.
 
SPEAKER BACKS TIME LIMITS ON WELFARE
 Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said that he would support time limits on welfare for childless, able-bodied adults if they refuse to enter job training or to search for work. B4.
 
SUIT SEEKS TV MONEY FOR VICTIM'S ESTATE
 In one of the first lawsuits filed under New York's revised "Son of Sam" law, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco asked a court to force Time Warner to pay $55,000 to the estate of a murder victim whose killing was portrayed in a made-for-television movie. B4.

HEADLINE: Dollar Dips As the Peso Falls Again

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration faced not one currency crisis but two today as the dollar slipped again, pulled down by a free fall in the value of the Mexican peso. That decline in the peso is threatening the American effort to keep its neighbor from financial collapse.
"I believe that in time, investor confidence in Mexico will be restored," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a speech this morning in which he tried to talk up the value of the dollar. "While markets will move around, the program is sound and it should work." 
 But in private, American officials were far less optimistic today, fearing that the United States might get dragged deeper into Mexico's financial quagmire.
American officials and private economists agree that there is now little question that Mexico's troubles have played a significant role in the precipitous decline of the dollar. That linkage has, in turn, brought demands on Capitol Hill that the Clinton Administration find a way to cut itself free of its $20 billion bailout plan for Mexico announced last month. Any such move was rejected by Mr. Rubin today.
Instead, American officials are hoping that investors who have been pulling out of the country at a tremendous pace will be tempted to return with Mexico's adoption of a tough new austerity plan.
"It is a horribly difficult situation, and there are a lot of reasons to wonder whether this is going to work," a senior Government official said today of the Mexican plan. "At this point we are in so deep that there is no turning back."
Mr. Rubin made a strong effort to talk the dollar up, repeating that "a strong dollar is in America's self-interest" and threatening to intervene in the currency markets -- something the United States has not done this week -- "when it makes sense."
But the markets shrugged off the statement from Mr. Rubin, who once oversaw currency trading at Goldman, Sachs & Company, and the dollar fell in New York today to 91.02 yen from 91.42 on Wednesday. It eked out a gain against the German mark, ending the day at 1.4055 marks, up from 1.3960.
The bigger worry for American officials was not the small slide in the dollar today, but the larger problem that the main objective of the Mexican bailout -- to strengthen the peso and persuade foreign investors to return to Mexico -- does not appear to be succeeding. At best, many economists said today, the plan announced by Mexican officials would cause a recession in Mexico that should give the country a good-sized trade surplus, which would probably come largely at the expense of United States exporters. Already, American exports to Mexico -- once hailed by President Clinton as a sign of the success of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- have come to a near halt. And, unless Mexican domestic inflation sends the prices of its exports up more rapidly than its currency is depreciating, it may be only a matter of time before imports from Mexico take off. For now, at least, exports from Mexico, when measured in dollars, are half as expensive as they were in December.
"The Mexican economy has hit a brick wall," said Lawrence Chimerine, the chief economist of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, which tends to favor a more confrontational United States trade approach. "Business is off 40 or 50 percent; the banks are in increasing risk of major failure, and the peso is dragging down the dollar. The only people coming out whole are the investors in Mexican bonds, who are cashing in and running."
The objective of the Clinton Administration's plan, part of a $50 billion international package of loans hastily assembled last month, was to stabilize Mexico enough that investors would be willing to keep their money there.
If that does not happen, it is only a matter of time before Mexico runs through the loans provided by the United States and the International Monetary Fund. At that point, the Administration will be faced with letting Mexico default -- a possibility Mr. Rubin called "extremely unlikely" -- or committing new money, which could prove politically ruinous.
Already Republicans like Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, are charging that the plan is a failure and that American aid to Mexico should be halted. Congress refused to act on the Mexican bailout earlier this year, forcing Mr. Clinton to move on his own, which left the Administration the focus of all the criticism. Mr. Rubin is scheduled to testify about the plan before Mr. D'Amato's committee on Friday morning, in what is expected to be a heated confrontation.
While Mr. D'Amato's call for disengagement from Mexico has drawn support on Capitol Hill, many leading economists argue that pulling out would only make things worse for American exporters and probably for the dollar. "It would be a total abdication of U.S. leadership," said C. Fred Bergsten, who heads the Institute for International Economics, which tends to push for free trade. "The message would be that the U.S. had gone isolationist, and that alone would trash the dollar. And Mexico would default, giving us the worst of all worlds."
But for Mr. Clinton, Mexico's crisis threatens to undermine a main theme of his Presidency: that the economic future of America is bound up in its partnerships with leading trading partners. Throughout last year, when Mr. Clinton deepened ties with emerging markets in Asia and convened the first Latin American summit meeting, he made a persuasive case that American job growth was directly linked to increasing exports to "emerging markets."
That is a far more difficult case to make today, and Mr. Rubin is clearly concerned that if Mexico's troubles spread to other markets, the United States is headed for an even larger trade deficit next year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up as Dollar Is Steadier

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury issues rose yesterday for a second day as the dollar steadied. Some traders also said that Mexico's deepening financial crisis encouraged demand for the perceived safety of United States debt.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 10113/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.51 percent, from 7.54 percent on Wednesday. 
 Treasury bills and notes that mature in two years or less, which are typically viewed as the world's safest and most easily traded securities, gained even more than bonds. The yield on the two-year note fell 5 basis points, to 6.82 percent, and bill yields dropped as much as 6 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Concern that United States banks may face losses on Latin American assets prompted some investors to swap bank stocks for short-term Treasury securities, traders said.
"It's the old 'flight to quality' thing, and it's helping the market," said William Feezer, co-head of trading at Sanwa Securities (USA). "Mexico is just slipping under the bridge. We've got to cut them loose at some point."
Bond traders said bank stocks could keep slipping as economic conditions in Mexico and other Latin American nations worsened, bolstering short- and medium-term Treasury securities.
"It would not shock me if somewhere, either in Europe or in the U.S., financial institutions were taking sizable hits," said Rebekah Helzel, a trader at BA Securities. "Where there is smoke, there is fire."
Treasury issues gained even though the dollar fell to 91.02 Japanese yen, from 91.42 yen on Wednesday. A weaker dollar makes United States securities less attractive to foreign investors and can accelerate inflation by making imported goods more expensive.
Bond prices fell for four days before rebounding on Wednesday as the dollar plunged against leading currencies. The resilience of Treasury securities yesterday in the face of a weak dollar suggested to some investors that a declining dollar would not necessarily drive down bonds, pushing yields higher.
"The dollar is being unfairly abused," said George Mateyo, chief executive of Carnegie Capital Management in Cleveland, which has $3 billion in bonds.
In a hopeful sign for bond investors, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, said yesterday that "there are indications, though not yet definitive indications," that the economy's growth rate was slowing from the 4 percent of last year. Mr. Blinder also said he did not see any signs that inflation would accelerate.
In the municipal market, Michigan's strong credit and an attractive maturity date of Sept. 29 helped to raise demand for $500 million in 5 percent notes issued by that state, said Mike Carbuto, who manages about $1 billion of securities for the Oppenheimer Management Corporation. "It's a balance between supply and demand."
A lack of new notes helped the offering, traders said. Municipal note sales have totaled $5.86 billion this year, down 53 percent from the period a year earlier, according to the Securities Data Company.
The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer's index of 40 actively traded municipals fell to 6.44 percent, from 6.45 percent on Wednesday.
In the corporate market, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation of North America and Spiegel Inc. took advantage of declining Government bond yields to sell $1.682 billion of corporate bonds and asset-backed securities.
Mortgage-backed securities also rose yesterday. Some investors are more optimistic about mortgage securities because they expect lower interest rates and the spring housing season to prompt more homeowners to pay off loans early by moving to new homes or refinancing.

HEADLINE: A House G.O.P. Leader Sets $200 Billion in Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Firing the first shot in what is bound to be a long battle over tax policy, Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed today a plan for cutting taxes by almost $200 billion over the next five years.
The proposals essentially follow the lines of the Contract With America, the campaign platform of Republican candidates for the House of Representatives last fall. The main aspects are tax reduction for almost all families of $500 for each child, a lower capital gains tax, tax cuts for working couples and retirees, and a variety of tax breaks for businesses. 
 The measure will be taken up by the Ways and Means Committee next week. Republicans in the House are so unified nowadays that the bill is almost certain to be approved virtually intact there.
But its prospects for eventual enactment are problematic because of strong opposition from President Clinton and from influential senators more interested in reducing the Federal budget deficit than in cutting taxes.
"The American people are highly overtaxed," Mr. Archer said in a speech today to the Family Research Council, a group that lobbies for conservative causes.
He took issue with politicians who say the Government cannot afford tax cuts because of the large budget deficit.
"The argument," said Mr. Archer, a 13-term Republican Congressman from Houston, "goes like this: Congress blew it. Congress spent it. Congress did it. So you, the taxpayer, must suffer.
"To that," Mr. Archer continued, "I say no way, no how, no chance. Not on my watch."
Democrats were quick to criticize the proposal.
At a news conference, Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, asserted, "It's the wrong time and the wrong tax cut."
"The most productive thing we can do for the American public now is to reduce the deficit," Mr. Gibbons said.
At the White House, Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, told reporters, "The President rejects the idea of targeting the most vulnerable in our society -- our children, needy families, the homeless -- in order to pay for these tax cuts, especially for tax cuts that are benefiting the wealthiest."
Such influential Republican Senators as Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, have said they are opposed to tax cuts as long as the budget deficit remains.
Mr. Archer insisted that "not one single penny of tax relief will be provided unless it is offset by spending cuts." But even if that is the case, the tax reductions would doubtless make deficit reduction harder.
The cost of his proposals in lost revenue from now through the year 2000 would be $189 billion, the Congressional tax staff estimates. Moreover, the full effect of many of the proposals would not be felt for several years.
The tax staff estimated last month that the tax provisions of the Contract With America would cost about $500 billion in lost revenue from 2001 to 2005, and staff specialists said today that the cost of Mr. Archer's measure in those years would be of the same magnitude.
His committee and others in the House have already approved billions of dollars in spending cuts for child welfare, food stamps, school lunches and other programs that mostly benefit the poor. Further cuts are expected to be approved soon in Medicare and Medicaid. Republicans in the House intend these spending cuts to help cover the cost of tax cuts in the first five years.
Republicans have given no indication how they hope to reduce spending enough to cover the long-term price tag of the tax measure and still reach their goal of a balanced Federal budget.
Mr. Archer's presentation this morning was carefully staged to emphasize the change in party control in the House.
Democrats used to make tax announcements in the cavernous, formal Ways and Means hearing room with lobbyists standing three deep along the walls. Mr. Archer made his presentation before a bank of television cameras in a cramped basement room, where he was introduced by a young couple from Virginia holding their year-old daughter.
"We will bring tax relief aimed at helping the American family get ahead and stay ahead," Mr. Archer said.
Mr. Archer's measure makes some small changes in the tax provisions of the Contract With America.
The main aspects of reductions in capital gains taxes -- a lower rate and the adjustment of gains for inflation -- would be retained. The top tax rate on capital gains, the profits from the sale of securities and other investments, would fall to 19.8 percent from the current 28 percent. But for assets that are already in a taxpayer's portfolio, the inflation adjustment would be measured beginning this year regardless of when the asset was bought. And investors would not be allowed to claim a capital loss just because their profits were less than what was needed to keep pace with inflation.
The Archer bill would also repeal the alternative minimum tax as it applies to businesses, an item in the tax code meant to make sure that profitable concerns with large write-offs still pay some taxes.
In addition, the tax credit for children that was outlined in the Republican contract would have been partly refundable, meaning that families with incomes so low that they did not owe enough taxes to take full advantage of the credit would have been given a cash rebate. Mr. Archer, on the other hand, decided that it should not be refundable. The credit would be fully available to families with annual incomes below $200,000 and partly available to those with incomes between $200,000 and $250,000.
These are some of the other aspects of the Archer bill:
*A tax cut of up to $145 for working couples, to reduce the unfavorable tax consequences that often arise when two single workers marry.
*A new and more generous retirement savings account that would allow penalty-free withdrawals for buying a home and some other purposes.
*A repeal of the higher taxes that were enacted in 1993 on the Social Security benefits of middle- and upper-income retirees, and an increase to $30,000 from $11,500 in the amount people from 65 through 69 can earn without reduction in Social Security payments.
*Tax breaks for adoption expenses, the cost of caring for the elderly, long-term-care insurance and life insurance distributions to the terminally ill.
*More generous depreciation rules for businesses with capital investments.
*Lower estate and gift taxes.
The Archer proposal is considerably more generous than separate tax-cut measures offered by President Clinton and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader.

(Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ian Ballantine, 79, a Publisher Who Led Move Into Paperbacks

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR 

 BODY:
Ian Ballantine, a pioneer in publishing and founder of three important paperback houses, died yesterday at his home in Bearsville, N.Y. He was 79.
The cause was cardiac arrest, his office said. 
 In a distinguished career that spanned more than five decades, Mr. Ballantine, who was devoted to the notion that people would read a wide variety of books if they were affordable and accessible, founded Penguin U.S.A., Bantam Books and Ballantine Books.
Born in 1916 in New York City, Mr. Ballantine showed an early fascination with publishing, when, as an undergraduate at Columbia University, he wrote a paper in which he described paperbound books as the great hope of publishing.
In 1939, as Pocket Books prepared to introduce one of the first American paperback lines, Mr. Ballantine, fresh out of the London School of Economics, arrived with a stack of paperbacks published by Penguin Books in Britain. He and his wife, Betty, opened Penguin U.S.A. and began importing such classics as "The Invisible Man" by H. G. Wells and "My Man Jeeves," by P. G. Wodehouse.
In 1945, the Ballantines left Penguin to begin a reprint house, which they named Bantam Books. Just months later, having bought the paperback rights for 20 hard-cover books, they released their first list, including "Life on the Mississippi" by Mark Twain, "The Grapes of Wrath" by John Steinbeck, "The Great Gatsby" by F. Scott Fitzgerald and several westerns and mysteries.
No longer were Americans, many of them former servicemen and women in the habit of reading paperback books distributed during World War II, limited to the costly hard-covers found in urban bookshops. They could now buy paperbacks in train stations and other retail outlets throughout the country as well. Hardcover editions had sold for $2 or more; the paperbacks cost 25 cents.
In 1952, the Ballantines founded Ballantine Books, turning their focus to paperback originals, or books first published in paperback form instead of hard-cover. While broad-based in their selections, they found their industry niche by publishing the science fiction, fantasy, western and mystery genres.
"That's where they made one of their most distinctive contributions," said Irwyn Applebaum, president and publisher of Bantam Books. "They really helped make the genres of science fiction, fantasy, western and mystery true mass market best sellers by nurturing a whole generation of novelists."
The Ballantines published a successful and original line of military histories and first-person accounts of World War II. They also developed lines of science fiction and fantasy, including the works of Ray Bradbury, who wrote "The Martian Chronicles," and Arthur C. Clarke, who wrote "2001: A Space Odyssey," and J. R. R. Tolkein, author of "The Hobbit" and "Lord of the Rings" trilogy. And they acquired, edited and published books by Carlos Castenada and Tom Robbins.
In 1974, the Ballantines sold the business to Random House and rejoined Bantam Books, where they worked with such authors as Chuck Yeager and Shirley MacLaine.
To his employees, Mr. Ballantine was something of an enigma, sometimes stern, sometimes playful. "Talking with Ian was a cross between a friendly browbeating and a sprinkling of pixie dust," Mr. Applebaum said.
Until his death, Mr. Ballantine maintained an editorial office at Bantam Books at 1540 Broadway in midtown Manhattan and still spent his days wheeling around a cart filled with illustrations and manuscripts.
In recent years, the Ballantines also worked under the name Rufus Publications, named for Mrs. Ballantine's dog, where they edited and put together illustrated art and fantasy books, like "Faeries," by Brian Froud, as well as the 1992 best seller "Dinotopia," by James Gurney.
The Ballantines were the recipients of the Literary Market Place's Lifetime Achievement Award last month.
He is survived by his wife; a son, Richard, who lives in England; a brother David, of Bearsville, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Popularity Suffers Sharp Drop in a Poll

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
After a year of high approval ratings for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, his austere budget proposals have apparently caused his popularity to sag sharply in the last few months, according to a poll released yesterday.
The poll, which was taken by Quinnipiac College, in Hamden, Conn., indicated that 46 percent of the people surveyed approved of Mr. Giuliani's performance, compared with 56 percent in a poll conducted by the college in December. In the same period, the Mayor's disapproval rating increased to 40 percent from 27 percent in the December survey. 
 "Mayor Giuliani's honeymoon is definitely over, as New Yorkers begin to weigh the personal implications of the budget crisis," said William J. McLaughlin, director of the college's polling operation. "His approval ratings, which were a consistent 2-to-1, now match the narrow margin by which he was elected."
Despite the drop in his overall popularity, Mr. Giuliani received high marks on his handling of crime, with 60 percent of the people surveyed approving of his performance, and 28 percent disapproving.
As in earlier polls, there were dramatic differences in Mr. Giuliani's approval ratings among white, black and Hispanic New Yorkers. Black respondents gave him a 19 percent approval rating, with 69 percent disapproving. Thirty-four percent of Hispanic New Yorkers approved of the Mayor's performance, with 50 percent disapproving. Among white residents, the Mayor received a 63 percent approval rating, with 23 percent disapproving.
When it came to Mr. Giuliani's handling of the city's budget deficit, 52 percent of those surveyed said they disapproved of his performance, with 33 percent approving and 15 percent saying they were uncertain.
The poll was conducted through surveys of 755 New York City residents between Feb. 28 and Tuesday. The poll has a margin of sampling error of 3.6 percent.
Speaking to reporters at City Hall, Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that his fiscal policies had hurt his popularity, but said that he viewed the impact as being short-term.
"It reflects the fact that we've had to make a lot of very tough decisions on the budget," Mr. Giuliani said. "I think as people understand the effect of it and see the positive impact it will have on the economy of the city, it will turn out to be a very positive thing."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
As Drive Ends, Thousands Have Fund to Thank

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
In Harlem, an orphaned boy grieving for his parents found solace in art therapy. In the South Bronx, a single mother returned to school when she found free day care for her toddler. And in Brooklyn, through counseling, a sorrowful old man finally accepted his wife's death.
They were among thousands whose lives were made better this year by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, whose 83d annual campaign ended last week. A total of 12,868 donors from Bay Ridge to Bangkok helped raise $4,526,919.95, the third-highest total ever. Although the campaign ended March 1, the final tally was not completed until yesterday. 
 The fund took in record amounts in December, but fell behind last year's pace by mid-January. In the end, it fell short of the 1994 appeal, which raised $4.59 million, but passed the 1993 effort, which took in $4.47 million. The lingering effects of a recession in the metropolitan area may be partly to blame; many donors wrote that they had to give less this year because of their own hardships.
Last week, it looked as if the fund total might be the lowest since 1989. But articles about the predicament stirred readers' compassion. In its final 24 hours, the fund received $144,521.
"We send this very modest donation in the hope that it will help (even if just a little bit) in the final push toward matching last year's contributions to the fund," wrote Michael Farber and Liz Luhoja of Manhattan, who sent $25. "In a time where so little attention is being given to social services, the fund is more important than ever."
Many people, like Barbara R. Robey of Manhattan, sent second donations after reading that the fund was behind.
"It's my way of saying that while the governments of this country and state and city are appearing mean-spirited and short-sighted, not all of the citizenry go along with that," wrote Ms. Robey, who sent $100.
Since it was established in 1912 by The Times's publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, the fund has proved the generosity of New Yorkers. The first appeal, in 1912, received 117 gifts totaling $3,630.88. The $1 million mark was passed in the 1970-71 campaign, and the fund's annual total broke $2 million in 1984, and $4 million in 1989.
In the coming year, Neediest Cases money will help the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service continue Project Moving On, which teaches job skills to mentally ill adults. It will enable the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies to finance antiviolence projects in neighborhoods rife with crime. And it will offer a lifeline to thousands of people for whom survival is a daily struggle.
The fund will help immigrants like Vitaly Nisanov, a mentally retarded man who has flourished in a day program sponsored by UJA-Federation of New York. It will help children like Nicholas Wright, who received a new set of teeth thanks to the Children's Aid Society. It will help homeless New Yorkers like Charles Foreste, who slept at the 79th Street Boat Basin before the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services found him subsidized housing.
For all the people who benefit from the fund, there are others who make it a success. Throughout the winter, a steady stream of contributions came from families, businesses and school children, many with their own compelling stories. They included Johnny Suzuki of Chiba, Japan, who sent $20 "to the good American people having a hard time," and Audrey Amdursky of Manhattan, who donated $9,050 in memory of a son who she said died of complications from H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
Contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund will continue to be accepted throughout the year and credited to next year's campaign, which will begin on Thanksgiving Day.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Losing Money and Nobels

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Save a dollar even if you wind up losing two, or three. Somehow it does not seem the greatest way in the world to run a business, or a government.
But it happens when business management gets panicky, cannot come up with a strategy of cost control, investment and growth and instead just hacks, hacks, hacks. 
 And it happens to governments, when cutting budget and taxes become so politically and emotionally overriding to public and officials that the knife lops off or cripples parts of American life that pay back far more than they cost.
Everybody with a slice of brain knows that if the city and state slash back too hard on money to the cultural life of New York they will wither one of its major industries, the taxes it pays and the billions it brings from tourism.
But it does not sink in that an important source of revenue and economic progress is the City University of New York. This quite stunning collection of senior colleges, community colleges, professional schools and graduate center now faces one of the most severe budget-cutting threats in its history.
Penny wise. In plain bottom line: College graduates earn more, spend more and pay more taxes once they get that degree.
CUNY estimates that graduates of the 1970 to 1993 classes annually returned $4 billion more to New York than if they had stopped at high school. That does not even count us, the heavier earning, spending and taxed older graduates; I think I paid $4 billion in taxes myself. Anyway, we CUNY people have paid back for decades of college budgets, and still are paying.
The state contributes most of the budget of the senior colleges, and the city the two-year community colleges. Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani demand deep cuts.
For the 11 senior colleges alone, Governor Pataki is proposing a cut of $158.1 million. CUNY says that is a 25.7 percent reduction, compared with an overall cut in the state budget of 3.4 percent. The Governor says it can be made up if the colleges raise their tuition by $1,000, to $3,450.
That is less than Harvard. But students and faculty are nervy enough to complain. Maybe that's because for most of the history of the colleges, beginning in 1847, tuition was what it had to be to carry out the founding philosophy that bright, poor boys -- no girls existed then -- had the right to try for higher education. Tuition was zero.
In 1976, CUNY was forced to begin charging tuition. That was impossible for most students to pay. So they had to apply for "student aid." How I would have hated that -- higher education as a charitable dollop instead of the American right to go as far as my brain took me.
Youngsters from lower-middle-class families were judged too rich for the aid they needed to stay in college. But they did not have money to go to "pay schools."
If the new cuts stand, CUNY will have to slash faculty and classes so deep that it will hardly be a university anymore, or pass the burden on to the students.
Students whose family incomes, meager though they be, disqualify them for student aid may drop out when they find that the new tuition requires a full-time job, and that it is just too much for body and brain.
I could not have done it. I would not have wanted my sons to have to.
The state demands elimination of "remedial" classes. That would account for only a small part of the cuts. Remedial classes do not belong in colleges. But they should be phased out by academic decision, not a government fiat that will be taken hard by families, mostly minority, who still see them as a key to a door.
If graduating classes dwindle and CUNY slides irretrievably into the oblivion of mediocrity, this city will lose not only taxes but economic and social propellant.
CUNY tops Standard & Poor's survey of baccalaureate alumni who are top corporate leaders. Will anybody ever be our modern Baruch, our 12th Nobel, our 2d Colin Powell, our new Salk? All those thousands of graduates who became doctors, engineers, teachers, business leaders and scientists because New York gave them the chance -- what is the bottom line on having them and what will it be if we lose them?

HEADLINE: Chrysler Cuts Sales Forecast

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 9

 BODY:
Citing two consecutive months of disappointing sales, the Chrysler Corporation has cut its forecast for 1995 sales in the United States by 200,000 units, to 15.8 million cars and trucks from 16 million vehicles.
The estimate was revised last week but made public at the Geneva auto show today by the chairman of Chrysler, Robert J. Eaton. It is the second reduction this year in the outlook of the auto maker for 1995. 
 In February an economist for Chrysler, Van Bussmann, lowered his forecast for 1995 by 200,000 units, to 16 million vehicles, after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates.
Mr. Bussmann was not available to comment on the latest revision by Chrysler. But Mr. Eaton said concerns about interest rates appeared to be taking their toll.

HEADLINE: PAN AMERICAN GAMES;
The Games Go On but Feel a Global Financial Pinch

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, March 9

 BODY:
The Pan American Games, a preamble to the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, opened today in this oceanside resort, but the anticipation of gold medals is tempered by hemispheric political and economic concerns, including the level of future participation by the United States.
The 19-day Pan Am Games are held every four years, in the year preceding the Summer Olympics. The United States is spending $4.1 million to send a contingent of 750 athletes and 450 coaches and officials to Argentina. But with the United States Olympic Committee facing the possibility of budget cutbacks after the Atlanta Games, the number of athletes competing in future Pan Am Games could be reduced. 
 "I don't think there is any question that future U.S. participation in the Pan Am Games is up for careful review within our anticipated budget constraints," John Krimsky, the interim executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, said today.
The U.S.O.C. is bound by the Amateur Sports Act of 1978 to participate in the Pan Am Games. They serve as a vital competition in the year before the Summer Olympics. Politically, the Pan Am Games have also been a valuable tool for the United States in securing support from Latin America to obtain host sites for the Winter and Summer Olympics.
Traditionally, the United States has fielded its full complement of roster spots for participation in international events. But, given the worst-case scenario that the U.S.O.C.'s budget could shrink from $400 million to $300 million in the next quadrennium, some financial belt-tightening is inevitable, if only to reduce the number of officials who attend.
Others among the 42 nations competing in the 1995 Pan Am Games are suffering far more urgent economic problems. Mexico has experienced a staggering devaluation of the peso, which appears to have had a significant impact on state-supported sports programs, U.S.O.C. officials said.
Mexico is sending 324 athletes to Argentina, 15 fewer than it sent to the 1991 Pan Am Games in Cuba, and has had to negotiate with private companies to pay for its contingent, according to Mario Vasquez Rana, a Mexican International Olympic Committee member who is also president of the Pan American Sports Organization. Vasquez Rana said the peso devaluation would have "no effect at all" on Mexico's participation in the Pan Am Games, but American officials said they had been told otherwise in discussions with Mexican officials.
After Puerto Rico withdrew from the women's basketball competition last week, the U.S.O.C. offered to fly the Mexican women's team to Argentina on its charter from Miami in a futile attempt to keep the event from being canceled. Mexico declined, partly for economic reasons, Krimsky said.
For reasons related to its deepening economic crisis, Cuba's entourage of 494 athletes at the Pan Am Games includes only those who are believed capable of winning medals, according to Reynaldo Gonzalez, the country's Minister of Sport. Included will be the boxer Felix Savon and the high jumper Javier Sotomayor, both Olympic champions. Absent will be the distance runner Ana Fidelia Quirot, an Olympic bronze medalist at 800 meters, who suffered severe burns in a fire at her home in January 1993. She had skin graft surgery, Gonzalez said, and "is not yet ready for competitions like this one."
Cuba could also lose more of its top stars through political defections that have already come in the sports of boxing, weight lifting, baseball, softball and basketball. Some 40 Cuban athletes defected at the Central American Games in Puerto Rico in November 1993.
"It's not a big concern," Gonzalez said. "You have to put it in perspective. It happens all the time, in a lot of countries. Athletes are free if they want to defect. But I don't believe it is ethical to emphasize the news about the few who defected over the accomplishments of the many athletes who stayed."
The opening ceremonies will be held here Saturday. Gymnastics competition began today, and the United States men finished second to Cuba in the compulsory portion of the team competition.
The United States will field Olympic-caliber teams in such sports as gymnastics, swimming, boxing, wrestling and cycling. The caliber of other American teams, particularly baseball and men's basketball, have been affected by the time of year, which is the end of summer in the Southern Hemisphere.
The United States threatened not to send a baseball team here, until field improvements were made at the Pan Am stadium in Buenos Aires. A college team had to be found that could fit a trip into its schedule with a minimal interruption. St. John's University was the choice.
Because this is tournament time in college basketball and the middle of the National Basketball Association season, players from various teams in the Continental Basketball Association, including the former Michigan star Rumeal Robinson, will represent the United States in men's basketball.
After Puerto Rico withdrew from the women's basketball competition, saying that six team members were playing college ball in the United States, the event was canceled. Only four teams were remaining -- the United States, Argentina, Brazil and Cuba -- one short of the minimum of five for a Pan Am tournament. Particularly affected were several members of the United States team who had passed up opportunities to play in Europe this season.
"We're greatly disappointed," Krimsky said. "We had a strong team."

HEADLINE: House Votes to Help Medical Profession in Court

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
After intense lobbying, pharmaceutical companies and doctors succeeded today in being included in a sweeping measure taken up by the House that would for the first time set limits in all of the nation's courts on damages awarded in civil lawsuits.
The House is set to vote on Friday on the complete measure, the last bill in a three-part Republican package intended to sharply reduce the number of lawsuits that go to trial. Like the two previous measures, which were easily passed by the Republican-controlled House, the bill debated today is expected to win approval, though the prospects in the Senate are far less clear. 
 The pharmaceutical industry had long sought the provision it won today, an amendment that would make it immune from punitive damages in suits involving drugs or devices approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The House approved the amendment by a voice vote. Drug companies would not have immunity if they gave false information to the F.D.A.
The American Medical Association, which represents about 40 percent of the country's doctors, has lobbied heavily this week to have medical malpractice awards included in some of the limits.
These were among the amendments to the measure taken up by the House today. In all the measure would make it more difficult for plaintiffs to win punitive damages against people they sue for negligence. It would set a cap on punitive damages of $250,000 or three times the amount of actual damages awarded, whichever is greater. It would also make it more difficult to win product-liability lawsuits, those arising out of claims that a product like a car or a toaster or a heart valve malfunctioned.
Punitive damages are awarded by juries on top of actual damages to express outrage or punish defendants for flagrant misconduct. The legislation would not put limits on actual damages like lost wages and medical expenses. The punitive damages are at the heart of complaints that the legal system is out of control with juries capriciously making excessive awards.
In the amendment backed by the doctors, introduced on the floor today by Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, jury awards for factors like pain and suffering would also be limited to $250,000 in medical malpractice cases.
"We consider this a litmus-test issue," said James Stacy, a spokesman for the medical association. "This is the first time that a cap on such awards has been on the floor of the House." The association was calling doctors around the country today, telling them to urge their representatives to approve the Cox amendment.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who heads the Judiciary Committee, said the bill would curtail what he called lawsuit abuse. "Lawsuit abuse saps our economy, eliminates jobs, pits neighbor against neighbor and injures our country's global competitiveness," he said.
The measure, like the other two bills in the package, is generally favored by corporations while opposed by consumer groups and trial lawyers.
The amendment sought by the medical association would work this way: A plaintiff sues a doctor after, say, a botched operation. The patient could sue for his actual damages, like lost wages or extra medical costs incurred. He could also sue for pain and suffering but under the amendment only up to the cap of $250,000. The cap for punitive damages would be $250,000 or three times the actual damages, whichever is greater.
Doctors and their advocates have been complaining for more than 20 years about skyrocketing malpractice insurance premiums, which they say are caused by the enormous awards for pain and suffering given by sympathetic juries. Punitive damages are infrequently awarded in medical malpractice cases.
Mr. Stacy of the medical association said the incidence of high awards for pain and suffering was the reason many insurance companies had stopped providing medical malpractice insurance.
For the last week, several chiefs of individual pharmaceutical companies have come themselves in Washington to lobby members over the drug amendment, House staff aides and industry representatives said.
Louis Hoynes, senior vice-president and general counsel of the American Home Products Corporation of New Jersey, said in an interview today that the industry was facing a growing number of lawsuits brought by people who are merely hoping to hit the jackpot with a sympathetic jury. The number of suits in which there is a sizable punitive damage award is rare, Mr. Hoynes acknowledged, but he contended the threat of litigation discourages development of new drugs.
But Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, said the amendment would give pharmaceutical companies an absolute defense against reckless behavior. He said if such an amendment were in force, women would have been blocked from getting extra damages for such problems as those caused in the 1950's and 1960's by DES, a drug that had been widely prescribed for morning sickness in pregnant women but resulted in severely deformed offspring.
Representative Michael G. Oxley, an Ohio Republican who sponsored the amendment on behalf of the drug industry rejected arguments that the Republicans were using the Food and Drug Administration as a shield for drug companies while simultaneously trying to weaken its procedures for approving new drugs or medical devices.
The House also passed by voice vote an amendment that would include products that are rented from the bill's protections, a provision that was sought by car rental companies. Although the Democrats are outnumbered in the House, they did manage to pass one amendment, which would hold companies more responsible, but it applied only to foreign companies.

HEADLINE: Balkan Brinkmanship

 BODY:
After smoldering over the winter, the brutish war in the Balkans may be re-ignited by Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman. The barrel of kerosene he is carrying is a March 31 deadline for the withdrawal of the 12,000 United Nations troops stationed in Serb-occupied areas of Croatia.
He imagines that Croatian forces, stronger than they were three years ago, can now defeat local Serbian militias and restore these areas to Croatian Government control. That ignores the virtual certainty that the Serbian Government in Belgrade would respond by sending its own powerful military and Bosnian Serb forces into the battle. 
 The consequences could be nightmarish. U.N. troops in Bosnia, cut off from supply lines, might have to be withdrawn as well. The open coordination of Serbian units across the fragile frontiers of former Yugoslavia could carry the war to powderkeg areas like Kosovo and Macedonia, which until now have managed to stay out of the fighting. The geographic containment of the conflict, the only indisputable achievement of three years of outside intervention, would be shattered.
A C.I.A. study on ethnic cleansing in Bosnia makes clear that the top Serbian leadership in Belgrade has sponsored a systematic policy of eliminating non-Serb inhabitants from territory it seeks to incorporate. Similar policies have been carried out, with the blessings of Belgrade, in Serb-held areas of Croatia and would doubtless be unleashed elsewhere if the fighting re-ignites and spreads.
The Clinton Administration's top European diplomat, Assistant Secretary of State Richard Holbrooke, is leading an international effort to persuade Mr. Tudjman to relent. He deserves the full support of Britain, France, Germany and Russia.
Mr. Tudjman has a legitimate grievance. The United Nations forces, sent to Croatia in 1992 under a peace plan negotiated by Cyrus Vance, the former Secretary of State, failed to act as a buffer against the Serbs. Since the U.N. troops arrived, the Serbs have transformed their territory into a small Serbian republic and used it as a staging ground for the war in Bosnia. But expelling the U.N. forces would be a grave mistake, and Croatia would be its first victim.
Washington's best hope is to appeal to predominantly Roman Catholic Croatia's longstanding desire to extricate itself from Balkan conflicts and associate itself more closely with the West. Mr. Holbrooke must make clear that such association would become impossible if U.N. troops were expelled. The other half of the message should be that Croatia's chances for economic association and support from Europe would increase, and the prestige of its President in Washington and other Western capitals would grow, if he agrees to let U.N. troops remain. Germany would be the most likely source of new aid. Russian consent would be necessary for any agreement to direct U.N. troops in Croatia to play a less passive role.
The violent breakup of the former Yugoslavia has been the major European failure of the post-cold-war era. Washington, rightly reluctant to commit American troops, has refrained from active crisis management, leaving the diplomatic initiative largely in British and French hands. But London and Paris, through a mixture of incompetence and pro-Serb bias, have all but expended their credibility among Croatians and Bosnians. By reasserting American leadership now, the Clinton Administration can help avert a wider war in the Balkans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Better Ways to Employ Substitute Teachers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding your March 1 news article about substitute teachers ("Teacher's Absent. Now What?"): 
 I am a substitute, and for many of us, the issue is an economic one. Approximately $98 a day seems adequate until you break it down and see that you're not paid for holidays, and when summer rolls around you're out of a job! Who can survive on this irregular income?
A solution would be to hire substitutes on an annual basis with benefits and let them work in one or two districts as needed. This is an excellent way to attract quality substitutes. The teachers would benefit, and the children would have teachers to rely on when their regular teachers are absent. The districts would get to know these teachers.
That would solve the problem of substitutes with no accountability. It would weed out the undesirables. When the district and children are familiar with substitutes, children are less likely to misbehave because they know this teacher will see their regular teacher. There are solutions, but it's going to take planning and a commitment to our children's education.
 
RUKIYAH ABDUR-RAHIM
New York, March 3, 1995

HEADLINE: The Catskills, on the Ropes, Rally for an Indian Casino

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

DATELINE: MONTICELLO, N.Y., March 9

 BODY:
Pat Croissant invested $1 million in Scalawags restaurant in 1987. With fewer customers each month, she says she'll lose everything unless the economy of the Catskills picks up soon.
So when the Oneida Indian Nation last week proposed building a casino on the grounds of the Monticello Raceway here, about 90 miles northwest of New York City, she thought her troubles might be over. 
 But the plan requires Gov. George E. Pataki's approval, and so far he has said no.
At a standing-room-only meeting of the Sullivan County Board of Supervisors today, local residents rallied in support of the Oneidas' proposal and said they would fight to change the Governor's mind. Without a casino, they said, the region's economy will continue to slide.
"If you look at the golden age of the Catskills, and the hotel industry, we had tens of thousands of rooms, and now we're down to 5,500," said Andrew Boyar, the board's chairman.
According to the Catskills Resort Association, hotel room bookings are down 35 percent from 1989, and the industry has lost more than 2,000 jobs since 1985, leaving only 4,000 jobs. The salary for the average hotel worker in the region is less than $13,000 a year.
In 1980, the raceway recorded its highest single-day attendance of more than 17,000. Now, a crowd of 1,000 is rare.
"If casino gambling doesn't come in some form soon, this community will lose everything," said Ms. Croissant, who has been a leader in the region's push to legalize casino gambling. She has already had to close a snowmobile business that once drew as many as 500 customers on a weekend day, and today her large dining room had just a handful of customers during lunch hour.
She and other local leaders said that they understand the Governor's concerns that any new casino on non-Indian land should provide tax revenue to the state. Under Federal law, an Indian casino would be exempt from state and local taxes.
Ms. Croissant and the leaders said that they favor legalized gambling at the region's resorts regardless of whether the Oneidas' plan goes through, but that the Oneidas' plan represents the most immediate hope.
"Some criticize this as a quick fix," said Pat Pomeroy, chairwoman of the County Planning Board. "Well, tell that to anyone who works in an emergency room. First, you stop the bleeding, they you develop a long-term cure."
Efforts are under way in the Legislature to legalize casino gambling through a constitutional amendment -- a process that would take at least three years since it would require the approval of two consecutive Legislatures and two referendums. Governor Pataki has said he supports the initial passage of such an amendment while officials study the impact of gaming on the state's economy.
"This casino is the only hope we have right now," said Gene Barbanti, who owns a Century 21 real-estate agency here. "If we wait three years, some more hotels are going to close, and some businesses will surely fold."
The Oneidas now run the Turning Stone Casino in Verona, 35 miles east of Syracuse, under the terms of a 1988 Federal law that permits sovereign Indian nations to operate the same games of chance that states allow at charity "Las Vegas nights."
But the raceway here is not part of the Oneidas' territory and can only be opened to casino gambling if Federal officials and the Governor approve.
The Oneidas have offered annual payments of $5 million to the county for 10 years and have said they are willing to negotiate payments to the state.
Officials said today that Sullivan County's unemployment rate was 8.5 percent and that nearly two-thirds of the high school graduates between the ages of 20 and 24 were unemployed.
The Oneidas estimate that their casino would employ 2,800 people at an average salary of $22,000 a year and would create 3,000 additional jobs throughout the community.
A spokesman for the Governor, Chris Chichester, said today that Mr. Pataki remained opposed to an Indian casino in the Catskills, but Mr. Boyar, the county board chairman, refused to give up hope.
"Our plight is quite well documented," he said. "The Governor has to be responsive to the needs of constituents, and we're his constituents."
