HEADLINE: House Passes New Standards Limiting Awards in Civil Suits

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
With little suspense and overwhelming support from the new Republican majority, the House today easily passed a measure that for the first time would set standards in all of the nation's courts for civil lawsuits.
The measure was approved by a 265 to 161 vote, giving the House Republicans a clean sweep this week on all three bills that made up a legislative package intended to sharply reduce the number of lawsuits nationwide. 
 The package now goes to the Senate, which is certain to be far less hospitable to at least two of the bills. President Clinton has said he opposes all three measures in their current form and White House aides said he is hoping the Senate rejects or revises the package.
The bill approved today would set limits on monetary awards available to people who sue for damages caused by devices as diverse as lawn mowers, toasters and artificial hearts. The measure, which would apply to state as well as Federal courts, would also set limits for the first time on the amount of punitive damages a jury could award a patient for pain and suffering in a medical malpractice suit. The American Medical Association, which lobbied heavily for the measure, complained to lawmakers that occasional large awards in celebrated malpractice cases have corroded the doctor-patient relationship and placed unfair costs on its members.
Congress can impose new Federal standards because almost all civil lawsuits in state courts involve interstate commerce, which Congress has the power to regulate under the Commerce Clause of the Constitution. Thus, under the House bill, even lawsuits brought in state courts would have a limit in punitive damages of three times a plaintiff's actual damages, like lost wages or medical expenses, or $250,000, whichever is greater. In medical malpractice cases, damages for pain and suffering could not exceed $250,000.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who heads the House Judiciary Committee, looked back on the week in which his party rolled to easy victory on its effort to drastically overhaul the legal system and said he was stunned. "I guess we're still getting used to being the majority party," he said. "I never dreamed we'd get to see the day when we would even be debating some of these issues on the floor."
Responding to accusations that Republicans had simply aided their patrons in business, Mr. Hyde said corporations provided jobs and growth in the economy, adding, "We shouldn't make an enemy or adversary of them just to satisfy some populist urge."
The possibility of blockbuster verdicts, he said, has led to a system that provides incentives for lawyers to bring unwarranted lawsuits. "The truth is that we're interested in a legal system that's fair," he said.
The debate this week pitted a range of powerful interests against each other in a high-stakes game. Trial lawyers, allied with consumer groups, were the principal opponents of the legislation, and thus the principal losers, so far.
In addition to the business community and the American Medical Association, other major beneficiaries would include the pharmaceutical industry, which successfully lobbied for a provision to limit damages to patients who sue drug makers.
All the bills are derived from the Republicans' Contract With America. The Senate, more lawyer-friendly than the House and less fervent about the campaign manifesto, is expected to seek significant changes in parts of the bills.
Senator Larry Pressler, a South Dakota Republican who heads the Commerce Committee, which is likely to be responsible for at least two of the bills, said he believed only one had a prospect of passing: the one approved by the House today involving product liability suits and medical malpractice.
"I think the prospects are grim for the other two," he said. "I know it's not good news for supporters of the Contract With America, but it's going to be tough going in the Senate." He said he expected Democrats would try to defeat the measures with a filibuster. To overcome that, supporters would need 60 votes to invoke cloture to end debate. "The only one that I think we could get cloture on is the product liability bill," he said.
He said he had relayed that assessment in a memorandum to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip.
Mr. Pressler also said he expected the Senate would strip the measure of the provision that so pleased the pharmaceutical industry. That provision would make drug companies immune from most damage awards if the Food and Drug Administration had approved the product.
The White House had little presence in this week's debate, apparently hoping the President would be spared by the Senate from having to decide on a veto. "We feel that the package of the three measures together doesn't do enough to protect the interests of the American consumer," the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said. "The President will be seeking modifications of this legislation as the legislation now moves to the Senate."
Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, the consumer advocacy group, said, "In the end, it's the consumer that is going to suffer from all of these measures." Limiting product liability lawsuits, she argued, would remove a powerful incentive for manufacturers to make their products safer. "This legislation should be called the corporate and medical wrongdoer's protection act," she said.
Larry Stewart, the president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which lobbied against all the measures, said the effect of the legislation would be to "give the rich an economic club to force ordinary Americans to stay out of the courts or take less than what they're entitled to." He said it was hypocritical of the Republican sponsors to have inserted a provision that would exclude commercial litigation from the limits on damages.
"If a machine blows up in a factory, the workers would be limited, but the factory owner isn't," he said.
The House Republicans began their march to victory on Tuesday by passing the Attorneys Accountability Act, a measure that would create enormous pressure on parties in a civil lawsuit to settle their dispute before going to court. The bill would put in place a sharply modified version of the so-called English system in which the loser in a civil lawsuit pays the legal costs and fees of his opponent. Under the measure, if a party in a lawsuit rejects a settlement offer from the other side and the jury comes in with an award less than that offer, that party would have to pay legal fees of the side making the rejected offer.
On Wednesday, the House approved a bill to limit the ability of stockholders and their lawyers to file suits accusing companies or stockbrokers of fraud.
 
LEGISLATION
Overhauling the Legal Sysytem: The Final Round
 
The House of Representatives today passed the last of three bills today aimed at reducing the number of lawsuits in the nation's civil justice system. The first measure, the Attorney Accountability Act approved Tuesday, is intended to discourage what sponsors call frivolous lawsuits by making some lawyers liable for their opponents' as well as their own legal fees. On Wednesday it passed the Securities Litigation Reform Act, which seeks to discourage investors from bringing lawsuits charging companies with fraud.
 
Yesterday the House passed the Common Sense Product Liability and Legal Reform Act, which would limit punitive damages in cases involving defective products and personal injuries. Here are the act's provisions:
 
STANDARDS:

Current Law: There are no uniform Federal laws governing personal injury and liability lawsuits for defective products, which are typically handled in state courts.
 
Proposed Change: Would set new Federal standards for these cases.
 
PUNITIVE DAMAGES
 
Current Law: A plaintiff generally may be awarded punitive damages, intended to punish willfully malicious conduct, in cases where he can prove that the manufacturer was "flagrantly indifferent" to consumer safety. Punitive damages are distinct from compensatory damages, which can be economic (medical costs, lost wages) or non-economic (compensation for such intangibles as mental distress, pain and suffering).
 
Proposed Change: A court may award punitive damages in any type of civil suit only if a plaintiff establishes by "clear and convincing evidence" that the defendant intended to cause harm or displayed a conscious, flagrant indifference to others' rights. Punitive damages would be capped at three times the plantiff's award for monetary losses (such as lost wages and medical bills) or $250,000, whichever is greater.
 
MEDICAL MALPRACTICE
 
Current Law: Plaintiffs may be awarded unlimited damages for pain and suffering from medical malpractice suits.
 
Proposed Change: Would limits damages for pain and suffering in these cases to $250,000.

USE OF ALCOHOL OR DRUGS
 
Current: In some states, an intoxicated individual who primarily causes his or her own injury is able to prevail in litigation.
 
Proposed Change: An injured person would be barred from recovering any damages if a court determines that the person was more than 50 percent responsible for the harm suffered because of drug or alcohol use at the time of the injury.
 
JOINT AND SEVERAL LIABILITY
 
Current: In cases involving multiple defendants, any of the parties could be responsible for paying 100 percent of damages. If, for example, one party is unable to pay its share, the plaintiff may present his bill to the party with the "deepest pockets."
 
Revision: In non-economic damage awards in product liability cases, defendants would be responsible only for the proportion of the harm they caused. Liability is still joint and several for economic damages.
 
RETAIL SELLERS
 
Current Law: Many states impose strict liability standards against retail sellers in cases involving defective products.
 
Proposed Change: Retail sellers, including those who rent or lease equipment, generally would be liable only for damages caused by their own actions - not for simply selling a defective product.
 
STATUTE OF REPOSE
 
Current: Fifteen states have enacted statutes of repose - the number of years for which a manufacturer can be held liable for his product. None are longer than 15 years.
 
Proposed Change: Would establish a 15 year limit, with certain exceptions, for which a manufacturer would be liable.

HEADLINE: Emotional March Gains a Repentant Wallace

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala, March 10

 BODY:
The marchers swarmed around the old man in the wheelchair, some to tell him he was forgiven, some to whisper that he could never be forgiven, not today, not a million years from now. Yet to all of the people who retraced the steps of the Selma-to-Montgomery civil rights march 30 years ago, George C. Wallace offered an apology for a doomed ideal.
The former Alabama Governor, whose name became shorthand for much of the worst of white Southern opposition to the civil rights movement, held hands with men and women he had once held down with the power of his office. To one aging civil rights war horse, he mumbled, "I love you." 
 Three decades ago, he was preaching the evil of integration and found approval, even adoration, in the eyes of many white Alabamians. There was the legendary stand in the schoolhouse door, to keep blacks from registering at the University of Alabama. It was his state troopers who used billy clubs and tear gas to control and intimidate marchers on the way to Selma. Then, he took his message nationwide in a run for President in 1968.
A would-be assassin's bullet in a Maryland shopping center in 1972 made him a cripple, but his old words and views echo today on the lips of conservative politicians and others, even though the man people here just call "Th' Guv'na' " has long since capitulated, apologized and begged for forgiveness.
Now 75, in a wheelchair for a third of his life, he was too old and sick to make a speech to the 200 marchers, mostly black, who gathered at the St. Jude School in Montgomery, as they did on this day three decades ago. Instead, an aide read his remarks as Mr. Wallace, who is almost completely deaf, sat in silence.
"My friends," the aide read, "I have been watching your progress this week as you retrace your footsteps of 30 years ago and cannot help but reflect on those days that remain so vivid in my memory. Those were different days and we all in our own ways were different people. We have learned hard and important lessons in the 30 years that have passed between us since the days surrounding your first walk along Highway 80."
A woman in a brown beret quietly said, "Amen."
"Those days were filled with passionate convictions and a magnified sense of purpose that imposed a feeling on us all that events of the day were bigger than any one individual," the speech continued in its borrowed voice. "Much has transpired since those days. A great deal has been lost and a great deal has been gained, and here we are. My message to you today is, Welcome to Montgomery.
"May your message be heard. May your lessons never be forgotten. May our history be always remembered."
The marchers applauded. For 10 years now, Mr. Wallace has admitted the wrongness of his deeds 30 years ago. Still, to many of the people who suffered at the hands of the law-enforcement officers he commanded, it was important that he said it on this symbolic day.
But 30 yards away, 58-year-old Rufus Vanable sat in the shade of a tall pine tree and refused to hear.
"I ain't even interested in what he's saying," said Mr. Vanable, a retired construction worker who was part of the march that was bloodied on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma. "If you lived through it, you wouldn't be either. If he thinks this will ease his mind in some way, let him do it. I'm not interested in looking at his face. It brings back too many memories.
"Seeing him say that he's sorry ain't gonna do me no good at all."
Like many others in the crowd, he said Mr. Wallace, a religious man, was trying more to clear a path to heaven than to soothe the painful memories of others. He said that he held no malice for Mr. Wallace and that he even believed the former Governor had changed, "but it means a hell of a lot more to him that it does to me."
"He's trying to get right with his maker, that's what he's doing," Mr. Vanable said. "It was hell. Any man who'd sic dogs on a child. He ain't made up for it."
As the marchers sang "We Shall Overcome," Mr. Vanable sat under his tree and sang to himself. Mr. Wallace, lost in the crowd, never saw him, either.
Others were more forgiving.
"Thank you, for coming out of your sickness to meet us," said Joseph E. Lowery, the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and an organizer of that first march. "You are a different George Wallace today. We both serve a God who can make the desert bloom. We ask God's blessing on you."
The politics and economics of race are more complicated now, and the marchers, including the old survivors of meaner days, worry that the nation is going backward in its racial tolerance. They hear modern-day leaders blame blacks, because of crime and welfare, for what is wrong with America.
The marchers said they hoped those leaders were watching as George Wallace joined hands with them and bowed his head with them. It might be only symbolism, they said, but it was the right kind of symbolism.
"It's very important, in this day and time," said Gerri Perry, the principal at St. Jude. "It is important for people to see him, saying this.
"Back then, 30 years ago, I didn't think I would ever see anything like this."
What she saw was an old man wanting to set things right, for whatever reasons. The marchers did not ask him to be there. He asked them if they would give him a few minutes of their time.
He might be the only Alabama Governor to meet them. As of Friday afternoon, the marchers and Gov. Fob James, a Republican who ran on a conservative platform, had still not agreed to meet.
Instead, the marchers gathered around the man they had once hated. That old Wallace, the fiery judge who stood on the back of trucks and shouted, "Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever," was nowhere around.
"He's been about to die for the last 10 years, and he's still living," Mr. Vanable said. "God's gonna make him pay."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The scene on March 7, 1965, when Alabama state troopers dispersed marchers in Selma. (Associated Press); Ex-Gov. George C. Wallace and the Rev. Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)(pg. 1)

HEADLINE: Space Station Insures a Future for Our Children;
The Inspiration Factor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was greatly disturbed by the tone of "Is NASA Among the Truly Needy?" (editorial, March 6). Growing up in Britain in the 60's and training as a scientist, I was particularly attracted to this country by the vigor of the space program. 
 You argue for the burial of the manned space program. Those of us determined to keep the dream alive can only hope and pray that the present lack of a manned mission to Mars via a base on the moon or a space station is only a temporary setback to mankind's space endeavors. An editorial calling for a Mars mission would have been more apt for the era we live in.
Overspending on defense during the 80's and the desire to preserve Social Security and Medicare at the present levels have created the need for short-term fiscal gratification, to which a vigorous manned and unmanned space program falls an easy victim. But the manned space program is an investment in our future:
First, developing the mineral and energy resources of our solar system will create great wealth for earth, stimulate the planet's economy and reduce environmental pollution, more than making up for any extra deficit produced now.
Second, if the modest shuttle program is killed, the expertise to create future space technologies will be lost and can only be recovered at great expense later.
Finally, the inspirational impact of space exploration upon humans' ability to foster creative potential in a way that can produce surprisingly rapid direct technological and social benefits must not be underestimated.
 
STUART A. KINGSLEY
Columbus, Ohio, March 8, 1995
 
The writer is director of the Columbus Optical SETI Observatory.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senators Would Kill 4 Agencies and Slash Benefits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Senate's Republicans moved belatedly but forcefully into the debate on Federal spending cuts today, disclosing proposals to abolish four Cabinet departments and slice as much as half a trillion dollars over the next five years from the growth in entitlement programs like Medicare and farm subsidies.
This was the first concrete indication that Republican senators, like their House counterparts, intended to follow up on their repeated demands for a balanced Federal budget with an actual plan to achieve it. And it placed the political onus on the Senate's Democrats, who complained only Wednesday that Republican budget policy was all talk and no action. 
 But it did not guarantee, or even make more likely, that spending cuts would actually pass both houses of Congress. Some of the Republicans' ideas already face intense opposition from interest groups or the White House; others are couched only as suggestions, not legislative proposals, and their prospects are unclear.
All are now in the hands of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, who presented one of the ideas in a speech today.
Mr. Dole told newspaper executives that he favored eliminating the Departments of Housing and Urban Development, Education, Commerce, and Energy. He would do away with some of their duties entirely, shift others to the states or private enterprise, and farm out whatever remained to other Federal offices. With 74,000 employees and annual budgets totaling $70 billion, he said, the departments are "overfunded, overstaffed and resoundingly unnecessary."
Mr. Dole, whose proposal was identical to one made last month by freshman Republicans in the House, called for eliminating the entire $3.6 billion budget of the Commerce Department and replacing public housing with vouchers that the needy could use to pay rent to private landlords. But he offered few hints as to which other duties would be killed altogether and which retained. Nor did he or aides say how much money his proposal would save.
Mr. Dole's speech did not address other budget elements. But other Republicans said he received from fellow Republican senators this week a draft of a plan to attack what most experts identify as the root of the deficit: spending on Federal benefits.
The draft was assembled by a group of senators led by Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire freshman whom Mr. Dole chose this winter to conduct a review of entitlement spending.
Senate leaders asked Mr. Gregg to cut the projected growth of the programs by $385 billion over five years. But his draft, now circulating in the Senate, goes further. It outlines as much as $495 billion in savings and suggests that Republican leaders meet their $385 billion goal by eliminating his least attractive proposals.
A final version of the Gregg report will be sent to the Senate Budget Committee to guide Republicans preparing an alternative to the five-year budget blueprint that the White House issued last month. But Republican officials indicated today that they expected few important changes in the report's recommendations.
The draft offers the most specific recommendations for major deficit reduction proposed so far by leaders of either party. They fall into five major areas.
One is health care. The draft would require Medicare beneficiaries to pay a fifth of the cost of home health care and laboratory tests, both of which are now fully covered. It would raise better-off retirees' premiums for Part B services, primarily physician care. In the longer term, it would also cut costs by giving retirees vouchers that they could use either to buy coverage from managed care organizations or pay their Medicare premiums; the beneficiaries could keep most of the savings.
Those changes, with an additional $20 billion that the Republicans take from White House budget proposals, would reap a total Medicare saving of at least $120 billion, the draft says.
Medicaid, the insurance system for the poor, would be shifted entirely to the states and financed by a Federal block grant that would grow by 4 percent a year. That would save $115 billion.
A second area of proposed cuts is welfare. The draft adopts Republican governors' plan to turn most Federal welfare services over to the states and finance them with block grants, saying this would save $40 billion. Supplemental Security Income, a fast-growing benefit for the disabled, would be "fundamentally reformed" to limit eligibility and costs, at a $22 billion saving. And the growth in the earned-income tax credit, which assists low-income working families, would be cut $27 billion, not only by eliminating fraud but also by closing loopholes that now prevent investment returns from being counted as income.
A third area is Federal pensions. The draft proposes applying cost-of-living increases only to the first $13,800 of annual Federal retirement benefits, the same level used to calculate increases in Social Security checks. The report also suggests increasing Federal workers' contributions to some pension accounts. Total saving: $17 billion.
A fourth proposal would revise the Consumer Price Index so that it reflected a lower rate of inflation. Since that index is used to calculate benefit increases in a range of Federal programs, the move would automatically cut Government expenses. The five-year saving, assuming an annual rate of inflation half a percentage point lower than the current index suggests, would total $64 billion.
Finally, the draft urges Congress to review and cut many of the 350 other entitlement programs, from a paring of farm subsidies -- a $15 billion saving -- to a two-week delay in mailing the first unemployment check to jobless workers, on the theory that most receive two weeks' severance pay. Total savings would amount to $50 billion.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE TUMBLES TO 5.4% ON SURGE IN HIRING

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
An unexpectedly large number of Americans found new jobs in February, and the unemployment rate matched a four-year low by dropping three-tenths of a point, to 5.4 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
After a tumultuous week in the financial markets, as the dollar hit record lows against both the German mark and the Japanese yen before recovering somewhat, investors found something to cheer in the latest figures. Under the weight of a yearlong series of interest-rate increases engineered by the Federal Reserve, economic growth is finally showing signs of slowing to a pace that could help extend the expansion that began in 1991. 
 The jump last month in job creation might typically have led to a selloff in markets that are often unnerved by evidence of exuberant growth that could lead to higher inflation. But traders were encouraged to buy United States assets because the economy appeared to be growing fast enough to keep any threat of recession at bay.
After an initial drop, bond prices rose as traders and investors delved behind the early headlines that suggested a rebound in growth to find further signs of an economic slowdown and a lack of pressure to bolster wages. The Dow Jones industrial average soared more than 50 points to a record, and other stock indexes climbed as well on expectations that profits would remain strong. The dollar regained some of the ground it lost earlier this week.
The dollar, which was helped by Mexico's announcement of a new austerity package, got an extra lift as currency traders appeared to conclude that the Fed now had no reason to flirt with lowering rates to bolster the economy and might even lift them at least once more. The central bank has historically avoided raising rates solely to make the dollar more attractive to international investors. The American financial commitment to Mexico has been one of several factors depressing the dollar.
Most analysts saw good news in today's figures. "I just can't see inflation becoming a major problem, even with the decline of the dollar," said Mark P. Vitner, an economist with the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C.
But others, including some Federal Reserve officials, saw more of a a mixed signal. "It just emphasizes the fact that it's very hard to read the tea leaves right now," said John P. LaWare, a member of the Federal Reserve Board. "There are parts of the economy that are soft and other parts that are doing well. This is another piece in the puzzle, and it's hard to fit them all together."
And William A. Brown, chief economist at J. P. Morgan & Company, said February's 318,000 jump in payroll jobs and upward revisions for December and January showed the economy still had considerable momentum. Yet most analysts said the Fed would probably pass up the chance to raise rates at its policy meeting on March 28, deferring action until later in the spring when it can better judge whether the economy is on track with a growth target of 2.5 percent or so.
President Clinton hailed the report as evidence that the Administration's economic strategy was working. "The fundamentals of this economy over all are healthier than they have been in a generation," he said at a news conference.
Dismissing critics who had predicted that tax increases would smother growth, the President boasted of the creation of 6.1 million jobs during his first two years in office. He took the opportunity to argue that a Republican tax-cut plan was too costly.
There was something for everyone in the February job report. While 318,000 new jobs were added to nonfarm payrolls, there were also some soft spots in the job market that provided reassurance to Wall Street that wages were still stable.
Unemployment fell almost everywhere, with the jobless rate dropping to 7.3 percent in California from an 8.2 percent rate in January. The rate was also lower than the 7.7 percent of December, suggesting that California, which accounts for nearly $1 of every $8 generated by the American economy, is clearly on the mend. Unemployment in Texas dropped to 5.1 percent from 5.8 percent in January.
Across the nation, average hourly earnings were unchanged last month at $11.31, the report showed, after spurting 6 cents in January. Wages are closely watched by investors and policy makers since they account for more than two-thirds of the average company's costs.
Moreover, the length of the private-sector workweek eased four-tenths of an hour, or 24 minutes, thereby more than erasing a sizable January increase. This caused a drop in the index of aggregate weekly hours, which skidded eight-tenths of a percent while the index for manufacturing was unchanged.
While factory jobs grew by 27,000, this was less than the 40,000-plus gains in each of the preceding four months.
The principal gains were in services, which advanced 191,000, the most in almost a year. Of this, 73,000 was in business services -- mostly temporary help and computer people, the Labor Department found.
The figures are adjusted for normal seasonal variations but are subject to wide swings when the weather is unusual.
Geographically, the South showed the most improvement last month; its jobless rate fell five-tenths of a point to 4.8 percent, the first time since 1979 the regional rate has been below 5 percent.
But unemployment also dipped two-tenths of a point, to 5.9 percent, in the Northeast, and three-tenths of a point, to 6.4 percent, in the West. The jobless rate in the Midwest was unchanged at 4.3 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S., Protesting Rights Abuses, Ends Military Aid to Guatemala

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Administration announced today that it was suspending the last of its small military aid to Guatemala. The decision came two days before an American woman plans a hunger strike in front of the White House to draw attention to the disappearance of her husband in Guatemala.
Administration officials acknowledged today that they were suspending the $200,000-a-year program partly in response to pressure from the woman, Jennifer Harbury. She is seeking the Administration's help to get information about her husband, a Guatemalan guerrilla leader believed to have been captured in 1992. 
 In a statement today, the State Department said it was suspending the program to protest what it called human rights abuses, and Guatemala's failure to turn over information about six killings and disappearances, including the case involving Ms. Harbury's husband. The five other cases also have American connections.
In 1990 the United States cut off most military assistance and all arms sales to Guatemala because of concerns about widespread rights abuses. Civil war has persisted in Guatemala for 40 years, and 100,000 people have died.
Ms. Harbury said in an interview today that she believed the military had held her husband in a secret prison and tortured him since he was captured in 1992.
Christine D. Shelly, a State Department spokeswoman, said "it is our considered assessment" that Ms. Harbury's husband, Efrain Bamaca Velasquez, "died in military custody in 1992 after a short but indeterminate period of detention and interrogation."
But Ms. Harbury said she was confident her husband was alive because several Guatemalans told her last fall when she conducted a hunger strike in Guatemala City that they had recently seen him alive, accompanied by several soldiers.
The Administration is seeking to prod the Guatemalan Government and the guerrillas to sign a peace agreement. Seeking to demonstrate its evenhandedness, the Administration also announced today that it would deny visas to guerrilla leaders to punish the movement for recent kidnappings and economic sabotage.
Despite the Administration's announcement, Ms. Harbury said she would begin her hunger strike on Sunday. "It's just a little step" by the State Department, she said, adding that she wants the Administration to cut off all aid to Guatemala.
Ms. Harbury, a Harvard Law School graduate who has written a book about Guatemala, said she would end her fast only when her husband is returned alive or when the Government there turns over his remains.
She fasted for a month in Guatemala City, and said she ended her fast when she was invited to meet with Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and other officials, who said they would help her. Disappointed by the Administration's response, she said she planned to resume her fast in front of the White House in an attempt to embarrass the Administration into applying more pressure on Guatemala.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
New jobs were found by an unexpectedly large number of Americans in February, as the unemployment rate matched a four-year low, dropping three-tenths of a point to 5.4 percent, the Labor Department reported. Traders in financial markets were exuberant, buying American assets in the belief that the economy was growing fast enough to keep any threat of recession at bay. [Page 1.] The celebration of lower unemployment figures left New York City, New York State and New Jersey mainly on the outside looking in. New York State's rate stood at 6.1 percent, up from 6 percent in January. [49.]
 
Kevin D. Mitnick, the computer hacker, was indicted on 23 counts of fraud in a Federal court in North Carolina. [48.]
 
The R.T.C. proposed ceasing business with Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley, saying they had violated gift-giving rules. [38.]
 
 
Markets
 
Financial markets surged in their first big rally since the dollar began tumbling this month. Stocks hit record levels, with the Dow industrials galloping 52.22 points ahead to close at 4,035.61. [37.]
 
Bond prices also rose strongly. The yield on the long bond fell to 7.46 percent from 7.51 percent on Thursday. [48.]
 
The dollar rose against most major currencies for a third day, helped by the jobless report and a rally in the Mexican peso. [47.]
 
Wheat futures prices fell sharply after the United States Agriculture Department trimmed its export forecast. [47.]
 
 
International
 
Mexico's tough economic recovery program cheered markets, but left many Mexicans fuming over big price increases and higher taxes. The peso surged 18 percent. [37.]
 
The president of Brazil's central bank vowed to defend the nation's currency at all costs. Brazilian and other Latin American stocks and bonds soared in response. [46.]
 
 
Companies
 
Bankers Trust New York said it could lose $125 million in the first quarter because of trading in Latin America and a slowdown in revenue from derivatives. [37.]
 
Richard Frank will leave the Walt Disney Company, where he heads the television and telecommunications unit. Dennis F. Hightower of Disney Consumer Products will replace him. [37.]
 
Union Pacific agreed to a $1.1 billion deal for the remaining 70 percent of Chicago and North Western Transportation. [39.]
 
Sammons Communications agreed to a $1 billion sale of 650,000 of its 1.1 million cable television subscribers to a group that includes Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and Goldman, Sachs & Company. [37.]
 
In a serious setback to Morrison Knudsen, the San Francisco area transit system awarded a $330 million contract to AEG Transportation Systems of Germany to refurbish 439 rail cars. [39.]
 
Borland shares surged $1.25 to $9.75 after an appellate court ruled that it had not infringed Lotus copyrights. [39.]
 
AMP agreed to acquire M/A-Com in a $360 million stock deal, creating a major manufacturer of wireless communications equipment with combined annual sales of $4.5 billion. [39.]

Dealing with a home-remodeling contractor can be a minefield. But savvy homeowners can act to protect themselves. [36.]

HEADLINE: Cocaine's Reality, by Garcia Marquez

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: NEIVA, Colombia

 BODY:
Speaking with the wisdom of 67 years and the gravity befitting a Nobel Prize winner, Gabriel Garcia Marquez proposed a new solution for the eternal problem of his country's cocaine exports to the United States.
"All the money that Colombia invests in fighting drugs should be invested in the United States to research synthetic cocaine," the novelist said in an interview recently. 
 Elaborating on this theory, he said that just as outlaw American gardeners took the marijuana business away from Colombian growers in the 1980's, outlaw American chemists could take away the cocaine business from Colombian traffickers in the late 1990's.
While his suggestion is unlikely to find favor in Washington, it comes freighted with the weight of a revered man who is Colombia's unofficial spokesman.
Presidents come and go, but the owlish writer, universally known by his nickname, Gabo, endures. His novels stray from starched official history into the realm of earthy and magical tales. In Colombia's press, his blunt views routinely win wider audiences than cautious statements from diplomats and Government officials.
A day spent with Mr. Garcia Marquez quickly sketched the dimensions of the man.
At the airport in Cartagena, where he lives, travelers recognized the author in his black-rimmed glasses and repeated his nickname in awe. At a prison in Itagui, outside Medellin, three convicted cocaine traffickers known as the Ochoa brothers tripped over themselves vying for the honor of serving him lunch. At a barracks in Neiva, uniformed helicopter pilots from Colombia's anti-drug police ignored the national police commander and jostled for position in souvenir photos with the writer.
Steeped in the Latin world, Mr. Garcia Marquez speaks little English. He has residences in Cartagena, Mexico City, Barcelona and Paris. Once denied a United States visa because of his long friendship with Fidel Castro, the author patched things up somewhat last August at a dinner with President Clinton on Martha's Vineyard.
On a plane carrying him to Medellin for his meeting with the Ochoa brothers, Mr. Garcia Marquez gripped the arms of his seat -- he has a fear of flying -- and opened up.
"My worry is that the U.S. will use the fight against drug trafficking as a pretext for intervention," he said. "The drug problem has been presented in reverse. In the U.S., addicts supply themselves as easily as they buy milk or newspapers. And yet we are accused of not doing enough against drug trafficking."
Pausing to point out a swamp where a Colombian passenger jet crashed in January, Mr. Garcia Marquez said drug trafficking is deforming Colombian society.
"Drug traffickers taught people that they were stupid to work," said the man who grew up in a depressed banana-growing town. "The notion of easy money is Colombia's worst problem. Today a young man swallows some pills filled with cocaine with the idea that with one trip north, he can buy a house."
Because of an addiction to easy money, Colombia now leads the world in kidnappings, he said.
"We are down to quickie 'secuestros' -- someone grabs a woman for four hours, then lets her go for a million pesos," he said, a ransom equivalent to $1,250.
Where Washington conservatives and this friend of President Castro see eye to eye is expressed in his lament that impunity breeds disrespect for the law.
"I enjoy driving, but not here," he said. "These same Colombians who run red lights and block intersections in Bogota are well behaved in Miami. I know because I have been in their cars. When there is authority, Colombians behave."
Although they reach the belief from very different directions, Mr. Garcia Marquez and the Republicans newly in power in Congress agree that the United States should not be hasty in lifting the decades-old embargo on trade with Cuba.
"If the blockade is taken away, it will create quite a problem for Fidel because the Cuban people believe that all their problems will be solved once it is lifted," said Mr. Garcia Marquez, who regularly goes to Havana. "In Cuba the Government's big worry is to not let the process escape from their hands. The potential for violence from the Cubans in Miami is very great."
With European and Latin American investors now flocking to Cuba, the United States investment ban helps insure that Cuba will not revert to its 1950's status as an American economic colony, he said.
Updating an old Latin American taunt for a new era, Mr. Garcia Marquez said with ill-disguised glee, "As long at the blockade endures, the U.S. loses market share."

HEADLINE: Mexico's Plan Drives Peso Up 18%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 10

 BODY:
Mexico's turbulent financial markets responded enthusiastically today to the economic recovery plan that the Government introduced on Thursday night, while ordinary Mexicans fumed over big price increases and higher sales taxes required by the tough measures.
 The peso, after declining for six straight days, rebounded strongly, gaining 18 percent over Thursday's level to close at 6.3 to the dollar. On Thursday, the peso had plummeted to 7.45 to the dollar, its lowest point since the currency was devalued in December. 
 Today, a peso was worth nearly 16 cents, compared with a little over 13 cents on Thursday, though well below the old level of 28.90 cents before the first stage of the devaluation on Dec. 20.
 Stock investors in Mexico City and New York also reacted positively to the harsh but realistic economic plan announced on Thursday night by Mexico's Finance Minister. The main Mexican stock-market index gained 3.31 percent, while in New York, American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, the phone monopoly, jumped $4.125 to close at $28.625 in trading of more than 22 million shares on the Big Board.
 Financial analysts, however, observed that in economic crises, the markets have several times reacted favorably to what were regarded as positive developments, only to turn around as new worries arose a few days later.
 In Washington today, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and several other officials defended the Clinton Administration's $20 billion bailout plan for Mexico and warned Congress that interference with its execution would hamper efforts to restore investors' confidence in Mexico. The Mexican Government has already spent $3 billion of the United States loans and loan guarantees to defend the peso.
 Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said he hoped that the plan would help Mexico recover. "The good news is that the markets have responded to it in a positive manner," he said.
 Mexican officials, while clearly satisfied with the way their economic plan has been received, were reluctant to consider today's market movements as positive signs, even preliminary ones.
 "All we're asking for now is a truce to show that this is going to work," said Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, a principal author of the plan. He said he would fly to New York on Tuesday to meet with Wall Street investors and explain the severe austerity measures.
 "What I'd ask of them is to stop going short on Mexico," Mr. Ortiz said. "Let us get on with solving our problems."
 Several times during an interview, he said the new economic measures were bitter medicine that would cause a lot of pain as they restored a degree of stability to Mexico's badly battered financial markets. But there was no alternative, he said.
 Kenneth R. James, senior vice president of James Capel Emerging Markets Sales in New York, said that based on what he had seen of the economic plan, he was now more willing to give Mr. Ortiz the respite he was seeking.
 "Can I live with it?" he asked. "Absolutely."
 But Mexican businessmen expressed fear that the plan would bankrupt them, while labor leaders expressed a grudging willingness to restrain pay demands in order to keep their members working through an expected deep recession.
 Currency traders said the peso's surprising rebound today reflected greater confidence created by the economic steps. The Mexican stock exchange also recovered strongly, gaining nearly 51 points to close above 1,591, partly because investors saw the peso moving in the right direction.
 In its basic outlines, the economic emergency plan envisions that Mexico will end this year with a budget surplus. To create the surplus, the Government will cut its budget about 10 percent while increasing revenue through tax rises and higher prices for goods produced by some state-owned companies. As a result, Mexico will remain in recession throughout 1995.
 Mr. Ortiz said he hoped that the plan would reduce the country's reliance on imports, while sufficiently spurring exports that it would end 1995 with a trade surplus. Annual inflation is expected to reach 42 percent, while salaries for minimum-wage workers will go up 10 percent. Other contract wages will be negotiated between unions and employers without the constraint of Government guidelines.
 The Government did not raise either personal or corporate income taxes, as, according to rumors, it intended. It did, however, propose to increase to 15 percent, from 10 percent, the value-added tax, a broad-ranging national sales tax on goods at each stage of their production and distribution.
 Analysts saw the peso's sharp gain today as an indication that the economic plan could help stabilize the value of Mexico's currency even if it stopped short of fixing a new exchange rate. "We haven't had a day like this in a long time," said Jaime Campbell, a trader with C.B.I. brokerage in Mexico City. "They've diagnosed the illness and given the prescription; now we need to wait and see if it is the right prescription."
 The largest single price increase under the plan was levied on gasoline, which rose 35 percent at midnight Thursday. Further increases of eight-tenths of 1 percent a month through the rest of 1995 will mean a total rise of 48.5 percent. Before prices were raised last night, regular unleaded gasoline had cost about 75 cents a gallon. The increase brings the cost of a gallon of gas to $1.18, while the minimum wage will rise to $2.60 a day.
 "It's just not right," said Jesus Zavala, a salesman from Mexico City, who grumbled as he bought gasoline for his white Topaz. "With this Government, every day is worse. While prices are going up, our salaries are going down."
 Other Mexicans who woke up this morning to find that gasoline had gone up in price by one-third were similarly angry.
 "It's the worst time to raise the price of gasoline," said Salvador Soledad, 36, a toy salesman. "Everything is more difficult now, and then the Government raises prices. This is going to bring on discontent."

HEADLINE: At Issue in College Sit-In: Desire to Keep Studying

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 10

 BODY:
It did not look like much of a protest, with about two dozen students scattered around a college library, cramming for midterm exams.
 But a glance at the clock showed that the time was 4:22 A.M. Under a new austerity schedule, the library was supposed to have closed for the night more than six hours earlier. And the students, holding their ground in perhaps one of the final battles to save Upsala College, were demanding nothing less radical than the right to study for another year. 
 "Even if they wanted to, they don't have enough security staff left to kick us out of here," said Darnell Grant, the student government president.
 At this point, the odds against Upsala, a tiny private institution with a massive debt, appear insurmountable. On March 3, the trustees voted to close the college at the end of May unless a fiscal miracle occurred. Despite a pervasive sense of futility on the campus here, students and a couple of sympathetic faculty members pulled one last all-nighter to bring attention to their school's plight -- and to reflect on some of the very difficult real-life lessons in politics, economics and sociology they are learning.
 "All the problems and statistics that students at other schools read about, we live them here," said Mr. Grant, a senior majoring in political science. "We know all about urban blight. We know all about the abandonment of cities."
 Students complain that the white-flight mentality that swept through Newark and surrounding towns after the 1967 riots spread to the school's pool of applicants and eventually to the college's board of trustees as enrollment gradually grew to more than two-thirds black and Hispanic. But even as they accused the trustees of betrayal, they spoke lovingly of the school itself and of faculty members who stubbornly refused to give up on them.
 "Even if the school closes, as long as I know that while I was here I struggled to keep it open, that to me is a great experience, fighting for my education," said Maritza Lozada, a 25-year-old political science major from Paterson, who helped organize the United Coalition to Save Upsala College. Ms. Lozada has taken to wearing black a lot lately -- "both to mourn the loss of the college, and because black represents the power of the people" -- and is trying to get her credits transferred to the Newark campus of Rutgers University.
 Mr. Grant, 22, who credited Upsala with transforming him from a tough freshman off the streets of Irvington into a future teacher with dreams of writing books, said he has also enjoyed fighting the good fight.
 "I'm not saying it's helping me complete my course work, but the struggle is so important it gives new meaning and direction to my studies," he said. "A lot of people take for granted that you have the right to go to class, that you have the right to go to the library."
 Andrea Tschemplik, a classical philosophy instructor who is also an Upsala alumna, said the school was small enough for faculty members and students to form unusually close ties. For years, enrollment hovered around a thousand, though it is now down to 435.
 "This place is so unique I feel like I have to do anything I can to keep it open," Ms. Tschemplik said, picking at a plate of Chinese food delivered to the library just after 3 A.M.
 Like many faculty members and students, Ms. Tschemplik has made great sacrifices to help keep the school running. Faculty members took a voluntary 40 percent cut in their already meager salaries at the beginning of the year, and most are now doing double duty as administrators. Ms. Tschemplik, who has seen her salary dwindle from $24,000 to less than $15,000, has been working 10 hours a week in the registrar's office, besides doing her teaching.
 Rodney Newby, 24, a senior in the communications department, has been working extra hours at the financial aid office to make sure students have their paperwork in order. He watched his 5-year-old nephew, Quran Justice, whose mother is also a student, running among the stacks this morning and said the boy was his inspiration.
 "I feel like if I don't help save an institution that gives, quote unquote, minorities the opportunity to attend school, what's going to happen to him?" said Mr. Newby, an Air Force veteran who managed video stores before going back to school. "I need to make sure he gets a chance."
 Mr. Newby, like the other students, was unfazed by the absence of response from school administrators to the sit-in, which had the approval of the library director.
 "Just because they're not here now doesn't mean they don't know I'm here. I have to be here."
 At a few minutes after 6, the last dozen students decided to call it a night, and Ms. Tschemplik walked across campus to her office to stare at the wall for a few hours before a faculty meeting aimed at producing an alternative to the trustees' bankruptcy plan, one that would keep Upsala open.
 "This has been an incredible night," she said. "The time I've spent with these kids, the stories they've told me, are things that will stay with me."
 Did she feel the protest was likely to have any effect on the school's future?
 "Probably not," she said. "You still need someone with a plan and with money."

HEADLINE: Stocks and Bonds Soar on Positive Jobs Report

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the first big rally since the dollar began falling sharply this month, financial markets rose yesterday, with stock prices hitting record levels, bond prices moving higher and the dollar gaining against the German mark.
 The Dow Jones industrial average jumped more than 65 points and closed at a record 4,035.61, up 52.22 points. Other leading stock indexes exceeded or came close to records, too. Stocks from General Electric to Coca-Cola to Lotus Development all rose sharply on heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of 383 million shares. 
 The immediate cause that sent financial markets higher was a stronger-than-expected unemployment report yesterday that showed the February jobless rate in the United States falling to 5.4 percent from 5.7 percent in January.
 But traders cautioned that the rise might be short-lived. Fundamental factors, like the weak Mexican economy, may continue to drag down the dollar. A falling dollar adds to uncertainity and market volatility and makes stocks and bonds less attractive to foreign investors, a big source of investment capital for the United states.
 "I don't think the dollar has found its bottom yet," said David De Rosa, a currency trader at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
 And next week markets could be battered by important economic reports, like the February Consumer Price Index on Thursday, and special trading factors, like the expiration of quarterly options on Friday.
 Long-term interest rates fell as bond prices rose. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.46 percent, from 7.51. The dollar ended trading in New York at 90.90 yen, little changed from 91.02, and the dollar rose to 1.4155 German marks from 1.4035.
 A more stable financial market in Mexico may have also helped the dollar, at least for now. Mexican stocks and the peso soared as Mexico started receiving money under the Clinton Administration's aid package and the Mexican Government announced an economic austerity program.
 Only a few months ago, a report showing a drop in unemployment could have sent the stock market -- and probably other markets -- down sharply because falling unemployment is seen as a sign of rising inflation. Yesterday, while each market seemed to read something slightly different in the jobs data, traders and investors came to positive conclusions.
 For stock traders, the jobs report meant that a recession was less likely and that corporate earnings might continue to rise. "It was party time for Wall Street because the jobs report was good news for profits," said Todd Clark, managing director for equity trading at Mabon Securities.
 For bond traders, the fine print in the jobs report, like the hourly earnings and workweek data, was weaker than the headline decline in the jobless rate.
 At first, bond prices plunged in the morning for about 10 minutes after the release of the jobs data. "The headline sent us lower, but as the underlying data came out, the market shifted quickly because the jobs data was flattish rather than inflationary," said Barry Kirschner, a bond trader at Chase Securities.
 For currency traders, the jobs report meant that the Fed might now have to raise interest rates again, which could make the dollar more valuable for currency traders. An interest rate increase, however, might hurt stock and bond prices.
 Some currency traders, however, saw no effect at all from the jobs data, saying that short-term technical factors were responsible for the rise in the dollar. They pointed out that most of the rally in the dollar came in overnight trading in Europe before the jobs data were released here. The dollar jumped some more after the employment report, but then fell back. And it was no surprise that the dollar rose against the mark rather than the yen, Mr. De Rosa of the Swiss Bank said.
 The dollar-yen relationship is based mainly on the United States-Japan trade relationship and is strongly influenced by trading in the Tokyo time zone, Mr. De Rosa said. By contrast, the dollar-mark relationship is based mainly on liquidity in many countries in Europe and issues inside the European Union, and is also more influenced by round-the-clock trading.
 The Dow rose so quickly that "circuit breaker" rules, which are intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading, were imposed. The Dow has now pushed past its old Feb. 24 record of 4,011.74. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 6.41 points to a record 489.57, exceeding the previous Feb. 24 record of 488.26.
 The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.98 points, to 802.22, close to its 1994 record of 803.93. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks closed at 256.01, up 1.22 points, still far from the old record of 271.08 on March 18, 1994.
 Advancing stocks substantially outnumbered declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,612 stocks rising in price and 675 falling in price. Sixty-one stocks hit new highs and 29 touched new lows.
 Telefonos de Mexico, the most heavily traded stock at 22.4 million shares, rose 4 1/8, to 28 5/8. American portfolio managers often buy or sell Telmex, the largest stock on the Mexican exchange, as a proxy for the entire Mexican stock market. Mexican and other Latin American stocks rose after Mexico received its first $3 billion installment under the international aid plan.
 Chicago and North Western Holdings, a rail carrier, rose 8 1/8, to 34 1/4, after Union Pacific bid $35 a share, or $1.2 billion, for the company. Union Pacific gained 7/8, to 51. Wabash National, a maker of truck trailers, rose 4, to 31 7/8, after management said profits were expected to meet analysts' higher projections.

HEADLINE: Brazil Currency Moves Spur Huge Rise in Latin Markets

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, March 10

 BODY:
The president of Brazil's central bank said today that the Government would defend the nation's currency at all costs and declared that speculative attacks against the Brazilian currency, the real, had failed.
 Officials moved early today to stop the outflow of foreign reserves by raising interest rates and limiting dollars that banks can hold in foreign-exchange operations. A series of measures caused the real to gain 2.7 percent against the dollar in early trading, and the main Sao Paulo stock market index to soar by 25.62 percent in a single day. 
 Other big Latin American stock markets also rose very sharply -- by 12.83 percent in Argentina, and 9.40 percent in Chile.
 The prices of Latin American bonds also jumped, led by gains in Brazilian debt. Closed-end funds in the United States that invest in Mexican and South American stocks rallied sharply, as well. The rebound was led by such issues as the Mexico Fund, the Mexico Equity and Income Fund, the Emerging Mexico Fund, the Brazil Fund, the Argentina Fund and the Latin American Discovery Fund. Their prices rose as much as 26 percent.
 The real later weakened, closing at 0.88050 to the dollar.
 The central bank chief, Persio Arida, said the bank would not yield "to any speculative attack against the real." The currency is the backbone of an anti-inflation program that in eight months has kept inflation under 2 percent a month, down from 45 percent before the real began circulating in July. Speculators tested the Government's will after the central bank moved on Monday to widen the trading range.
 The central bank said it would buy or sell dollars to keep the real at a rate of exchange between 86 and 90 centavos through April, and 86 to 98 centavos after May 2.
 Since the move came at a time of turmoil in Latin American financial markets, when it was unclear at what rate officials wanted the real to trade, speculators began testing the 90-centavo floor.
 "I don't have any doubt that the foreign-exchange measures are coherent with all the actions taken up to now," Mr. Arida said, referring to Monday's widening of the trading band.
 The immediate effect of the Government's measures today was that whoever bet against the real was hurt, said Gilson Schwartz, chief economist at Banco de Boston in Sao Paulo. "The Government waited, waited, and then released the measures at the right moment," Mr. Schwartz said, adding that the speculators would come out badly.
 The Government is thought to have spent $4 billion or more since it moved on Monday to widen the currency's trading range.
 Selling dollars to keep the real within the band may have been costly, Mr. Schwartz said. But the dollars the Government now buys back will be cheap. "It's fantastic," he said. "The Government will recover the reserves it lost and even make a profit."
 However, he said it would take time to see whether the measures will help improve investor confidence in Brazil and reverse a sharp slide in stock and bond prices in recent weeks.
 Today, officials raised interbank lending rates to 6 percent a month, from 4 percent on Thursday, to make the real more attractive than the dollar. It also plans to sell $10 billion in new debt indexed to the dollar.
 In a third series of measures, the central bank limited the positions that banks can hold in foreign-exchange operations to $1 million from $50 million.
 The measures put selling pressure on the dollar, said Roberto Luis Troster, chief economist at Banco Itamarati S.A., and as a result, "they now have to get rid of the dollars."

HEADLINE: Big Bank Expects Loss For Quarter

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation announced yesterday that it expected to lose as much as $125 million after taxes in the first quarter of 1995.
 In a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the corporation, parent of the Bankers Trust Company, said that the losses would stem from two core businesses: trading for its own account, primarily in Latin America, and a slowdown in revenues from the controversial financial instruments widely known as derivatives. 
 Derivatives are contracts whose value is derived from the value of underlying assets like stocks, currencies or commodities. Bankers Trust refers to them as risk management products.
 "The corporation has experienced losses in certain of its Latin America and other trading positions, as well as a sharp falloff in revenues from the sale of risk management products," Bankers Trust said in its 10-K filing. "The corporation cannot predict when the business environment will improve."
 Based on this announcement, Moody's Investors Service Inc. placed the long-term ratings of Bankers Trust under review for possible downgrade, affecting about $4.1 billion of securities. "The possibility of a first-quarter 1995 loss suggests that B.T.N.Y.'s businesses may have been impaired to a greater extent than anticipated in February," Moody's said.
 Raphael Soifer, a banking analyst for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, said: "This year is going to turn into a rebuilding year for Bankers Trust. They are going to have to downsize the factory and restructure the business."
 On Thursday, rumors circulated on Wall Street that United States banks might face significant losses on their Latin American assets, particularly one major bank. Some bank stocks slipped that day -- including Bankers Trust, which fell 87.5 cents.
 Bankers Trust's stock rose $1.125 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $61.375. The report of the $125 million loss came out after the stock market closed. For the first three months of 1994, Bankers Trust reported a net profit of $164 million, or $1.90 a share.
 Four top Latin American traders and investment bankers left Bankers Trust for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette last month. Latin American markets have declined sharply in the wake of the devaluation of the Mexican peso in December and the financial crisis that has followed in that country.
 Bankers Trust has suffered a series of mishaps recently in the derivatives area, causing it to reclassify derivatives deals valued at $351 million as nonperforming loans. In December, it paid a $10 million fine to settle charges that it had hidden the extent of the losses from derivatives securities from one of one of its clients, Gibson Greetings Inc. It has also had public disputes over derivatives with other corporate customers, including the Procter & Gamble Company, which in February amended an earlier lawsuit against Bankers Trust seeking additional damages.
 "Derivatives were very slow for Bankers Trust in the first quarter," Mr. Soifer said. "It's not that clients aren't trading with them. But the type of trading being done is mainly plain vanilla and the dealer doesn't make much money on that."
 Bankers Trust said that the estimated $125 million loss did not include a possible charge in connection with its cost reduction program. On Tuesday, the company said that it cut 60 jobs, primarily in derivatives, as the first step in a plan to reduce expenses in 1995.

HEADLINE: Little Cheer in Jobs Data for New York Area

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
While declining national unemployment figures touched off joy in Washington and buoyed the stock markets yesterday, the celebration left New York City, New York State and New Jersey mainly on the outside looking in.
 The latest monthly unemployment figures left no doubt that if the national economy was heating up, the region was still feeling the effects of the recession's big chill. 
 "The region has certainly not participated fully in the recovery, not having gained back jobs lost during the downturn," said Anthony J. Ferrara, acting regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor. "Hopefully, a growing national economy could eventually pull it along, which it hasn't done so far.
 "On the other hand, if it were to be cooled down -- and some people are talking about inducing a soft landing -- it could be a bumpy landing for New York and New Jersey."
 Connecticut is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases national jobs data.
 While the national unemployment rate for February was put at 5.4 percent, a four-year low, the New York State rate stood at 6.1 percent, up from 6 percent in January but down from 7.8 percent a year earlier.
 New York City's rate climbed to 9 percent, from 7.7 in January, but it was below the rate a year earlier of 10 percent.
 Only New Jersey's rate dropped in February, to 6.1 percent from 7.2 percent in January. The rate in February 1994 was also 7.2 percent. While calling the New Jersey numbers "fairly positive," Mr. Ferrara cautioned against overreacting, saying that the figures might reflect not only a buildup of employment during December, with its holidays, but also an abnormally warm February.
 Nevertheless, Mr. Ferrara said, New Jersey added 78,000 jobs in February, for a growth rate of 2.2 percent. "That's certainly the best performance among states in the Northeast," he said.
 In comparison, Mr. Ferrara noted, New York State added only 56,500 jobs in the entire year from January 1994 to January 1995, the latest period for which data are available. "That's a minor growth rate of seven-tenths of a percent, which is the lowest among all states except Hawaii," he said.
 At the same time, he said, New York lost 15,000 manufacturing jobs. "And there again, only three states performed more poorly," Mr. Ferrara said, naming Connecticut, Delaware and Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Data on Credit Had Big Error

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve disclosed today that it had made a $ 4 billion "miscalculation" in its report earlier this week on January consumer credit, but it refused to say how the error happened.
 Consumer installment borrowing rose $ 7.645 billion in January, not $ 3.673 billion as the Fed first reported on Tuesday. The December increase of $ 6.554 billion was not revised. 
 "There was a misreading of a number," a Fed spokesman, Joseph Coyne, said. He declined to provide further details.
 Corrections of government figures of this size, while not unknown, are still rare.
 In addition to correcting the gain in consumer credit for January, the Fed also said the annual rate of credit growth was 10.1 percent -- not 4.8 percent as first reported. The error occurred in only one category and figures for previous months were not changed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Jobs Data Push Dollar Up, With Fed Rate Rise Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies for a third day yesterday after a jobs report that was stronger than expected caused traders to speculate that the Federal Reserve would soon push interest rates higher again.
A rally in the Mexican peso also helped the dollar, traders said. The peso has been affecting the dollar recently because many investors are concerned that the United States has become a lender of last resort to Mexico. 
 The dollar also benefited from a big increase in American stock prices. Foreign investors need dollars to buy American securities.
After gaining in European trading, the dollar climbed further in the wake of a Labor Department report that the economy added 318,000 jobs in January, surpassing economists' expectations of a gain of 245,000.
"The very strong nonfarm payroll data is supporting the dollar, and the recovery of bonds is helping, too," Tom Hoge, corporate currency trader at the Bank of New York, said. "There is talk that these numbers will justify a Fed rate hike."
Higher interest rates often bolster a country's currency by making interest-bearing deposits in that country more attractive.
The dollar was last quoted at 1.4120 German marks, up from 1.4055 marks late Thursday in New York, and up from a record low of 1.3960 marks set Wednesday. It also stood at 90.90 yen, little changed from 91.02.
Traders said this week's negative sentiment toward the dollar stemmed from speculation that interest rates might have peaked, but today's jobs report makes that unlikely, they said.
Also, the concerns about Mexico eased, at least temporarily, after the Mexican Government disclosed an economic austerity plan late Thursday featuring spending cuts, sharp price increases for products like gasoline and electricity and higher taxes.
The peso rose from record lows against the dollar this morning. Its late quote was 16 cents, up from 13.42 cents late Thursday in New York.
The dollar gained against most currencies. The British pound fell to $1.57 from $1.6085 late Thursday in New York. The dollar rose to 1.1810 Swiss francs from 1.1725 and to 5.0455 French francs from 4.9705. The Canadian dollar was unchanged at 71.09 United States cents.

HEADLINE: Bonds Up Sharply Despite Jobs Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose strongly yesterday despite employment data that suggested the nation's economy was still growing at a pace that might justify caution about inflation.
 Traders instead focused on components of the Labor Department's employment report that showed little inflationary pressure. In addition, demand for bonds grew as the dollar performed better against other currencies, including both the Japanese yen and the German mark. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond finished up 19/32 point, or $5.94 for $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.46 percent, from 7.51 percent on Thursday.
 Some market analysts expressed surprise about the strength of Treasuries, which surged for a third straight day and finished near the week's high.
 "It's actually been a remarkable performance," said Joseph Liro, money market economist at S. G. Warburg. "What we have here is the dominance of bullishness on the notion the economy will slow down over the next few months so that any inflation we see will be fairly modest."
 Inflation erodes the value of fixed-length investments like bonds, causing traders always to watch for signs of it.
 The employment figures that were announced yesterday, showing a drop in unemployment during February to 5.4 percent from 5.7 percent, could have been expected to cause more worry than they did.
 Indeed, bond prices fell initially because the figures that were first reported suggested the economy was growing at a brisk pace.
 But as details emerged, market participants focused on data that showed average hourly earnings were unchanged and the length of the average workweek decreased.
 "If you pick through the number, it wasn't as strong as it looked," said Jim Kenney, head trader at Prudential Securities.
 In an unusual twist, currency traders took a different view of the employment data and ended up helping the bond market.
 The currency market saw a strong economy and inflationary pressure in the report and bid up the value of the dollar in the belief that the Fed would raise interest rates to curb inflation. Higher rates make the dollar more attractive to international investors, and that in turn makes dollar-denominated investments like bonds more attractive.
 Short-term Treasuries rose 1/32 point to 1/16 point and intermediate maturities rose 3/16 point to 13/32 point, the financial information service Telerate Inc. reported.
 The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, went up 0.24, to 1,205.53.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Flat European Sector Was Best Overseas

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
Although it's not saying much, Europe was the best of the overseas stock sectors last year. Its markets were flat over all, while markets elsewhere turned in losses.
 To make the list of top European funds for the last three years, managers had to cherry-pick stocks from many countries and industries. Foreign fund managers who use the top-down approach -- choosing countries that look promising, industries there and then specific stocks -- have had less success since the European exchange rate mechanism collapsed in 1992, leaving the Continent's economies less closely linked. 
 One way to profit in a flat market is to make bets on currencies. The top two Europe funds, from Dean Witter and Putnam, did just that, deciding not to hedge their currency risks in 1994. That meant their investments abroad gained in value as the dollar weakened.
 In its economic cycle, Europe may be several steps behind the United States, where markets were battered last year by rising interest rates after several strong years. "Europe tends to lag the U.S., so it's still in the early stages of its economic recovery," said Natalie Andrus, an analyst for Morningstar Inc.
