HEADLINE: In a Tense Zone in Croatia, Respect Wanes Along With U.N.'s Mandate

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: KNIN, Croatia, March 10

 BODY:
Told that Croatian troops were massing in a demilitarized zone, the Czech commander of United Nations troops around this separatist Serb city jumped into a four-wheel-drive vehicle the other day and rode out to protest.
But when the commander got there, United Nations officials said, the Croatian Government troops in the so-called zone of separation bluntly told him he had no business interfering. One Croatian officer even warned that he might be "declared persona non grata" if he sought to enforce his mandate to keep combatants out of the area. 
 "There's no respect," the commander, Maj. Gen. Rostislav Kotil, reflected during an interview.
The incident suggests the uneasy role of the 12,000 United Nations troops in Croatia, whose future has hung in the balance since the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, threatened to expel them two months ago. [Senior Clinton Administration officials said on Saturday that the Western allies had been reached a tentative deal with Mr. Tudjman to keep a much reduced force in the country.]
The Croatian President has taken a hard line in negotiations with Western diplomats, saying the troops' three-year presence as a buffer force has only helped solidify the 1991 conquests of the rebel Serbs. The peacekeepers' mandate is formally scheduled to expire March 31.
Since Mr. Tudjman demanded the pullout in January, the position of the United Nations troops has become increasingly tenuous. Most worrisome, said Lieut. Bob Rogers, a Canadian officer in the United Nations force, the cease-fire zone itself "is starting to collapse," with both sides seeking to gain ground and sending bellicose messages to diplomats in Washington, Zagreb and elsewhere.
Beyond words and persuasion, the United Nations troops have little leverage to try to prevent cease-fire violations. The peacekeepers may use their weapons only if their lives are threatened.
Standing atop a rainy, rocky hilltop near Drnis, at town in the cease-fire zone, Capt. Ole Saitambao, a Kenyan member of the United Nations force, watched powerlessly the other day as Serbs openly plowed a road to a neighboring summit in breach of the cease-fire.
Within sight of a United Nations observation post at Skbranje, Serbian rebels were digging new emplacements this week on a site that Canadian peacekeepers now ruefully call "Bunker Hill."
The United Nations forces in Croatia are deployed along a clearly defined cease-fire line, a ribbon of land one and a half to two miles wide that follows the perimeter of the areas seized by rebel Serbs in 1991. Under the terms of the cease-fire signed a year ago no armed Serbs or Croats are supposed to enter the "zone of separation," let alone dig trenches in or near it.
In another area 6 to 12 miles back from the cease-fire line, Serbs and Croats are supposed to keep their heavy weapons in depots where the United Nations can inspect them.
Under the current mandate, which now seems certain to be modified in diplomatic negotiations, the United Nations troops are also charged with protecting the few Croats still living in the separatist Serb region. They also clear mines from graveyards and escort people from both sides to bury their dead or visit graves.
The region under the Serbs' control, some 30 percent of Croatia's territory, is not much to look at. The fighting and the Serbs' systematic efforts to drive out Croats have left a terrain of near-empty villages, wrecked houses, booby-trapped ruins and hastily dug cemeteries.
"There's the mass grave," said Lieut. Jamie Robertson, a Canadian officer, in a matter-of-fact way, gesturing toward 26 wooden crosses in an unkempt field in Skbranje.
The churches are flattened. Schools are destroyed. At night, a single light from a Serb home might be the only glimmer in a village whose Croats have been slain or expelled.
Gunfire sometimes rattles, as it did several times this morning near a Canadian outpost. The cherry trees have begun to blossom with the coming spring, but the thaw only coaxes weeds in agricultural fields that have no one to till them.
The countless land-mines strewn on the front-lines here will probably take 50 years to clear, said Sgt. John Butler, a Canadian engineer.
Many United Nations officials consider Mr. Tudjman's condemnation of the peacekeepers for maintaining the division of the country to be unfair. Such criticism ignores the way the United Nations troops have kept the two sides apart, they say, and even fostered the beginnings of a reconciliation.
After intense and then sporadic fighting, "there has been a year of cease-fire between two parties," said General Kotil, the commander of 4,200 United Nations troops in the southern part of the Serb-held region, known as the Krajina. "It's a clear example that something is working."
Before Mr. Tudjman's announcement in January, the two sides had taken the first, halting steps toward economic cooperation, opening a main highway and an oil pipeline and fielding teams of technicians to discuss rebuilding water and electric power supplies. Those contacts have now been suspended.
But many United Nations officials acknowledged that their mission faltered, for neither Serbs nor Croats displaced in the fighting have been able to return home. In preserving the cease-fire line, the United Nations troops are thus also cementing a line of ethnic division.
"The security situation has simply been too uncertain for that," said a United Nations official in this so-called Serb capital, a strategic railroad town ringed by snowy mountains. "We are accused of cementing the status quo, but it's one of the paradoxes of peacekeeping that maintaining the status quo is what we are supposed to do."
Behind the lines, the Krajina Serbs have done their best to implant a Serbian mini-state. Phone lines and supply routes run from Knin to Belgrade. The currency used here and the Cyrillic script are Serbian, too. The Krajina Serbs now have their own parliament, Government and army, all supported by Serbia, but not much in the way of prosperity.
That gives the United Nations force another, less official role. While it may not trade on the local market, it employs hundreds of Serbs as drivers, cooks, cleaners and interpreters, spending millions of dollars on rents, salaries and even contracts for the removal of sewage and garbage.
That, some observe, makes peacekeeping the only growth industry in town.

Mark Gray, a Canadian private in the United Nations force, reported a cease-fire violation yesterday from an observation post in the southern town of Skbranje. (Michel Albert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton to Recommend Wolfensohn to Head World Bank

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
President Clinton has chosen James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker and arts patron, as president of the World Bank, the White House announced today.
The selection is formally a recommendation to the World Bank's directors, who elect the president. By tradition, the World Bank presidency goes to an American and the directorship of the International Monetary Fund to a European. 
Mr. Wolfensohn, 61, will succeed Lewis T. Preston, who is ill with cancer and who has asked to retire before his five-year term ends next year.
The Administration chose the Australian-born Mr. Wolfensohn, a naturalized American citizen, over two other insiders: Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a former World Bank chief economist, and Stanley Fischer, also a former chief economist at the bank and now a deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Wolfensohn, who actively sought the World Bank presidency, has maintained his investment banking business in New York while serving part time and without salary since 1990 as chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
Mr. Summers's candidacy may have been hurt by his role on behalf of the Administration's Mexico rescue package in Congress, where it was unpopular. While the World Bank presidency is not subject to Senate confirmation, the Administration is seeking Congressional support for multibillion-dollar contributions to the World Bank's International Development Agency.
In making the announcement today, President Clinton said Mr. Wolfensohn "has already had an extraordinary career in finance and public service, spanning four decades and three continents." Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Wolfensohn's international background and wide-ranging contacts would permit him to be a "forceful advocate for the bank and development issues."
Mr. Wolfensohn, a member of Australia's fencing team in the 1956 Olympics, became an American citizen in 1980. The chairman of his firm, James D. Wolfensohn, Inc., which advises major corporate clients, is Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman.
Before founding his firm in 1981, Mr. Wolfensohn was a partner in Salomon Brothers. He received undergraduate and law degrees from the University of Sydney and an M.B.A. at Harvard Business School.
But what has most distinguished him from myriad other wealthy investment bankers has been his involvement in the arts. A cellist, he served as chairman of Carnegie Hall for more than 10 years and helped raise money for refurbishing the hall in time for its centennial.
As chairman of the cash-starved Kennedy Center, he has raised money to help the center remain open. His daughter Sara is a concert pianist. He and his wife, Elaine, also have a son, Adam, and another daughter, Naomi.
The World Bank entered its second half-century this year facing questions about the environmental consequences of its large-scale development projects and doubts about the efficacy of channeling money to state-owned enterprises in countries with unstable governments.
The bank, which issues about $17 billion in loans each year, has increased its spending on environmental and human development projects, but has been criticized on those issues in the past. A coalition of environmentalist, human rights and even competing aid groups, calling itself the "50 Years is Enough" campaign, said last year that the bank should mark its 50th anniversary by going out of business.
The bank has also been criticized as overstaffed. Mr. Preston recently announced plans for a 12 percent staff reduction during the next two years, and Mr. Wolfensohn has said he would like to make further cuts.
The World Bank president earns a salary of $190,000 a year plus a $90,000-a-year expense account.

HEADLINE: NASA Turns to Industry for Next Generation of Launchers

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The space agency has begun a competition within the aerospace industry to design and build a new family of reusable rockets that would eventually replace the space shuttle and other satellite launchers.
In a move that could fundamentally change the way the nation puts payloads into space, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration last week selected four companies to propose new launch systems that would not only greatly reduce the costs of space flight but also take NASA out of the business of building and operating its own fleet of rockets. 
 If the program is successful, experts said after the Wednesday announcement, it will result in a new generation of reusable rockets, owned and operated by private industry, that the Government and other customers would pay to use when they needed to launch satellites or other cargoes.
Turning the space launching business over to private industry would not only reduce the cost of the space program and the size of NASA, they said, but would also encourage a robust commercial space business in the United States to compete with the rocket-building programs of other nations.
Under the plan, the Government would pay for research on crucial new rocket technology and would finance the building of sub-scale, flying test rockets to see if the new systems worked. Then it would be up to the aerospace industry to finance the construction, operation and marketing of the new rockets.
"This will fundamentally change the space program and fundamentally change NASA," the agency's administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, said on Friday. "NASA will become a smaller, leaner research and development agency emphasizing cutting-edge science and technology, and not putting its resources into operating rockets."
Speaker Newt Gingrich endorsed the NASA plans in a speech on Monday in Georgia, saying the new approach to space flight would be akin to the relationship between commercial airlines and aircraft manufacturers, with airlines stating their needs and the aircraft industry building planes to meet them. Contractors have told him, Mr. Gingrich said, that they can probably build a new rocket to replace the space shuttle in a third of the time for no more than 40 percent of the cost of the Government doing it.
Experts said the effort is economically viable if NASA and other Government users serve as "anchor tenants," providing a core of business as the industry develops a larger, private customer base.
"This concept represents a real transition to the next phase of space flight," said Dr. John Logsdon, director of George Washington University's Space Policy Institute in Washington. "It's certainly the next step beyond the shuttle for routine and affordable access to space."
About half of NASA's $13 billion budget goes for maintaining and operating its aging fleet of four space shuttles. While reusable, the shuttles are complicated machines based on early 1970's technology. On each flight of the shuttle, its large external fuel tank is discarded and its twin rocket boosters must be recovered at sea for refurbishing, an expensive process.
The new program calls for developing a large, totally reusable, unpiloted rocket that takes off, goes into orbit and returns as a single unit. Such a rocket should be able to lift shuttle-size payloads and carry 25,000-pound cargoes to the planned international space station, program officials say.
In addition, the program calls for developing a smaller, mostly reusable rocket that could cheaply take small payloads -- between 1,000 and 2,000 pounds -- into low Earth orbits.
NASA said it would negotiate contracts with three groups of companies for the first phase of the large-rocket project, on which the Government will spend $24 million over 15 months and the contractors will contribute a matching amount. During this period, the contractors are to design a vehicle and develop business plans and operations strategies.
The Government will then decide whether to go to the second phase, building and flying an experimental rocket called the X-33 by the end of the decade at a cost to the Government of about $650 million.
Mr. Goldin and other supporters of the program said they would prefer building prototypes of the two leading contenders for Phase 2 and having a fly-off to decide which is best, but it is uncertain if money for this would be available.
NASA selected these three X-33 proposals:
*The Lockheed Advanced Development Company of Palmdale, Calif., has proposed building a wingless, flat-bottomed rocket called a lifting body that would take off vertically and land horizontally like an airplane.
*Rockwell International Corporation's Space Systems Division of Downey, Calif., working with Northrop Grumman of Los Angeles and other partners, has proposed a winged ship that looks somewhat like a large shuttle, which Rockwell builds, but without external tanks or boosters. It would also would rise vertically and land horizontally.
*McDonnell Douglas Aerospace of Huntington Beach, Calif., working in partnership with Boeing Aircraft of Seattle, said it had not yet settled on a design, but experts familiar with its program said the company was considering both a winged model similar to the other proposals and an innovative concept that would both take off and land vertically on downward-firing engines. The company built and flew a small, vertically landing test rocket, called the DC-X, in 1993 and 1994
For the small-rocket project, which would produce a prototype called the X-34 to fly in late 1997, the agency selected the Orbital Sciences Corporation of Dulles, Va., in partnership with Rockwell International. The companies plan to spend $100 million on the project, and NASA will contribute $70 million for research and testing through 1999.

Rockwell's concept for a reusable rocket is shown in an artist's rendering. (Rockwell International)

HEADLINE: As World Leaders Confer on Poverty, Mitterrand Urges New Tax

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, March 11

 BODY:
The largest gathering of world leaders ever assembled began a two-day marathon of speeches today on improving the lives of the world's 1.3 billion most destitute people. Many promises were made, but few new high-level commitments or concrete proposals.
President Francois Mitterrand of France, making his last appearance before a large international audience before elections in France next month, was an exception. He supported a proposal to tax speculative international currency transactions as way of raising money for development. The suggested levy was proposed by James Tobin, an American who was awarded the 1981 Nobel Prize for economics. 
 Austria also made a concrete gesture, saying it was writing off $100 million in debt for the poorest nations, in line with a recommendation to lender governments in a declaration to be signed Sunday. The declaration also asks the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to reexamine the indebtedness of countries in distress and find more ways to cushion the harsh measures that are often part of economic reform.
The declaration urges, but cannot compel, donor Governments to earmark 20 percent of aid for spending on education, health and other human development programs. It asks other countries, including those receiving assistance, to devote 20 percent of their budgets for spending in the same areas. Most developing countries are far below that figure.
President Mitterrand, who has cancer and who appeared drawn and weak as he spoke, said he had no illusions about the difficulty of establishing a tax on financial transactions. But he challenged the audience of more than 115 government leaders to make a real commitment.
"Are we just acting before the world?" he asked. "Or are we really determined to raise social issues to the rank of peace and the economy?"
On Sunday, the assembled kings, presidents and prime ministers will sign a declaration negotiated this week during working sessions of the World Summit for Social Development. Vice President Al Gore is scheduled to speak on Sunday, along with President Fidel Castro of Cuba.
The declaration includes a broad plan of action, saying that democracy, a rule of law and human rights and environmental protection are needed for public well-being. Several large developing nations objected to these references.
One argument holding up negotiations this week was over national sovereignty. Developing nations lost a fight to have the principle of noninterference stated explicitly -- to spare them international scrutiny of their policies.
Today Prime Minister Li Peng of China, Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao of India and President Suharto of Indonesia, representing three nations that regularly oppose the expansion of international human rights monitoring, all demanded that the world allow them to find their own way to social progress.
The declaration is vague on the issue of raising money for development aid, to the distress of many private assistance groups and some United Nations officials. This has led to considerable discussion of the Tobin tax by private groups that have come to lobby at the conference.
The idea is likely to be explored in a preliminary way at a meeting of the seven major industrial nations in Canada in June, said George Greene, policy director at the Canadian International Development Agency. Such a tax would help Governments like the United States that are under pressure to reduce foreign aid, he said.

HEADLINE: The Safety Zone;
Coast Guard Tries to Rid Waters of Deficient Foreign Ships

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The aging Russian freighter did not seem menacing, just another maritime pack animal hauling scrap metal or waste paper or some other bulk leftover. But when it crept into New York Harbor the other day, it became an outlaw. The United States Coast Guard moved in. The vessel was impounded. Its crew was interrogated. Its records were checked. Its holds were searched.
It was not that the freighter, the Favorit, was smuggling drugs or illegal immigrants. Its sin was its condition: its hull was pocked with leaks, and its decks had rusted to a crumbly orange. It was in danger of causing an accident that might disable shipping lanes that are as finely calibrated as the runways of a busy airport. 
 "Would you let somebody you care about sail on this?" said Lieut. Eric G. Westerberg, a Coast Guard inspector, as he walked through the ship's belly, thumbing every so often through a Russian-English dictionary for words like "crack" or "broken" so he could question members of the crew.
As the shipping industry endures another year of recession, more poorly maintained vessels from other countries are plying the seas, hoping to make do without costly repairs. Some find their way to New York Harbor, a cramped and bustling place where a seemingly minor mishap can wreak heavy financial losses on companies whose ships or goods are delayed.
Seeking to protect the safety and health of United States harbors, the Coast Guard has started a campaign to rid the waters of substandard ships that are registered in foreign countries, often detaining them for weeks at anchor or in terminals until their owners fix the deficiencies. The new policy mirrors similar ones in Europe and Japan.
Since last May, when the stepped-up inspections began, 21 foreign-flag ships, most of them freighters, have been detained by the New York office of the Coast Guard, including four at the Port of New Haven, officials said. Just yesterday, the office was holding another Russian freighter at New Haven until it made repairs.
The total since May includes the most well known of violators, the ocean liner Queen Elizabeth 2, which was held at dock for more than a day in December.
The Queen Elizabeth 2 would most likely have been penalized under the old rules as well, for passenger ships have long been subjected to rigorous inspections because of the greater risk to human life should accidents occur.
As a result, it is rare for them to be detained because their owners take precautions not to run afoul of the rules. And tankers have come under intense scrutiny since the Exxon Valdez oil-spill disaster in 1989.
The big change involves freighters. Nationally, 303 foreign-flag ships were cited by the Coast Guard in 1994, four months of which fell under the old rules, officials said. The total for 1994 is a sharp increase over that for 1993, though it is difficult to make an exact comparison because the Coast Guard kept track of detentions differently before last May, officials said.
"This is a threat that is beginning to materialize," said Roger Kohn, a spokesman for the International Maritime Organization in London, an arm of the United Nations that regulates shipping.
"Owners are not replacing ships the way they used to, so the ships are getting older and older," Mr. Kohn said. "The average age is 18 years, and that's very old. Some owners are finding it difficult to do the maintenance that is necessary. They are also going for cheap crews from developing countries. If you look at the casualty and accident records each year, you find that the same group of countries comes at the top of the list."
The violations are wide-ranging: faulty steering, navigation, engines or firefighting or lifesaving equipment, including lifeboats; structural damage to the ship, like the leaks on the Favorit; defects that lead to pollution, like oil spills, or poorly trained crews.
The Coast Guard stresses that only a small percentage of foreign-flag ships are in poor shape. It has found that those in violation of the policy are usually registered in nations that may take little interest in whether the ships are seaworthy.
The agency has targeted ships that are registered in 15 countries, including India, Argentina and several others in Latin America. Even as the Favorit was forced into drydock in January, another freighter, the Harkishin, which sails under an Indian flag, was being detained in the harbor because of leaks and defects in its lifeboats and electrical systems, the Coast Guard said.
The inspection of the Favorit provided a glimpse of the hazards that the Coast Guard often detects.
After the Favorit, which was built in the 1970's, hobbled into a drydock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, Lieutenant Westerberg and three other Coast Guard officers spent several hours examining the structure of the ship and its equipment. They learned from the crew that in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, the leaks in the hull had been letting in dozens of gallons of water a minute.
The crew had resorted to a desperate fix: pushing wooden boxes filled with concrete against the leaks and buttressing them with rods. The damage was apparent. But the Coast Guard also discovered shoddy lifesaving equipment and sections of hull weakened by corrosion.
"There are more vertical cracks here," Lieutenant Westerberg said at one point, slamming a hammer into a beam to test its strength. "Do you realize the potential of that? We suspect that many of the freight vessels that disappear without a trace break in half. It's a cause for concern whenever cracks develop in the middle of a ship."
Lieutenant Westerberg and the other inspectors -- Lieut. Jennifer Rusiecki, Lieut. Chris O'Brien and Lieut. David Flaherty -- said the crews of the impounded ships tend to be cooperative, often because they are grateful that owners are being pressured to make repairs. The crew of the Favorit was no different, dutifully pointing out, in halting English, the damage and the repairs in progress. The ship left after being detained for more than a week.
Many owners of foreign-flag ships, including United States companies that have registered their vessels in other countries because of less costly regulations, were at first wary of the new policy, questioning whether foreign-flag ships were being picked on. But some now say that the Coast Guard has carried it out fairly.
"It's certainly had an impact in upgrading the quality of ships coming to U.S. ports," said Philip J. Loree, the chairman of the Federation of American Controlled Shipping, which represents American companies that have registered vessels in Liberia, the Marshall Islands, the Bahamas and Panama.
"If you had called me last May or June when this was announced, I would have said that there was great concern," Mr. Loree said. "But I can say now that in the American ship-owning communities, there is almost zero concern."
Mr. Loree and other shipping executives also said that when rickety ships create accidents, everyone in the industry suffers.
There has not been a serious incident in New York Harbor involving a foreign-flag vessel in recent years, but there have been close calls. And foreign ships have done serious damage elsewhere. In the Houston ship channel, for example, a freighter registered in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a Caribbean island group, collided with a barge in 1992.
The accident caused $1 million in damage to the vessels, and the shipping channel was closed for three days, causing $6 million in delays for shipping companies, Federal officials said. Investigators later criticized the crew of the freighter, the Juraj Dalmatinac, for failing to use its navigation equipment properly.
It is the fear of a similar disaster that hangs over New York Harbor, which many thousands of vessels visit every year.
"This has traditionally been a problem," said Capt. William W. Sherwood, the president of the New York Sandy Hook Pilots Association, whose members assist commercial ships with navigation.
"We see on occasion vessels that are in pretty tough physical shape," he said. "We have had vessels that have had problems with oil spills or have damaged a particular segment of the waterway. The port effectively loses its ability to function. So anything that the Coast Guard can do is very much welcome."

Jennifer Rusiecki of the Coast Guard inspect the hull of the Favorit, a detained Russian freighter. (Photographs by Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Gambling Debate, Foes Await Bridgeport Casino Vote

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 10

 BODY:
The political and business leadership of this city is determined to show state legislators that Bridgeport voters want a casino so much that they will vote overwhelmingly for it in a referendum on March 28.
In a fiercely waged contest, the Bridgeport Regional Business Council expects to spend $190,000 campaigning for a casino, which it says is the key to transforming the struggling city's port into a tourist attraction like the Inner Harbor in Baltimore. 
 But whatever a casino might do for Bridgeport, Connecticut's largest city, its impact on the state began to loom larger this week, as the General Assembly's Public Safety Committee approved a bill that would establish a commission to select a Bridgeport developer.
Signing that bill, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians warned Gov. John G. Rowland, would cost the state the $130 million a year the tribe provides from the profits of its Foxwoods casino, by breaking a compact negotiated by his predecessor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., that gave the Pequots a monopoly on slot machines.
Bills drafted to replace the Pequot millions would not only put a casino in Bridgeport, but also spread slot machines across the state in parimutuel establishments like jai alai frontons and teletracks.
"This is not about a casino in Bridgeport," said a lobbyist for the Pequots, Charles Duffy. "Those are not parimutuel facilities with a few slot machines; they're casinos, too. All of this struggle, to replace revenue that is coming to them regularly and without travail."
The Pequot money has stood in the way of expanding casino gambling in Connecticut ever since Mr. Weicker, an opponent of casinos, negotiated a deal that gave the state a 25 percent share of the tribe's slot-machine revenue in return for the games' being permitted only on tribal reservations.
Since the state gains more than $130 million a year from the deal, and since $85 million of that is distributed to towns and cities for tax relief, legislators have always known that any bill authorizing a casino would have to replace that money.
Developers like Mirage Resorts and Donald Trump have pledged to make up the revenue, but one problem is how to cover potentially hundreds of millions lost between the Pequots' expected cutoff and the new casino's opening two, three or four years later.
"The issue is, the Pequots are up and running now, and we don't want any down time in that revenue stream," said State Representative Stephen D. Dargan, a Democrat from West Haven who is co-chairman of the Public Safety Committee. "Everyone has a grave concern with the budgetary constraints upon us."
"But I've said many times," he continued, "I don't think the state or we as a legislative body want to be held hostage by the Pequots."
The current bill provides for putting slot machines in parimutuel establishments within 90 days and permitting a temporary riverboat casino in Bridgeport to replace some of the revenue. The developer would cover the remaining difference, minus any taxes it paid to the state during construction.
But Mr. Rowland, who has endorsed a Bridgeport casino as a way to restart the city's economy, surprised many legislators this week by threatening to veto the casino bill because of the Pequot money.
He later reassured the Public Safety Committee that he would support a bill that fully replaced the Pequot money -- if, in addition, Bridgeport residents approved a casino in a referendum, and if a majority of its jobs went to Bridgeport residents. He also asked the Pequots to consider bidding to be the developer.
The momentary alarm underlined for casino advocates the task they face in reassuring not only their opponents in Bridgeport, but also legislators across the state, that the revenue and jobs from a casino here will help rebuild the city without harming the rest of the state.
The goal, said Paul Timpanelli, president of the Business Council, is to have revenue from a single casino finance the redevelopment of the city's harbor, producing another family-oriented Baltimore Inner Harbor instead of another Atlantic City.
Property taxes on a casino estimated at $15 million a year, plus $15 million from the city's share of a casino tax, could finance in a decade the development of other new businesses that otherwise might take 30 years to build, he said.
"We're not just for a casino," Mr. Timpanelli said. "We're for an overall development plan centered on the waterfront. We have a plan, and we have a means of expediting that plan with a casino."
This week, Bridgeport's Mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, released a consultant's study that concluded that a casino here, little more than an hour from New York City by rail, highway and ferry, could gross a billion dollars a year, easily outdoing the Pequots' contribution to the state.
But the projections of casino developers are already under attack by opponents here, who include clergy groups and a coalition called Bridgeport Residents Against Gambling.
Noel Furie, a leader of the residents' group, borrowed money for a billboard above the Connecticut Turnpike that says "Casino gambling -- a lousy deal for Bridgeport." The group, she said, has about $800 on hand to wage a campaign against the Business Council's efforts, and hopes to spend $10,000.
Bridgeport, Ms. Furie said, already has a strategic plan that focuses on developing the port and new industries like entertainment, and a casino and its self-contained shops and restaurants would simply draw people and money away from those.
She argued that the casino would also make the city unattractive to new families with young children, and to businesses that might consider the city. "Nothing else is going to happen as long as the casino interests are here as a possibility," she said.
A recent survey of clergy by the Council of Churches of Greater Bridgeport found that a large majority of those responding opposed a casino, said the Rev. John S. Kidd, the council's executive director. Moral and social issues connected to gambling were only one concern.
"They believe the casino interests are holding out promises they aren't going to fulfill," he said. "They describe casinos as vacuum cleaners, as a variety of images suggesting a casino costs a community more than it contributes."
Just how much a Bridgeport casino, in heavy competition with Foxwoods and other casinos under development, can contribute to the city and the state compared with what Foxwoods guarantees now, will soon be scrutinized by the legislature's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee.
"People keep asking, how can you guarantee this, and you can't guarantee it," Mr. Timpanelli said. "You have to have a good marketing plan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A billboard over the Connecticut Turnpike expresses opposition to the proposed casino in Bridgeport. A referendum will be on March 28. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Bronx Miracle

 BODY:
The Bronx may well be the nation's most nfamous symbol of urban blight. Battered by highway construction begun in the 1950's, abandoned by the middle class in the 60's, torched by arsonists through the 70's, the South Bronx in particular became a bombed-out relic and a synonym for hopelessness and decay.
 But that image is no longer accurate. Take a Sunday drive and you will be surprised to see that the burned-out Bronx is largely gone. The dispiriting stretches of ghost buildings that once loomed along the Cross Bronx Expressway have either been reclaimed as cooperative apartments or cleared to make way for hundreds of new town houses. 
 After Mayor Edward Koch initiated a citywide $5 billion housing renovation plan in 1986, the city and not-for-profit groups began renovating thousands of apartments each year. Additional city funds were committed to help subsidize the construction of new homes. The Bronx has clawed its way back and is rapidly becoming a borough of middle-class homeowners. Since 1986, 19,000 apartments have been refurbished and more than 2,500 houses have been built for working-class home buyers, with 2,000 more in the pipeline.
 The heroes of this story are the not-for-profit community development corporations that build and rehabilitate buildings and counsel the first-time home buyers who make up just about all of the new owners. The C.D.C.'s organize the process and instruct the buyers in everything they need to know, including the art of applying for a mortgage in a community whose real estate the banks once looked upon as having zero value.
 The banks and some builders remain skeptical. Thus the buyers must part with their down payments while the homes they wish to buy are yet to be built. For a working-class family living in the much-maligned Bronx, this requires a huge leap of faith.
 That faith is paying dividends. Neighborhoods once made up entirely of the poor are being economically integrated. With ownership comes pride in community -- and vigilance against crime and disorder. While small patches of desolation remain, the vast empty stretches have all been renewed. Neatly kept town houses have cropped up where the eyesores used to be. Markets and retail stores are cautiously returning to the neighborhoods.
 Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer declares with pride that his community has reversed middle-class flight. Only the next census will show how true that is. But for now, the signs of promise spring abundant.
 The Bronx has shown that government can help pull communities back from the brink and rebuild inner cities. The question is whether Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki will eradicate the housing program in the next round of budget cuts. If they do, a vital tool for reclaiming other battered parts of New York City will be lost.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Smoking Mountain

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
Of the many jokes making the rounds about Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, maybe the most appropriate one is this: Mr. Zedillo is in a rowboat with the Pope and a big wind blows the Pontiff's miter off his head. Mr. Zedillo climbs out of the boat, walks on water and retrieves the Pope's cap. The next day's headlines in the Mexican newspapers read: "Zedillo Can't Swim."
 Since taking office Dec. 1, Mr. Zedillo has been overwhelmed by Mexico's economic crisis, which erupted 19 days after he was sworn in. This has left the impression that his Cabinet is the gang that couldn't shoot straight. His aides openly concede that they were not prepared to deal with the economic situation, largely because they thought they were going to inherit a Rolls-Royce economy and when they discovered they had the keys to a jalopy about to be repossessed they weren't sure what to do. It has taken them two months to come up with a real rescue plan. 
 But what has been obscured is that Mr. Zedillo, while stumbling around in economics, has simultaneously instituted an impressive series of political reforms -- making Mexico more open, democratic and less corrupt than ever before -- for which he has gotten no credit, at home or abroad.
 Since coming to office, the Yale-educated Mr. Zedillo has sacked the entire corrupt Supreme Court, which he replaced with new judges and made independent of the presidency; he has suppressed the guerrilla insurgency in Chiapas; he has empowered the traditionally rubber-stamp Mexican legislature with real oversight responsibilities; he has given the political opposition a significant role in his Cabinet; he has begun instituting the rule of law, where arbitrariness used to reign, and he has jailed the brother of ex-President Carlos Salinas, in a courageous effort to root out corruption in Mexico's Mafia-style ruling class.
 In the short run, Mr. Zedillo is calculating that because Mexico is about to go through a brutal recession, with massive unemployment, having a more open political system that allows for more demonstrations and channels discontent via the ballot box may enable this society to blow off steam without blowing off the lid.
 In the long run, Mr. Zedillo is gambling that by diffusing power, rather than concentrating it like his predecessors, he will ultimately have more legitimacy, more authority and more cooperation from labor and business in getting this economy out of Chapter 11. That is a big bet. Mexico has always been a country that relied on a strong presidency to deal with crises, and what is democracy to Mr. Zedillo could be a tempting power vacuum to his opponents.
 "This moment is one of a profound shaking of the political system," said Antonio Lozano, Mr. Zedillo's gutsy Attorney General, whose investigations of the previous Government have turned up a trail of murder and drug money that has rattled the traditional power elite. "I have received full support from the President for my investigation. But we need support at home and from abroad."
 That's for sure. As I left Mr. Lozano's office, I went to close his door and it was so heavy with bullet-proof glass and steel I could barely move it. No Toto, this isn't Kansas.
 And that's what worries me. Talking with several of Mr. Zedillo's aides and ministers I came away feeling that they are "nice guys," who are in a bit over their heads. They lack what Mexican politicos call "colmillo," or fangs. They need our help, and I think they deserve it. If Mr. Zedillo succeeds, we will finally have the sort of democratic Mexico as a neighbor that we have long coveted. If he fails, there will be an explosive, nationalist backlash here that will certainly spill north.
 "Wall Street can help by giving us a break -- stop attacking us for 90 days," Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz told me Friday. "You don't have to be bullish on Mexico; just stop dumping the peso. Give our plan a chance."
 There is a semi-active volcano east of Mexico City known as "Popo," an Indian word that means smoking mountain. Last December, the same week Mexico announced its disastrous peso devaluation, Popo started to spew smoke and ash, after a long period of inactivity. Let's not fool ourselves. Mexico today is Popo. It is a smoking mountain, and Ernesto Zedillo is sitting on top of it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Grover Cleveland's Gold Strategy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your profile of Robert Rubin ("The Education of Robert Rubin," Feb. 5) garbles the historical comparison of present day Mexico with Grover Cleveland's Administration. President Cleveland, a "gold Democrat" and an unflinching defender of the gold standard, did not seek to repeal gold backing for Government bonds. Rather, by convening an extraordinary session of Congress at the height of the financial panic in the summer of 1893, he sought the repeal of the Sherman Silver Purchase Act of 1890. The Sherman Act, an unholy compromise between Western silver-mining interests and eastern Republican protectionists, had authorized monthly Government purchases of silver, thus adding millions of silver certificates to the nation's money supply. The increase in the money supply undermined the credibility of our commitment to the gold standard in the eyes of our European creditors. Thus, it was the prospect of an inflationary shift to the silver standard, and not the President's actions, that precipitated the European capital flight that had paralyzed the nation's money markets. 
 Unlike Mexico, the United States managed by 1896 to avoid devaluing the dollar. Yet if Newt Gingrich attends to the lessons of history, he should note the way Republican tariff policies, as well as Republican spending on veterans' pensions, aggravated the crisis by depleting the Government's gold reserves when they were needed most.LOREN GATCH Ithaca, N.Y., Feb. 7
The writer is a Ph.D. candidate in government at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: The Israeli-Egyptian Cold Peace Once Fostered Medical Ties

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re your March 7 news article on the bitter debate among Arabs over cultural ties with Israel: It is puzzling to witness the deterioration in attempts at normalization between the Arab countries and Israel. 
 When a disease called Rift Valley Fever threatened the Middle East in 1979, the Camp David peace agreement between Egypt and Israel allowed for the first cooperative health program ever in the region between the Kuvin Center for the Study of Infectious and Tropical Diseases of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Ain Shams University in Cairo.
 This $10 million, 12-year program was financed by the United States Agency for International Development and managed by the National Institutes of Health.
 The program was successful as judged by the publication of 50 joint papers, international meetings held in Egypt and Israel, control of the disease problems we were contracted to deal with, and Israeli scientists working as visiting professors in laboratories in Cairo and Egyptian scientists working in these same cooperative programs in Jerusalem.
 Most of all was the establishment of a core of Middle East scientific talent that became a family of scientists with an esprit de corps whose medical discoveries benefited the region and the world.
 Now the peace has turned cold, and the cultural links Egypt has with Israel are at a minimum to maintain "normalization."
 Some of our dearest Egyptian medical colleagues and scientists have had to seek employment in the Persian Gulf states and elsewhere because they were discouraged or prohibited by governmental authority from cooperating with Israel.
 Egyptian professional bodies still ban cultural exchanges with Israel.
 Our window into the world of Egyptian medical and scientific talent has been a wonderful experience with deep relationships established between dedicated individuals who yearn to see their country prosper. It is shameful that politics is preventing cultural regional cooperation.
 
SANFORD F. KUVIN, M.D.
Palm Beach, Fla., March 9, 1995
The writer is chairman of the Kuvin Center for the Study of Infectious and Tropical Diseases.

HEADLINE: Hit the Poor. Reward the Rich.

 BODY:
The stark unfairness of the House Republicans' legislative agenda was on display last week when committees approved three bills that would drive millions of poor people off welfare in order to finance tax cuts that have been made even more favorable to the rich. The G.O.P. is careering in a destructive direction.
By cutting perhaps $70 billion, or 15 percent, out of poverty programs over five years, the G.O.P. would drive hordes of the poor off welfare without any help in finding jobs. This assault on the indigent cannot be explained away as a necessary belt-tightening to reach a lofty purpose, like cutting the Federal deficit. The Republicans need these cuts now to offset their first round of tax cuts, even before they get down to deficit reduction. 
 Last week they released proposals for cutting taxes that start with the skewed promises in the Contract With America and make them worse by giving less relief than originally planned to low-income families. A large part of the tax cuts goes to upper-income families with capital-gains income, retirement savings accounts and Social Security benefits. Middle-class families with children get a tax credit. But gone are previous proposals to provide refundable tax credits for poor families in two categories -- those with children and those that incur expenses for adoption.
To help pay for these tax cuts, the welfare bills would discard the current pledge to aid every entitled poor person. They would cap Federal spending for cash assistance, food stamps and child welfare and turn over fixed pots of money, called block grants, to the states for them to spend largely at will. These ingredients do not mix well.
Block grants would be callous to the poor and harmful to the economy. When recessions hit, Washington now automatically spends whatever additional welfare money it takes to assist newly impoverished families. But under block grants, welfare money would not increase as the economy soured. Instead, the states would stay within preset spending limits either by raising eligibility standards or reducing benefits. That would eliminate a tool Washington has used to fight off recession: pumping money into the hands of poor consumers.
The Republican bills would also discourage work. States could qualify for block grants either by placing a high percentage of recipients into jobs, a costly exercise, or by reducing welfare rolls. Fiscally strapped states would almost certainly duck spending money on welfare-to-work programs and simply save money by paring caseloads.
Block grants would be destructive for another reason. States compete against one another to attract tax-paying families and corporations. A state that would raise taxes to pay for job placement and other poverty programs would risk repelling taxpayers and attracting poor residents from nearby states.
To embrace the G.O.P. plan, you have to believe at least three tales. First, teen-agers will stop having babies they cannot afford to raise if they face a future without welfare. Second, states will indeed spend money to help the poor in economically strained times. Third, the tax cuts that the G.O.P. proposes will lead to an economic resurgence. Not one of these propositions finds wide support among experts.
On welfare reform, President Clinton's vision has been largely right: he would offer assistance to the indigent if they agreed to undergo training, accept job placement and identify the fathers of welfare babies. The G.O.P.'s vision is largely wrong: it would drive recipients off welfare even if they were willing to play by these reasonable rules.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
THEY WHISPER
By Robert Olen Butler. Penguin, $10.95.
This novel is a tale of marital hypocrisy in which Ira Holloway, a man of about 35, betrays his wife not only by seducing other women but also by drawing away from her the love of the couple's young son. Presented as Ira's sexual history, it is "a shape-shifting narrative that lingers in the reader's moral consciousness and memory," Jane Smiley said here last year. 

JOSEPHINE: The Hungry Heart
By Jean-Claude Baker and Chris Chase. Adams, $12.95.
Josephine Baker, the alluring singer and dancer who faced racism in American society but became the toast of France in the 1920's, is the subject of this ambivalent biography. She emerges as a talented, determined and brave woman who could also be childish, manipulative and dishonest. Jean-Claude Baker, who was taken under the performer's wing when he was a boy and later adopted her surname, tells the story with Chris Chase, a professional writer. Last year our reviewer, Mindy Aloff, praised the book's "rhetorical fluency and narrative techniques," adding that Baker's "legend is dismantled with a vengeance, yet . . . her humanity is affirmed."
THE BALTIC REVOLUTION: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and the Path to Independence
By Anatol Lieven. Yale University, $15.
In a revised and updated edition, the author examines the ethnic nationalism of these former Soviet states and its implications for the West. Such a political climate, he argues, fostered the drive for autonomy but also gave rise to authoritarian new governments. His "sensitive account" succeeds in "raising questions, sharpening our vision and forcing us to reconsider our notions," Liah Greenfeld said here in 1993. The future of the former Soviet Union is also explored in the newly revised RUSSIA 2010: And What It Means for the World, by Daniel Yergin and Thane Gustafson (Vintage, $13). Analyzing studies conducted by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm, the authors imagine four possible scenarios: economic collapse, a military dictatorship, miraculous prosperity or civil war. In 1993 our reviewer, Serge Schmemann, said the work is like "a sophisticated board game, challenging the reader." Two books about the dark side of the Soviet past have also been reissued. THE UNQUIET GHOST: Russians Remember Stalin, by Adam Hochschild (Penguin, $12.95), features interviews with both perpetrators and victims of the dictator's repression, as well as their descendants. The result is "a perceptive, intelligent book demonstrating that the significance of the gulag transcends the confines of one country and one generation," Paul Goldberg said here last year. STALIN AGAINST THE JEWS, by Arkady Vaksberg, translated by Antonina W. Bouis (Vintage, $13), discusses the regime's murderous anti-Semitism, which was disguised by giving Jews empty appointments and meaningless awards. Last year one critic said it "draws much important new information to the surface."
THE GRANDMOTHERS' CLUB
By Alan Cheuse. Southern Methodist University, $10.95.
Ordinary life proceeds in extraordinary ways in this novel, which concerns a group of elderly women who discuss the fates of the generations they've spawned. At its center are Minnie Bloch and her son, Manny, a rabbi. It is "a bitter, brilliant series of songs, heartless and tender," Jerome Charyn said here in 1986.
ON LOOKING INTO THE ABYSS: Untimely Thoughts on Culture and Society
By Gertrude Himmelfarb. Vintage, $12.
Post-modern academia is under attack in these seven essays, which underscore the dangers of espousing "value-free principles" and regarding morality as a variable to be manipulated. Last year our reviewer, Michael Howard, said, "They are unashamedly and enjoyably bellicose, and their succinct form makes them all the more effective." Miss Himmelfarb's 1968 collection, VICTORIAN MINDS (Ivan R. Dee, $16.95), has also been restored to print. In this intellectual history she analyzes the philosophies of thinkers ranging from Edmund Burke to John Buchan. "She is always sharp, and often original," John Clive said here.
THE FLIGHT OF PETER FROMM
By Martin Gardner. Prometheus, $15.95.
Is religious belief justified, and if so, what kind? These are the questions posed by the author, whose main characters, a lapsed Pentecostal divinity student and his skeptical Unitarian teacher, dramatize the possible answers. In 1973 our reviewer, Martin Levin, called the book "a brilliantly illuminating metaphysical novel."
THE PAINTED ALPHABET
By Diana Darling. Graywolf, $12.
Myth and magic blend in this tale of a Balinese peasant who travels into the mountains with his wife and niece, seeking enlightenment through the teachings of a holy man. Based on a traditional Balinese dance drama, the novel "is a vastly entertaining story, told with warmth, humor and wisdom," Edward Hower said here in 1992.
SILK HOPE, NC
By Lawrence Naumoff. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $11.
When two sisters inherit the family farm, their reactions illustrate the different ways of regarding home: as a refuge to preserve or as an encumbrance to flee. Last year our reviewer, Linda Barrett Osborne, found the novel "irresistible . . . a love note to the American past."
DEADLINE
By Gerry Boyle. Berkley, $4.99.
A burned-out newsman leaves New York City for Maine, where he is to edit a small mill town's weekly paper. Instead of peace, he finds murder and corruption. This is "a bone-cracking first novel" that "strongly conveys that stark terror of isolation," Marilyn Stasio said here in 1993. LAUREL GRAEBER
