LENGTH: 7015 words

HEADLINE: HOUSES AS ART;
The Masterpieces They Call Home

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger, chief cultural correspondent for The New York Times, won a Pulitzer Prize for his architectural criticism.

 BODY:
WHEN I FIRST SAW the model in the architect's ffice, long before construction began, it struck me as a case of overbearing architectural hubris. The arrogance of it all -- those huge logs, fastened together with steel, serving as columns to support this vast gable confronting the snow-capped peaks. Who needed such monumentality? Weren't the mountains monumental enough? What kind of people would build such a house?
Then I went west to see it. The house, by Cesar Pelli, architect of notable skyscrapers like the World Financial Center in New York but of few private dwellings, turned out to be -- well, surely no modest cottage in the woods (it's 10,000 square feet on 90 acres) but much more than the rich person's extravagance I had feared. 
 It had an aura, a presence, that only true works of architecture possess: it managed, in a way that seemed almost mystical, to be at once powerful and endearing. The house is long and tall, organized around a central spine of columns made of huge logs. The spine functions as a kind of interior street, running down the middle of the structure and reaching up to support a pitched roof. The rooms of the house are placed on both sides of this central spine, which also contains the stair and balconies overlooking the double-height living room. The rest of the exterior is formed by more log columns, with panels of wood and glass set in between them.
The design merges worlds that by all normal measure have nothing to do with each other: the sleekness of modernism married to the embracing warmth of a log cabin. And for all the hugeness and luxury (the house cost several million dollars), in the end it celebrates the land far more than it defies it. This house possesses human warmth but also the essential quality of all art, which is the ability to make us see the world in a slightly different way. I thought of Frank Lloyd Wright; I thought of Wright's Arkansas follower, E. Fay Jones; but I thought most of all of Cesar Pelli and how he had designed something that is not like any building I had seen before.
The experience of visiting this house gave me pause. It reminded me of the first rule of architecture criticism -- that nothing ever matters except the real building. More, the visit underscored the extent to which -- for all that has happened in architecture, for all that has happened in the economy, for all that has happened in the evolution of cities -- the design of the single-family, private house remains an architectural touchstone. Houses are still what many architects want most to build, even though they take more time, cause more stress and earn lower fees than most commercial projects. They are utterly irrelevant socially. Yet they are architecture's laboratory. The creation of a serious, ambitious house -- a house that will serve not merely as a sign of wealth but also as a sign of cultivation -- has an allure to certain clients like no other way of spending money.
Houses may be the last form of private artistic patronage. Few of the rich commission paintings or sculpture any longer, or support the writing and performance of music, and when these things do occur in our time, they tend to be public events, not private ones. But at the end of the 20th century, a house can be what a piece of chamber music was in the 18th century: a work of art commissioned for the owner and his friends alone. When a person of means orders a house from a serious architect, it is pure patronage, not philanthropy. It does no good for anyone except the owner and the architect.
In an age when most of the arts have become relentlessly democratic, the commissioning of an architecturally ambitious house is a statement of private connoisseurship. No one will see it unless the owner wants them to; in some instances, no one will even know that it exists, since far from seeing their act of patronage as a means to fame, a great many of the builders of patronage houses avoid publicity like the plague. The owners of the Pelli house in the mountains hesitated for a year before allowing pictures of it to be published here, and when they finally said yes, they insisted that their names not be used, even though they are as proud of the house as if they had designed it themselves.
Important houses, no matter how private, do have a way of coming to light, first in design magazines and then in the architectural history books, where they influence other architects and shape the developing taste of architectural students. Architectural fashions shift slowly. But patronage houses can change them profoundly: there is no question that the architecture of our time would be different if, say, Robert Venturi had never designed his 1962 house for his mother or Charles Gwathmey had not designed his 1966 house for his parents, both celebrated masterworks of patronage in our age. (See "Be They Never So Humble," page 60).
Of course, the Gwathmey and Venturi houses were built for patrons who, like the architects themselves, had more zeal (in their case, parental zeal) than money. Most of today's patrons are different: they are rich and also anxious about how their houses will play in the outside world, particularly in the supposedly pared-down 90's. A patronage house may be important enough to find its way into architectural history, but it is an outrageous thing to spend your money on -- millions of dollars and countless hours struggling with an architect to get a roof over your head and, moreover, a roof that doesn't look like anyone else's, so that it will likely be all the harder to sell someday. (Try selling a Frank Gehry house. Gehry tried to sell his own celebrated house in Santa Monica, Calif., a remake of a Dutch colonial house that looks as if it had been partly deconstructed, and after two years and no nibbles he gave up and stayed there.)
And yet. Virtually all of the patrons I spoke to seem driven by the determination to embark on a creative act. It is not only because they see what passes for elegance and grandeur in the standard upscale American house -- those garish, 20,000-square-foot imitation Taras -- as vulgar and boring. They see their patronage as a kind of mad adventure. All of them, from the clients who have had a lifelong interest in architecture to the clients who came into it barely having heard of Frank Lloyd Wright, seem to embark on the process in search of some connection to the making of art.
Surely that is why Frank Gehry, the soft-spoken California architect whose work is now in such demand, has had so little luck in persuading his most extravagant house client, a Cleveland insurance company owner named Peter Lewis, to cut back on the house he is designing for him -- a house that is now estimated to cost some $30 million. (Architects generally negotiate their fees as a percentage of a project's construction cost, and there is quite a range: from a low of 10 percent to a high of 25 percent. Usually, the more complex the project, the higher the percentage, with 15 to 20 percent the most common.)
"I'm a do-gooder Jewish liberal to the core, and it's hard for me to think I'm solving any problems doing a rich guy's house," Gehry says. "I said to him, 'Why don't you just build a little $5 million house and give the rest to charity?' Do you know what he said to me? He said: 'Look, I'm going to give lots to charity -- this is only a small part of my wealth -- and can't I have this one indulgence in my life? It may be a folly, but I would like to be identified with this kind of effort.' "
 ONCE -- AS RECENTLY AS 30 or 40 years ago -- it cost a hefty but not an insane amount of money to commission an architect to design a house, and often the most important houses, the ones that pushed ahead the art of architecture, were modest ones, houses designed for people who had more artistic daring than cash. Some of Frank Lloyd Wright's most important clients were schoolteachers and journalists and academics who came to him with bags of cash representing their life savings and they got wonderful, if small, houses, just like Charles Gwathmey's parents.
But if Gwathmey's parents, an artist and a photographer, came now to Amagansett, L.I., where their house was completed in 1966, they would probably be laughed out of town by the first real-estate agent who heard their budget ($35,000, the equivalent of $165,000 today). It costs so much to build even the smallest custom-designed house that there aren't very many small custom-designed houses being built, period. Hiring an architect to create something special has become almost exclusively a sport of the rich.
The people who do embark on this mad indulgence seem to fall into three general categories: the patrons who are motivated by pure belief, for whom the house is a chance to prove the glory of architecture; the patrons motivated by hubris, for whom the house is a trophy, a chance to prove their own stature, and the patrons motivated by the collecting instinct, for whom the house is another way of indulging in a larger process of acquiring art. These, at least, are the conscious patrons. But there is also, I think, a fourth kind of patron, the accidental patron, the client who does not intentionally start out on the mission of building a serious house but who finds a talented architect, establishes a comfortable relationship with him and, in the process of fulfilling the basic needs of a house, ends up transcending them and creating a great work.
DEEDIE ROSE, A DALLAS art collector and president of the Dallas Museum of Art, might well be the Platonic version of the architecture-believing patron. A longtime lover of great buildings, she set out from the beginning to produce a house that would not only shelter her family but would communicate to them and to her friends her enthusiasms and even, she hoped, in some way advance the art of architecture. Rose began by hiring Lawrence Speck, dean of the University of Texas School of Architecture, not to design the house himself but to put together a list of important architects around the country and advise her on how to choose among them. She then embarked on a national tour to meet these architects and see their work. The process -- which Rose called "more fun than anything I've done in my life" -- took three months. It finally brought Rose and her husband together with Antoine Predock, an Albuquerque-based architect who designed a sprawling, crisply geometric structure of concrete, glass and steel that has gotten Dallas talking more than any piece of architecture since I. M. Pei's Symphony Center.
Like all of Predock's work, the Rose house is a striking abstraction, at once sleek, sensuous and minimal. The front of the Rose house is a series of terraced limestone planes, planted with local flora; the entry tunnels through this mass of masonry. This is not a design that makes any pretense of relating to its neighbors; indeed, on a street of banal suburban houses its blunt geometries hit you like a ton of, well, limestone. Once through the door, however, the house breaks wide open and creates its own universe: the interior is a set of bright, sharply angled spaces, with huge walls of glass facing a stunning site overlooking Turtle Creek. The climax is the "skyramp": a black steel bridge extending out 60 feet from the cylindrical dining room and rising 35 feet up into the trees. It is a platform intended to give Rose's husband, who is an avid bird watcher, a place to pursue his hobby. But since it literally slices into the sky, it has become a kind of exclamation point for the entire house, an exuberant burst that counters the sharp forms and concrete walls of the interior spaces.
Rose's earnestness led her, at first, to put almost too much trust in Predock. "We described to him what we wanted from the house -- a sense of mystery, a place that would unfold gradually, architecture that would delight," she says. "But I never told him how I wanted it to look. After all, he is the architect, and he came up with something that never in 1,000 years could I have dreamed up.
"Then, about halfway through, we thought we were done and I realized I couldn't do a furniture arrangement in the living room. I called him up and said: 'Antoine, how could you put a sofa in the living room? Where can I hang a painting?' It made me realize I hadn't taken the responsibility I should have as a good client, because he couldn't see inside my mind and I hadn't told him everything I needed. We had a very tense couple of days and had to redo all the construction drawings, but we came back to the same design and made it work."
That Rose saw this problem as her failing and not the architect's may say more about her graciousness as a patron than about the realities of the architectural process. Predock recalls Rose as "very insightful, very impressive -- her patronage extended even to the ecology of the site, to the way the house would use native Texas plants and materials." As to the changes made just before construction started, he admits there were some tense moments but minimizes the conflicts in retrospect and says that despite her last minute crisis of confidence in the design, Rose "never messed around with the main flow of experience in the house."
PETER LEWIS, FRANK Gehry's wealthy Cleveland client, must be the most striking example in the country right now of patron motivated by hubris -- the patron who views his house as a trophy. An intense, wiry, energetic man, he has yet to see one bit of construction on his place. He has spent nearly eight years working with Gehry on design after design for a 35,000-square-foot house that Lewis himself calls "a blatant bid for immortality on my part -- it could be another Fallingwater." (The evolution of Gehry's thinking about the house is shown above.)
"I had never heard of Frank Gehry before I went to a lecture of his, and afterward I called him up and said I just bought a piece of property and do you want to do the greatest house you ever did?" Lewis says.
"He wants to push the limits," Gehry says of Lewis. "He has paid for experiments in technology so that we can use the most advanced materials; he has commissioned Philip Johnson to work along with me doing a guest house; he's brought in Richard Serra, Larry Bell, other artists -- the more we push it, the more excited he seems to get."
The Lewis house, if it gets built according to the current design, is a set of seemingly discordant curving elements, arranged around a central courtyard that can be used for large parties. The various elements are made of different materials -- glass, stone, metal -- and in the plan, they combine to create a sense of swirling form. Much of the success of Gehry's work has always come from his tight juxtapositions of contrasting forms and materials, and it is difficult not to wonder whether expanding it to this huge scale, not to mention this level of grandeur, will diminish the intensity that is so essential to his architecture.
Unlike most trophy patrons, who are wild with impatience, Lewis seems willing to wait for Gehry. Indeed, he seems almost to care about the process as much as the product. And for all his determination to build a house that will put his name in the architecture books, he has not been particularly involved in the esthetics of the design. He has given Gehry nearly carte blanche. And when asked what he likes best about the design, he hesitates, then speaks about how his philosophy in business is to hire good people and give them plenty of room.
"I did say I wanted to build a space where a man and a woman could live together in a perfect arrangement, a place where you could have grand parties, an indoor pool and the greatest bathroom in the world," he says. But the rest was up to Gehry. "I'm interested in artists, in creative people. I've paid Frank whatever he's billed and told him to push the envelope."
VERY DIFFERENT FROM THE trophy patron is the collector patron, who may have some elements of the other types but is not nearly as attached to the house being built for him. Richard Ekstract, a former New York publisher of electronics magazines who is now chairman of the Home Office Association of America, is the collector patron par excellence. Within not much more than a decade, he has renovated one house with Robert A. M. Stern and built one with Alexander Gorlin, and for the last two years, he and his wife have occupied a house by Diana Agrest and Mario Gandelsonas -- which they have now put on the market so that they can commission another architect to build them another house.
"I like creating new things -- I like the process," Ekstract says. "Everyone says to me, Are you crazy? But I would hope that the next house we do would be even more exciting. I guess I'm like those deal makers -- going from one deal to the next."
All of the Ekstract houses are within a few miles of one other in the Hamptons on eastern Long Island, where the chief local crop sometimes seems to be the latest house to come forth from the drawing boards of Gwathmey, Stern, Jaquelin T. Robertson or Richard Meier. Even in this company, the Agrest and Gandelsonas house is a striking presence. A kind of exploded farmhouse, it consists of traditional architectural tropes that say "house" arranged to look like abstract elements. The main rooms are set in a long wing with a low, vaulted roof; projecting from it are several wooden towers containing bedrooms and a glass, silolike form with a study at its base and a master bathroom above. A freestanding wooden gazebo, a kind of tree house without a tree, is perched on the lawn, reached via a bridge from the master bedroom. Beside the pool is a stark stucco wall in the manner of Luis Barragan, but sliced by a pair of wooden sheds containing cabana rooms, a perfect metaphor for the way in which the house attempts to put common imagery into a starkly dramatic new context.
"I said I wanted a traditional country house," Ekstract says, "but Mario waxes very poetic. He can be mesmerizing. You get caught up in the momentwhen he is talking to you and you feel you are making history. I would tell him we needed room for our art. He would say the house should be the art, that everything here should challenge your eye."
But if his needs were not being fulfilled in the house, why did he give in? Should he not have questioned the architects more along the way? "You know, I'm a trustee of the New Museum; I collect art. If I were not respectful of the cutting edge, I'd be a hypocrite," he says.
While Ekstract may recall having been dragged, kicking and screaming, by his architects, they remember differently. "Richard saw a project for another house we did in East Hampton that was never built and said he loved it and wanted us to do something similar for him," Diana Agrest says. "When we were designing the house for him, we kept trying to keep it simpler and he kept wanting more, more, more."
Conflicting versions of history notwithstanding, the Ekstract house is actually more comfortable than its startling form at first suggests. It is logically planned, with a master suite reachable by a private stairs on the other side of the house from the three guest bedrooms. And there is large and comfortable space for both indoor and outdoor entertaining. It was exceptionally difficult to construct, however. The first contractor who worked on the house had serious financial problems and left the job; the house was finally finished by a second builder. The only ventilation in the master bedroom comes from a door to the gazebo, since the windows were finally nailed shut -- this being the only way to stop them from warping and leaking. It is the only one of several patronage houses I visited that had significant post-construction problems -- and the only one in which architect and client ended the process no longer speaking.
"I would ask them to accept responsibility and they would say, 'We're theoreticians, we're intellectuals,' " Ekstract says. "I said to them, If you felt that way, why did you build a real house?"
The architects, not surprisingly, remember it differently. Diana Agrest says: "I don't build a house just to deal with a theoretical issue, never. Actually, Richard was very good as a patron -- it only became difficult at the end, when we started having problems with the contractor."
The Ekstract house has mellowed considerably in the two years since it was finished, as the wooden sections have faded to a natural, weather-beaten gray, the landscaping has grown in and the sharp-edged forms have become less startling. Indeed, the real surprise of this house is how, now that it has lost its power to shock, it retains a power to please.
IF RICHARD EKSTRACT WAS somewhat of an inadvertent patron in his most recent effort, the Laybournes were truly accidental patrons. Geraldine Laybourne, president of Nickelodeon, the children's television network, and her husband, Kit, an independent film producer, hired the Berkeley-based Richard Fernau and Laura Hartman to design their vacation house in Colorado after their misgivings about an earlier scheme by another architect led them to decide not to build it. The intention was to construct a relaxed country house that would encourage a sense of involvement with the land and what resulted was a casual compound of buildings, a kind of gentle, modernist play on a Colorado mining camp that hints at a certain funkiness but is, in fact, as carefully composed as anything by Mies van der Rohe.
Richard Fernau is uncomfortable with the whole notion of patronage and says he likes to think of the Laybournes less as patrons than as collaborators. "The idea of carte blanche, of letting the architect do whatever he wants, is antithetical to the way we work," he says. "I think it is almost pornographic. We do not think of our work as having one meaning that clients get in the way of. We are much more interested in having real involvement with our clients, in having the client become part authors of what we are doing."
The Laybournes, Fernau says, gave him and Hartman only "extremely vague" instructions. The couple had produced a 30-page memorandum for their first architect, and when all that attention to detail didn't yield the house they wanted, they decided to move entirely in the opposite direction -- to architects they could bond with. "We spent a lot of time together getting to know each other," Fernau recalls. "We would go to Colorado and look at old mining areas; we would walk the land; we would have dinner and drink lots of wine."
"Richard actually watched Nickelodeon to try to learn more about me," Geraldine Laybourne says. "He and Laura wanted to figure out our personalities."
The sense of a natural, easy collaboration that arose between the Laybournes and Fernau and Hartman does not in itself guarantee a workable house, of course. Frank Lloyd Wright and Edgar Kaufmann, the great patron who built Fallingwater, perhaps the most important patronage house of the 20th century, liked each other's company and became good friends, but it did not spare Fallingwater from leaks. Gwathmey's de Menil house in East Hampton, a magnificent modernist villa, has an awkwardly proportioned living room and an uncomfortably tight stairs; Pelli's spectacular house in the West has a poorly thought-out relationship between the entry drive and the front door, leading most visitors to come in through the garage.
Nor is this tension between art and livability a new one. The Villa Rotonda by Palladio was not exactly livable and Monticello certainly wasn't, unless you were Thomas Jefferson. Le Corbusier's Villa Savoie is controlling, rigid, absolute in its crisp determination to symbolize the machine age -- but it is profoundly exhilarating. If this is oppression, then this is a house that makes you want to be oppressed. So, too, with the greatest patronage houses of the postwar era. Of course, there is no privacy in Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House or its great sibling, Philip Johnson's Glass House, but there is utter magnificence. And why should the shortcomings of these houses matter to those of us who do not have to sleep in them? (When the Glass House was new, one visitor sniffed that it was all very nice, but she certainly couldn't live there. "I haven't asked you to, Madam," was Philip Johnson's reply.)
ROBERT A. M. STERN, WHO HAS designed some of the grandest and most ambitious houses of the last decade, has made his reputation largely by rejecting the argument that an overwhelming esthetic experience is worth sacrificing the comfort of daily life. To Stern, people who tolerate difficult modernist houses are the architecture world's equivalent of fashion victims, highly cultivated sheep being led into foolishness by huge egos. Stern argues that a talented architect's highest contribution should not be to invent new form but to take traditional elements like space, proportion and detail and produce them more skillfully and organize them more inventively than a builder or a lesser architect might be able to do.
"I think a really good architect has a sense of how spaces unfold visually, how you get people to move through space, how people really live," Stern says. "The house is the one kind of building that is experienced day in and day out by the same people, not like a museum you go to just a handful of times. It is a series of extraordinarily complex specifics that an architect has to put together and end up with something general enough to be understood by a lot of people."
In his insistence that it is part of the goal of the serious house to be comprehensible and readable -- that it be what he calls "in the most profound way sensible" -- Stern is somewhat of a renegade, almost a Luddite. Most leading architects who design houses, if too clever to risk alienating clients by openly discounting comfort, seem almost to feel that acknowledging the search for comfort as a primary goal in design would be akin to admitting a weakness. To Stern, that weakness is a strength. In a sense, his work is not unlike that of the great revivalists of the 1920's, architects like David Adler, Delano & Aldrich and James Gamble Rogers who served the rich not by challenging their beliefs but by giving them the highest quality possible of the tried and true.
While Stern is not completely alone among serious architects of the first rank who design in mainly traditional styles -- there is, for example, Jaquelin T. Robertson, whose shingled manses and historicizing villas rival Stern's and whose client list is at least as well populated with prominent members of the Wall Street aristocracy of the 1980's -- the clear majority of patronage houses being built now are much more modernist in style. The determined architecture victims of today have gone back to modernism. In fact, if patronage houses as a group were to be taken as an index of where American architecture is going, it would be hard not to conclude that the post-modern revolution of the 1980's is more or less over.
There is nothing radical now about going back into history, as there was in the late 1970's and early 1980's when the work of Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown still seemed startling and Philip Johnson and John Burgee could shock the world by proposing a skyscraper like their AT&T building with its Chippendale top. Back then, the art patrons Peter and Sandra Brant, who built a notable Venturi house in 1970 in Greenwich, Conn., could appear to be moving even closer to the cutting edge by commissioning the distinguished classical architect Allan Greenberg to build them a mansion inspired by Mount Vernon, as they did in 1983.
But once the prosperity of the 1980's sent demand for traditional architecture soaring, often more because it looked opulent than because it had a serious message to impart, all connections between traditional architecture and the cutting edge disappeared. It became harder and harder for architects like Stern, Robertson and Greenberg to distinguish their work from that of their lesser competitors who produce traditional houses for the rich without any real intellectual aspirations. Not that their work is the same as the garish Georgian manses and Spanish villas and French chateaus put up by builders; far from it. It's just that the difference between their houses and the grand pretensions of the suburban landscape often comes down to subtleties like better proportions and finer detailing. There isn't a different intellectual concept underlying the serious architect's version of a traditional house; it's just more likely to be done with sophistication, intelligence and restraint.
THAT SAID, IT SHOULD NOT BE surprising that the modernist firm of Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel has emerged as perhaps the apotheosis of patronage architecture: the one to see if you are rich, take architecture seriously and want to commission a house that will be widely recognized as Important. Hiring Gwathmey Siegel involves a commitment not only of vast funds but of a willingness on the part of the client to accept Gwathmey and Siegel's design style and process of working. If you hire Gwathmey, you want not only his name but also his particular brand of modernism, influenced by the modernist master Le Corbusier but in some ways even more determinedly abstract, more rigidly formalist, more concerned with the interpenetration of spatial volumes than Le Corbusier was. And probably more obsessive in its regard to detail.
"We don't compromise on certain principles of architecture and order," Robert Siegel says, "but those principles can be adjusted and tuned to an endless variety to respond to a client's needs."
In other words, a Gwathmey Siegel house looks like a Gwathmey Siegel house. But not all Gwathmey Siegel houses look exactly alike. A client's site, his budget and his program -- how many bedrooms, how much entertaining space, the need for such things as a home office or gym or screening room or playroom -- obviously play a role in determining the final form. But these things must be fit into Gwathmey and Siegel's continuing quest to explore the nature of architectural space.
"A house is the architectural problem in microcosm," says Gwathmey, who adds that clients come to him and his partner because "they endorse the idea of making a house a work of art, of being part of the process of making the history of architecture."
Modesty is not a virtue often found in the architects of patronage houses. Gwathmey is celebrated both for his stubbornness with clients who he feels are unsympathetic to his ideas and for his patience with clients who are. "Charles is a remarkable teacher," Siegel says. "He can spend endless time to make a person comfortable -- if he feels that person is responsive."
And if he doesn't? Woe to the client. Gwathmey, who may be architecture's most perplexing combination of hotheadedness and gentleness, has been known to explode at clients, to write them angry letters and to resist to the end unwanted changes in his designs. But his passions have earned the loyalty of a remarkable array of powerful people like David Geffen, Steven Spielberg (who is now on his fifth Gwathmey project, an apartment renovation in New York) and Ronald Lauder, to mention just a few. Gwathmey clients, as a rule, are not easily intimidated. They relish the give and take that working with Charles Gwathmey entails. There is an allure to Gwathmey, particularly in the entertainment business, where for many clients he is the man you have to get into the ring with to prove that you're big time.
One Gwathmey client in the movie business, who insisted that his name not be used, recalls the period when his house was being designed as exhilarating. "We really did collaborate," he says, "but it worked because of my background, which is to deal with creative people every day. Their value is their vision, yet it needs to be guided into practicality. A house is not a monument -- people have to go to the bathroom. We were always saying things like 'No, you can't have stone on the floor there; it's too cold or too noisy.' But I wanted a Charles Gwathmey house, not a house by me, and so every time I said no to something, I was smart enough to leave it up to him to find a substitute. By the end, all the ideas in the house were still his, not mine."
WHOEVER THE CLIENT AND whatever the relationship, the house is the arena in which an architect can express his ideas most easily. Architects who routinely design skyscrapers and museums crave the chance to do houses if only because there is no purer testing ground for architectural issues. When the family that built the large Pelli house out West first approached Pelli, it was in the hope that he would provide a referral to another architect, since the husband had met Pelli on one of his skyscraper projects and respected his judgment. Pelli, a suave Argentinian-born architect who could be played by the actor Ricardo Montalban, said he would like to do the job himself: that after dozens of huge commercial buildings, he wanted to design a house.
William Pedersen, the chief design partner in the firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox, has done the same thing. In two recent houses, one in Vermont and another on Shelter Island, L.I., Pedersen, whose practice consists mostly of high-rise and institutional buildings, was desperately eager to break out of corporate work and spread his wings as a designer. In a sense the two houses are almost a form of validation for Pedersen, whose commercial work, for all its strength, offers far less leeway for expression. He may have designed dozens of skyscrapers, but he needed those houses to gain a certain kind of credibility as an architect.
It is a paradox: an architect who designs only houses is viewed as too small-time and inexperienced to take on major public buildings; yet an architect who designs no houses at all is viewed as lacking a certain esthetic legitimacy. Early in an architect's career, he or she often gets nothing but houses to design, so they are the places in which a style is created and refined; the houses done later in a career prove that an architect can still dance a deft solo and still has creative juices flowing.
WHILE ARCHITECTS like Robert Venturi and Michael Graves continue to produce occasional houses that quite brilliantly reinterpret traditional form in a newer, more challenging way, most of the houses that seem to be pushing the art forward deal in one way or another with issues of abstraction. It may be the Gwathmey Siegel search for a pure, abstracted kind of space, coolly divorced from direct connections to culture. It may be the Japanese architect Tadao Ando's sensuous forms in concrete, even sparer than Gwathmey Siegel's. It may be Richard Meier's exceptionally elegant compositions, pristine objects intended to prove that abstraction can, in its way, be shimmeringly beautiful (a new Meier house now rising in Texas summarizes 30 years of this quest with exceptional grace). Or it may be the approach of a younger generation of architects, influenced both by Frank Gehry and the Deconstructivists of the late 1980's, who seem to want to celebrate blunt structure, hard-edged materials and juxtapositions of angular form and space. To these architects, the celebration of conventional "house-ness" in the manner of a Stern design is mere sentimentality, barely a step above Disneyland.
There is plenty of romanticism to these neo-modernists, of course, though few are naive enough to take on the utopian dreams of the early modern architects who inspire them. The modernism of today is far less innocent: it has no intention of changing the world, and the sensibility of its architects has been shaped not only by their modernist forefathers but by their post-modern parents. Today's modernism rejects both the pieties of modernism's rejection of history and the pieties of post-modernism's insistence on returning to history.
There are some younger architects, like Eric Owen Moss of Los Angeles, who take it all one step further. They believe it is the responsibility of serious architecture to question values and that the most valid way for a house to become memorable is for it to challenge its occupants. Moss sees his aggressive and powerful compositions, with their sharp forms and odd angles, as a way of deliberately upsetting the visual, and ultimately the psychological, status quo of their owners. As a bleak novel or a film noir can inspire profound, if disturbing, thoughts about the human condition, so Moss wants his houses to shake their occupants out of complacency. He is interested neither in the purely formal search of Gwathmey and Siegel nor in the feel-good architecture of Stern, both of which, in the end, aspire to present to the world a kind of order, a sense of certainty. In its very disorder, Moss wants his architecture to carry a message about uncertainty -- even about the discordance and anguish of human society.
Is that a lot to cope with? Obviously. But the owners of patronage houses want more than mere shelter, as the patrons who commissioned Bach concertos wanted more than background music. Patronage contains more than an element of ego and even -- let's come right out and say it -- narcissism. Patrons want to create something that will last beyond them.
And sometimes it does, as in the case of the handful of houses -- Fallingwater, the Villa Savoie, the Glass House -- that have become 20th-century icons as powerful as Picasso's "Demoiselles d'Avignon" or Stravinsky's "Sacre du Printemps." Most patronage houses do not become cultural artifacts, of course; they are still houses, houses whose main purpose is to shelter their owners with a degree of emotional intensity that they could not find elsewhere.
Many of these houses affect the culture in another way, however, which is that they tend to influence other houses: architecture begets more architecture, as architects (and clients) see it and want something like it or something that melds what they see with demands of their own. And no matter how much architects would like it to be thought that their designs spring full-blown from their brows, architecture, all architecture, is inevitably shaped by other architecture.
FRANK ISRAEL IS A LOS Angeles architect who is producing what is perhaps the most important cutting-edge residential work in California, after Frank Gehry. His most recent house, in the Berkeley area, was designed for a client who told him she wanted something different, something that, as she put it to Israel, would enrich her life and the lives of her husband and their children. The client, Sharon Drager, a vascular surgeon, got an angular house of copper and stucco that is tightly composed and beautifully crafted, riding the prow of a hill like a -- well, like a house. The startling thing about this house is that, for all that the architect and client were joined in their belief that it should be different, it is not, in the end, so unusual. It is not a spaceship or an explosion or a piece of sculpture. It is more like an essay on the continuing evolution of modernism, a structure that gracefully melds the sensibility of early modernism with that of today.
The success of the Drager house underscores the extent to which the modern versus post-modern argument may have become irrelevant. A house is a house, and houses are almost invariably about other houses, however much their architects may want us to think that they are completely original creations. This is the real way in which patronage houses have an effect on society: they influence other houses, not literally (nothing is more pointless than a copy of a house designed to be unique) but by letting their ideas seep into new places. For it is impossible to completely reinvent the idea of the house, and few architects, however radical their purely architectural impulses, are foolish enough to try. Whether it is a Stern mansion paying quite literal homage to the Spanish colonial (as in a recent design for a sumptuous mansion outside Houston) or an abstract essay in copper, wood and stucco by a Frank Gehry protege, the underlying architectural theme is still the idea of the house itself, the tension and energy that springs out of the conflict between an architect's notions of form and a family's notions of how it wants to live.
These two things are always somewhat at war, except in houses where either side has abdicated. When the architect abdicates, there is no architecture and that is the end of the story. When the client abdicates, things are rarely much better, since almost invariably an architect's best work comes out of a strong, sometimes even painful, dialogue between client and architect. If the client who can only say no is impossible to contend with, the client who can only say yes is not really any better. The client who loves architecture so much he leaves his architect alone may not be serving architecture at all, for the truth of architecture is that its essence comes out of turning mundane, real-world needs into art. When those needs are thrown to the winds, the dialectic out of which architecture happens no longer exists.
This, in the end, may be the real test of a great patron: not only a love of architecture and an ample bank account but a clear vision to present to an architect. By a vision I do not mean a design scheme but a set of goals and a willingness to hold one's ground when the architect wants to push too far from those goals. If the client holds too firmly, the architect's ideas may be crushed; if he does not hold at all, the ideas lack the connection to the real world that makes a house something more than just a building that could be built anywhere for anyone. Patronage houses are not only challenges from architects. At their best, they are challenges from the patrons.

(pg. 62)(PHOTOGRAPH BY GRANT MUDFORD); Greatness by Design -- The 10 contemporary American houses that matter most to architects:
Gwathmey Siegel
DE MENIL HOUSE, EAST HAMPTON, L.I. (1983)
This moderist villa by the sea was built for Francois de Menil, who was so captivated by being an architectural patron that he gave up a career as a film producer and became an architect himself. It is one of Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel's most self-assured houses, marrying the crispness of their earlier work to the formal, monumental grandeur of a traditional mansion. (Norman McGrath)
 
Walter Chatham
CHATHAM HOUSE, SEASIDE, FLA. (1988)
Chatham built this two-part house for his family, and it immediately caused an uproar: Seaside is one of the nation's most carefully planned neotraditional communities, and Chatham's crisp structure struck many as an attempt to sneak moderism past Seaside's gingerbread guardians. It was, but Chatham broke none of Seaside's strict design guidelines, deftly proving that you can reinvent traditional architectural form if you know what you are doing. (Michael Moran)
 
Frank Gehry
SCHNABEL HOUSE, LOS ANGELES (1989)
"I always wanted to take an 80-by-100-foot lot and create a village," is how Gehry explains the genesis of this house, built in the Brentwood section for Marna and Rockwell Schnable. The basic idea here: each room is a separate pavilion with a different geometric shape, and together the pavilions make a sculptural and architectural whole. (Grant Mudford)
 
Simon Ungers and Tom Kinslow
T HOUSE, WILTON, N.Y. (1992)
This house, named for its shape, directly expresses the aspirations of its owner, Lawrence Marcelle. The dominant form of the structure is a two-story-high, 44-foot-long library, cantilevered over a lower wing that contains a living room, kitchen and bedroom. The message: a rigorous symbolic order in which the functions of daily life support and elevate the higher pursuits. (Eduard Hueber/Arch Photo)
 
Josh Schweitzer
MONUMENT HOUSE, JOSHUA TREE, CALIF. (1990)
Architecture for the desert, in living color. Schweitzer and two friends built this house for their own use. The interiors are simple and matter-of-fact; it is the stucco exterior, three boxes with trapezoidal cutouts for windows and an entry porch, that gives this small place its combination of starkness, playfulness and monumentality -- and its remarkable ability to stand powerfully against the desert landscape. (Tom Bonner)
 
W. G. Clark and Charles Menefee
REID HOUSE, JOHNS ISLAND, S.C. (1987)
Clark and Menefee merged influences as diverse as farm sheds and Palladian villas to create this very modern whole. It's a structure that manages at once to be monumental and intimate. Here, traditional form is brilliantly reinterpreted, as in the 14-foot windows opening onto a two-story living space. (Mick Hales)
 
Charles W. Moore
MOORE HOUSE, AUSTIN, TEX. (1984)
Moore, who died in 1993, was one of the few architects who designed houses for himself throughout his career; this was his last, a container for his collections of toys, models, books and memorabilia. The living room is a highly complex set of spaces in which every step, every window, every piece of molding plays a role in a larger, tightly scripted drama of architectural pleasure. (Timothy Hursley)
 
Steven Holl
STRETTO HOUSE, DALLAS (1992)
Several themes are interwoven here: proportions based on the golden section; rhythms based on the connections between the curving roof sections and the concrete-block masses of the house itself, and, most important, the way the house's form echoes the site, marked by three spring-fed pools and cascades. (Paul Warchol)
 
Richard Meier
GROTTA HOUSE, HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J. (1989)
Meier's pristine, elegant houses have been a stunning presence for a generation, and while Meier's basic stance is unchanged, he continues to refine, refine, refine. It's all in the sureness of composition as shown here: a half-cylinder plays off beautifully against the structure's straight lines and solid masses. Modernism not at the cutting edge, but with the lightness and nimbleness of a dancer. (Scott Frances/Esto)
 
Frank Isreal
GOLDBERG--BEAN HOUSE, HOLLYWOOD (1992)
An exuberant play on the style of the 1950's, this is one of the most sensuous of patron houses. It's a place in which the love of color, shape and texture is brilliantly joined to the discipline and rigor normally associated with more somber, late-moderist enterprises. (Grant Mudford);

SECTION: Section 2; Page 38; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
What of Cities If the Blueprint Is Republican?

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
IS ARCHITECTURE LIKELY TO BE affected by the Republican agenda? How can it not be? Architecture is a social art. To a more or less conspicuous degree, every building bears the imprint of the social contract. And last November's elections expressed a national desire to renegotiate the terms of that contract. Sooner or later, that desire will express itself in built form. If things go according to the Contract With America, architects can at least look forward to a brisk trade designing prisons.
A correctional facility may not be every architect's idea of a dream commission, but it could stand as a good symbol for the grim mood in which much of the profession now finds itself. Thus far, the 90's have not been golden years for architecture. Many architects were thrown out of work by the recession and remain underemployed, at least by standards of the 1980's. Some feel cut adrift by the absence of a unifying ideology or style. Others are feeling displaced by the exaggerated claims for cyberspace and virtual reality: will buildings be reduced to mere pit stops on the information highway? Above all, perhaps, many feel let down by the Clinton Administration and its failure to bring architects together behind a compelling urban vision. 
 Two years ago, there was considerable hope that a new administration would help restore a sense of idealism to a profession that had lost its ethical bearings in the building boom of the 1980's. Clinton was the first baby-boom President, the first post-cold-war President and the first President elected since the population has become predominantly suburban. And he campaigned on the theme of change. It was natural to hope that his Administration would help to formulate a new vision of urban America.
Many thrilled to the prospect that the 1990's might conform to Arthur Schlesinger Jr.'s theory about the 30-year cycle in American liberalism. The 1930's and the 1960's were both recalled as periods of great public works, when architects were able to channel their social idealism into housing, transportation and parks and in urban design initiatives that raised the level of these projects. Would the 1990's witness a renewal of that tradition?
There were encouraging signs that this hope might be fulfilled. In the past two years, there have been some impressive museum shows dealing with urban issues and countless conferences on the public realm. In trade publications like Progressive Architecture, an emphasis on the social dimension of architecture has displaced the esthetic slant that prevailed in the 1980's. Some architecture schools have revised their curriculums along similar lines.
These efforts, undertaken to boost professional morale, have partly backfired. For one thing, whatever their value in raising the civic consciousness of the profession, the shows, conferences and publications appeared to make little discernible impact on government decision makers. Indeed, they ran counter to a political trend that was evident long before the November elections. While architects were talking up the virtues of the public realm, politicians were warming to the prospect of privatization. This did not increase the likelihood that the 90's would be a legendary decade of public works.
Then, too, it was disconcerting to see that all the attempts at consciousness-raising did not add up to a coherent picture. For instance, "Urban Revisions," an exhibition of recent urban plans at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles last year, offered a view of the city as a contemporary Tower of Babel, a metropolis abuzz with the competing voices of modernists, post-modernists, neo-traditionalists, deconstructionists, environmentalists and assorted mavericks. Consensus and solidarity were conspicuously absent.
In "Urban Revisions," the colorful display of professional discord presented a strong contrast to the form that idealism took in architecture for much of this century. Coherence, standardization, universal application: these were the hallmarks of the Radiant City proposal drawn up by Le Corbusier in the 1920's. With blocks of nearly identical skyscrapers rising at regular intervals from a lush landscape of green, open space, Le Corbusier's vision of the modern city was taken up as a model by a generation of architects and planners. But to a later generation, the Corbusian model did not look so idealistic. Instead, it came to symbolize the determination by architects to recast the city in their narcissistic self-image. In 1961, following the publication of Jane Jacobs's seminal book "Death and Life of Great American Cities," many architects began to reject uniformity and standardization in favor of diversity and complexity.
If "Urban Revisions" made one thing clear, it was that these values still prevail. Architects remain phobic about master planning. Heterogeneity remains the paramount urban virtue. But what would a government decision maker have made of this well-intentioned, sprawling mess? What kind of vision emerged from all these disparate urban revisions? Or, to put it another way, how can architects come up with a comprehensive vision so long as the idea of comprehensiveness remains in disrepute? While complexity may be an urban virtue, solidarity may have its uses after all.
In other words, the current malaise in the architectural profession stems from something more than disappointment with the Clinton Administration. It also arises from the profession's dawning awareness that it is time to rethink some of the assumptions that have guided its thinking on urban issues for the past 30 years. Architecture had "devolved" long before the Republicans proposed scaling down Federal programs. But the November elections have thrown the crisis of architecture's devolution into sharp relief. While progressive architects may have grasped the value of complexity, politicians are under no compulsion to follow suit. If voters are willing to spring for easy answers, who are politicians to resist the popular will? Why not build more prisons? Who doesn't want safe streets?
ARCHITECTS WHO HAD THEIR hearts set on the renewal of public works must feel a twinge of envy as they scan the Contract With America, particularly the section on the proposed Taking Back Our Streets Act, with its rousing call to build more jails. Why weren't progressives able to put together an effective agenda for parks, schools, subways, housing, museums, hospitals, recycling plants and airport transit? But the moment one starts to compile such a list, one begins to see the futility of it, at least compared with the elegant simplicity of the Republican contract. There's nothing wrong with the cities that a few more prisons can't cure is one way to read the contract. It's the ultimate easy answer, as stirring, in its way, as Le Corbusier's Radiant City. But how dispiriting it is to compare these two simplistic visions: the utopian dream city of green, open space, and the dystopian nightmare of gates and cells! Has the century of progress been one grand march from hope to fear?

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Haiti Makes Effort To Revive Tourism

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
HOPING to overcome nearly a decade of neglect and the impact of three years of political turmoil and economic sanctions, Haiti's recently restored democratic government has begun an effort to revive tourism in a nation that has been almost entirely bypassed by the Caribbean vacation trade. President Jean-Bertrand Aristide has appointed a cabinet-level Secretary of State for Tourism, and the country has initiated contacts with leading international cruise lines, hotel chains, tour operators, airlines and trade groups.
The campaign has been undertaken with the full realization that Haiti, the poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere, must improve both its image and its infrastructure if it is to attract foreign visitors. "It is no secret that Haiti is far behind our Caribbean neighbors in development, especially in the tourism area," Maryse Penette, a former diplomat and restaurateur who heads the new tourism secretariat, acknowledged in an interview. "We do not intend to delve into the market of mass tourism, for we realize that would be unrealistic." Nevertheless, she added, the Aristide administration believes that tourism, if developed properly, can become "our No. 1 source of foreign exchange in the future." 
 Maj. Eric Flaxman, a partner in a travel agency in the Philadelphia area who is the American military advisor to Ms. Penette, said that Haiti hoped in the initial phase to persuade visitors to neighboring countries such as Jamaica, Cuba and the Dominican Republic to make short side trips here, and will also focus on cruise ship passengers. Though Haiti has its share of beaches, the Government believes it will have better luck attracting visitors if it emphasizes the country's African-French culture, including colonial architecture, artwork, music and folklore.
A few adventurous souls, European and Japanese students and backpackers for the most part, began turning up almost as soon as American troops landed here last September. But the first sign that mass commercial tourism has returned came on Jan. 23, when Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines once again began calling at Labadee, an isolated peninsula on Haiti's northern coast. Royal Caribbean suspended visits there after Mr. Aristide was overthrown by a military coup on Sept. 30, 1991; economic sanctions imposed by the Organization of American States and the United Nations then put an end to what was left of the tourism industry.
"Labadee was always an extremely popular port with our passengers and crew because of its natural beauty and the wide variety of activities available there," said Jim Lida, a spokesman for the Miami-based cruise line. "President Aristide and his officials have made a concerted effort to re attract tourism since he was restored to office, and since we had an established record in Haiti, we thought it was now appropriate to return." Under current plans, two 2,500-passenger ships will call each week at the secluded anchorage.
After the return of Mr. Aristide last October, all the foreign airlines that traditionally served Haiti also resumed service to Port-au-Prince: American Airlines from New York and Miami, Air Canada from Montreal and Air France, ALM and Copa from points in the Caribbean. But newcomers are also appearing. Carnival Air Lines began daily service from Miami on Jan. 19 with one-way fares as low as $99, and American Eagle is to begin flying from San Juan on April 15.
The most severe bottleneck, officials agree, is the shortage of hotel space. A Club Med with 704 beds, closed since 1986, is expected to reopen in a few months, but the country has just 4,000 beds, of which only 1,200 are classified as international standard. Negotiations are near completion on renovating several large properties abandoned in recent years, but construction of any new hotels will take considerably longer.
What few hotel rooms meet international standards have almost all been snapped up by international organizations that are helping in the rebuilding of the country or by businesses. Such diseases as malaria, dengue and typhoid remain a danger, especially in the countryside, sanitation is precarious and transportation links are tenuous.
"Haiti could be developed into a very good tourist destination," said Reuven Wertheim, chief executive officer of Carnival Air Lines. "It has all the naturals -- fun and sea and nice people, a unique culture. All it needs is the infrastructure."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Handling Financial Troubles

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IT doesn't take much to send a tight household budget into a tailspin. A job loss or temporary layoff, a sudden rise in real estate taxes or an unexpected medical bill can all quickly trigger a cash crunch for those without a safety net.
Add to that list the adjustable-rate mortgage. 
 "In the past year, 55 percent of all new housing loans were adjustable-rate mortgages," said David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington.
Most adjustable-rate mortgages are "re-priced" every year, Mr. Lereah said. Interest rates have surged in the last 12 months. And, he said, such loans are most attractive to "consumers on the margin, those trying really hard to qualify."
"Virtually all of the ARM-holders with one-year ARM's will be repricing with 2-percentage-point increases," he said. "That can mean a significant increase in monthly payments. Mortgage delinquency rates will be on the rise."
What can a homeowner do when the mortgage is due and there isn't enough in the bank to cover it?
"Almost every type of debt is negotiable in one way or another," said William Joyce, a Westchester lawyer who specializes in averting foreclosures and bankruptcies. "There are all kinds of deals out there."
One of the most important things to do when trouble arises, Mr. Joyce said, is to be up-front with the bank or mortgage company. "The worst thing you can do is bury your head in the sand and allow things to get out of control," he said.
Donald L. Shapiro, president of the New York Federal Savings Bank in Manhattan, agreed. "Come in, sit down and explain what the problem is," Mr. Shapiro said. "Generally, a bank will want to work with people who are open and aboveboard."
Most lenders, he said, prefer to avoid foreclosure proceedings and will usually find some way to help a homeowner who can come up with a workable plan to surmount a financial difficulty. "Banks don't want other people's houses," Mr. Shapiro said.
Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates, a financial publishing company based in Butler, N.J., said that in some cases a lender will defer part of the mortgage payment for a few months so that the borrower can get back on track.
If the financial crisis is only temporary, he said, there are other possible solutions.
"If you have any equity in your home you might be able to tap into an equity line and draw funds to pay the bills, at least until you have improvement in your circumstances," Mr. Gumbinger said. "But remember, you're really borrowing from yourself. This is not a permanent solution."
Another possibility, Mr. Gumbinger said, particularly for those who have adjustable-rate mortgages with increasing interest rates, is to take out a new adjustable-rate loan. "You can always find an adjustable with a lower rate," he said. "And there are ways to roll in the closing costs."
The disadvantage of frequent refinancing, however, is that the term of the mortgage begins all over again. "You can do it every year," he said. "But you're never going to own your home that way."
For owners of condominiums and co-ops there are maintenance charges to contend with in addition to the monthly mortgage payment. If there is not enough money to pay both, which should be paid?
"That's a very difficult call," said Bruce A. Cholst, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law. Mr. Cholst said that most people would probably make the mortgage payment first, thinking that if the mortgage payment is made, the bank cannot foreclose. But nonpayment of maintenance charges in a coop, he said, gives a bank the right to begin foreclosure proceedings even if the mortgage is current.
"First and foremost, communicate with the board," Mr. Cholst said. "Neighbors are more likely to cut you some slack than a bank."
Another course of action for cash-strapped homeowners is to obtain the services of a credit counselor. "If you need help negotiating with your lender, we will act as a go-between," said Lynn Gerrity Ames, director of counseling for the Consumer Credit Counseling Service in Syracuse.
Ms. Ames said that credit counselors are often quite successful at negotiating informal "forbearance" agreements between homeowners and their lenders. The credit counselors, she said, help borrowers "reprioritize" their budgets and present workable payment strategies to their creditors.
"It sounds simplistic, but just scaling back your budget and making different choices can make the difference," Ms. Ames said.
Consumer Credit Counseling Service, a subsidiary of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit in Silver Spring, Md., is a nonprofit organization with 1,100 offices nationwide. Durant Abernethy, president of the foundation, said that about one-third of the offices provide services free of charge. The remainder, he said, offer services at an average of about $9 a month. The location of local offices can be obtained by calling (800) 388-2227.
What happens, though, when negotiations fail and the bank initiates foreclosure proceedings?
The most obvious answer -- and often the least desirable -- is to sell the property to pay off the mortgage. But that isn't always easy, and in some cases the selling price may not cover the outstanding mortgage.
For homeowners with Federal Housing Administration-insured mortgages, however, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development recently instituted a "pre-foreclosure program" designed to minimize the impact of a forced sale on both the seller and the mortgage holder.
Under the program, homeowners whose F.H.A. mortgages are in default can apply to HUD to participate in the program. The program allows the owner to sell the property at market value through a licensed broker, even if the sale price is less than the balance of the outstanding mortgage. "We pay the difference to the lender if there is a shortfall," said John Petricco, the area coordinator for HUD in Albany. Moreover, the owner is not held responsible for the deficiency.
By protecting both the borrower and the lender against a shortfall, Mr. Petricco said, the program encourages an orderly sale of the property and avoids lengthy and expensive foreclosure proceedings.
The pre-foreclosure program is available only to those with F.H.A.-insured mortgages, Mr. Petricco said. But other defaulting borrowers should consider suggesting to a foreclosing lender that the borrower be given time to sell the property at market value, even if the sale generates a shortfall, without any further obligation on the part of the owner.
"I would imagine that if you're a lending institution, and you're about to foreclose on a mortgage, you're going to have to seriously consider it," he said.

HEADLINE: Why Can't SoHo Have Trees?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a SoHo resident for nearly 20 years I'm tired of people who don't live here, like Margot Gayle [Letters, Jan. 8] and the whole Landmarks gang telling us we can't have trees. It shows a small, bureaucratic mind-set. Whether trees existed here 150 years ago is beside the point. SoHo is a living, breathing part of this city. It's not a museum. And its many sightseers, workers and residents deserve the beauty, shade, warmth and, yes, oxygen that trees provide. 
 In the 19th century there were no sodium lights in SoHo, but today they're necessary because they provide an element of safety. In the 19th century, galleries, stores and tourists didn't exist here, but today they all help the city economy. In the 19th century artists didn't live in these factory buildings but we're lucky they did 30 years ago -- because it was they, and not city planners, who saved SoHo. In fact, they saved Soho from urban planners who wanted to raze the buildings and put in a lower Manhattan expressway.
Small minds may be able to live in the past, but cities have to change. And it was SoHo's ability to change -- from obsolete manufacturing to residential use -- that kept it alive. This residential aspect should be strengthened, not stifled.
People are the heart of a city, but it's the trees that are its soul. And it seems outrageous that at the close of the 20th century, there are still those who can't see the value that trees add to the quality of life in this concrete jungle.
Please, let's not go backward into the 21st century.
 
MIKE LICHTMAN
Manhattan

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/White Plains;
Balancing Tranquillity With Tax Benefits

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

 BODY:
SHOPPERS headed for The Westchester, the new luxury mall scheduled to open in White Plains next Friday, will use routes bypassing the city's 13 residential neighborhoods.
That will please the city's nearly 50,000 inhabitants who are as determined to protect the residential tranquillity of their tree-lined streets as they are eager to enjoy the property tax benefits a varied economic base provides. 
 The balancing act is difficult, but the city is intent on combining the best aspects of both environments, preserving gracious neighborhoods while serving as the business, retail and government hub of Westchester County.
"White Plains is a place that is carefully trying to straddle polar opposites of city and countrified suburb," said Mayor Sy J. Schulman. "How do we balance our desire to be a dynamic city while preserving the small-town quality of our neighborhoods? We worry all the time."
Preserving continuity, Mr. Schulman said, requires citizens with a "citywide mentality," which the city has in abundance. Many participate extensively in its activities, often through a network of neighborhood associations.
Others join civic groups, including the 30-year-old Beautification Foundation, which has raised more than $1 million for gardens, small parks, a carillon and barrels of flowers to participating merchants.
The city's recent call for volunteers to develop a new comprehensive plan attracted 400 residents, and Mayor Schulman observed, "The process may be as important as the product.
"Four hundred people is incredible," he said. "That's 1 percent of the city."
The planning groups have plenty to think about. The Westchester, one of four malls within a walk of one another, is needed to help White Plains recoup some of the 18 percent in property taxes it has lost over the last decade as companies including I.B.M., Nynex and AT&T have vacated space while others have won tax abatements.
The million-square-foot mall, anchored by Nordstrom and Neiman Marcus and including Tiffany and F.A.O. Schwarz, will increase the city's retail market to 4 million square feet. City officials say it will eventually generate $3.5 million in property taxes and $5 million in sales taxes annually.
Downtown revitalization, which already includes new sidewalks, trees and lights, has taken on a new urgency with the arrival of the new mall on the edge of the city's business district. Shops and restaurants on Mamaroneck Avenue, the city's main shopping thoroughfare, are already suffering from mall competition and the loss of area office workers.
There are a number of good ethnic restaurants downtown, including The Bengal Tiger, Reka's, Fujinoya and Dawat, but the city has no movie theaters, although the council is considering at least two proposals. A local law banning live entertainment was recently lifted.
IF location is everything, White Plains has it all. Halfway between the Tappan Zee Bridge and Long Island Sound, the city is a commuter's dream, with direct access to three major highways.
Downtown, a public-transportation hub adjacent to the headquarters of the county's bus system includes express trains to Manhattan, just a half hour away by rail. Westchester County Airport is five miles away.
Most of the estimated 200,000 people who commute to White Plains daily are workers headed downtown or to corporate parks ringing the city, students enrolled at Pace University Law School or the Lubin Graduate School for Business, or shoppers.
Originally called Quarropas, or the White Marshes, by the Siwanoy Indians, White Plains has had a rich past. On July 9, 1776, the Declaration of Independence was adopted by the New York Provincial Congress sitting in the courthouse on Broadway. Three and a half months later, a crucial battle was fought in and around the city.
The most recent notable event occurred only 30 years ago. As Renoda Hoffman, a lifelong resident and city historian has observed, "There are few small cities in the nation that have changed so quickly and so radically as White Plains."
In 1964, the city launched a massive central urban renewal project -- now nearly complete -- that has rebuilt a third of the central business district. Involving almost $100 million in Federal and state grants, the effort has transformed the area, tearing down the library Andrew Carnegie financed along with blocks of urban blight. New roads have been built and office superblocks created. Residents were moved and 712 units of subsidized housing were built elsewhere.
Today, the central business district includes the 850,000-square-foot Galleria mall, a modern library, a police headquarters, the transportation center (known as TransCenter), the County Courthouse and several parking garages. A new Federal Courthouse will open by the end of the year.
Strict zoning has allowed little more than a corner deli to operate in most residential neighborhoods, and an $11 million neighborhood revitalization program has helped preserve the quality of residential life surrounding the downtown hub.
Kenneth Wyatt grew up on Battle Hill, a fringe neighborhood where his parents still live. Three months ago, Mr. Wyatt, a wine importer with Remy Martin, decided to move back to White Plains from Manhattan with his wife, Emmy, a human resources consultant, and their son, James Calvin Wyatt 2d, who celebrates his first birthday today.
"I feel good about having him grow up where I grew up," Mr. Wyatt said, referring to the city where he was born. "We got a really good residential value." The family now lives in a four-bedroom colonial in the gracious Soundview neighborhood.
The city needs to pay more attention to its fringe neighborhoods, Mr. Wyatt said. "The value of my real estate is tied directly to the quality of life in other neighborhoods," he said, adding that "my parents are concerned about where they live."
Mr. Wyatt's neighborhood borders Scarsdale where, he said, "our taxes would have been double." A black whose wife is white, Mr. Wyatt said he chose to return to a city where different races live harmoniously and, he added, "I love my commute. I can leave my house at 6:20 A.M., and I'm at my midtown desk with a bagel at 7:20."
Single-family homes make up about 31 percent of the 20,714 housing units in the city, many of them built before 1950. Four- to six-bedroom Tudors, colonials and Victorians can be found less than a mile from downtown, some available for under $400,000.
Small three-bedroom Cape Cods can be bought for $250,000, but they are hard to find.
HOUSES are also moving briskly at several developments of newly constructed luxury housing in the south end of the city, led by Toll Brothers of Huntingdon, Pa., which has revived a number of languishing projects. At Hillair Estates, 4-bedroom homes are being sold with prices starting at $595,000, many to empty-nesters moving from elsewhere in the city, said Nancy D'Arcy of Houlihan/Lawrence. At Ridgeway, 80 semi-detached 3- and 4-bedroom homes are selling for $354,900 to $459,900.
Interest in the city's luxury apartment complexes has also revived after several stood partially empty for several years. At the 244-unit Westage Towers, one-bedroom condominiums start at $118,000, 2-bedrooms at $235,000 and 3-bedrooms at $330,000.
Portions of the 235-acre New York Hospital-Cornell Medical site are likely to be developed despite the protests of nearby residents.
Both the middle and high school have been named Schools of Excellence, a Federal designation based on the quality of curriculum, students and teachers. Two years ago, the district was rated among the top 10 in the nation by Expansion Management Magazine for families involved in corporate relocation.
Of the 330 members in last year's graduating class at White Plains High School, 88 percent went on to higher education. There were three national Merit Scholarship winners and 31 finalists and commended students. The boys basketball team won the New York State championship.
The district is participating in two significant national educational reform efforts -- calling for higher student performance standards and helping younger students become more responsible -- and an elementary school program to encourage parent participation in the schools while insuring racial balance has won national attention.
Parents of incoming kindergarten children are invited to select from five elementary schools, each offering a distinct academic emphasis. The Parent Choice program has been so successful, said Dr. Saul Yanovsky, the superintendent, that 90 percent get their first choice, and most others get their second choice. Last year, in a district that includes a 52 percent minority enrollment, 40 percent of incoming parents chose a school that was not in their neighborhood.
The city provides 200 acres of outdoor recreational space, two outdoor swimming pools, 28 tennis courts, 17 baseball and softball diamonds and the Ebersole Skating Rink with its attached warming house.
County parkland in the area includes the Bronx River Parkway Reservation, with hiking and bicycle trails, Silver Lake Park and the 18-hole Maplemoor Golf Course. There are also two private golf clubs, Ridgeway and Westchester Hills.

 HOLIDAY MISCREANTS: The city's Fourth of July celebration is an annual tradition, featuring a big parade, community picnic and fireworks display. But one 19th century celebration nearly ended the fun. On the eve of the holiday, an unusual amount of attention surrounded a Revolutionary War cannon on the Broadway Commons. Shortly before midnight, the cannon, filled with blasting powder and newspapers, exploded. Windows were blown out for blocks around and pieces of the cannon landed all over the city, one 21-pound chunk tearing through a barn a quarter of a mile away. The perpetrators were never caught.
