HEADLINE: Reconstructing a Spanish Ghost Ship and a Tale of Slavery

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
WELL into the last century, piracy was still a matter of great concern, and several sightings of a mystery ship off the Atlantic coast in the summer of 1839 both fascinated and bothered sailors and newspaper readers alike.
The ship, described as a "long, low, black schooner," would be seen and then disappear, only to reappear a bit further north. It was like a ghost ship, zigzagging aimlessly and seemingly lost. Then, in late August, the mystery ended when the ship was confiscated off Montauk Point by a naval brig doing surveys in the area. 
 Her name was the Amistad and she had a number of black people on board, including a few children, who had been captured in Africa, taken to Cuba, sold into slavery and put on the Spanish schooner to go around the island from Havana to a sugar plantation in Principe.
They rebelled, taking over the Amistad and in the process killing the ship's captain and cook while losing several of their own number. The slaves -- led by a young man called Cinque -- then attempted to return to Africa by forcing the two men who had bought them to steer the ship in an easterly direction. But at night the slaveowners would change direction, to the northwest, hoping to land at a port in the United States where they could arrange for the slaves to be imprisoned and punished
After the ship was confiscated at the entrance to Long Island Sound, it was towed to New London and the slaves were taken to the New Haven jail, charged with piracy and murder. In jail, they became instant celebrities. More than 5,000 people paid 12 1/2 cents each to see them exercising on the nearby town green. Life masks of each were made by a wax museum entrepreneur. A local artist painted a portrait of Cinque.
More importantly, the prisoners became a rallying cause for abolitionists. Their incarceration was followed by a series of court actions, in Hartford, New Haven and finally in Washington, D.C.
The fate of the Amistad slaves was finally decided after former President John Quincy Adams, old and tired, made a dramatic appearance before the United States Supreme Court to plead their case. The High Court ruled that a decision by the district court in New Haven was correct: the Amistad passengers had been illegally pressed into slavery, which, although it was widespread in Cuba, was technically illegal there.
Three years after they had been captured in Africa, 35 of the original group of 53 slaves were returned to their native land, Sierra Leone, as free people. The other 18 had died in captivity or during the takeover of the Amistad.
Records concerning the Amistad slaves -- court papers, newspaper stories of the time, a book that appeared shortly after they were imprisoned in New Haven, detailed descriptions of each of them, the portrait of Cinque -- have documented the Amistad story thoroughly, except in one major respect: the Amistad itself.
What was the ship really like? Where had it been built? How long was it? How wide? What eventually happened to it? In many ways, after a century and a half, the Amistad is still a mystery ship.
Questions about the ship have become important this year, particularly to Quentin T. Snediker because he is in charge of building a new Amistad. He calls it a "reconstruction" for which he has no blueprints.
Last October, the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society received a $2.5 million grant from the Connecticut's Department of Economic Development to build a reproduction of the Amistad to be used as a floating museum, as a reminder of the horrors of slavery. The society turned to Mystic Seaport, the internationally known maritime museum, and Mystic turned to Mr. Snediker. The 44-year-old white-bearded Mr. Snediker looks like a ship captain in the age of sail and indeed he once did fit that role but long after the age of sail. A graduate of the New York Maritime College, he later was responsible for constructing the Mystic Clipper, a 100-ton sailing vessel, and from 1973 to 1981 was the captain of the passenger ship. He has also been in charge of maintaining Mystic Seaport's fleet of vintage sailing ships and most recently had been an official of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in Maryland.
One major difficulty in duplicating the Amistad, Mr. Snediker said, is that there is only one painting of it, now at the New Haven Historical Society, which is unsigned and undated. The painting may be an accurate depiction, but it may have been done long after the ship disappeared, he said. Maritime paintings were numerous during the period but they were mostly of famous clipper ships, or of passenger ships between cities along the East Coast or on its rivers. The Amistad -- the "long, low, black schooner" -- became famous only after its major story was told and it was tied up, covered with barnacles and slowly rotting, at New London.
It is known that in 1841, the ship was bought by a Rhode Island man, John Holland of Newport, for the low price of $250. He renamed her Ian, took her to Newport, and resold her. She was sailed to the French island of Guadalupe in the Caribbean, and there the trail turns cold.
For the last few months Mr. Snediker said, he has been checking the National Archives in Washington, D.C., and several other sources for any information he can obtain on the Amistad. When the checking is completed in the next few months, he said, he will start drawing up plans for construction of the ship.
Mr. Snediker has no doubt that he can obtain enough specific information to produce a nearly exact duplicate of the ship. "We will never know whether a nail went here, or over there, but it will be a good reconstruction," he said, adding that ships have a habit of leaving extensive paper trails to work with.
"There have always been very tight regulations on ships, because of revenues they bring in and politics of the times. So documents do exist here and there," Mr. Snediker said.
Information on the size of the Amistad, for instance, was available at the old United States Customs House in New London, now a museum. The legal document of the ship's sale to John Holland, registered there on June 4, 1841, gives dimensions of the ship, starting with her length of 64 feet. Descriptions of her cargo, other than slaves, are in old newspaper accounts.
A major misconception about the Amistad and one that has continued to be perpetuated in newspaper stories, Mr. Snediker said, is that she was a slave ship.
Rather, he said, she was a coastal schooner. "They were the tractor-trailers of their day," Mr. Snediker added. "They were part of daily life. They carried raw materials, produce, passengers -- and occasionally slaves."
On its fateful slave voyage, the Amistad was also carrying clothing, saddles and bridles, lookingglasses, foods, books and olive oil.
In style, the Amistad was a Baltimore model schooner, Mr. Snediker said, a sleek, fast ship with masts that leaned back developed during the War of 1812 to prey on enemy shipping. She could have been built in Baltimore or at many other locations on the East Coast.
After Mr. Snediker finishes his plans, construction will take about two years, he said, with no fewer than 6 and as many as 12 skilled workers -- carpenters, shipwrights, riggers, caulkers, sailmakers -- busy at any one time.
He does not know whether the work will be done indoors or out at the seaport -- "We're leaning to outdoors under a shelter," he said -- but he and Khalid Lum, president of the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society and director of educational planning and development for Amistad America, the nonprofit organization set up to reproduce the ship, agree they want the construction of the ship to be a very public event.
"We want to do it where lots of kids, and others, can see it and possibly help out," Mr. Snediker said. That is important, he added, because there is a big lesson to be learned from the ship.
"The revolt always fascinated me," he said. "These people suffered horribly, and even though there were only 53 of them, they represented six million Africans. It was a glimpse of the horror of slavery."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Jorden Schiff;
For Principal, 28, Youth Is No Barrier

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AT an age in life when most people are working on the first rung of their career ladders, Jorden Schiff is closing in on the top rung of his.
In January of this year Mr. Schiff, who is 28, became one of the youngest public school principals in the state when he was hired by the High Bridge School District to take over the top job at the 300-student High Bridge Elementary School. 
 Mr. Schiff has been a teacher since 1989 -- the year after he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from Rutgers University in New Brunswick. His first assignment was at the Somerset Hills School, where he instructed emotionally disturbed boys. Later he taught fifth grade in Bridgewater.
In August 1993, Mr. Schiff moved into his first administrative post when he was appointed supervisor of fine arts for elementary schools in the North Brunswick School District. That same year, he was hired as the assistant principal in the Judd School in North Brunswick.
In October 1994, while browsing through the classified advertisements in a local newspaper, Mr. Schiff discovered that the High Bridge School District was looking for a principal. He and about a dozen other candidates applied for the job.
After two interviews with the High Bridge Superintendent of Schools, and then a third call-back before the full school board, the search committee still had not made a decision.
It was only after several members visited the Judd School and talked to students, teachers and Mr. Schiff's supervisor there that their choice became clear.
Mr. Schiff talked recently about his new position.
Q. How did you feel when you first learned that you had just become one of the youngest principals in the state?
A. I was very excited. I felt that all the hard work at graduate school had finally paid off. That was my initial reaction. My next reaction was: "Now I have a real responsibility and a real opportunity to make a difference with kids."
Q. Why do you think the board chose you over the other applicants?
A. Well, I think they were looking for someone who had a background in elementary education, and I think my experience with special education also tilted the decision in my favor.
Q. At 28, aren't you considered quite young for a principal?
A. Yes, and I think it's a shock for most people dealing with me as their administrator. At first blush, people look at me and they pretty much know my age and think, 'Wow, he's young!'
But after spending some time with me and talking about educational issues and how to solve problems and how to make decisions, the age becomes less of an issue. Once they deal with you on that level, it becomes an issue of character, not an issue of age.
Q. So what does a school principal do?
A. There are really a hodge-podge of many different responsibilities. What I do on a daily basis is help provide a warm and caring environment so that the children and the staff and the community feel welcome. I believe that facilitates the learning process.
The principal also bears the responsibility for what goes on in the school in terms of curriculum, instruction, student achievement, staff development, community relations, getting parents involved, and developing opportunities for private industry to come and form a cooperative bond with the school.
Q. What do you believe is the most important issue in elementary education today?
A. I think we need to take a critical look at the way we assess students' performance in the classroom. We need to have a more comprehensive approach, where we balance standardized assessment scores with performance-based assessment and where we look beyond students just reaching a particular standard.
For example, if you have a student who is scoring at the 99th percentile on standardized achievement tests, I still would want that child to grow and meet his or her potential. We want to see everyone move and everyone grow, not just students at the 50th percentile.
Q. What do you think is the basic responsibility of a principal of an elementary school?
A. You have to work from the bottom up. You have to make sure you have the basic needs for all the children satisfied. You need good facilities; before you even worry about anything else, the children have to be safe and they have to be healthy. They have to be in a clean and adequate facility before you even discuss instructional curriculum. It's a fundamental educational issue to address those basic needs.
Q. What do you think might be missing in elementary classrooms today?
A. We have dedicated professionals in schools across the country. We have many, many teachers doing what they believe is right for the kids. What we need, though, is strong leadership. We need people at the principal's level who are able to take the teachers and give them a focus, give them a vision. I think we need quality leaders who know how to deal with people, who know how to problem-solve, and who are willing to take risks.
Q. Isn't that difficult to do when you're the new kid on the block?
A. You can't effect change without upsetting the apple cart. But I'm not someone who's going to come in and tear up the place. I'm a very balanced administrator. I solve problems in a deliberate fashion, I take incremental steps and I don't rush headlong into things. I take a slow and measured approach, and that seems to be working rather well.
Q. What do you bring to the job at 28 years old that makes you unique?
A. I'm about a generation older than the students here, and it hasn't been that long since I was in a classroom myself. I'm closer in age to the children, and there's a different rapport that a younger person can have with the kids. I think I can make contributions that people in the generation that preceded mine didn't even have an opportunity to make.
I was in graduate school when the new ideas for curriculum were being developed. I've had a chance not only to study them in school, but to apply them in the classroom as a teacher. I also think my background in computer technology is going to be a benefit for the school.
Q. In what way?
A. I think we're at the tip of the iceberg with educational technology right now. People are now asking, "How can we use this technology effectively in the classroom as an instructional tool?"
Here at High Bridge, we have a computer lab at the school, and we're using it to enhance our writing program. We have kids in kindergarten in there. We're teaching basic computer skills, word processing, spreadsheets, databases, telecommunications.
Q. Do you miss being a teacher?
A. Very much so. But being a principal in a school like this keeps me close to the classroom and the students. I'm in and out of the classrooms all day long, and even though I'm not directly teaching them, I still feel I'm an integral part of the education process.
Q. What do you think you'll be doing 10 years from now?
A. Ten years there may be some other opportunities, but right now, I'm focusing on being the best principal I can be.
 
Profile
 Born: Dec. 5, 1966, in Sacramento, Calif.
Education: B.S. in economics from Rutgers University, 1988; master's degree in education, Rutgers, 1990; working on doctor of education degree in administration and supervision, Rutgers.
Career: Special education teacher, Somerset Hills School, 1989-1990; fifth- grade teacher, Adamsville School in Bridgewater, 1990 to 1993. Supervisor of fine arts, North Brunswick School District, and assistant principal, Judd School, 1993 to 1994.
Family: Married to Debby Schiff, a teacher in the Bridgewater school system.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Looking at U.S. Markets Through Japanese Wallets

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE American stock market hit a four-year low last week, more than 20 percent below the record set way back in June of 1990, before the last recession.
If that doesn't sound like what you thought you read in the papers, its because you measure stock prices in dollars. In dollars, the market hit a record high on Friday. But for a Japanese investor, one who measures profits and losses in yen, the statement is true. On Tuesday, the S.& P. 500 was at its lowest level, in yen, since Jan. 22, 1991. 
 On June 12, 1990, the S.& P. 500 closed at 367.27. By the end of last week, it was up 33 percent since then. But the value of the dollar, in yen, had plunged 41 percent. Put them together, and the value of the S.& P. 500, in yen, was down 23 percent.
All of which shows that sometimes currency moves can dwarf anything else for international investors. It also may help to explain why, to some foreigners, American stocks look cheap. FLOYD NORRIS

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2811 words

HEADLINE: 'Morphing' Into The Toy World's Top Ranks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AT the New York toy fair in February 1993, a Japanese company with limited name recognition in the United States displayed a new line of action figures in a small showroom and struggled to get toy buyers to look. "We had to go out in the hall and drag some of them in," recalled Trish Stewart, marketing director for the company's American subsidiary.
The action figures, the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, went on to become one of the greatest hits in American toy history. At last month's toy fair, the manufacturer, the Bandai Company, couldn't keep the crowds out of a showroom that was four times as large as the old one. 
 The phenomenal, and unexpected, success of the Power Rangers provided a new opportunity to Bandai, which has long been Japan's largest conventional toy company but which had so little success in the United States that its American subsidiary seemed to outsiders to be on the verge of disintegrating a few years ago. Now, like the toys it makes, Bandai has a chance to transform, or "morph," into a major player in the American and European markets.
Makoto Yamashina, the company's aggressive president, aims to have Bandai's sales, about $2.2 billion, surpass those of the American giants Mattel ($3.2 billion) and Hasbro ($2.7 billion) by 2000. That would make Bandai the largest conventional toy company in the world and No. 3 over all behind video game kings Nintendo and Sega, which expect revenues of about $4.3 billion and $3.9 billion, respectively, in the fiscal year ending this month.
To do that, Bandai plans to ride the wave created by Japan's fertile comic book and cartoon industries, whose products are gradually catching on around the world. This fall, two or possibly three new Japanese children's programs will debut on American television. Bandai, which specializes in character-based toys, will have the licenses for all three.
The most highly anticipated of the new programs is "Sailor Moon," a cartoon series about a long-legged, clumsy, blond junior high school girl who transforms into a heroine with super powers. A big hit in Japan for two years, the Sailor Moon program has also done well in France, Spain and Hong Kong.
 
New Directions
 Bandai is also plunging into the multimedia and video game business in partnership with Apple Computer Inc. In December, Bandai said it would make and sell the Pippin Power Player, a $500 scaled-down version of Apple's Macintosh computer that will plug into a television set and play games and educational programs stored on CD-ROM's.
"We need another $2 billion to $3 billion business," Mr. Yamashina, who writes books about religion when he is not hatching new super-hero action figures, said about the move into multimedia.
But there are numerous risks ahead. Unlike more stable toys like Mattel's Barbie doll, Bandai's character toys can rise and fall sharply with the unpredictable shifts in moods among fickle youngsters. Coleco Industries, whose Cabbage Patch dolls were as popular in their day as Power Rangers are now, fell into bankruptcy when sales of the dolls declined and the company was left with huge inventories.
Last Christmas, American parents frantically searched for scarce Power Rangers as Bandai struggled to meet demand. But now the shortages are abating. Mr. Yamashina said he expects Power Ranger sales in the United States to increase to about $400 million in 1995 from $330 million in 1994 because of new products and because Twentieth Century Fox will release a Power Ranger movie for the summer. In Europe, he said, sales might rise as high as $150 million this year, compared with $100 million last year.
But some analysts think Power Ranger sales will start falling this year. "I would say the second half of the year in the U.S. will show a very steep decline in Power Ranger merchandise," said Sean McGowan, toy analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company in New York, who was basing his judgment partly on the sensitive barometer provided by his own 5-year-old son. "He hasn't asked me for a Power Ranger toy since Christmas," Mr. McGowan said.
The video game business is also treacherous. Mattel failed in video game machines. Bandai has been trying, with mixed success, since it made imitations of the early Atari Pong game in 1977. Its latest hardware effort, the Playdia CD-ROM player for toddlers that is sold in Japan, has been swamped in the marketplace by Sega's child computer, the Pico. Already, Mr. Yamashina concedes, the Macintosh-based multimedia player, due in the fall, has slipped behind schedule, and it will be difficult to get high volumes into the market in time for Christmas.
IN the fiscal year that ends this month, Bandai expects to record sales of 220 billion yen, or $2.2 billion at the exchange rate of 100 yen to the dollar. That is up 22 percent from a year ago. The company expects net income of $110 million, compared with a loss of $18.6 million a year earlier, when Bandai pulled out of an unprofitable agreement to distribute Nintendo video game cartridges in Europe and wrote off its inventory.
Many analysts here estimate that profits and revenues will be flat or grow only slightly in the year that begins in April. Bandai's stock, traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, has fallen from 5,040 yen a year ago to 3,240 yen on Friday. (To further enhance its visibility in the United States, Bandai is considering a New York Stock Exchange listing.)
But Mr. Yamashina is nothing if not ambitious. "He might make a mistake once again, but he will find the way," said Yoshio Tsukuda, a toy wholesaler. "That is what he has done in the past."
Bandai (pronounced BAHN-dye) was founded as a toy wholesaler in 1950 by Mr. Yamashina's father, Naoharu. The company name comes from part of a Chinese phrase meaning "things that are eternal." Within a year Bandai began manufacturing its own toys, concentrating on cheap metal replicas of planes and cars that were exported to the United States. "We called them $1 toys," Mr. Yamashina recalled.
But after that good start, Bandai never had much success in the United States. Perhaps its biggest hit before the Power Rangers was the Gobots, vehicles that transformed into robots, which were sold in the United States by Tonka Toys in the mid-1980's.
But if it did not succeed abroad, Bandai found the key to success in Japan. It aggressively licensed characters from comics and television shows to make into toys. Today, character merchandise -- mainly toys but recently also clothing and candy and other goods -- accounts for more than 80 percent of sales.
Comic books, many of which contain liberal doses of sex and violence, are almost a national mania in Japan, read by children and adults alike. The successful comics are often made into animated cartoons. While Japan is known as a nation that lacks competitiveness in software -- like computer programs and movies -- comics and animations are an exception. Japanese comics and cartoons have developed big followings in other parts of Asia and in Europe, and cult followings in the United States.
Bandai employs people in their 20's and 30's to scan comics, cartoons, video games and commercials looking for characters that might appeal to children. The company creates no characters itself.
OFTEN, Bandai goes for the toy license at the time a successful comic is ready to be made into a cartoon for television, so that the toys can appear at about the same time as the program. Bandai pays a royalty of 2 to more than 10 percent, depending on the character. Bandai usually conceives of the toys to be made from the character but contracts out design to an independent company. It then either makes the toys itself or contracts out the manufacturing.
To sell its toys, Bandai becomes the main sponsor of the shows for which it has the license. There are now 35 half-hour-long cartoon shows on television in Japan and Bandai is the sponsor of 18.
"Our stance is to be the first licensee for any character," said Mr. Yamashina, who added that only about one-third of the characters turn into successful toys.
Take the case of Sailor Moon, which has been Bandai's biggest hit in Japan recently, far outselling the Power Rangers.
The character was created by Naoko Takeuchi, a woman just out of college who quit her job as a hospital pharmacist to seek her fame and fortune as a comic strip author. In 1992, Pretty Soldier Sailor Moon, as it called here, was accepted, out of hundreds of submissions, for publication in Nakayoshi, a monthly magazine filled with serialized comics for girls.
Thanks to Sailor Moon, Nakayoshi's circulation began soaring, so Toei Animation decided to make it into a television cartoon program. The comic and the television show are big hits among young girls (and also, it is said, among computer nerds and some other men).
Bandai, which expects to sell about $220 million worth of Sailor Moon toys, clothing and other goods in the fiscal year that ends this month, pays a 3 percent royalty that is split among Toei Animation, the broadcasting station, Nakayoshi and Ms. Takeuchi. As a result of her success, Ms. Takeuchi, now 27, tools around Tokyo in a Porsche and is about to buy a Ferrari.
DIC Entertainment, a children's programming subsidiary of Capital Cities/ABC, is now adapting the cartoon for American audiences and it will be shown starting in September. "The issue of a girl being empowered is a wonderful theme you just don't see in American animation," said Andy Heyward, DIC president.
DIC was well on its way to giving the license for the American toys to Kenner, a Hasbro subsidiary, Mr. Heyward said. But Toei Animation argued that Bandai, because it already makes the toys for Japan, would be able to begin sales in America more quickly. DIC turned down Bandai's request to get licenses for merchandise other than toys because those other areas are not Bandai's main business.
This fall, Saban Entertainment, the Burbank, Calif., company that brought Power Rangers to America, will put on the air another Japanese kids' show called "Masked Rider," a live-action program that was first broadcast here in 1971 and has been off the air for several years. Bandai has already introduced toys from the program into the American market.
The third show that could go on the air in the United States this fall is "Dragon Ball," another Toei Animation cartoon, which is being Americanized by Funimation Productions of Fort Worth.
Bandai has now started to look abroad for characters to license. Its first such move was for an American cartoon figure, the Tick, a 7-foot, 400-pound blue super-hero.
Mr. Yamashina said he does not get directly involved in choosing characters to license. "I leave it to young people," he said. "I don't touch it. It's like the fashion business. It requires a keen sense for young people."
As a young person himself, Mr. Yamashina was surrounded by toys and wanted to do something else with his life. After graduating from Keio University with a degree in economics, he joined a publishing company, hoping to become an editor, but was assigned instead to sell encyclopedias. After two years, he left and joined Bandai.
In 1980, Mr. Yamashina became president at 35. His father still comes into the office once a month or so to give advice. Mr. Yamashina and his father own a combined 5.3 percent of the company, a stake worth about $80 million.
MR. YAMASHINA is considered an aggressive manager who has trouble following traditional practices like lifetime employment. He once told a Japanese newspaper that getting rid of unproductive employees is like pulling weeds. After taking over from his father, he purged many of his father's associates to install a younger group loyal to him.
"He fires people quickly," said Atsuko Tatsumi, editor of the Weekly Toy News and of the English-language monthly Japan Toy and Hobby Market Report. "Even people who worked 30 to 40 years for his father, he fires them."
Mr. Yamashina has also angered some retailers and wholesalers in Japan because he has worked to streamline the toy distribution system here. The mom-and-pop stores and multiple levels of distributors are giving way to big chains like Toys "R" Us that buy from manufacturers directly. As the largest toy company, Bandai has set the pace by selling to these retailers.
With his nearly fluent English and direct style, Mr. Yamashina apppeals to Western executives. Satjiv Chahil, vice president and general manager of the new media division at Apple, said Bandai has little of the bureaucracy and time-consuming protocols of the other Japanese companies Apple has worked with. "He's been swift, responsive and open," Mr. Chahil said.
Mr. Chahil said Apple had wanted a toy company to sell a simplified Macintosh, a product that was too inexpensive for Apple to sell profitably itself, but had not had Bandai in mind. But at the Macworld Expo in Tokyo about a year ago, Mr. Yamashina approached Apple.
"We instantly were on the same wavelength," Mr. Chahil said. "In less than an hour, we had come to a virtual agreement on what we wanted to do."
The Pippin Power Player is an attempt to come up with a machine that combines the low price of a video game machine with the versatility of a personal computer. "Just one that is able to meet your will," is Bandai's slogan, using the awkward English that is considered fashionable in Japan.
CD-ROM's made for Pippin will be playable on the Macintosh, though not necessarily vice-versa. Apple is designing the product and Bandai will contract out for its manufacturing and sell it.
But while Pippin is designed to combine the best of video game machines and computers, it might end up being considered too slow and expensive for a video game machine and too unsophisticated for a computer. Moreover, Mr. Yamashina freely acknowledges that little or no profit can be expected on the players, especially since Apple is planning to license other companies to make Pippins as well.
But Bandai hopes to prosper from software. As with Nintendo and Sega, Bandai and Apple will charge a license fee to each software company that wants to make programs for Pippin. Bandai also hopes to sell its own software for the machine.
Mr. Yamashina has two children, a 20-year-old son and 18-year-old daughter, and it is unclear yet whether either will enter the toy business. In his spare time, Mr. Yamashina likes to sail and play golf.
He is also the author of two books about religion that he said he wrote out of curiosity. One seeks to explain the words of Buddha and the other the Bible. Mr. Yamashina himself does not adhere to any religion.
His book about the Bible tries to uncover its hidden truths. For instance, where the Bible states that Adam lived 930 years, Mr. Yamashina writes that he knows from inspiration that the real age was 120 years and was hidden using a Jewish code. To see the truth, rearrange the number 930 as (9+3) x 10 + 0 = 120.
Apparently, Mr. Yamashina's inspirations about religion are not nearly as perspicacious as his inspirations about toys. Unlike the Power Rangers, he noted, "My books don't sell at all."
 
 
 
A Morphin Power Pitch
ACCORDING to Haim Saban, the man who brought the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers program to American television, the show almost didn't make it. "I had been schlepping the Ranger series for nine years until I got one buyer," said Mr. Saban, owner of Saban Entertainment, a children's programming company in Burbank, Calif.
The American program is a descendant of a Japanese show called "Go Renjaa," or "Five Rangers," which was created by the Toei Company, a leading movie company, and first broadcast in Japan in 1975.
The program has undergone many changes since then, but a Ranger-related show is still on the air in Japan. Sales of Ranger toys in Japan are steady but not spectacular, at about $50 million a year, said Makoto Yamashina, president of the Bandai Company.
Mr. Saban said he and Mr. Yamashina had been talking for 10 years about bringing a television program related to Bandai's toys to the United States. Most American television executives rejected the Rangers as too silly, but the Fox Children's Network decided to broadcast the show in the fall of 1993.
The program is live-action, not a cartoon. It is about teen-agers who can be transformed into super-heroes who fight aliens with karate chops and fantastic robots. Saban reshot some scenes using American actors.
While Mr. Yamashina denies it, some industry executives say that within Bandai there was some reluctance to make the toys for the American market because the company had never done well in the United States. Now, thanks largely to sales in the United States, Power Ranger toys account for about one-fifth of Bandai's total revenues.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1428 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 5-10

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

Americans Can Still Get 100 Pennies for a Dollar
The plunging dollar and peso have, it seems, matched headline for headline lately, which could lead a casual observer to think this country's woes match Mexico's. That's silly, of course. For starters, while Mexico's currency has lost half its value in a few months, the dollar, after falling for a decade, has lost far less. But the bigger point is that America is big enough, ultimately, not to care that much. We buy 90 percent of our stuff right here, and that spending won't be seriously affected by what happens across the ocean. So while Alan Greenspan hinted at raising rates again, which arrested a dollar slide last week, some economists say it would be foolish to go through such hoops that it lands us in recession. Look at it this way: it's not that the dollar is low, said Paul Krugman, a Stanford economist, but that "the yen and the mark are getting ridiculously high." 

Welcoming a Jobs Report
Declining unemployment is always good news -- as it was last week when the rate fell to 5.4 percent, a four-year low. This report was especially welcome, for it showed that with all the Fed's rate increases, economic growth persists -- with no inflation to speak of. And payrolls increased by a surprisingly high 318,000. The not-so-good news, yet again, was that job growth was concentrated in temporary workers and part-timers -- hardly foundations for careers. But the market thought positive, as the Dow leapt 52.
 
When in Doubt, Sue Someone
Few would disagree that this nation is awash in lawsuits, many of them frivolous. "Lawsuit abuse saps our economy," said Representative Henry Hyde. What to do? The Republican solution is simply to throw out most of the bath water in sweeping tort reform, but will the baby be thrown out, too? No, the House insisted, as it plunged ahead last week on its crusade to limit investors' suits against companies or brokers and put a cap on damages in civil lawsuits. It also voted to force the loser in a Federal civil suit to pay the opponent's legal costs. A clear deterrent to frivolity, say supporters, while critics say corporations could pay less heed to safety.
 
Do-It-Yourself Health Reform
Who says health care reform fizzled? New twists pop up everywhere -- they just don't have "Made in Washington" labels. "The future," said one health economist, "is in the large capitated medical group" -- unsettling language that simply refers to the per-capita fee that H.M.O.'s charge. And those H.M.O.'s won't be the sole domain of insurers and other middlepeople. Across the nation, doctors have already been finding strength in groups, and now they're going a step further, banding together -- in El Paso and elsewhere -- to create their own H.M.O.'s. These cost-pinching days, the economist said, "individual doctors don't stand a chance."
 
Welfare, by Lots of Other Names
This is the age of militant self-sufficiency. Don't expect handouts, don't go whining to the courts about life's slings and arrows -- that's the message to folks on the sidewalk. But do corporations fit this ruggedly independent mold? Not exactly. With Washington's checkbook in the news, some attention has shifted to business subsidies -- what Robert Reich calls "aid for dependent corporations." The "market promotion" program of the Foreign Agricultural Service, for one, doles out $110 million a year for things like helping Campbell advertise V-8 Juice in Argentina. And the Cato Institute said last week, "Corporate pork is pervasive."
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Facing Grim Facts in Mexico
For a while, there was a sense that a quick fix was possible in Mexico -- that the crisis was a blip that could be corrected with a few carefully targeted billions from outside. That was not the tone last week though. "There's no easy way out," said Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz; one observer saw "no magic cure." With the peso at another low, Mexico's Government adopted a tough economic plan that pointed unambiguously to hard times: raising gasoline prices 35 percent, the value-added tax to 15 percent.
 
One for All, All for Barings?
It made a great story. A trader barely out of his financial diapers brings down a venerable British firm singlehanded, proving yet again the amazing power of whiz kids let loose in the money shop. Sorry, but the case of Nicholas Leeson and Barings's collapse doesn't look that simple now. A glance at the way many American firms now operate -- elaborate controls, monitors and double-checks -- suggests that the fault, dear Barings, was not in your superstars. That, at any rate, was the tack taken by Mr. Leeson's lawyers last week. As one of them put it: "The reporting so far has not even scratched the surface" of what went on. "Everything he did, he did as an employee of Barings."
 
An Outcast, Still in Business
Iran, theoretically an outcast nation, has not exactly been cast out of the world's business loop. True, since that 1979 hostage mess, most American trade with Iran has been banned -- direct trade, that is. But by Al D'Amato's estimate, 25 percent of Iran's oil has been bought by American companies, for sale elsewhere. And last week the spirit of this ostracism was stretched closer to the breaking point when Conoco, through a Dutch affiliate, made a $1 billion deal to develop an oil field on Sirri Island, off Iran. It's "within the intent of the law," Conoco insisted, but the White House said, "This is not a helpful development." And Mr. D'Amato, saying he was "deeply distressed," said the Senate Banking Committee, which he heads, would try to tighten the embargo.
 
COMPANIES
 
USAir, Shrinking to Fit
Some of the nation's airlines have shown in recent years that shrinking, not expanding, is the way to go. American cut its capacity 5 percent a year or so ago, and America West trimmed 12 percent, and both moves proved profitable. Now USAir -- which lost $685 million last year, partly because of fears resulting from the crash of two of its jets -- is trying this approach. Last week it said it would cut 5 percent of its capacity, dropping 240 flights while adding some new ones. In most cases, though, this cutback will simply involve trimming some flights on certain routes, not whole routes.
 
This Time, It's Not I.B.M.'s Fault
Yes, there are some dark sides to computers taking over our lives -- like that mix of neck, arm and hand maladies known as repetitive stress injuries. But who's to blame for R.S.I. -- the user of the keyboard or the manufacturer? Some have tried to pin it on the latter, saying designs are faulty and conducive to injury, while keyboard makers insist that work habits are the culprit. Like any self-respecting dispute these days, this one sometimes lands in court. And last week, in a closely watched case, the manufacturer -- I.B.M. -- came out on top. A Minnesota jury decided that I.B.M. was not liable for injuries that a secretary blamed on a keyboard. This could well embolden other companies not to settle similar claims. And it could give workers added reason to take those recommended rest breaks.
 
A Gift of Words
Imagine a world without paperbacks -- no mounds of three-for-a-dollar romances at garage sales, no bookshelves that seemingly fill to bulging of their own volition. Truly a bleak prospect, but one we need not face -- thanks, in large part, to a man named Ian Ballantine. In 1939, Mr. Ballantine and his wife, Betty, founded Penguin U.S.A. -- and, later, Bantam and then Ballantine Books, making a big contribution to creating a mass market for all sorts of tales. Their titles over the years ranged from "The Grapes of Wrath" to the works of Ray Bradbury and J. R. R. Tolkein. Mr. Ballantine died last week at 79; untold millions of books survive him.
 
Quick: What's 3% of Zero?
Here's an existential question: if the Yankees aren't playing, can they be fairly said to exist? Do they exist, that is, in the sense of being worth anything? Well, two years ago, someone offered $500 million for the team. But that was then. Now, a part owner named Harvey Leighton is trying to sell his share -- just over 3 percent -- and can't find a buyer, even at the seemingly bargain price of $2.95 million for 1 percent. One possible problem: George Steinbrenner, who owns 55 percent and has such a grip that one former investor said, "There's nothing more limited than a limited partner in the Yankees." And then, of course, fans nationwide are starting to forget that baseball ever existed.

LENGTH: 1074 words

HEADLINE: Argentina, a Victim of Mexico's Fall, Tries to Recover

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
ARGENTINA isn't Mexico. But Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's finance minister, has had a hard time trying to convince investors and creditors that his nation is really different.
Since Mexico surprised the financial markets in December by devaluing the peso, the ripple effect has been felt throughout Latin America -- and nowhere more so than in Argentina. The country's once-vibrant economy is threatened by recession as credit dries up, foreign investors take flight and Argentines pull their money out of banks. 
 Until a rebound on Friday, fueled largely by the announcement of Mexico's austerity plan, Argentine stocks dropped roughly 38 percent since the Mexican devaluation on Dec. 20. Additionally, an estimated $3 billion of deposits has been withdrawn from Argentine banks. Recently, four banks were forced to close for lack of funds, and the Government has cobbled together emergency support for other endangered banks, hoping to prevent a collapse.
Mr. Cavallo said last week that his Government would seek another $2 billion from the International Monetary Fund. The new request comes just a week after Argentina said it needed $420 million from the I.M.F. to supply funds to its strapped banks. After Mexico, it does seem as though the next currency ripe for devaluation is Argentina's peso.
On numerous trips to the United States and Europe this year, Mr. Cavallo has tried to assure investors and bankers with two messages: Argentina is on more solid economic footing than Mexico, and there is more discipline in his country's exchange-rate system, which should blunt speculation.
In the last four years, Argentina's growth rate -- roughly 7 percent annually -- has been far higher than Mexico's. Argentina's current-account deficit, though rising, is proportionately far less than that of Mexico, which reached 7.6 percent of gross domestic product last year. And inflation in Argentina, once a textbook case of hyperinflation, has dropped to less than 5 percent.
Much of the improvement here dates from April 1991, when the Argentine Congress passed the "Convertibility Act," which pegs the peso tightly to the dollar at a one-to-one ratio. Under the convertibility plan, every Argentine peso in circulation is backed by a dollar reserve in the central bank. Mexico had no such fixed system.
In a recent interview with Telem, a local news agency, Mr. Cavallo blamed speculators for growing hysteria and pressure on Argentina to devalue. He insisted that no Argentine economy indicator justified the steady losses on the stock market.
"The economic signs are very positive, and I hope market operators in Argentina as well as abroad will see this and will reverse the climate of panic or terror that is being installed here," Mr. Cavallo said.
The first signs of a squeeze on Argentina's economy appeared early last year when interest rates in the United States and Europe began rising. That made Western investors more likely to keep money in their home markets, slowing the inflow of foreign capital to Argentina and other developing nations. But Argentina was hit hard when the Mexican financial crisis prompted many foreign fund managers and investors to pull out of Latin America. The decline in foreign investment is expected to stunt economic growth in Argentina and reduce tax revenue, raising questions about whether the country can meet its debt payments.
In an interview last week, Mr. Cavallo insisted that Argentina's debt payments of $5.2 billion would be made on time this year and that the funds had already been allocated. "Any statements saying that we are not going to meet payments are false," Mr. Cavallo said.
Asked if a recession might arise from the lack of liquidity, Mr. Cavallo said that there would be "a decrease in production" in 1995 but "not a strong recession."
Economists now predict that with the loss of foreign investment and the credit crunch, Argentina will post no growth this year and may even shrink slightly, compared with earlier forecasts of as much as 6 percent growth.
The real threat in Argentina, economists say, is less of capital flight in the traditional sense than an old-fashioned run on the banks. Argentina's convertibility system is intended to make conventional currency speculation pointless.
But bank withdrawals are running so high because depositors -- both Argentines and some foreigners -- are afraid that the banking system could collapse. Local bankers here report that many Argentines are withdrawing dollars from their savings accounts and placing them in safety deposit boxes or under mattresses at home.
In the past, Argentina relied on foreign investments to balance its trade accounts, paying for its imports and other obligations from abroad. Yet with foreign investment declining, Argentina has been forced to adopt an austerity package to avoid what Mr. Cavallo has called "the unthinkable -- devaluation."
The Finance Minister announced the austerity program two weeks ago. The main elements are $1 billion in budget cuts and a drive to generate another $2.5 billion in revenue by eliminating tax deductions and cracking down on tax evaders. The measures are intended to help close a projected budget deficit of $4.5 billion this year.
Most economists and financial analysts here believe that Mr. Cavallo will stand by his word and not devalue the peso, despite the growing pressure on the currency. Were Mr. Cavallo forced to reconsider, a devaluation would require approval of Argentina's Congress. Any devaluation, analysts say, would certainly not occur before the Presidential elections in May.
Most economists and analysts believe that the inherent strength of Argentina's economy should make it possible for Mr. Cavallo to avoid a devaluation. But the skittishness of depositors and investors, both at home and abroad, after the Mexican collapse could make it all the harder to stay on course. And the jump of nearly 13 percent in the Argentine stock market on Friday shows, for better or worse, how much investors still link Argentina's fortunes to those of Mexico.
"It's been a long, difficult haul trying to persuade people that things are stable and Argentina is different from Mexico," said Christopher Eccelstone, an analyst for Interacciones, a brokerage firm here. "What's happening is that everybody got it wrong on Mexico and they are trying to make sure that they don't get it wrong again on Argentina."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Is South Korea Poised to Rise Again?

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
IT may seem foolhardy to write again about a so-called emerging market when blood is running all over the floor of Latin America's stock exchanges, but then is South Korea really an emerging market, given that the term is virtually synonymous with being a developing country?
The International Finance Corporation, the World Bank's business promotion arm, coined the emerging market designation and includes South Korea in its index of such markets, as do other financial houses tracking these new and relatively undeveloped stock exchanges. 
 Yet South Korea, along with Taiwan, is very close to joining the industrial world and there is a case for saying that its stock market does not deserve to be tarred with the Mexican brush. In the worldwide flight to quality now under way, Seoul may have more to offer than intrinsically weaker emerging economies.
With an average income of $7,670 in 1993, according to the latest World Bank figures, South Koreans earn twice the income of workers in Malaysia, Mexico or Indonesia. And South Korea should cross the $8,356 barrier sometime this year, becoming a high-income country instead of a middle- income one. Later this month South Korea is due to apply formally to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the rich countries' Paris club.
South Korea, which already has the world's second-largest steel manufacturer, traditionally vies with Japan to be the world's top ship builder. Last week, it became the 26th country to "graduate" from the World Bank, and is now an aid donor rather than a recipient.
"South Korea is on the borderline of becoming a high capital, knowledge-based economy, although its leaders still often see themselves as third world," said Robert G. Rich Jr., a former United States Ambassador to Seoul and head of the Korea Economic Institute of America, which is based in Washington.
South Korea's stock market, which peaked last November, has not escaped the emerging-market sell-off brought on by the Mexican fiasco, falling about 20 percent since then.
However, the decline is certainly being aided and abetted by a tighter monetary policy as the Central Bank fights economic overheating by attempting to slow last year's 9 percent growth rate -- Asia's fastest -- to a target of 7 percent for 1995.
The case for remaining bearish on South Korea is essentially political. Kim Jong Il's Communist state in North Korea could implode. If it does, the argument goes, South Korea would face even greater budgetary strains in taking over that impoverished country than the collapse of East Germany placed on West Germany after the Berlin Wall came down. Since Seoul would be forced to pump resources into the North to avert an economic catastrophe there, deficit spending and inflation would rise.
The bullish case, on the other hand, rests on the premise that none of the above will happen, allowing South Korea to gradually expand its business links with the North, effectively taking over North Korean economy without undermining the longtime Communist state.
"Economic integration followed by slow political integration is what the South wants and what would reassure China," said Michael Porter, an analyst who follows South Korea for Smith Barney Inc.
Some South Korea watchers expect the present phase of tight liquidity and market weakness to give way to easier conditions later this year, with interest rates coming off their present 15 percent peak and stock prices strengthening.
According to this view the strength of the Japanese yen will help South Korea's chaebol, as its dynastically controlled conglomerates are called, to remain competitive, allowing them to cash in on the heavy investments they have made recently in new Japanese capital equipment.
Analysts say June's regional elections should encourage monetary easing. Meanwhile, both domestic and foreign interest in the stock market ought to pick up. Plans to raise taxes on bank-deposit interest and to make it harder to conceal real estate ownership should push funds toward stocks.
At the same time, the Seoul Government plans to raise the 12 percent limit on foreign holdings in any quoted company to 15 percent this year, thus creating more space in the market for foreign investors. "For all these reasons we expect to see the market rise again later this year," said John Bai, the Korean expert for Baring Securities.
Investing in the South Korean market is not easy, however. Individual foreign investors face a regulatory obstacle course, so country funds make the most sense.
The two oldest, the Korea Fund and the Korea Investment Fund, traditionally command a premium because they hold blue chips now closed to foreigners. The Fidelity Advisor Korean Fund and the Korea Equity Fund are more recent, while January saw the creation of the Mathews Korea Fund by the Mathews International Fund Group in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: At Work;
A 'Married, With Children' Bias?

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
IN lots of ways, Rebecca Mark and Jeffrey Lockman are not a typical American family. They aren't married, they don't live together and both are gay.
They do, however, share responsibility for what most people would consider the defining aspect of family: a child. Together with Mr. Lockman's partner of 11 years, a physician who asked not to be named, they are raising Benjamin, now seven months old. Ms. Mark, an English professor at Tulane University in New Orleans, and Mr. Lockman, a Tulane psychology professor, live near each other, to make those sanity-saving baby handoffs easier; they own a house together, where Ms. Mark lives with Benjamin; they spend much of their free time in each other's company, and have a joint checking account. Ms. Mark and Mr. Lockman's partner are the baby's genetic mother and father, but the three adults have a legal agreement that they should all be considered parents. Imagine Murphy Brown forgoing single parenthood for a child-rearing arrangement with long-time companions Ward Cleaver and Mike Brady and you have their family configuration. 
 So when Ms. Mark and Mr. Lockman learned from colleagues at Tulane that married couples who both work on campus do not pay a monthly charge for dependent health care coverage, the pair decided to apply. The university didn't exactly say no, but it didn't say yes, either, leaving the two professors to charge that Tulane's coverage is at odds with its nondiscrimination policy and raising questions about how family is defined and who may confer legitimacy on one form versus another. Though the Lockman-Mark situation is unusual, the issues raised apply as well to unmarried heterosexual couples who have children together. As all types of nontraditional families become more common, institutions and companies are increasingly likely to find themselves grappling with such issues.
A Tulane official objected, saying the "benefit" heterosexual couples get is essentially a coincidence of their legally sanctioned union. Tulane contributes $200 a month toward health care for every employee. That automatically makes one person of a heterosexual marriage a dependent, and means they pay no further cost to cover their children. Single parents must pay $200 for dependent coverage. Because the benefit lasts until children are college-age, it could be worth close to $50,000.
Whatever commitments Mr. Lockman and Ms. Mark have made to each other on Benjamin's behalf, for insurance purposes, she is considered a single mother. Sexual orientation, the university says, is immaterial. "This is a single-mother-with-a-child issue," said Ronald Mason Jr., senior vice president and general counsel at Tulane. "Technically, she is not Lockman's dependent. They have no legal relationship."
The two professors point out that as gay people they would be prevented from marrying. In any case, they would not marry each other because theirs is a relationship based on the desire to bring up a child together, not to sustain a romantic-economic union. By refusing to recognize them, they argue, the university is elevating heterosexual matrimony over other forms of commitment. "The university is not supporting its gay families and children," Ms. Mark said. Mr. Lockman added: "Our family seems very different on the surface, but the values and stability of our unit are very much the same as other families. Families come in different forms."
Not according to the Internal Revenue Service and insurance industry standards, the guidelines Mr. Mason says Tulane uses to define dependents. Marriage is the issue, he says, and Tulane doesn't want to know the details. "People don't get married for a lot of reasons," Mr. Mason said. "We don't get into the whys. All we know is that she is an unmarried mother with a child."
Like most universities and hundreds of companies, Tulane has a nondiscrimination policy that includes language covering marital status and sexual orientation. That, the professors argue, is the core of their complaint. "Either they have a policy or they don't," Mr. Lockman said. "They shouldn't be picking and choosing whom it applies to."
If Tulane is in violation of its own policy, it is certainly not alone. Nondiscrimination statements are easily ignored because their legal force is ambiguous. But, said Suzanne B. Goldberg, a staff lawyer at the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay legal rights group, "a nondiscrimination statement is part of a university's promise to its employees. The purpose of the benefit is to assist employees who are raising children together. It seems to me that marriage is immaterial to the purpose."
Last year Tulane considered and -- because of the cost -- decided against paying for dependent coverage for unmarried employees, including domestic partners. Mr. Mason acknowledged that Mr. Lockman and Ms. Mark's application for dependent health care has moved the university to re-evaluate its coverage. "We're looking at a cafeteria-style plan, where employees can choose the coverage they want," he said. "There's a lot of need out there and a limited ability of the university to provide." The university committee that has tabled the professors' request twice will rehear it sometime in the next few weeks.
The professors see a judgment on their lives and the legitimacy of gay and other nontraditional families in Tulane's current policy. "I get outraged because marriage becomes something that gives you benefits," Ms. Mark said. "Look around, and see all the women who can't afford coverage, at a liberal university." Mr. Lockman is particularly impatient with the cost analysis: "It's a moral issue. They are discriminating against our type of family."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Looking Back at the Overlooked

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
WITH all the attention paid to mutual funds these days, some good ones still slip by.
Maybe it's because more than 5,000 funds are vying for attention. Or maybe it's a matter of marketing. Or just bad luck. 
 The bottom line: There are a few small winners waiting to be discovered. And because more and more good funds are shutting out new investors, it's worth investigating these so-called forgotten funds.
There are five such funds on the sixth annual list as compiled by Morningstar Inc., the fund research company in Chicago. Each holds less than $ 125 million and has had the same manager for at least three years.
Three ply their trade in the fixed-income arena, offering alternatives to leery bond-fund investors. For stock investors, there is a conservative equity pick and a more aggressive one.
The $ 102 million Loomis Sayles Bond Fund walks its own path, Morningstar said. Its returns differ greatly from the United States corporate bond market, given the investments made by its manager, Daniel J. Fuss, in discount-priced bonds, convertible holdings and foreign debt.
"We're not much of a believer in market forecasting," he said. "We're bond pickers."
His typical investor: his father-in-law, who invested all his retirement money in the fund and lives off the income. The fund yields just over 9 percent.
The portfolio sports an average credit quality of BBB, just above junk-bond level, and its maturity now averages 20 years. While the fund is less than four years old, "its prowess in both bull and bear markets, along with unusual breadth, give us a good dose of confidence about its future," Morningstar wrote.
Michael C. Brilley has managed the $ 36 million Sit U.S. Government Securities Fund since its 1987 inception. It owns government issues only and yielded 6.84 percent in January. He says his goal is to "position ourselves as a more conservative bond investment with a fairly intermediate duration," now about 2.2 years.
That's lower than usual for the fund, which currently has higher-than-usual investments, 10.9 percent, in Treasury bills waiting for the market to rise another 10 to 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, before reinvesting. "We look for a modest increase in inflation, to about 3 1/2 percent by year-end," Mr. Brilley said.
A big chunk of the fund -- 70 percent -- is in Ginnie Mae manufactured housing pass-through certificates, loans for buyers of mobile homes. These are less volatile than conventional Ginnie Maes because prepayments are rare and the loans are smaller.
Edward A. Killen helped his brother, Robert, research investments for 16 years and signed on as official manager of the $ 63 million Berwyn Income Fund in June. Berwyn can keep no more than 25 percent of its holdings in common shares; otherwise, Mr. Killen can pretty much do what he wants.
He describes Berwyn as "relatively defensive, a complement to an equity fund."
Fund shareholders agreed to let him invest in junk issues last June, and that is where most of his corporate exposure is now. "We feel that the credit risk is less than the principal risk in higher-grade securities," he said.
Despite the tremendous correction in Treasuries in 1994, "the basic industry economy is very strong," he said. The fund's two largest sectors are computers, 12 percent, and oil and gas, 10.3 percent.
Convertible securities account for 43 percent of the fund, which recently yielded 8.2 percent. Common stocks, 18 percent of holdings, include Occidental Petroleum and A. O. Smith, a maker of frames for utility vehicles.
The $ 105 million Franklin Equity-Income Fund stands out because it relies on high-dividend stocks and convertible preferred shares, not bonds, to create its income. The fund recently yielded 5 percent. Its co-managers, Frank M. Felicelli and Douglas Barton, seek blue-chip stocks yielding at least 25 percent more than the market.
Their biggest sectors are utilities and basic materials, both 15 percent. The biggest holdings: Chemical Banking, Hanson P.L.C. and GTE.
The $ 80 million Wasatch Aggressive Equity Fund is not a "gunslinging, churn or burn fund," its manager, Samuel S. Stewart Jr., says. Wasatch's 1994 turnover was just 40 percent.
Mr. Stewart looks for small growth companies with "an identifiable and sustainable advantage in markets where they have room to at least double the size of the company in at least five years." Its biggest holdings are Loewen Group, a British Columbia company with 80 percent of its funeral-home-consolidation business in the United States; U.S. Cellular, in Chicago, and Heilig-Meyers, a furniture store chain in Richmond.
Mr. Stewart cheered last year's bad market: "We're finding plenty of companies in the current environment given the fall in prices."

HEADLINE: Markets Rise and Fall, but He's Always Looking Up

BYLINE: By ANNE MATTHEWS; Anne Matthews teaches journalism at New York University's graduate program and writes frequently about contemporary social issues.

 BODY:
TO the Manhattan financial astrologer Arch Crawford, 1995 is slated to be a grim untidy year: plenty of earthquakes and a stock market heading south.
"Prices will top the first week in April," he says firmly. "Then a good summer rally. Mid-November brings a serious, serious correction." He pushes at his wire-rimmed glasses, concentrating. 
 "I see at least a 1,000-point drop in late '95, with the Dow stabilizing at 2,600 to 2,800. But there'll be a sharp rally after Thanksgiving, back above 3,200," he says kindly, draining his decaffeinated cappuccino.
Archibald A. H. Crawford, 53, is a professional astrologer, a Merrill Lynch alumnus and an Aries -- "a fine sign for investors," he adds, in a soft North Carolina drawl. Mr. Crawford specializes in market timing -- the art of calling portfolio switches in and out of the stock, bond and gold markets -- and his recommendations appear in a monthly newsletter, Crawford Perspectives. Its motto is "Market timing by planetary cycles and technical analysis since 1977"; a year's subscription is $ 250.
Early last month, Mr. Crawford's forecast was "instability, big time" for March 5 and 6 -- the start of the currency crisis as it turned out. Two months ago, he predicted earthquakes for the days that brought the Kobe tremor. He kind of predicted the 1990 start of the Gulf war: "expect some major catastrophe Aug. 2-7," his newsletter warned, "Mars opposite Pluto suggests coercion, force." So far, forecasting the October 1987 stock market crash is his biggest triumph. "Be out of all stocks by Aug. 24," he warned clients late that summer. And -- win some, lose some -- he has made a number of miscalls, like the market collapse he envisioned in late '82 that turned instead into a record rally.
Mr. Crawford's view of the stars is severely statistical -- or tries to be. "What I do is totally science," he insists, "but in the process some very strange stuff, weird magic, comes to light." Believing that heavenly events affect human events that sometimes affect financial markets, Mr. Crawford calculates percentage changes in the Dow Jones back to 1897, relates that data to astronomical events like sunspots or solar flares and, aided by 28 conventional market indicators, fits the whole into a cyclical prediction line.
He doesn't make specific portfolio recommendations. Instead, he advises his clients on mutual fund switching (among money markets and gold, stock and bond funds) and on the optimal moments to go to cash. Trading under his direction can be brisk, even hyperactive: followers last year would have switched in and out of the market, on average, every eight weeks.
What unnerves more conventional stock analysts is Mr. Crawford's latest ranking by the Hulbert Financial Digest, based in Alexandria, Va., which is widely considered the most rigorous national observer of financial-newsletter performance. Of the 42 market timers assessed over the last year, Mr. Crawford is No. 2.
"Numbers and track record are all I watch," says the publisher, Mark Hulbert, a touch stiffly. "If tea leaves or sunspots or piles of dirty laundry in my apartment prove significant, I have to take notice." He adds: " His three- and five-year records have beaten a buy-and-hold strategy. And he did slightly outperform the market in 1994."
Last Wednesday, Mr. Crawford was ranked No. 1 in stock and bond timing by the Investment Newsletter Timer Digest published in Greenwich, Conn., by James H. Schmidt, a former Wall Street brokerage house vice president.
New York has other financial astrologers, but Mr. Crawford is one of the few to offer a newsletter and a hot line. (In the fiercely competitive, ego-intensive world of financial advising, the cooler players offer a "900" number with twice-daily updates.) One longtime competitor, William Meridian, currently manages investments in Abu Dhabi. Another, Henry Weingarten of the New York School of Astrology, offers the Astrologers Fund, a mutual fund run on astrological principles. The school is planning a May symposium on astrology and the market.
There are, of course, those who question the Crawford strategy. "The random walk theory allows for all kinds of people to have a good year occasionally," says Howard A. Rubel, vice president of investment research at Goldman, Sachs. "But most professional investors focus on fundamentals -- earnings, track record, market share, cash flow. Their interests don't include the ethereal."
WHO consults an astrologer before making stock trades?
Mr. Crawford's approximately 1,000 current subscribers include heads of several regional brokerage houses; executives from the Indian subcontinent who live in the West yet retain a taste for astral authority; 4 of the 20 champion investors profiled in Jack Schwager's recent book "The New Market Wizards," Mr. Crawford claims (he declines to name them), and enough Zurich gnomes and Bonn bankers to warrant a separate German edition.
"North Americans have no idea how seriously Europeans take mystical investing," says one Credit Suisse banker.
Although oracle investing is very much taboo on Wall Street, it has begun to draw second looks, if not respect. Eighty percent of all mutual-fund buyers and financial newsletter editors now fail to beat the markets, says Mr. Hulbert. "In last year's bond rout," noted Institutional Investor in January, "more wealth was wiped off balance sheets than in any other market debacle since the crash of 1929."
"The ultimate American fantasy has become security: social, emotional, spiritual, financial," says Hayden White, a professor in the history of consciousness program at the University of California at Santa Cruz. And investors are reacting in very different ways to Wall Street's now-chronic insecurity, a condition aggravated by industry layoffs and terrorist checkpoints. Some redouble their herd instincts; others discover a lusty appetite for the strange. At the same time, Wall Street is morphing into an entertainment form rich in stars and sinners, cults and rites. And New Age objets.
Traders once content with lucky socks can now soak in jinx-remover bath salts. They can check the Internet's Divination Web before buying bonds. They can pay for emergency sessions at the Wall Street Hypnosis Center with Mastercard's new Horoscope Card, embossed with the user's name and zodiac sign. Thriving astrological-software companies like Astrolabe let anyone try star-based trades.
Financial astrology is now part of the multibillion-dollar New Age movement -- disorganized, apolitical and growing. "Washington doesn't get it, but Wall Street should be more nimble on this," observes David H. Thorne, a former real estate developer who heads New Age Publishing in Watertown, Mass. "We're talking many, many billions, a growing chunk of the new economy. One in three Americans now pursues alternative forms of health care. Natural foods and products annually top $ 6 billion. New-age music, another $ 1 billion. Self-help and new-spirituality publishing? Billions there too. It's not just crystals any more. Besides, a financial astrologer who can beat the markets is a guy to watch."
As the nonrational turns ever-more marketable, all manner of seers are popping up: chaos-theory visionaries, sunspot trackers, astrologers who work up natal horoscopes for companies based on their hour of incorporation, mutual-fund clairvoyants, feng shui consultants who free unlucky conference rooms from evil spirits.
ARCH CRAWFORD, studied physics and math at the University of North Carolina, but left without a degree to work as a research assistant to Robert Farrell, the long-time Merrill Lynch technical research chief. In 1963, Mr. Crawford discovered his metier when he read an article in The Wall Street Journal on investors who used heavenly events to guide commodities buying. In his spare time, Mr. Crawford began serious research into the subject, looking for connections between astrological goings-on and the prices of stocks, copper and gold.
After a three-year stint in the Army in the late 60's, including a year in Vietnam, Mr. Crawford worked as a financial analyst and stockbroker and even studied to become a psychologist. Then in 1975 he had a dream, he says, that he should return to Wall Street trading. He bought options and made money. He combined astrological methods and technical indicators; he made more money.
Today, Mr. Crawford is joined in his newsletter venture by his wife, Carolyn Snedden, whom he met in 1988 at an astrology convention in Las Vegas, Nev. Ms. Snedden -- who casts $ 150 personalized horoscopes for investors who want to know which days are good for clear-headed trading -- has spiffed up Crawford Perspectives, taming her husband's idiosyncratic page layouts, if not his staccato prose ("Dec. 2: Jupiter conjunct Pluto. Perigee new moon. Powerful. Low in bonds!" "Dec. 6: Mars square Pluto = More about war, fires, murder.").
Nonetheless, financial astrologers like Henry Weingarten, of the Astrologers Fund, are bullish about their brand of financial forecasting. "Getting fund managers out of the closet is really our goal," says Mr. Weingarten. "We had $ 4 billion in funds represented at our last conference. Financial astrologers are everywhere. You know them only as investment bankers with terrific records. Let a pension fund announce it's run by astrologers, and 20 percent of the clients vanish. The other 80 percent, of course, say, Great, fine. But there's tremendous prejudice -- tremendous!"
In the unruly world of alternative finance, Mr. Crawford is as buttoned-down as they come, meeting fellow market-cycle enthusiasts for cocktails and forecasting at the Princeton Club, delivering painstaking addresses on astrological methodology to the Market Technicians Association. "But there's always a bunch in the back of the room," he acknowledges, "growling that I'm a travesty of justice."
Mr. Crawford's newsletter's recommendations to dive for cover when Jupiter, Uranus, Saturn and Venus conjunct are likely to continue to circulate through research departments and executive suites, if only in brown paper bags. Asked if they would ever consult his hot line, a dozen traders and analysts had the same firm reply. Yes, all agreed -- but from a pay phone.
