HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lamborghini Diablo VT;
'Do You Know, Mr. Vader, How Fast You Were Going?'

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
IF Darth Vader agreed to do another "Star Wars" sequel and rented a weekend place in Malibu, what would he drive?
Corvettes and Vipers have the muscle, but lack the finesse. Ferraris have finesse to spare, but look too much like Japanese knock-offs of Ferraris to make the proper impression in Tinseltown. 
 What's left for the ultimate macho guy? A Diablo VT, Automobili Lamborghini's ultimate macho driving machine. And just in case The Force deserts Mr. Vader at some inopportune moment on the twists and turns of Topanga Canyon, he can rely on the Diablo VT's four-wheel drive to save his bacon.
Lamborghini, you may not remember, is a relatively recent (1964) addition to the world of exotic cars, the hobby and passion of the Italian tractor maker. And while it is apparently not true that Ferruccio Lamborghini went into the car business because he got wretched service from the imperious Enzo Ferrari, the myth has a certain appeal.
The first Lamborghini, the 12-cylinder 350GT, was designed by an engineer pirated from Ferrari. And while Lamborghini never challenged the Ferraris on the race track, its futuristic Countach, introduced in 1973, beat all contenders as the tough car of choice for those who didn't have to ask how much it cost.
Signor Lamborghini probably never made money on the cars, and production never exceeded a few hundred a year. And when the rest of his industrial empire tottered in the 1970's, he relinquished control of the tiny auto maker. It ended up in the hands of Chrysler in 1987, which invested in one new design -- the Diablo -- and was mulling over plans for more when the market for exotics evaporated in the recession of the early 1990's.
Megatech, a group of Indonesians, bought the name and the factory near Modena, Italy, a year ago. The latest model to come to America is the mid-engine V12 Diablo VT, which pushes 492 horsepower through all four wheels.
Like the Countach, the Diablo is a jaw-dropper. The aluminum body, 43.5 inches at its highest, is one long swoop from the huge rear wing to the front spoiler. The doors pivot vertically on hydraulic arms, opening just enough to allow driver and passenger to wedge into bucket seats anchored a few inches above the floor pan.
But unlike the user-unfriendly Countach, the Diablo VT is made to be driven by mortals. The seats are comfortable -- well, comfortable enough to use for hours at a time without chiropractic intervention. Controls, including those for the powerful (if noisy) air-conditioning and adequate radio, are within easy reach, and the analog instrument panel is a model of clear design. All the right surfaces are covered in beige leather.
What's more, the view over the short, sharply sloped hood is excellent. And -- surprise, surprise -- the rear spoiler sits high enough above the engine compartment to provide adequate rear vision.
A Diablo may look as if it is moving when it is parked, but the real adventure begins when you turn the key. The 5.7-liter, 48-valve aluminum engine, positioned just inches behind the driver's head, idles with a delicious rumble reminiscent of a Harley-Davidson. The stick on the five-speed, chrome-gated transmission, though, clunks into first like the control lever on one of Signor Lamborghini's old tractors; presumably it will slide with more grace when the car is broken in.
Takeoff (what would you call it?) is undramatic, the throttle feeling almost sluggish. That sounds like a serious handicap, but it is not: the Diablo VT behaves itself in traffic, noodling along in first or second gear below 30 miles an hour without complaint. The real action -- that is, most of the 428 foot-pounds of torque -- hits when the monstrous engine is turning above 4,000 r.p.m.
Hence, while the engine breathes without the aid of a turbocharger, the power kicks in after a brief pause with what feels like "turbo lag." This noticeable delay in gratification is a sensitive subject for the image makers at Lamborghini, who assert that the Diablo VT can still make it from zero to 60 in 4.1 seconds without vaporizing the clutch. But such improbable boasts should not discourage those tempted to buy the Diablo to drive rather than to brag about: once the mighty 12-cylinder is turning at warp speed, the acceleration is astounding.
The Harley-like rumble becomes a MIG-like howl as the car explodes from 30 to 70 in second gear. The noise and the proximity to the asphalt heighten the sensation of speed, especially on curves. But the electronically controlled suspension -- it automatically stiffens the otherwise pliant shocks on bumpy surfaces -- assures a comfortable ride. And four-wheel drive eliminates the threat that the rear end will break loose on anything less than the most reckless provocation.
Allow me to elaborate. The Diablo VT is subject to the laws of physics; push it hard enough in a turn and the superfat 17-inch tires will eventually lose their grip. But unlike rear-wheel-drive cars with engines this powerful there is no danger that a loss of nerve -- a lift of the throttle that shifts the weight balance from rear to front in the middle of a turn -- will send the Diablo VT spinning toward the guardrail.
Is this latest Lamborghini worth $239,000, plus assorted taxes? Probably not as an investment. The days of watching exotic cars appreciate in the garage is apparently over. Probably not in terms of pure performance, either. Top-of-the-line Porsches and the new "entry level" Ferrari F355 are nimbler -- and half the price.
But the Diablo VT is a wonder on its own terms: kinetic sculpture, proof of affluence and amusement park ride wrapped into one. And if that isn't sufficient temptation, the nice folks at Lamborghini will throw in a set of leather luggage specially designed to fit the miniature trunk.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Recherche styling and brute power in one handy, unaffordable package.

HEADLINE: Hey, Big Spenders

BYLINE: By David M. Kennedy; David M. Kennedy is the Donald J. McLachlan Professor of History at Stanford University. He is completing a study of the United States during the Great Depression and World War II.

 BODY:

THE END OF REFORM
New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War.
By Alan Brinkley.
371 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
IT is by now a commonplace that the New Deal era in American history has come to a close, an observation given emphatic punctuation by the conservative Republican sweep of the 1994 elections. Liberalism, for nearly half a century this country's regnant political philosophy, apparently now belongs to history -- and to the historians.
Over the history of all the modern liberal tradition, of course, hangs the shadow of the New Deal. Venturing into battle against the Great Depression, Franklin Roosevelt and his fellow reformers blazed a new pathway into the political future. Escaping from the confining doctrines of laissez-faire that had stunted previous reform campaigns, so the conventional story goes, the New Dealers transformed the character of government and began the process of building contemporary American society.
Yet even in that heady and creative moment, as Alan Brinkley explains in "The End of Reform," liberalism was not free of travail. Overestimating the scope and strength of the mandate he received in his hugely lopsided 1936 re-election (in which he carried every state except Maine and Vermont), Roosevelt recklessly attempted to "pack" the Supreme Court with additional Justices who would presumably be more amenable to his programs. Ultimately, this episode squandered the prodigious political capital with which he began his second term and stalled the New Deal in its tracks.
Moreover, the hullabaloo over the Court was closely followed, in the fall of 1937, by a recession even more precipitous -- though, as it turned out, shorter-lived -- than the slide that had begun in 1929. Argument now intensified about what course liberalism should take. Reformers of all persuasions bombarded Roosevelt in 1937 and 1938 with a bewildering battery of conflicting advice. Government power, liberals agreed, must be invoked. On the precise policies that might be deployed there was no agreement whatsoever.
Much of this book focuses on the "intense ideological struggle" of late 1937 and 1938. It was, says Mr. Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, "a struggle to define the soul of the New Deal." By extension, it was also a contest to define the content of liberalism itself. The outcome of that contest, in Mr. Brinkley's view, left much to be desired. What's more, he provocatively suggests, the resolution of the policy debates of the 1937-38 period, effectively institutionalized in the great upheaval of World War II, seems to explain "why modern American liberalism had proved to be a so much weaker and more vulnerable force than almost anyone would have imagined a generation ago."
Rehearsing arcane debates among economic policy makers -- the kinds of chart-flourishing, number-wheezing specialists known to a later generation as wonks -- tests the skill of even so accomplished a writer as Mr. Brinkley. Yet from the cacophony of opinion that filled the air in the late 1930's, Mr. Brinkley teases out several distinct voices. Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau intoned pieties about restoring business confidence by balancing the budget. Assistant Attorney General Robert Jackson, the ubiquitous insider Thomas Corcoran and a raft of eager young men, many of them proteges of the Harvard law professor Felix Frankfurter, urged an all-out attack on the allegedly stultifying power of monopolies. One older New Dealer dismissed this crowd as "boys with their hair ablaze." And ironically, Thurman Arnold, the chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, had once sneered at the antitrust statutes as so much "thick priestly incense"; he argued instead for an invigorated regulatory state in which expert bureaucrats would continuously fine-tune the nation's economic machinery. Marriner Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Roosevelt's confidant Harry Hopkins championed deficit spending not just for relief purposes, as in the early New Deal, but for the general purpose of economic stimulus, a stimulus that the private sector seemed chronically unable to provide.
The spenders carried the day, persuading Roosevelt to submit a budget for fiscal 1939 that consciously embraced a deficit for purposes of economic recovery. Roosevelt's decision is usually cited as the first deliberate embrace of the ideas of John Maynard Keynes in the history of American economic policy, a point familiar to readers of Herbert Stein's classic 1969 study, "The Fiscal Revolution in America." Yet as Mr. Stein also points out, Keynes did no more than provide a coherent rationale and a politically usable explanation for economic practices that grew not from the tidy pages of textbooks but from the jumble of circumstance and adaptation. Deficit spending had become by 1939 a virtually inevitable policy, given the demonstrated inefficacy or political unpalatability of such alternatives as the failed National Recovery Administration or a drastic tax reduction -- not to mention the evolution of powerful constituencies whose claims to Government funds were quickly assuming the character of rights. Mr. Brinkley's account expands on that insight of Mr. Stein's and exposes the practical and political logic of the deficit strategy that was finally adopted.
Yet if Mr. Stein found much to admire in Roosevelt's "fiscal revolution," which underlay America's prosperity in the post-World War II era, Mr. Brinkley finds much to regret. A specter haunts this book -- the specter of "planning" as envisioned in the N.R.A. of 1933 and later known as "industrial policy." Though he does not develop the point fully, Mr. Brinkley suggests that when the liberals of the late 1930's abandoned hope for a far-reaching overhaul of the American economy and instead embraced the Keynesian notion that government's principal duty was to protect national economic health by underwriting aggregate consumer demand, they in fact beat a craven retreat from "genuine" reform. They deferred to a later day the moment when state power would have to be applied to the economy in more vigorous and intensive ways.
It is arguable whether that day of reckoning has now arrived. Surely much current evidence, both here and abroad, suggests other strategies for achieving economic vitality and social progress. It is further arguable whether it was liberal spinelessness and the revitalization of American capitalism occasioned by World War II that thwarted the emergence of the kind of interventionist government that Mr. Brinkley seems inclined to favor. As he acknowledges here -- and as he brilliantly argued in his earlier book, "Voices of Protest" -- suspicion of centralized state power is deeply rooted in American culture, and yields but grudgingly even in the face of traumas as disruptive as the Great Depression. Indeed, even the early New Deal, which Mr. Brinkley describes admiringly as "awash in ideas" for ambitious reform, was, in the last analysis, remarkably cautious in its encroachment on the prerogatives of private capital. Given the history of the intervening half-century, who can say that such caution was altogether misplaced?

HEADLINE: Leased-Employee Concept Rides Again

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to "leased employees," Pinkerton started the practice more than 100 years ago with guards that protected Pony Express riders. Yet, it was only recently when the costs of employee benefits and personnel administration skyrocketed, that the Pinkerton man was transformed into an industry called out-sourcing.
"What we mean by out-sourcing is that we take over all the functions of a company's human resource department," said Steven Tessler, head of an employee management concern called Corporate Management Group. "What we do is contract with companies to provide them with such things as health insurance, pension plans, payroll processing: all the administrative responsibilities that were formerly handled by a company's human resource staff or its people in the comptroller's department." 
 Mr. Tessler, 42, lives in New Rochelle. He founded the Corporate Management Group in Manhattan four years ago. The company recently opened a regional office in Scarsdale.
"Inflationary factors, such as the 20 to 30 percent annual rise in health-care costs, has prompted companies to look for ways to curtail costs. Mr. Tessler said that that had contributed to the rapid growth of his company.
"I've been an entrepreneur from way back -- from the days I ran a college student window-cleaning business," he said. "I guess I like the excitement of starting businesses. With Corporate Management, I was lucky in the timing because I managed to plug into an emerging growth industry. Since 1991 we have grown from a 0 to the largest company of our kind in the Northeast. We are now doing business in 23 states for 116 client companies who have a total of over 15,000 employees among them, and this year we expect to generate $60 million to $70 million in sales."
By consolidating small and medium-size businesses into groups, Mr. Tessler said, savings allow Corporate Management to give businesses and their employees the widest choice of options for health, pension and other benefits.
"For example, when you are buying health insurance for 15,000 employees, it obviously gives you much more clout in the marketplace and you can get a better price," Mr. Tessler said. "So instead of having to reduce the health care and fringe benefits, companies are actually able to offer employees more when we act as their human resource department."
And, he emphasized, what is equally important is that it evens the playing field.
"When small companies can't attract employees because they can't compete with the big boys, the Fortune 500's, in offering employee benefits, they lose out."
Although the majority of clients are small to mid-size companies, Mr. Tessler observed that there are also a number of Fortune 500 companies represented.
"We don't work for the entire Fortune 500 company but rather for a division or a department of the company," he explained. "For example, Bankers Trust is a client. And we work for their security division: their bank guards and concierge people and for their infirmary, which is the internal medical division of the company, which is about 50 of their employees."
By eliminating personnel administration, Mr. Tessler said, companies benefit by having more time and energy to devote to their main event and that lets them expand their business and become more profitable.
"One client said that the extra time he gained -- he estimated it at 80 hours a year -- proved to be more valuable to him than the saving he got in his health costs," Mr. Tessler said.
Another client, Yoram Shemesh is the president of World Class Films, a packaging materials company employing 130 people in Yonkers. Mr. Shemesh and his partner, Tom Gessler, have been in business since 1976. It was their controller, Lorelei Koran, who upon speaking to Mr. Tessler, suggested that World Class Films use the services of Corporate Management Group.
Mr. Shemesh recalled: "She said that by freeing her from unproductive things such as workmen's compensation, unemployment paperwork, payroll and other nonrevenue-producing areas that took up 40 percent of her time, she thought she would be more effective because she would be able to devote more time to strategic planning. We talked to Mr. Tessler, and we decided to go ahead with it. A health plan was a big factor. We are able to buy better coverage cheaper with more flexibility, which is tailored to each employee's need."
Although Mr. Shemesh said that there have been no reductions in staff since he contracted with Corporate Management, he added that "staff members now have time to do more productive things."
Stuart Kolbert, who opened Corporate Management's Scarsdale office in January, said that the company had already signed up six clients in Westchester.
"However," he said, "employee leasing is not a concept everyone is able to relate to. We can talk to 100 companies before we sign up two clients."
The prototype of a most unlikely candidate is, he said, "a business owner who is in his late 50's or early 60's who has been running his business for 20 or 30 years." He continued: "The perception of having an outsider come in and take over functions of his company is one of losing control. It's an emotional thing but a very powerful deterrent."
On the other hand, Mr. Tessler said, not every company that is willing to become a corporate-management client can do so.
"We walk away from about one-third of the business we are offered because, basically, we are underwriters," he said. "We have to assess the element of risk because when we sign a contract with a company we become the employer of record. We are the ones who are held accountable if a company can't meet its payroll. So we screen our clients carefully before we take them on."
Companies with 10 or more employees pay Corporate Management 3 to 6 percent of gross payroll in fees, he said, while companies with fewer than 10 employees pay a yearly fee of $1,000 to $2,000 for each employee.
"Their contracts come up for renewal in January," Mr. Tessler said. "And our renewal rate is very high. Clients don't leave us, but sometimes we have to terminate relationships. This past January we had to terminate five relationships. Companies who can't meet our payroll are, to my mind, dead in 24 hours."
Mr. Tessler and Mr. Kolbert met when they were both working for the same employee-leasing concern in Manhattan. Both have strong sales and marketing backgrounds. Mr. Kolbert, 57, a Scarsdale resident, was the co-founder and former executive vice president of RAMS Marketing, a real estate sales and marketing company in the New York City area.
"When I sold out to my partner in 1988, I felt I was too young to retire, and I was looking around at businesses," Mr. Kolbert said. "I happened to stumble on employee leasing. It sounded interesting but too good to be true, so in order to do a little research I went to their national convention to see it for myself. What I found was serious people in a real industry. And I thought it supplied impressive benefits to both employers and employees."
The Westchester office, Mr. Kolbert said, gives the company local representation. "Clients like to see a real somebody," he said.
Corporate Management also has offices in Los Angeles, Washington, and Cherry Hill, N.J.

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS

BYLINE: By Betsy Hearne; Betsy Hearne is the author of books for both children and adults. She is the former editor of The Bulletin of the Center for Children's Books.

 BODY:

IT'S PERFECTLY NORMAL
A Book About Changing Bodies,
Growing Up, Sex, and Sexual Health.
By Robie H. Harris.
Illustrated by Michael Emberley.
89 pp. Cambridge, Mass:
Candlewick Press. $19.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
 
HEARTBREAK AND ROSES
Real Life Stories of Troubled Love.
By Janet Bode and Stan Mack.
158 pp. New York:
Delacorte Press. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up)
 
CHANGES IN YOU AND ME
A Book About Puberty, Mostly for Girls.
By Paulette Bourgeois
and Martin Wolfish.
Illustrated by Louise Phillips and Kam Yu.
64 pp. Kansas City, Mo.:
Somerville House/Andrews & McMeel. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up) 
PUBESCENCE is quirky and unpredictable, filled with individual variations on a universal theme. Too many instructive books for children have diagramed sex and reproduction -- or worse, romanticized those subjects. But in "It's Perfectly Normal: A Book About Changing Bodies, Growing Up, Sex, and Sexual Health" the author, Robie H. Harris, and the illustrator, Michael Emberley, manage to be honest without losing their senses of humor. Ms. Harris's text is informal, wide-ranging and candid; Mr. Emberley's pictures are informal, wide-ranging, candid and funny. No fact or image is too embarrassing for them to take on. If you doubt me, just turn to page 23 and check out the girl looking upside down into a mirror to locate her anus, vagina and urethra -- all conspicuously apparent to the reader.
Other pages discuss and portray different-size penises, different possibilities for birth control and safe sex, and different ways a baby can be born. The illustrations show an array of anatomical shapes, ethnic variations and sexual persuasions. The design is a marvel of coordinated information and illustration. This is cartooning at its best -- witty, expressive and accurately reflective of human antics. Perhaps the closest relative to the bird-and-bee duo who comment throughout "It's Perfectly Normal" is the mammoth who chats to the reader in David Macaulay's handbook "The Way Things Work." In fact, "It's Perfectly Normal" is a kind of human companion to Mr. Macaulay's marvel of mechanical explanation.
One of the advantages of the design of "It's Perfectly Normal" is that the cartoon illustrations extend its appeal to readers in a remarkably broad age range even though the book is intended for early adolescents. A younger child can enjoy the art while a parent paraphrases an introduction to the facts of life. An independent reader in the lower grades can seek definitions of both familiar and less familiar terms in privacy. Preadolescents can test their knowledge against what's so clearly demonstrated here. And adolescents can give a superior smirk while secretly learning what they most need to know about sexual survival in a world threatened by sexually transmitted diseases.
"Heartbreak and Roses: Real Life Stories of Troubled Love" is a book aimed straight at adolescent sexual survivors. Based on interviews with a dozen teen-agers of both sexes, these brief stories describe dramatic situations that developed in their love lives. Janet Bode, who was careful to include a cross section of economic classes and ethnic groups in her powerful book "The Voices of Rape," does the same thing here. Bonnie learns to leave an abusively jealous boyfriend. Louis suffers the whims of a flirt he's fallen for too hard. Pam details her first painful intercourse. Ofelia, who uses a wheelchair, explains how her boyfriend's understanding overcomes the sexual awkwardness of her disability. Kirsten's romance with a skinhead is depicted in the familiar comic-book style of Stan Mack, Ms. Bode's co-author. I would like to have seen a note on how these interviews were collected and how much they were edited (some of the dialogue is fictionally smooth). I admit, however, to zipping right through them with only the occasional incredulous pause. Adolescents' lives often do sound like soap operas; two teen-agers I know consumed this book in the same afternoon.
"Changes in You and Me: A Book About Puberty, Mostly for Girls," by Paulette Bourgeois and Dr. Martin Wolfish (there is a companion volume for boys), did not hold their attention. It's a responsible book, but not much fun. For those who like their sex serious and straight-faced, however, here is an encyclopedic presentation with transparent overlays that would be satisfying if the figures underneath were not so stiffly drawn. The scope of the information is exemplary, including, for instance, information on toxic shock syndrome, douching and pelvic examinations that most girls need to know and may not find elsewhere. Unfortunately, this is offset by misinformation, such as these questionable assertions: "Most girls are healthy and fit and have no weight problems. . . . If people tease you about your weight, then you probably are carrying more weight than is healthy." Or vague information: "Before two people have sexual intercourse, they usually kiss and touch each other above and below the waist." Nevertheless, this book is better than no book. As a 14-year-old once wrote in a term paper on sex education, "It is important to understand what you are getting into before you get into it."

HEADLINE: Access Gets New Meaning In Local Politics

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
A PUBLIC-SPIRITED citizen no longer has to use paper to post a notice at Town Hall, the library or any other public agency. That's because, increasingly, the bulletin board is of the electronic variety.
Want to know the date of the next town meeting? Learn how to compost yard waste? Obtain some assistance figuring your state taxes? Research a term paper? Chat with the mayor? Look up a bill that's making its way through the legislature? You can do it all on line through government computer services that are springing up around the state. 
 A project manager for the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, David W. Chrzanowski, said that more than 400 calls were logged on his agency's bulletin board service in its first few months of operation.
The service lists information about management of solid waste, with tips on recycling, hints on how to make things from natural ingredients and environmental news being particularly popular these days. "The software out there these days is very user friendly," Mr. Chrzanowski said. "To date we haven't had any critical comments about our service. It would be great if all state agencies were on line, be- cause it would mean more people could get involved with the
process."
Stephen W. Lewis, who set up his own computerized bulletin board service for information about the legislature last year, said allowing people to access information electronically would also save copying, paper, postage and other costs associated with traditional forms of disseminating information. With the push of a button and at almost no cost an electronic message can be copied to millions of homes.
"At this time it's impossible to quantify what the savings might be, but they would not be insignificant," Mr. Lewis said. "We could maintain a huge mailing list without any real expense."
"We have in Connecticut a very highly educated, very high-income state, so this would be a natural place to establish computer access to government. I guess it's just that there haven't been enough people in government who have the experience with computers to bring these ideas forward."
But a new legislative task force is recommending wider use of the information superhighway as a way to encourage participation in government.
Its report urges state support for libraries to purchase computers that would be available to the public, that legislative data be made available via toll-free telephone lines and that legislators be given electronic mail addresses.
One task force member surveyed members of the General Assembly on E-mail; 82 percent of those responding said they would be interested.
Richard Ferrari, a Republican of East Granby and a member of the task force, said that disseminating information via printed documents "is little better than scribes scribbling down the stuff."
Computerized bulletin boards and E-mail will give legislators the chance to communicate with more of their constituents.
"We're supposed to be accessible to our constituents, and this is just another way to be accessible," Mr. Ferrari said. "The more information we get out there, the better. It's essential, for us to do a good job, that people know what we're doing and react to it."
Mr. Lewis, the administrator of the legislature's public health committee, set up a bulletin board service a year ago that lists the committee's bills, as well as general information about the legislature, including a list of the names, home telephone numbers and addresses for all 187 state legislators.
"When I first suggested the idea to the Office of Legislative Management, I don't think anyone knew what I was talking about," Mr. Lewis said. "I got them to agree to give me a copy of all the bills on diskette -- if I provided the diskette."
Mr. Lewis set up the system on a computer in the basement of his home. As of the end of January, the bulletin board listed 564 available files and had logged more than 1,000 calls, with 222 active users.
"There are new users coming on line every day," Mr. Lewis said. "If you took that interest and multiplied it times the number of committees up here, it could mean thousands of users on a daily basis."
Libraries have been at the forefront of the trend in Connecticut. The capitol region's Library Council has developed an electronic card catalogue known as Connect, which users can access via home computers or from terminals in any of the 23 participating libraries.
People tapping into Connect can download magazine abstracts and, in some cases, the full text of articles. They can search for books by author, title or subject. Data bases are also available through CARL, the Colorado Association of Research Libraries, which has expanded to 411 institutions across the country.
"From the response we've been getting at member libraries, I guess a lot of people have modems and are using them," said Betsy Wilkens, assistant executive director of the council. "It's exciting that people can actually bring the library into their homes."
The director of administrative services at the Ferguson Library in Stamford, Nicholas A. Bochicchio Jr., said a dial-up service has more than 1,000 registered users.
In addition to the library's catalogue, users can call up back issues of the local newspaper. The library also provides Internet access to three other city agencies -- computer services, traffic and parking, and the health department -- with four more being hooked up.
"I'm not a real techie person, but I've got Internet access on the computer next to my desk," Mr. Bochicchio said. "It's not an easy source of information, and I think that's one thing librarians don't like about it, but there's an enormous amount of information there, and you need to know how to get to it."
Mr. Bochicchio said he was also negotiating with local groups about the possibility of an on-line community calendar, with individual groups updating their own entries periodically.
Schools, too, have been technology pioneers. The principal at Brookfield High School, Dr. Thomas M. Smyth, said a bulletin board operating there gives people information on town meetings, events, meetings of groups such as the Rotary and Lions, and cancellations.
"It's just starting to become popular," Dr. Smyth said. "I think it's the type of thing that, over a two-year period, will double or even quadruple in use. It's the same thing that happened with computers -- there's a lag between when the technology becomes available and when it reaches the masses. There's a learning curve."
And, as was the case with computers, it will be the children who drag the parents into the modern information age, he predicted. Children will get up in the morning after a snowfall, for example, to check the bulletin board for a school-closing message and parents will be looking over their shoulders at the other services available. Before long, the parents will sign on to find out about a town meeting.
Town governments are also getting interested. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities conducted a survey a year ago and found two dozen towns using telephones to access computer databases, or making information available to other computers via phone lines. "And there's been a lot of activity since then," said Kevin T. Maloney said, the group's spokesman. An all-day seminar about the Internet this month was well attended, he said.
The group's newsletter, Connecticut Town and City, regularly lists the way municipalities are using computers for communications.
The Mayor of Meriden, Joseph J. Marinan Jr., has a bulletin board that he uses for an occasional electronic chat with town residents. He said he has filled two positions on town commissions with people he met on line and has received a lot of feedback on the town's snowplowing, sanding and street repair.
"It took a while to get comfortable with it, but there were people right there, on line, helping me through the process," Mr. Marinan said. He has now ordered all town departments to adopt E-mail by the next fiscal year.
"You send a memo out and there's too many people involved -- the department head has to dictate it, the secretary types it, someone brings it to the mail, someone delivers it, then another secretary opens it, and finally the other department head reads it," Mr. Marinan said. "It's too expensive to have all those hands on it, so everyone's going on line. It's a question of getting smarter."
And a regional economic development effort is also under way. The Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a Fairfield County business group, is setting up a prototype electronic community that would offer information on job training programs, venture capital sources and other data important to businesses getting started or expanding.
"We have a growing reliance on knowledge and computers are instantaneous and very powerful in that regard," said Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president of the council. The problem now, he said, is making sure the information is not just on line but accessible as well.
"There are still some people without the capability to tap into these services," Mr. Ercolano said. "There are public terminals available at libraries and other locations, so I don't think ultimately the technical issues have to be overwhelming. It's going to be a question of making sure people know what services are available and how to get to them."
Mr. Ferrari said that as a member of the computer task force he advocated opening legislative data to computer users, but he is concerned that not everyone has a computer, a modem and familiarity with on-line databases and electronic bulletin boards. "I use our computer at home for word processing only, like 90 percent of the people with computers," Mr. Ferrari said. "This is a computer as powerful as the one that brought Voyager to Mars, and I'm printing letters on it. It never even breaks a sweat."
A different problem, he said, is the sheer volume of information now becoming available. "The thing I see as a problem is that there's getting to be so much information out there," Mr. Ferrari said. "This is going to be another pile for people to go through, and maybe people won't have the time to digest it all."
Yet another consideration is cost. Although information disseminated via computer networks is less expensive than sending someone a paper copy, the task force estimated that providing five toll-free lines into the legislature's computer databases would cost, depending upon the degree of public usage, between $45,000 and $125,000 a year.
"The legislature will just have to see if the demand makes it worth the cost," Mr. Ferrari said. "If the public uses it heavily enough, it will continue to grow."

HEADLINE: Word for Word / Pie Fights;
Italy Has Pizza Wars Over Crusts. Americans Do It for the Dough.

BYLINE: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO 

 BODY:
IF you think pizza cools down when you carry it across the ocean from Italy to America, just try transporting a pizza war.
 A few months ago, Romano Fornasari, a Northern Italian pizza instructor from the Associazione Pizzaioli Europei e Sostenitori (the European Pizza Makers Association and Supporters), which represents 173,059 Italian pizza workers, made a terrible faux pas: he gave his students guidelines for what a "true pizza" is, delineating everything from the consistency of the dough to the size and weight of the finished pizza and how it should all sit in the stomach. 
 The reaction from Naples was fast and furious.
 Since 1984, the Associazione Vera Pizza Napoletana (the True Neapolitan Pizza Association) has proposed issuing a governmentally recognized trademark for Neapolitan pizza (something like Italy's guarantee of authenticity for wines, the Denominazione di Origine Controllata, or D.O.C.). But Mr. Fornasari's description was not what they had in mind.
 Soon the fracas spilled over into various Italian newspapers and magazines. Even Antonio Bassolino, the mayor of Naples, was dragged into the fight. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
 In October 1994, the newspaper Corriere della Sera summarized Mr. Fornasari's rules:
 Let's begin with the rules. They have been dictated by Romano Fornasari, instructor with APES, the Association of Pizza Makers. The Pizza "D.O.C.," he maintains, must have a soft border (which in Naples is called a cornicione) and not higher than one and a half centimeters.
 The diameter must not exceed 28 centimeters and the total weight must not exceed 200 grams. "The dough must not be too leavened" -- adds Fornasari -- "because the pizza must continue to leaven in the stomach subduing the feeling of hunger for many hours."
 In the same issue, Antonio Pace, the founder of the True Neapolitan Pizza Association, rebuked Mr. Fornasari, who is not from Naples but from Granarolo, in the northern Italian region of Emilia:
 He would do well to occupy his time with Grana padrano [an Emilian cheese] which he knows very well . . . but he should leave pizza alone. . . . I don't want to hear any more from people, from Oslo or who knows where, who want to teach us our job. We set up the "true pizza" association so that it was possible to establish real rules.
 
 
 
All in Your Imagination
 Those rules refer to the ingredients, to the principal characteristics, and to the possibility of variations that do not conflict with good taste and that pass the indisputable judgment of the technical committtee. But pizza is imagination, not a question of centimeters or grams. And above all it is Neapolitan. . . .
 What's weight or diameter got to do with it? . . . The secret of pizza is in the handling, the dough, the cooking. For example, he does not talk about the oven, which must be wood fueled and must arrive at a temperature of over 400 degrees Celsius, so that the cooking is over in a minute. And then that bit about leavening continuing in the stomach, it's another piece of nonsense. Pizza must be digestible, very digestible."
 That was not the end of the matter. The magazine Europeo threw fuel on the fire by recalling in its November 1994 issue that during a radio interview, Silvio Berlusconi, who was then Prime Minister, had weighed in about the gravity of pizza:
 Foreigners see Italy as the Mafia, pizza, and fortunately, AC Milan [the Prime Minster's soccer team].
 At that point, the mayor of Naples, Antonio Bassolino -- who has his hands full wrestling with one of Italy's highest unemployment rates and with the Camorra, the Neapolitan version of the Mafia -- had no choice but to jump in too:
 What does it mean putting the Mafia and pizza on the same level? . . . The Mafia must be fought, pizza must be defended. . . . It is the most eaten food in the world, a Neapolitan product that has had planetary success, which must be defended from degenerative imitations and above all from mistaken opinions. . . .
 America has its own pizza wars, but they are not fought over crusts. Indeed, no one seems to argue much about the characteristics of pizza, or how they should sit in the stomach. (On Tuesday, the Pizza Expo in Las Vegas, Nev., will honor winged pizzas, breakfast pizzas and dessert pizzas.) What does fire up a pizza war in America is a scrappy two-for-the price-of-one offer.
 The latest edition of "Pizza Today," the publication of the National Association of Pizza Operators, recapped the highlights of pizza wars on this side of the Atlantic:
 Winter 1992. Pizza Hut -- feeling invincible after capturing a huge chunk of the delivery market -- covetously eyes Little Caesars' domain, the carryout, deal-shopper market. To overtake it, the company designs and begins testing what it believes will be the atomic deal-shopper weapon: Bigfoot, a 12-inch by 24-inch pizza. . . .
 Spring 1993. Little Caesars -- always vigilant of every move by a foreign army -- engineers in record time a counter-weapon. Then ka-boom! To the apparent surprise of Pizza Hut, Little Caesars rolls out a pre-emptive strike on Bigfoot. The price of Big!Big! Cheese with one topping is a profit-pinching $8.88.
 
 
 
No Sasquatch?
 Summer, Fall, Winter 1993. Pizza Hut scrambles to blunt Little Caesars' surprise attack and launches its national Bigfoot advertising within weeks. The company commits an incredible $60 million to the campaign.
 Meanwhile, Domino's Pizza tries to ambush both of them with the cleverly conceived Dominator. But, because the company fails to back up the product with a heavy marketing arsenal, Dominator never becomes a major contender in the Giant Pizza fight.
 Spring 1994. The time for the Mother of All Pizza Discount Battles has finally come. Frustrated by shrinking profits and stagnant (or sliding) sales, some pizza companies pull out the stops in what amounts to . . . a fanatical scorched-earth rampage.
 The most notable attack, memorable for its creativity and put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is commitment, is Little Caesars' "Third Pizza for a Buck" campaign . . . an offer that threatens to transport pizza discount into a new sphere -- "buy one, get two free!"
 . . . Summer 1994. Having lost faith in the idea of winning the pizza wars with discounting, some pizza companies begin searching for ways to retreat with dignity . . . lo and behold, they discover that not every pizza buyer is intrigued by cheaper pizza. To the contrary, a significant number of them . . . seek out a better pizza-eating experience rather than a cheaper one. . . .
 Little Caesars virtually scuttles the sacrosanct Pizza!Pizza! program . . . and replaces it with a Quality!Quality! program. . . .
 Fall-Winter 1994. The waning months of '94 see Little Caesars' major competitors stepping forward to contest the company's claim to the quality domain. Pizza Hut . . . announces that "Bigfoot just got better."

HEADLINE: Denver Journal;
City, Fighting Back, Puts Emphasis Downtown

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
From the very beginning, when its fortunes depended almost exclusively on gold, silver, oil and real estate, Denver has been a boom-and-bust town, riding a Wild West economic roller coaster, now soaring, now crashing.
Good times and bad, they always seem to hit harder in Denver. 
 Throughout the 1970's, no American city boomed more than this one, as high-rolling oilmen, land speculators and savings and loans bet it all. At one point, a dozen office high-rises were going up downtown, enough to double existing rental space.
Then, poof!
Recession struck in the early 1980's, bursting the boom balloon, and the city tumbled as far down as it had been up. Things were so bad at one point that a desperate office developer, stuck with a brand-new but ghostly empty high-rise, put an ad in national publications that offered "a whole building" for what it would cost to rent "a closet" in Manhattan or "a shelf" in Tokyo's Ginza.
Now the economic worm has turned again.
Today much of that building is rented. Denver is thriving, its newly opened $4.9 billion airport the most visible, but hardly the only, example of another impressive economic comeback. Fueled by a new building boom -- a good part of it paid for, Great Depression-style, with public works money -- the city's downtown pulsates with new stores, new restaurants, new cultural attractions, even a new ball park.
"Somehow Denver always manages to fight back, only to go down again later and then fight back still again," said Tom Noel, a history professor at the University of Colorado and the author of a dozen books on the city and the state. "We'll just have to wait and see if this particular boom lasts."
Why so many wrenching ups and downs for Denver?
Some people say the problem is greed. They contend that beginning with its founding by gold prospectors in 1858, the city has always tried to make a living by hungrily exploiting every last thing that nature has to offer, from the gold, silver, oil and other resources that lie beneath the ground to the rain, snow and bright sunshine that come down.
Others postulate that Denver's problem is municipal schizophrenia: that the city is of two minds about itself and thus is prone to setting economic goals in conflict with one another. They argue that one moment Denver is reveling in its way-out-West status as the nation's most geographically isolated major metropolis, and the next moment trying to slip out of its cowboy boots and into the tasseled loafers and sophistication of New York and San Francisco.
Still others say that Denver is just snake-bit, a victim of a long string of bad breaks.
Whatever the case, the city's optimism is once again soaring as high as the Rockies, which rise in snowy grandeur on the western horizon.
It has captured worldwide attention with the opening of its shiny new international airport -- never mind the sticker-shock cost and the infamously balky baggage system. But equally impressive, if less noted, its downtown is no longer just another struggling business district, mostly known in the rest of the country, if at all, for the 1890's elegance of the lobby of the venerable Brown Palace Hotel.
The rejuvenated downtown now boasts not only a new baseball stadium but also a new library, a new rail system and a soon-to-be-completed amusement park.
Whole blocks of decrepit old inner-city office buildings and factories have been transformed into restaurants, clothing boutiques, art galleries and microbreweries.
"Denver is on a very good roll these days," said former Gov. Dick Lamm, a Coloradan not known for effusive praise of growth and expansion.
But what of tomorrow, always a fair question given some of the city's yesterdays? Are old mistakes being repeated today?
The proud promoters of the new airport continue to insist that within a few years at least 50 million passengers a year will be passing through the stunning new terminal. But aviation experts say a more realistic figure is 30 million at best, which could mean serious trouble when it comes to paying off the construction bonds.
Housing developers are once again rushing headlong with speculative tracts, relentlessly chewing up huge chunks of the great American prairie stretching eastward from Denver. Only a year or so removed from the latest bout with hard times, most Denverites are in no mood to entertain the cautionary warnings of growth-control advocates.
And there are even some stirrings among office developers about putting up new high-rise projects.
True enough, the huge surplus of office space left from the last collapse is being steadily whittled down. But by just about any business measure, the city is still very much a renter's market.
Denver's economic bounce-back means there are jobs to be had here now. And every week sees the arrival of 2,000 people, a migration that has pushed the population of the metropolitan area above two million.
In earlier days, the Denver economy was narrowly balanced, heavily dependent on a few major job sources like mining, agriculture and defense. But now, at the start of the latest growth era, the job mix is much broader and better balanced.
While the old employers are still around, other industries are of increasing importance -- tourism, higher education, transportation, computers, communications.
"We've got a much bigger cushion now to catch us if we stumble, and that's a very significant change," said the city's chief cheerleader, John Lay, president of the Metro Chamber of Commerce. "We've become a genuine world-class city. Now if we can just find a way to build an ocean."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Denver's optimism is soaring as high as the Rockies as it once again goes through a building boom. Not only is it boasting a new $4.9 billion airport, but the popular Denver Amusement Park, above, is relocating near the South Platte River, where the Denver Nuggets owner is planning a major arena. (Brian Brainerd for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
The Renaissance Banker: James David Wolfensohn

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
In today's Wall Street of 12-hour days and 7-day weeks, James D. Wolfensohn is probably as close as the modern investment banker can get to being a Renaissance man.
A renowned international financier, Mr. Wolfensohn has for 14 years successfully forged his own company, James D. Wolfensohn Inc., into an investment banking powerhouse that competes with giant firms like Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, while doing annual business of $8 billion to $10 billion a year. 
 An accomplished cellist, committed philanthropist and student of development and environmental issues, Mr. Wolfensohn, also rebuilt Carnegie Hall, where he is board chairman emeritus, and has headed the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington for the last five years.
President Clinton on Saturday nominated the charismatic and feisty Mr. Wolfensohn, 61, to be the next president of the World Bank. Mr. Wolfensohn, who has involved himself with environmental and development issues for 30 years, was the favored candidate of Vice President Al Gore to succeed Lewis T. Preston, who asked to retire early from the World Bank after he received a diagnosis of cancer in January.
The World Bank's directors are expected to vote on Mr. Wolfensohn's proposed appointment within the next few days, and provided his appointment is ratified, Mr. Wolfensohn will take over the World Bank early this summer.
His anticipated arrival comes at a particularly challenging time in the development organization's history. Its clientele has never been more diverse and complex. It is seeking to aid the states of the former Soviet Union, to insure that fast-growing developing nations do not destroy themselves environmentally and socially in their rush for economic prosperity and to halt the slide in the fortunes of the very poorest peoples in the world, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa.
The 50-year-old organization, which was founded at the Bretton Woods conference and makes $17 billion in loans a year, has also recently been challenged by those who argue that its mission is over and that it has been insensitive to environmental concerns. Those critics, grouped in the "50 Years Is Enough" coalition, were not in their Washington offices yesterday and offered no comment.
All those interviewed yesterday sang Mr. Wolfensohn's praises.
"Jim Wolfensohn is an unusual banker who brings a whole range of qualities that few in the financial community have," said Maurice Strong, the chairman of the World Resources Institute and of the Earth Council, who headed the United Nations 1992 conference in Rio de Janeiro on environment and development. "He cares deeply about the issues of sustainable development and will be a strong leader for the World Bank at a critical stage in its history." Mr. Strong, who is also president of Ontario Hydro, first met Mr. Wolfensohn when the two men worked together at a conference on the environment and the economy in Stockholm in 1972.
Mr. Wolfensohn, born in Australia but now an American citizen, did many of his first investment banking deals in developing countries and is a self-described devotee of the economist Barbara Ward, whose books, like "The Rich Nations and the Poor Nations," dealt with development issues. He is also a board member of the Business Council for Sustainable Development, the Population Council and a trustee of the Brookings Institution, with a long history of involvement in development and environmental issues.
Those socially progressive credentials are backed by a master's in business administration from Harvard and a law degree in Australia. He was a partner at Salomon Brothers for 10 years, where he was head of investment banking and was the firm's lead investment banker in the reorganization of the Chrysler Corporation when that car maker was on its knees.
Mr. Wolfensohn, an open and approachable man, also has a reputation for speaking his mind and working quickly to get a job done, qualities that can sometimes leave others feeling that they have been treated brusquely.
"He's a Renaissance man, with extremely good judgment and great integrity," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International Inc. and a former official in the Carter and Reagan Administrations. Mr. Hormats, who has known Mr. Wolfensohn for 25 years, said, "The World Bank now needs a banker-plus" to run it and that Mr. Wolfensohn is "a superb candidate for that job."
Gedale B. Horowitz, Salomon's senior managing director, said: "He's a first-class person, intelligent, charitable and caring. He's always handled himself with class."
Reached at his Lexington Avenue office yesterday, Mr. Wolfensohn declined to be interviewed until his appointment had been voted on by the World Bank board. His friends, though, say he considers the opportunity to run the World Bank the chance of a lifetime.
Mr. Wolfensohn returned from several weeks' working overseas for interviews last week with President Clinton and Vice President Gore. It is understood that he argued for a proud reassertion of the vision of the institution and its mission, though he cautioned that it would initially take him some time to properly understand the agency and the challenges it faces. A friend and admirer of Mr. Preston, Mr. Wolfensohn has also argued for pushing ahead with Mr. Preston's desire to focus the agency better.
Because of his responsibilities at the Kennedy Center, to which he was appointed by President Bush, Mr. Wolfensohn has been deliberately apolitical in recent years, but friends describe his political views as centrist, perhaps leaning to the Democratic Party.
In Mr. Wolfensohn's absence from his firm, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is expected to continue as chairman. Mr. Wolfensohn succeeded in getting Mr. Volcker to join his investment bank in 1988, persuading him to pass up opportunities to work at the biggest and best-known companies on Wall Street. James D. Wolfensohn Inc. now has 10 partners and more than 140 employees and offices in London, Tokyo and Moscow, as well as an investment banking partnership with Fuji Bank of Japan and Lord Rothschild of Britain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James D. Wolfensohn, the Wall Street investment banker who is President Clinton's choice to become head of the World Bank, is described by colleagues and friends as a financier with heart and taste. (Chester Higgins Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

International A2-9
 
SALINAS SAID TO LEAVE MEXICO
With his elder brother jailed on murder charges and his own reputation in tatters, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has left Mexico for the U.S., senior Mexican officials said. A1
 
REPORT ON ARGENTINE ATROCITIES

HEADLINE: An Arab Ally Has Warning For Clinton

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: RABAT, Morocco, March 12

 BODY:
Before departing for a trip to the United States, King Hassan of Morocco, a pillar of Middle East peace efforts for decades, warned in an interview that the momentum for peace was receding, pushing Arabs and Israelis into "absolutist" positions.
The King, whose family has long maintained friendly ties with Israel and Jewish populations around the world, said in an interview on Saturday that unless peace efforts move ahead before the American and Israeli election seasons arrive this summer, a wave of instability will sweep the region. 
 Speaking in his office at Rabat's ornate, Moorish-style royal palace, King Hassan said he would urge President Clinton, whom he is to meet for the first time on Wednesday during a state visit, to reconsider the consequences of sanctions on Iraq and Libya.
"Iraq is a country and a population," the King said. "We must not see only Iraq of Saddam Hussein. We must see the Iraqis of the next 10, 15 or 20 years. We cannot continue to humiliate and despise a people without thinking what may come of it."
The King said sanctions deserved to be re-examined in light of their economic and social impact on the countries and their neighbors.
"There is an article in the United Nations Charter which says that if we impose sanctions upon a country, other countries that would be hurt by that would be compensated," he said.
Morocco now loses nearly $1 billion each year because of the sanctions against Libya and Iraq, he said.
King Hassan, who has reigned for 34 years successfully balancing enforcement of Islamic religious practices with steady modernization of the country of 28 million, said he takes issue with those who characterize Islamic militancy as the principal adversary of the West in the post-Communist years.
Islam, he asserts, is not to be confused with Islamic fundamentalism.
"I have yet to see a militant who advocates Islamic fundamentalism for the love of God. Fundamentalists preach their ideology because they consider Islam the elevator to take power. The day I see a fundamentalist who preaches religion for the love of God then I'll say, fine, let's listen. But so far, I haven't heard that".
He said the chaotic spread of fundamentalism and the sorry state of Middle East peace efforts were paramount concerns that he would raise in Washington.
"For all the parties involved, there is an important common denominator: time. The Palestinian Authority must be affirmed as soon as possible. If we leave it in its present condition, it risks getting weaker. The time factor also plays for the Israelis, who will enter an electoral period in July. And the time factor also plays for the Americans because next year is presidential election year," the King said.
King Hassan said that while he is confident that the "will for peace" that started in Madrid during the Middle East Peace conference of 1991 is "irreversible," but cautioned it could be overtaken by "elements of instability"
"There is a psychological cross-fertilization that must be taken into account. Until now, the Arab world was against Israel because of the Palestinians. As soon as the air cleared up between Palestinians and Israelis, the Arab world took a deep breath of relief. It is certain that if the situation became negative between Palestinians and Israelis, the Arab world will return to its questioning and could revise the situation again. That is why I talk of instability, an instability of behavior, not of politics."
Casting a look at a crisis closer to home, the King said the war between Muslim fundamentalists in Algeria and its military-dominated Government cannot be resolved by force of arms, but only through dialogue.
"It is certain the Algerian drama is very regrettable for the Algerian people and their neighbors and for a certain image of Arabism and Islam."
He also noted, mockingly, that a NATO statement issued a few weeks ago said the organization must now turn its attention to fighting Islamic fundamentalism.
"NATO is a defense organization for the North Atlantic region. I don't think NATO was created to fight fundamentalism, but to fight Soviet guns and missiles.
"Anyway, if fundamentalism has to be engaged in battle, it would not be done with tanks. Fundamentalists don't have armored divisions, they are not scud missiles, and not an atomic weapon. It is a behavioral question, a psychology which cannot be fought with armadas but with other ideas."
Asked how it would be possible to resolve the issue of Jerusalem, King Hassan said Israelis have to give some ground on the ultimate ownership of Jerusalem.
"The Israelis can enlarge West Jerusalem as much as they like, but Holy Jerusalem is something that has been profoundly anchored in the Arab and Muslim world for 14 centuries. We are not claiming all of Jerusalem, but just that holy Muslim part of Jerusalem." he said.
"Now, do we tackle the Jerusalem problem immediately or in a further stage? That, is a matter of strategy. We don't want everything. We want what's ours."

GRAPHIC: Photo: King Hassan of Morocco discussed challenges facing the Middle East before a state visit to the United States. (Abdelhak Senna for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Union and Waiters Face Off in Chinatown

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Beating drums, displaying a coffin and chanting, "Slavery must go," a group of about 200 labor advocates and restaurant-union members protested outside the Jing Fong restaurant in Chinatown yesterday. They accused the restaurant's management of violating labor laws by demanding shares of waiters' tips and refusing to pay minimum wage and overtime.
But the protesters faced equally vocal opposition outside the restaurant, on Elizabeth Street, from about 40 Jing Fong waiters and their relatives. Carrying a large aluminum board to deflect the bad luck brought by the coffin, the workers clanked a wok and serving plates and chanted, "Leave us alone" and "Let us live." 
 The clash reflected the complexity of labor issues in Chinatown. Officials of the Chinese Staff and Workers' Association, which has led sporadic protests against Jing Fong for a month, said they were fighting for better pay and working conditions at the restaurant, which they said paid as little as 75 cents an hour, far less than the minimum, which varies from $2.25 to $2.90 for employees making tips.
They said the conditions were typical in Chinatown, which has only one unionized restaurant, the Silver Palace, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January.
Workers at Jing Fong said they had voted unanimously last month not to join the union, Local 318 Independent Restaurant Workers' Union, because they feared that labor disputes could lead to unemployment.
"The union won't be happy until all of us are out of a job," said David Chow, a Jing Fong waiter. He said the protest had hurt the restaurant's business and caused him to lose at least $200 a week in tips. "The Silver Palace has already filed for bankruptcy," he said. "I want to have to freedom not to be controlled by them. I don't want to have to pay dues and demonstrate whenever they tell me to. By carrying a coffin and deterring customers from coming in, they're smashing our rice bowls."
Mr. Chow and other workers disputed the union's claim that they were underpaid, saying that Jing Fong workers were the highest-paid restaurant workers in Chinatown, averaging about $2,000 a month.
Despite the protest, the Jing Fong restaurant was packed. Customers said they were unfazed by demonstrators outside.
"I would normally not cross the picket line," said a customer who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But I don't have a problem with it this time, because the workers are against what the union is doing."
Neither the union nor the Chinese Staff and Workers' Association would comment. But Stanley Mark, program director at the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund, which supports the protest, said that despite opposition from the Jing Fong restaurant workers, the union had the right to force employers to abide by state and federal labor laws.
The union's latest efforts have also prompted members of the Chinese Restaurant Association, an organization representing Chinatown restaurant owners, to discuss changing their ways, said two association members, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Members met on Saturday to discuss ways to improve working conditions. They have also agreed to consult with the National Labor Relations Board and the State Labor Department to improve their understanding of the American labor law, the members said.

HEADLINE: Failure by Pledged Donors Drains Gaza-Jericho Fund

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 12

 BODY:
An international aid effort for the Palestinian Authority has been thrown into crisis because donors have not honored pledges to support a fund for the fledgling self-rule administration in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
The fund, administered by the World Bank to help cover the authority's operating expenses, has run out of money, aid officials said. The donors have failed to honor pledges worth about $36 million out of $60 million made at a meeting in Brussels in November. 
 The donors pledged at the meeting to provide an emergency aid package for the Palestinians through the end of March. The fund, called the Holst Peace Fund, was set up to help meet the authority's operating costs. It is named after Johan Jorgen Holst, the late Foreign Minister of Norway, who helped broker the September 1993 self-rule accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
The Palestinian Authority has begun collecting taxes in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Revenues fell last month, however, because Israel denied entry to thousands of Palestinian laborers after a suicide bomb attack killed 21 Israelis. United Nations officials in Gaza have estimated the loss to the economy there at $2 million a day.
After the Israeli-Palestinian accord was signed, foreign donors pledged $2.5 billion in aid for five years. But lack of coordination among the donors and Palestinian inability to process the aid led to delays in delivery of the contributions. Out of $800 million pledged for last year alone, only $228 million was delivered.
Officials coordinating the aid effort here warned that the Israeli-Palestinian accord could unravel if it loses financial support. The current crisis threatens payment of salaries to about 24,000 employees of the Palestinian administration, including teachers, doctors and office staff.
Odin Knudsen, the World Bank representative in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, said donors were less eager to give money for such day-to-day expenses than for development projects.
"This aid is invisible, because it shows up in salaries and not in new roads or sewage systems," he said. "But this kind of money is essential because it keeps the administration going. If it is not paid, it can lead to a political crisis."
While the United States honored its $12 million pledge for the Holst Fund, several European and Persian Gulf nations are among the donors that have not made their payments. The officials said the Europeans had been slowed by bureaucratic delays. The Persian Gulf states, which pledged more than $20 million, are reluctant to help Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, who heads the authority. Gulf nations cut off earlier financial support for the P.L.O. after Mr. Arafat supported Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.
Informal talks and a formal donors' meeting are planned for April to discuss outstanding pledges and ways to cover the expected Palestinian budget deficit for the rest of this year, estimated to be $250 million.

HEADLINE: U.S., China Will End Trade Rift

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 12

 BODY:
Ending months of recrimination, China and the United States agreed today to press jointly for Beijing's entry into the new World Trade Organization on a "flexible, pragmatic and realistic basis."
The accords signed here today seek to put an end to the atmosphere of enmity that has characterized Chinese-American trade negotiations in general, and in particular, the negotiations over China's entry into the world trading system. And for the first time since December, the Beijing authorities have given a clear signal that they intend to return to the negotiating table after the collapse of China's original bid for membership in the World Trade Organization. 
 The words from both sides at a news conference were warm and optimistic. Yet few details were offered of what changes China might undertake to satisfy the requirements of the international trade body, the organizational successor in Geneva to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. And until those issues are resolved, many vexing issues remain.
The World Bank noted last year, for instance, that "on average, China's tariffs" and other trade barriers "remain higher, more numerous and more dispersed than those of most other large developing countries."
Tariffs on American cars, computers and Japanese fax machines all run 100 percent or more. China bans all American citrus fruit from its market and has refused to accept wheat shipments from the Pacific Northwest or tobacco from the Southeast.
The United States, in agreeing to sponsor China's renewed bid for membership, also pledged to make concessions that would allow China to phase out some tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers over a number of years under the more lenient rules written for developing countries.
The agreement was reached here between the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and China's Trade Minister, Wu Yi, in resolving Beijing's suspension of a 1992 market-access accord that was to have opened the Chinese market to a broad assortment of American goods.
As part of today's accord, China agreed to resume applying the market-access agreement no later than the end of this month.
Over the last two months, Western diplomats here had begun to wonder whether the Communist Party leadership was balking over the high price China would have to pay as a World Trade Organization member. Under the organization's rules, China would be forced to expose its heavily protected domestic industries to competition from Western and Japanese goods, while at the same time opening foreign markets for its products.
The United States Ambassador to China, J. Stapleton Roy, recently told analysts with the American Embassy here that Prime Minister Li Peng seemed to be signaling a leadership decision when he departed from the prepared text of a speech to the National People's Congress on March 5. In the original text, Mr. Li said China was "willing" to join the World Trade Organization, but in delivering the speech, he changed the wording to say that China "should" join the group.
An American trade official said today that "a date has not been set yet" for new negotiations in Geneva, "but I would assume it would be relatively soon."
Under the eight-point accord, the United States would in some cases grant China the special developing-nation exemptions that allow it to phase out trade barriers over a number of years. But Washington would insist that Beijing drop some trade barriers more quickly, using timetables required of more advanced industrial nations.
An American official said this would be a hybrid formula that would look at China's demands for exemptions issue by issue.
China's insistence on being granted exemptions as a developing nation was the most contentious aspect of the eight-month negotiations last year that ended in China's failure to become a founding member of the World Trade Organization on Jan. 1.
But today, even that was glossed over in the agreement, which says that the United States would support China's entry "as a founding member."
Further, "the United States and China will pursue China's W.T.O. accession talks on a flexible, pragmatic basis, and agree to address realistically the issue of China's developing-country status" under the trade organization's guidelines.
In his statement, Mr. Kantor said he and the Chinese Trade Minister "agreed that both countries, in negotiations at all levels, will exhibit a positive attitude in recognition of our growing relationship."
Under the agreement, China pledged to base any restrictions on American agricultural products on "sound science." By agreeing to conduct specific tests and risk analyses, Beijing would be expected to end its ban on American citrus fruit out of fear that the Mediterranean fruit fly, recently re-emerged in Southern California, could be transported to China.
"That is not based on sound science," an American official said today. "That's a market barrier that's unfair."
Mr. Kantor came here for the formal signing of an agreement to end Chinese piracy of copyrighted American music, videos and other intellectual property, ending a dispute that nearly erupted into a trade war last month. In his statement, he said he had also won Chinese consent to pursue greater market access for American telecommunications and insurance companies.
Mr. Kantor, making his first trip to China, "will personally be involved with a review of all relevant proposals as regards the W.T.O. accession of China," the accord said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: China's Trade Minister, Wu Yi, in an expansive moment, as she welcomed the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, to negotiations at the Chinese Trade Ministry in Beijing yesterday. They agreed to end several months of trade friction between their countries. (Reuters) (pg. D8)
