HEADLINE: TOP FED OFFICIALS NOT ENTHUSIASTIC FOR HIGHER RATES

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Senior Federal Reserve officials are expressing little enthusiasm for raising interest rates further despite sharp recent declines in the dollar and in the unemployment rate, which have created some pressure for another increase.
Four of the Federal Reserve Board's seven governors, in interviews on Friday, said they thought the American economy was slowing to a point of steady, sustainable growth with moderate inflation. At the same time, they discounted the warnings of some economists that the central bank's seven interest rate increases over the last 13 months might brake growth so drastically that the economy would fall into a recession. 
 "There are signs of a slowing down, but it's a slowing down in the rate of growth -- it's not the kind of slowing down that says you're in a nose dive," said John P. LaWare, one of the Federal Reserve governors.
The question of interest rate increases was reopened last week when the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, hinted that he might consider raising rates if the dollar's fall threatened to increase inflation.
Any such interest rate increase would be a departure from the Federal Reserve's traditional practice of paying little heed to currency values in deciding on interest rates. Many analysts and economists took the comment at the time as a sign that the central bank suddenly found itself faced by new and conflicting international demands just when it thought it had adequately moderated economic growth by pushing rates higher.
All four governors interviewed declined to discuss the dollar in specific terms. Mr. LaWare did say that he doubted a low dollar would increase exports so much that overstretched factories would raise prices, feeding inflation. .
While three of the seven Federal Reserve governors were not available, the tenor of the comments of the other four about the domestic economy supported the view that Mr. Greenspan's remarks on Wednesday were not a threat to raise rates soon but an effort to stop the dollar's slide by nudging currency traders to stop selling dollars and start investing in the United States in hope of higher returns here.
Mr. Greenspan's comments on Wednesday represented a subtle shift in tone from his Congressional testimony two weeks earlier. Mr. LaWare and the other governors interviewed all echoed the gist of Mr. Greenspan's earlier testimony: Enough drag has already been put on the economy to slow it from last year's overheated growth, and there is no sign that the Federal Reserve applied the brake too heavily.
The problem with this stance is that it has unnerved currency traders, who sent the dollar plunging to record lows against the German mark and Japanese yen early last week.
Mr. LaWare, however, defended Mr. Greenspan's original testimony two weeks ago. Federal Reserve officials should not "ignore what we think is going on in the economy and continue to indicate we're on a path of tightening simply because some external factor is soft," he said.
Federal Reserve officials are reluctant to respond to short-term problems like the dollar in part because changes in interest rates can take nine months or more to affect the economy. Federal Reserve officials make policy changes based on their forecasts of the economy's future health.
"I think that we all recognize that monetary policy acts with a lag, and we have to build some of that into our thinking," said Susan M. Phillips, another governor. "Recognizing that we've got these lags, I think there's still a sense that there are more of these effects in the pipeline" from interest rate increases over the last year.
To be sure, the Federal Reserve's calculations could change in a hurry should there be an unexpected shift in the economy's fortunes or a plunge in financial markets. Janet L. Yellen, another Federal Reserve governor, was particularly guarded on Friday. "We've seen some signs of a moderation of growth, but it's too soon to make a call on what's happening and the employment reports remain confusing," she said.
The bond and stock markets interpreted Friday's report of falling unemployment by concentrating on underlying signs of an economic slowdown and then rallying strongly. Federal Reserve officials also said they looked at the details of the unemployment report on Friday and found few signs in them of inflation pressures.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, was chatting in his office with a visitor Friday morning when he abruptly realized that his copy of the unemployment report must have arrived. Returning from his secretary's office with the document, he plunked himself down in a green-and-red-striped easy chair next to an unlit black marble fireplace and began reading the key statistics aloud.
He started with the 318,000 new jobs that the American economy produced in February. He only briefly mentioned the fall in the unemployment rate to 5.4 percent in February from 5.7 percent in January. But he really stopped and took notice of a figure that many Wall Street analysts initially played down on Friday: the average length of the workweek, which fell by 24 minutes, to 34.5 hours.
"What I personally tend to look at is the index of weekly hours -- it's just me -- and it's down," suggesting that the economy cannot be growing that strongly, Mr. Lindsey said.
Employers tend to hire more workers when their existing workers are putting in long weeks and earning a lot of overtime. A shortening of the average workweek means that employers may feel less pressure to hire more workers in the coming months -- an early signal of a slowing economy.
Shorter workweeks also tend to mean that people are producing fewer goods and services.
Mr. LaWare cited other evidence of weakening economic growth. "Auto sales are off a little bit, and production schedules have been cut back," he said. "Housing starts and permits are down somewhat, at least for one month. One month does not a trend make, by a long shot, but we're seeing purchasing agents indicating that the order flows are not as heavy as they were, and the order books are a little thinner. Retail sales have not been anything that you could describe as exuberant. There are just a lot of little things like that, that add up to a slowing down."
Yet the central bank's reluctance to continue raising interest rates is proving difficult for Federal Reserve officials to explain to financial markets and politicians alike.
The Federal Reserve raised rates repeatedly last year even as inflation was falling. That angered Main Street but delighted inflation-wary investors on Wall Street.
Now Federal Reserve officials are inclined to hold rates steady, and perhaps reduce them eventually, even as inflation may rise this spring. That may not please Wall Street but is also unlikely to mollify Main Street businesses, like car manufacturers who are continuing to lose sales because of rising interest rates on car loans.
Mr. Greenspan tried to explain some of this in his testimony before Congress two weeks ago, but ended up contributing to the dollar's plunge.
"Because the effects of monetary policy are felt only slowly and with a lag," he said then, "policy will have a better chance of contributing to meeting the nation's macroeconomic objectives if we look forward as we act -- however indistinct our view of the road ahead. Thus, over the past year we have firmed policy to head off inflation pressures not yet evident in the data. Similarly, there may come a time when we hold our policy stance unchanged, or even ease, despite adverse price data, should we see signs that underlying forces are acting ultimately to reduce inflation pressures."
But when the dollar subsequently began to plunge on March 2 in response to the Senate defeat of the balanced budget amendment, some traders cited the use of the word "ease" as reducing the incentive to hold dollars. The Senate defeat was widely interpreted by foreign traders as a signal of weak resolve by the United States to reduce its budget deficit, although Democrats and Republicans criticized this view as inaccurate.
The four governors who were interviewed represent a full range of views at the Federal Reserve and had all coincidentally agreed early last week to interviews on Friday. The other three governors are Mr. Greenspan, Alan S. Blinder and Edward W. Kelley Jr.
The seven governors decide interest rate policy together with the presidents of 5 of the 12 Federal Reserve regional banks. They meet eight times a year; the next meeting is scheduled for March 28.

HEADLINE: New York City Stops Foreclosing on Tax-Delinquent Buildings

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Overwhelmed by the expensive task of managing thousands of dilapidated apartment buildings that have become the city's property because their owners failed to pay property taxes, New York City has quietly halted the process of foreclosing on any more buildings.
Officials say that the city -- which in the last two decades has become the largest landlord in the five boroughs and a powerful force in maintaining the housing stock in poor neighborhoods -- simply cannot afford to keep playing this role. 
 The city now spends at least $220 million a year managing the 3,000 occupied buildings it already owns. It has not taken a property in foreclosure since 1993, according to the Department of Finance, the city agency responsible for assessing and collecting taxes.
City officials say they are looking for alternatives to foreclosure that might include a variety of programs to help prop up landlords who are having trouble paying their taxes, as well as new programs to return the city-owned buildings to private landlords.
"Our focus has been on trying to find long-term solutions to some of these problems," said Deborah Wright, Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which manages nearly 30,000 units the city owns. "By that I mean, how do we reform our strategy so we can protect the existing tenants and get buildings out to private hands and have them remain there?"
City officials and housing experts agree that the heart of the city's problem is that many of its poorest tenants cannot pay rents that support the cost of the buildings. The city's seizure of buildings in the past has in essence been a housing subsidy for the poor, as the city holds onto buildings that would not be financially feasible for another landlord to run.
Now, city officials are trying to come up with alternatives that might be less expensive. But city officials say such proposals could take months to form.
The cost of managing the housing has grown steadily over the last decade, from about $180 million in 1986 to $220 million this year. City officials fear contributions from Washington, which now account for nearly two-thirds of the cost, are unlikely to increase and may well decline.
New York is not alone in foreclosing on owners who do not pay their property taxes. If the owners make no attempt to reclaim them, most cities auction off these buildings. But in New York, although many tax-foreclosed properties do end up on the auction block, there are few takers for large apartment buildings where tenants do not cover expenses.
Advocates for both low-income tenants and landlords in New York have suggested many ideas for changing the system. Some say the city needs to consider a taxing policy that takes into account the ability of the buildings tenants to pay rent.
Others say the city could ease the impact of recent increases through lower water and sewer charges. Still others say that the city needs to approach landlords who fail to pay their taxes much more quickly, before the building falls into disrepair. Currently, a notice of foreclosure is filed when a property is 12 months behind if its annual tax bill is $2,750 or more. Owners then have up to two years or more to rescue their properties before the city takes title.
As the process wears on, buildings usually deteriorate rapidly because no maintenance is being done. This means the city faces huge costs when it does take over the building.
Landlords in particular say that the city's rent control laws, which prevent steep increases in rents, need to be abolished.
"It's not a question of owners walking away from their responsibility," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlord advocacy organization. "Most owners are falling behind for legitimate reasons. They cannot afford to operate their buildings at rent levels over which they have little control."
City officials say they realize that they cannot simply eliminate foreclosures, but they have no timetable yet for resuming them.
Critics of the city's "unofficial moratorium" on foreclosures say that even a short-term moratorium on the current backlog of foreclosures means that thousands of apartments in the city are getting only emergency maintenance right now, like repairing broken boilers on freezing days.
"The cost of managing these buildings is huge," said Frank P. Barconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit research organization. But he said that when the city delays foreclosures, it makes it harder and harder for some building owners to catch up eventually on their payments. "For these landlords, the hole is getting deeper. When landlords lose their buildings, the tenants suffer."
Moreover, since tax policy must by law be equitable, the city has made no attempt to take over the more valuable properties that could have been auctioned and gone back on the tax rolls.
At the end of fiscal year 1994, tax-delinquent owners for all categories of properties, including commercial buildings and single-family homes, owed a total of $403.4 million in back taxes. Property taxes represent about 43 percent of all the city's tax revenues. The Department of Finance projects that property taxes will bring in nearly $7.4 billion this fiscal year.
The city has not always been a red-ink landlord of such a huge number of apartment buildings. After taking over and managing buildings as an antidote to widespread abandonment in some neighborhoods in the 1960's and 70's, the city made significant progress in cutting the number of apartment buildings it held from the mid to late 1980's.
But the early 1990's, when the economy soured, introduced a new wave of abandonment. In 1988 the city filed foreclosure proceedings against 6,609 property owners. By 1993 the number of foreclosure filings was 18,003.
At the same time, fewer landlords were trying to get their property back. In 1988, for example, 6,021 delinquent owners retrieved their properties. But in 1993, only 5,816 owners saved their buildings.
Officials are not sure exactly how many buildings the city would have seized if the foreclosure process had proceeded, but in 1993 it took in 397 buildings and still is responsible for 75 of them.
Exactly how much it costs to run the city's thousands of buildings is still in question. City officials have asked Arthur Andersen & Company, an accounting firm serving as a pro bono consultant, to determine the "real" costs to the city of its housing management responsibility.
Ms. Wright said the cost of managing and upgrading the housing that has come into city hands reaches beyond what the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development spends.
"The real cost to the city of being in this position is not really known," said Ms. Wright. "There are lost taxes and water and sewer charges, the cost of liability of ownership, and the interest the city pays on the debt we take to cover the cost of management."
"We don't want to send the signal that you don't have to pay taxes," said Ms. Wright, "We believe that it is just a small number of landlords who are trying to get around the system. Most tax-delinquent owners are having real problems meeting their expenses."
Any efforts to change the system, experts say, would have to be carefully constructed to keep landlords who don't need such help from abusing the system.
Some housing advocates say any new housing policy must take into consideration the poverty of tenants in these buildings.
"I don't disagree that part of the solution is in private ownership," said David R. Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society, a housing, health and education advocacy group for the poor. "But the conservatives are right in that you cannot play with the economics of the situation. Poor people just do not have the incomes to pay rents high enough to make these buildings profitable to many private owners."
"Whatever policy changes are made," Mr. Jones said, "must be realistic about what people can pay. When poor people lose their housing options , you raise the number of homeless. One way or another, the city will pay the cost."

HEADLINE: Christopher Recuses Himself On Conoco's Iranian Oil Deal

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 12

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that he has withdrawn from policy discussions on a sensitive oil deal between Conoco Inc. and Iran because his former law firm is representing the American company.
Mr. Christopher told reporters en route to Saudi Arabia that he decided to take "a very conservative position" after the State Department informed him last week that Conoco had retained O'Melveny & Myers, the Los Angeles-based law firm where he had been chairman. 
 Thomas E. Donilon, Mr. Christopher's chief of staff and a former partner at the firm, has also recused himself.
"In conflict of interest matters I think you have to take a conservative position," Mr. Christopher said. "I will not be stepping out of Iran policy by any means."
President Clinton and his advisers were stunned last week when they learned that the Houston-based oil company had clinched a deal to develop two huge offshore oil and gas fields in the Persian Gulf, a senior Administration official said.
In recent months, Conoco had informed the American Consul General in Dubai in vague terms of its negotiations with Iran, but American officials did not take the talks seriously, assuming Iran could not afford such a contract.
The Administration did not learn that the oil company had retained the law firm until Thursday when Conoco representatives came to discuss the deal with the State Department, an Administration official said.
A lawyer familar with the deal said today that O'Melveny & Myers had represented Conoco Inc. for several years on a variety of foreign and domestic matters. He said it was one of several outside counsels working for Conoco and said that the firm had intended to inform Mr. Christopher before the deal was announced, but that the news was made public before the Secretary had been told.

 Mr. Christopher said he has an ongoing association with the firm because of his retirement benefits.
News of the deal has pushed the Administration to speed up a review of its policy toward Iran, and various agencies have prepared papers laying out options ranging from largely symbolic steps to an executive order imposing a total unilateral ban on trade with Iran.
Mr. Christopher has taken a tough line against Iran, because of its support for terrorism and its determination to build a nuclear weapon.
His absence in discussions of the oil deal will deprive the Administration of Iran's harshest critic. Officials traveling with Mr. Christopher deny that Conoco intentionally sought to weaken the Administration's arguments against the deal by cutting out Mr. Christopher.
In recent months, Mr. Christopher has told aides that he is increasingly uncomfortable with the policy that allows American oil companies to buy Iranian oil and sell it abroad and allows Iran to buy an array of nonlethal items from the United States.
That inconsistency has made it difficult for Mr. Christopher to persuade allies to block investments, loans and credits to Iran.
The deal is particularly worrisome for the Administration because it means that for the first time since Iran's revolution 16 years ago, a major American company is willing to invest huge sums of money in Iran's faltering economy and that Iran is willing to work on a major joint project with an American firm.
The contract with Iran, which was signed by a Dutch affiliate, Conoco Iran N.V., does not violate American law because none of the oil and natural gas is to be brought to the United States.

HEADLINE: Gore Says U.S. Will Shift More Foreign Aid to Private Groups

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, March 12

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, speaking today at the close of a United Nations conference on poverty, said that within five years the Administration plans to channel nearly half its foreign aid through private organizations rather than governments.
The United States will also increase support to projects that decentralize political power and give more authority to local communities in developing nations, Mr. Gore said at the World Summit on Social Development, which was attended by more than 120 world leaders. 
 Both steps, part of what the Administration is calling its New Partnerships Initiative, respond to critics of foreign assistance who say that millions of dollars are squandered by inefficient or corrupt governments. The policies are also in line with a growing perception that private aid groups, both American and foreign, are better able to identify needs and deliver help.
Mr. Gore acknowledged that this is a difficult time for spending on social development at home and abroad, but said that Washington was not withdrawing from the world. In the debate on foreign policy, he said, what is being tested is "whether we will step back from the front ranks of nations that recognize a bond of shared responsibility toward men and women elsewhere in the world who are struggling to climb by their own efforts out of degradation and despair."
"I believe that at the end of the day, the United States will not step back," he said. "The Clinton Administration believes that in its commitment to remain engaged, we have the support of the vast majority of the American people in both our major political parties."
A few hours after Mr. Gore's speech, the United Nations Development Program stopped its "poverty clock," which calculated the number of children born into families around the world earning a dollar a day or less. The tally was 598,070 babies born since the clock started on March 3, when delegates at a parallel forum for nongovernmental groups began to gather in Copenhagen.
"We have turned off the display, but of course the clock ticks on," said James Gustave Speth, administrator of the development program. More than a billion of the world's 5.7 billion people live in absolute poverty, according to the United Nations.
Mr. Gore -- who did not refer to reforming the United Nations as American officials here thought he would -- spoke on the same day that President Nelson Mandela of South Africa made a plea to world leaders that the African continent should not be allowed to be "marginalized" further by denying Africans the right to a voice in a choice of assistance and by withholding advanced technology from Africans.
Mr. Mandela said, "It is to perpetuate difficulties of the South for the North to relate to us as consumers of arms and finished goods, as passive recipients of project assistance without transfer of skills and technology, as hapless victims to dictate to regarding loans and employment of aid."
President Fidel Castro of Cuba also spoke today, and his was an address full of bitterness about a world living under "the blind and cruel laws of the market." He spoke of a "criminal blockade" to which Cuba is subjected "only because it does not share the ideas of its powerful neighbor to the north."
Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia gave an address more sorrowful than hopeful on a day when many world leaders congratulated themselves on completing a conference that "puts people first."
"A distinguished speaker said that we must put children first," Mr. Silajdzic said. "We in Bosnia wonder if we have any children left. Seventeen thousand children have been killed in Bosnia in the last three years. Those living, some with gray hair and eyes and hearts of old men, are hardly children any more."
In the United States, the Agency for International Development, which directs about $9 billion in nonmilitary aid programs, has already moved toward greater cooperation with private organizations. Two years ago, 17 percent of aid was delivered through private groups. The Clinton Administration has increased that to nearly 30 percent, according to agency officials in Washington. Mr. Gore raised the target today.
"Under this initiative, the United States Agency for International Development will be channeling 40 percent of its development assistance through nongovernmental organizations, both U.S.-based and indigenous," Mr. Gore said. In addition to fostering local government, the money would go to aiding economic growth at the grass-roots level, he said.
"The New Partnerships Initiative has three main objectives: to empower small businesses and entrepreneurs to drive economic growth, to strengthen the role of nongovernmental organizations in development programs and to help nations bolster democracy at the local level," he said.
"Families and individuals, when given the power and opportunity to change their lives, do exactly that," he said.
As the conference drew to a close today, Juan Somavia, Chile's delegate to the United Nations and the originator of the conference, known as the Social Summit, was optimistic.
"This summit has put the interests of people back in the picture, and I think it's going to do for the world what the 1972 Stockholm Conference did for the environment and the 1975 conference on women did on gender issues. Twenty years down the road, we will realize that this conference got a process going," Mr. Somavia said in an interview.
"It is also an acknowledgment that the unfinished business of the 21st century is the eradication of poverty," he added. "The century that multiplied wealth, technology, trade, freedoms in the most incredible way also multiplied poverty, and that's completely unacceptable."

HEADLINE: Salinas, at Successor's Request, Leaves for Virtual Exile in U.S.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 12

 BODY:
With his elder brother jailed on murder charges and his once-celebrated reputation in tatters, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has left Mexico for virtual exile in the United States, senior Government officials said today.
The officials said that Mr. Salinas, who ruled until Dec. 1, 1994, and was considered one of the strongest and most innovative Mexican leaders of this century, was asked on Tuesday to leave the country by an emissary of the man he chose to succeed him, President Ernesto Zedillo. 
 Mr. Salinas, 46, boarded a plane with his family on Saturday afternoon and flew to New York on his way to Boston, officials said. One senior official said the former President would not be prevented from returning to Mexico, but had agreed to stay abroad "for a considerable time."
Another official calculated that period as "five years, eight months," or the remainder of Mr. Zedillo's term.
"He was asked to leave," said one senior official, who, like others, would discuss the situation only on condition of anonymity. "Being reasonable, he felt it was appropriate that he go."
The departure of Mr. Salinas removed what some politicians had seen as the threat of a serious political conflict between Mr. Zedillo and the man who had led him by the hand into the Government's upper ranks.
Hours after the arrest of Mr. Salinas's brother, Raul, on Feb. 28, the former President broke what had been an unwritten rule for former Mexican leaders by speaking out bitterly against the Government. He then went on a bizarre, two-day hunger strike, demanding that the Zedillo Government absolve him of blame for the country's economic crisis and for what it said was the fabrication of evidence in the investigation of the slaying last March of a former governing-party presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio.
Mr. Salinas's exit, however, raised new questions about how Mr. Zedillo might face the possibility that Mr. Salinas had played a role in what officials describe as the elaborate cover-up of another major political murder last year, that of a former governing-party leader, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu.
Mexican prosecutors say Mr. Ruiz Massieu's own brother, Mario, who served as a deputy attorney general under Carlos Salinas, altered testimony and intimidated witnesses to keep Raul Salinas's name out of that case. But the Government has offered no explanation as to why Mario Ruiz Massieu might have done so.
Based on the testimony of a jailed suspect and other, circumstantial evidence, Raul Salinas, 48, was charged with ordering and financing the assassination of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu.
Mario Ruiz Massieu was arrested on a customs charge 10 days ago at Newark International Airport as he prepared to board a plane to Europe. He is being held in the Metropolitan Corrections Center in Manhattan pending hearings on a Mexican Government request for his extradition.
Mexican officials say Mr. Ruiz Massieu will also be charged with the embezzlement of some $ 750,000 in public funds. And after the discovery of more than $ 10 million in bank accounts in his name, they said he is under investigation both here and in the United States in connection with a scheme to collect bribes from drug traffickers in exchange for protecting their operations.
Carlos Salinas has said he believes firmly in his brother's innocence. But he made no public remarks about what, if anything, Mario Ruiz Massieu might have told him about Raul Salinas in connection with the assassination.
Government officials have confirmed that Mario Ruiz Massieu briefed Carlos Salinas repeatedly about the case. Given the extreme sensitivity of the case, they say they will proceed against the former President only if they are certain he was involved. Senior officials have insisted, however, that if they have that certainty, they will act.
"There was no deal," one official said today when asked if Mr. Salinas was promised anything in return for agreeing to leave the country.
In a televised address to the nation this evening, Mr. Zedillo did not even mention the former President. But in urging Mexicans to accept the painful sacrifices demanded by the new economic plan his ministers announced on Thursday night, he promised not to tolerate government corruption and he repeated the message he has given again and again since the arrest of Raul Salinas.
"The law obligates all of us equally," Mr. Zedillo said, "and no one, absolutely no one, can be above it."
One Government official said Mr. Salinas and his family had flown to New York on Friday in the private jet of a corn-flour magnate, Roberto Gonzalez Barrera, but that could not immediately be confirmed.
Officials said he planned to go on to Boston, where his three college-aged children were expected to study. One senior official said Mr. Salinas might teach at Harvard, where he received his doctorate in political economics in 1978. But a senior official of the university said by telephone that he had no knowledge of any such arrangement.
Officials at the State Department and the White House said they did not know anything about Mr. Salinas's movements.
Anna Cobian, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department, which oversees the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said, "We don't have any information that a request for permanent residence has been made by former President Salinas."
Three former aides to Mr. Salinas said that while he became the object of public anger and ridicule for his hunger strike, he appeared to be more concerned that he might somehow be implicated in wrongdoing in the Colosio and Ruiz Massieu investigations.
"What he did was to stop the momentum toward something worse," one of the former aides said of the fast. "He hurt the Government. And what he was saying was, 'Anytime you want, I can do it again.' "
For a man who had risen from a narrow election victory marred by fraud to become one of the most popular and respected Mexican leaders in years, it was a devastating fall. In what seemed to many politicians as an almost stingy farewell, Mr. Zedillo told Congress last year, "I follow a President who governed with vision; who with intelligence and patriotism conceived great transformations and knew how to carry them out with determination."
During his six-year term, Mr. Salinas presided over the renegotiation of Mexico's huge foreign debt, the restructuring of the country's economy, and the reorientation of foreign policy in line with the economic and political alliance that ultimately joined Mexico with the United States and Canada in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The morning that the agreement took effect, however, peasant rebels rose up against the Government in the southern state of Chiapas. Mr. Salinas managed to contain the fighting with a cease-fire 12 days later. But he could not contain the political turmoil that included the assassinations of his protege, Mr. Colosio, and a longtime friend and political ally, Mr. Ruiz Massieu. .
After being forced to take steps toward greater democracy that he had resisted throughout his administration, Mr. Salinas helped Mr. Zedillo to victory against relatively weak opposition in elections on Aug. 21. But with his own political future seemingly on the line, including his candidacy to run the World Trade Organization, Mr. Salinas resisted pressure for a devaluation of the peso and left his successor to manage what quickly became a crisis.
Barely 24 hours after Mr. Salinas's departure, Mr. Zedillo went on television to tell Mexicans that the glittering future his predecessor had promised them was no more and that his new economic plan was the only hope he could offer.
After outlining a future of growing inflation, high interest rates, a contraction of the economy and big increases in gasoline prices and utility rates, he warned, "The months ahead will be the most difficult."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Down the Shore and the Hatch

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
It's not even spring, but hotel executives, restaurant managers, travel agents and convention-center directors will lunch today on foods typical of casual summertime dining at the shore: hoagies, soft pretzels, pizza, hot dogs, sausage and peppers. 
 About 400 travel professionals are taking part in the three-day Governor's Conference on Tourism, intended to promote the state's $20-billion-a-year industry. They met yesterday at the Holiday Inn in Tinton Falls. Today and tomorrow, they will be at the Ocean Place Hotel here. Linda Mysliwy Conlin, director of the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism, a sponsor of the conference, said tourism is the state's second-largest industry, after pharmaceuticals. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will present economic development awards tomorrow to 10 New Jersey businesses for creating jobs in tourism.

HEADLINE: Washington Newly Aloof to Its Ex-Hero

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Last year the Clinton Administration was -- publicly at least -- calling Carlos Salinas de Gortari a hero of democratization and free markets. He was its candidate for the one of the most powerful posts of the new economic age, director of the World Trade Organization.
Today, in a measure of how quickly the former Mexican President's star has fallen, the White House was scrambling to find out if Mr. Salinas was really seeking to take up residence in the United States and through much of the day professed not to know where he was. Administration officials said they had not struck any kind of deal to give him sanctuary, but expressed hope that Mr. Salinas's departure from Mexico would help the chances of repairing the economic damage for which he has been partly blamed. 
 "Where is Salinas?" President Clinton's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, asked this morning. "To quote the President, he's probably hanging out with Carmen Sandiego," he said, referring to the fictional secret agent in a popular software program for children.
It may have been a more telling one-liner than Mr. Clinton intended: In the computer program, Ms. Sandiego heads a gang of provocateurs who roam the globe causing trouble, usually by stealing a great national treasure. Mr. Salinas is accused of derailing Mexico's rise toward prosperity, contributing to the dollar's fall and sending a $100 billion trading relationship between the United States and Mexico into a nose dive.
"So it only makes sense," one senior Administration official said, half in jest, "that he is about to become the first world leader ever to receive economic asylum."
In fact, only Mexican officials have said that Mr. Salinas has entered the United States to stay. An Administration official said this evening that Mr. Salinas arrived in Brownsville, Texas, on Friday evening aboard a private jet. The aircraft was cleared on to New York, the official said.
In Mexico City, Mr. Salinas's office released a statement today saying that the former President was traveling to honor commitments to attend various international conferences. "Currently he is in New York, and he will travel to other nations to attend to the aforementioned invitations," the statement said.
The White House said that Mr. Salinas held a multiple-entry visa that had already allowed him to enter the United States three times since he left office at the end of last year. That visa would permit Mr. Salinas to stay in the United States for up to six months without the need for further approval.
Mr. Salinas's relationship with the Administration in recent months has been strained at best. The United States agreed to back him as the first head of the new World Trade Organization before he left office last year, hoping that he would be a symbol of the kind of deregulation and commitment to free trade that Washington wants to spread to other emerging economies. But his candidacy was in trouble before the Mexican peso began its free fall in mid-December, and once the scope of the economic wreckage was clear, there was no chance he would win.
Nonetheless, Mr. Salinas refused to back out of the race until 10 days ago, after his brother was arrested on charges that he had been behind the assassination of a leading politician of the governing party. President Salinas has not been implicated in that investigation. But the delay was damaging to the Administration, reducing its ability to offer an alternative candidate to head the organization. It now appears likely that Europe's candidate, Renato Ruggiero, a former trade minister of Italy, will end up with the job.
In recent weeks Treasury officials have said that tensions with Mr. Salinas's Government go back to last summer, when, according to American accounts, Washington was already issuing private warnings that Mexico was running too large a trade deficit. In Congressional testimony on Friday, Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, refused to say who in Mexico received such warnings, and most documents Congress has requested on the issue are classified.
But Mr. Summers suggested that the warnings were ignored, and others in the Administration have speculated that Mr. Salinas did not want his reputation tarred by devaluing the country's currency just before he left office.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Gingrich Speak Louder on Action

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich agree on what they want: action. It's just that they are so far apart on what to do.
"The veto is a useful device and an important thing on occasion, but what the country really needs is action," President Clinton told the National League of Cities meeting here today. He had just outlined objections to Republican plans to cut some of his favorite programs, like national service, Head Start, school lunches and drug education. 
 But minutes earlier, after addressing the same group with his active plans for cutting red tape and building a third-wave world based on information, Mr. Gingrich, the House Speaker, had attacked Mr. Clinton for a failure of leadership.
"The President has an obligation to lead," Mr. Gingrich told reporters after his speech at the Washington Hilton. "So where is he leading us to right now? He seems to think he's the defensive back for some football team and his job is to counterpunch whatever we're doing."
In fact, as Mr. Clinton's comments acknowledged, the White House is torn between its distaste for much of what Mr. Gingrich proposes and its realization that it may have to accept some of it to avoid the even more perilous prospect of renewed gridlock.
Speaking to the League of Cities, which is made up of officials from municipalities big and small, Mr. Clinton ticked off objections to the Republicans' proposed cuts in spending for programs from summer jobs for youths to anti-drug education to environmental compliance. He is expected to raise more objections as the spending cuts come to the House floor later this week.
Mr. Clinton also restated his threat to veto any effort to relax or repeal a provision in last year's crime bill that would provide new money to localities on the condition it be used to hire more police officers.
"But let me say this," Mr. Clinton said, warming to the fight. "What we need is not more vetoes. What we need is more action. What we need is for people here to behave the way you have to behave or you couldn't survive."
"Half of you come from places so small that if you made people declare their party every time they walked through the door," the President added, "you would be run out on a rail within a week."
Mr. Clinton concluded with a batch of phrases that sounded like a campaign speech: "We've got to keep the American dream alive. Middle-class economics. Mainstream values. Jobs. Incomes. Work and family. We've got to make sure this country stays strong. And I'm telling you, it takes action, not just words."
But Mr. Gingrich earlier accused Mr. Clinton of using too many words of the unkind variety in "a certain disinformation campaign in this city which is, frankly, a little disheartening."
The Speaker said Mr. Clinton had taken to attacking Republican proposals without offering clear counterproposals of his own.
"It would be nice to see the President lead," Mr. Gingrich said. "The White House seems to have this campaign-of-the-week mentality as though this is going to be the longest-running Presidential re-election in history."

HEADLINE: Deadly Rainstorms in California Likely to Be Most Expensive Ever

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 13

 BODY:
One of the most disastrous storm systems to hit California this century continued over a broad front today, causing tens of millions of dollars more in damage to roads, homes and businesses, and ruining crops in some of the nation's richest farmland.
At least 12 people have died or are missing as a result of the series of winter storms that began sweeping off the Pacific last week and have drenched the region almost relentlessly since then. More rain is expected in the next few days, and disaster officials warned that rivers in the region could remain above flood levels for a week or more. 
 President Clinton declared Federal emergencies in more than half of California, making owners of homes and businesses eligible for low-interest loans and other relief, for the second time this year.
Federal and state officials said it was still too early to estimate the overall cost of damage from the storm system, but some said it would almost certainly exceed the $1.3 billion in damages from earlier floods in January, making it the most expensive in the state's history.
"It's one of the most widespread geographic storms in California this century," said Eric R. Butler, chief of the state-Federal storm operations center in Sacramento.
Some of the worst flooding occurred in Monterey County, where much of the farmland has been turned into a soggy bog. Agriculture officials said that the Salinas Valley had lost about half of its lettuce crop and that artichoke farmers had also suffered much damage. Farm officials said that prices might rise for some vegetables, like artichokes, especially in parts of the country that depend on California produce, but that the extent of the effect on consumers was not yet clear.
Monterey County leads the nation in the production of artichokes, broccoli, cauliflower, head and leaf lettuce, strawberries and zucchini.
Richard W. Nutter, Monterey County's agricultural commissioner, said the latest string of rainstorms were "probably the worst the county has experienced in modern times." He said: "It's not only a loss for the growers, it's a loss to the labor force as well. There will be thousands of people out of work."
H. Edwin Angstadt, president of the Grower Shipper Vegetable Association in Salinas, said: "There's standing water in the fields. I haven't seen damage like this since the mid-1960's."
Particularly hard hit has been the town of Pajaro, where gushing water broke a 200-foot section of levee, inundating the town of 3,300 and making it virtually uninhabitable.
"Every home in Pajaro has been flooded," said Joseph Hertlein, a spokesman for the Monterey County Office of Emergency Services. About 10 miles south, in Castroville, state officials have ordered the evacuation of about 5,000 people because of the health hazard posed by flooding that contaminated the water system and disrupted the sewer system.
In the Napa and Sonoma Valleys, where some of the nation's best-known premium wines are produced, thousands of acres of vineyards and parts of dozens of communities were under several feet of water. Many vines are just beginning to develop the buds that will produce this year's crop, and experts feared that low-lying vineyards could face serious disease problems if standing water remains.
Richard Thomas, director of viticulture at Santa Rosa June College in Santa Rosa, said: "The single major problem is that we need to get into the vineyards to start controlling mildew. With all the mud, we don't know when we'll be able to do that."
Farther north, flooding of the Sacramento River in the northern Central Valley caused millions of dollars in damage to orchard crops. Particularly hard hit were walnut, almond and fruit orchards in Tehama County, where trees whose roots were still saturated from the January storms toppled in the high winds. In Southern California, tens of hundreds of acres of oranges, limes and strawberries ready for harvest were washed out of orchards and fields, and wound up littering ocean beaches.
Perhaps the most-urgent worry for disaster officials were the bridges, as the rushing flood waters scoured away the river bottom around the supports of some structures. On Friday night, a 184-mile segment of Interstate 5, the state's main commercial artery, was closed after a bridge collapsed. Officials say it could take as long as a month to reopen it.
On the outskirts of Los Angeles, tons of mud from fire-stripped hills have inched toward the coast, temporarily shutting down miles of the Pacific Coast Highway and oozing into dozens of Malibu beach homes.
In San Jose, the Guadalupe River overflowed and flooded parts of downtown with six feet of water, forcing temporary evacuations of homes and businesses. Evacuees included residents of several trailer parks and shelters for the mentally ill homeless, who were temporarily housed in local churches.
Meg McKnight, a spokesman for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company said the current storm front had disrupted power to more people than the January storms. Since Wednesday, about 1.2 million customers lost power, she said, but most of them have gotten it back.
The worst trouble spots are in Big Sur and the Pajaro area, and it is uncertain when those vulnerable areas will be repaired.
"We have crews ready to go and repair the lines as soon as they can get to those customers," she said.
One of the many weekend power failures in the Lake Tahoe area on the California-Nevada line shut down a pumping station and allowed some 8,000 gallons of untreated sewage to pour into the pristine mountain lake on Sunday.
South of San Francisco, crews opened State Highway 17, the main link between Silicon Valley and Santa Cruz to the southwest. The route was closed over the weekend by mudslides and boulders, but was reopened this morning.
The National Weather Service said that with the ground "completely saturated throughout northern California, rapid rises could occur on small streams in any area of heavy rain." There was also a continuing risk of mudslides, it said.
 
AT A GLANCE: The Damage So Far
 Floods continue to cause widespread damage to northern and central California. Yesterday, the town of Pajaro remained under water. Most of the 3,300 residents, many of them poor farm workers, were froced to evacuate over the weekend when the Pajaro River overflowed.
 Floodwaters covered an estimated 10,000 acres of prime farm land in the Salinas Valley and on the west side of San Joaquin Valley. In the Salinas Valley, one of the world's richest farming regions, about half the spring iceberg and leaf lettuce crop was destroyed, a lost of at least $500 million. Strawberry and artichoke fields were also damaged. Farm officials say the region's broccoli, cauliflower and cabbage crops will also suffer.
 Portions of Interstate 5, California's major north-south highway, and the scenic Pacific coast route, Highway 1, were closed from Los Angeles to
Monterey.

HEADLINE: To Our Readers

 BODY:
Today is the beginning of a new chapter in business coverage in The New York Times. Starting with this issue, we offer readers an expanded news and analytical report on the world of business. To do the job, The Times has added strength to its reporting and editing team. It has redesigned the pages of Business Day. And this weekend it will bring a new focus and depth to the Sunday business section.
These changes reflect The Times's commitment to sophisticated coverage of the plays and players in the business and economic worlds and their impact on each reader's personal financial situation. 
 The Times's business coverage has not had a major overhaul since the debut of a separate business section in 1978. Since then, the world has undergone a revolution as obvious as your laptop computer and as subtle as the three-job worker.
The American economy's supremacy is a matter of debate today. A pension is no longer a pension, nor is a telephone a telephone. And no one is sure what the growth of derivatives will mean: many aren't even sure what a derivative is.
 The goal of The Times's business coverage is to help readers balance the broad knowledge of business needed to succeed in their working lives and as citizens with the specific information that individual financial well-being now demands.
The new Sunday section, Money and Business, will focus on the personal business interests of its readers -- how they invest, spend and earn money -- with more detailed coverage of personal finance, mutual funds, investing, career and workplace issues. Each issue will also open with a cover article on major trends and personalities shaping the business world.
In the daily paper, Business Day has been expanded by close to a page a day and redesigned to give readers a more accessible and comprehensive overview of the major stories of the day and to spotlight a particular idea, event or personality. With one glance at the front of the new Business Day, the reader will quickly be able to focus on the major business stories throughout the paper, whether in the arts, sports, national or foreign pages.
The Monday and Saturday papers will also be special. Starting later this spring, the Monday section will concentrate its coverage on the quickly converging worlds of technology and media. The Saturday paper will give readers an early start on the weekly financial tables.
Here are some of the specific changes that readers will see in the coming week:
THE LOOK The layout and typography have been designed to make articles easier to find and read.
THE BUSINESS DIGEST It will summarize and rank those top business news articles not on Business Day's front page, wherever they appear in the paper.
INTERNATIONAL World business news and stock listings will be packaged together.
YOUR MONEY The personal finance coverage formerly found on Saturdays in the Your Money pages will move to the Money and Business section on Sunday.
TECHNOLOGY The special technology coverage in the Sunday and Wednesday papers will move to Monday's section.
SUNDAY FINANCIAL TABLES These listings will be devoted exclusively to weekly stock and mutual fund performance. Weekly tables for other financial instruments, which have previously appeared on Sunday, will move to the Saturday paper.
MUTUAL FUND LISTINGS These tables have been greatly expanded in both Sunday and daily sections. More qualitative performance indicators have been added to the tables as well as a new format to increase readability.
OPTIONS AND SHORT INTEREST Daily and weekly options listings and monthly short interest lists will be discontinued. There will be a concise daily list of the most active options issues and a monthly list of the stock issues with major short interest positions.
In this new coverage era, some things won't change. Paramount among them is The Times's commitment to give its readers a clear and impartial understanding of the way business works at all levels of our lives.

HEADLINE: Winners of Wireless Auction to Pay $7 Billion

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
The Federal Government completed the biggest auction in history today, selling part of the nation's airwaves for $7 billion to a handful of giant companies that plan to blanket the nation with new wireless communications networks for telephones and computers.
SC.1Lasting more than three months and 112 separate rounds, the auction marked the most ambitious attempt so far by the Government to sell the kinds of radio licenses that were once given away. 
 The Sprint Corporation, which has formed a consortium with three of the nation's biggest cable television companies, led the way by successfully bidding $2.1 billion for licenses in 29 metropolitan and regional markets with a total of about 150 million people. The group won licenses for markets that include New York, San Francisco, Detroit and Dallas-Fort Worth.
The AT&T Corporation finished second, successfully bidding $1.7 billion for 21 markets that cover 107 million people, including Chicago, Boston, Washington and Philadelphia.
A consortium led by three regional Bell companies came in third, bidding $1.1 billion for licenses in 11 cities, including Chicago, Dallas and Houston.
At auction were 99 large licenses to offer "personal communications services," a catch-all phrase that includes a new generation of cellular telephones as well as two-way wireless links for portable computers, electronic notebooks and new information services delivered over the air.
Today's totals put the Federal Communications Commission within reach of its goal of raising an estimated $10 billion in its wireless auctions. An auction last summer raised nearly $2 billion for paging and interactive television licenses. Still to come in the months ahead are several more auctions for smaller blocks of wireless telephone licenses.
But the auction completed today had all along been expected to be the one for the high rollers. Indeed, the bidding got so high that even the Craig O. McCaw, the billionaire and wireless communications entrepreneur, dropped out last week.
Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C.'s chairman, said today's results would be a "triple win" for the economy, consumers and taxpayers.
He also noted that the auction means that cable TV operators might well become the country's biggest operators of wireless communications as well. Sprint's bidding group, which calls itself Wirelessco L.P., involved the cable companies Tele-Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications.
"The auctions just created the single largest wireless company in the world, and it's the cable television industry," Mr. Hundt said. "This is the place where actual convergence between telephone, cable and long distance is taking place."
For all the winning bidders, the opportunities and the risks are epic in scale.
The cellular-telephone business, now 11 years old, has 25 million customers and has been growing at an annual rate of nearly 50 percent. The new services are likely to continue expanding the base of wireless customers, adding at least two new services in every major market within about three years.
But the costs will be staggering, too. The Sprint coalition will pay $442 million just for the license that covers the New York metropolitan area. And it will have to spend at least that much again to build the system and absorb all start-up costs.
Multiply those types of costs for every big and medium-sized city in the country, and today's winners will very likely spend at least $7 billion more before they take in their first dollar of new business.
And when they do switch on those costly new networks, they will face intense competition from existing cellular carriers, which have been girding for battles in their home markets. Many cellular companies have also used the auctions to expand their wireless reach.
Indeed, Wall Street investors have become increasingly skittish about the risks. Sprint's stock has taken a beating in recent months, largely amid concern about its prospective capital requirements. Trading at more than $40 a share in August, the shares dipped to less than $26 by early January, a few weeks into the auction.
Though the share price has recovered somewhat recently, the decline has thrown a wrench into Sprint's attempt to sell 20 percent of itself to the French and German telephone companies for $4.2 billion. That figure was based on Sprint's stock price when the deal was negotiated last year; the French and Germans are now seeking new terms. Sprint's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $28.75, today on the New York Stock Exchange.
Today's close of bids left little doubt that this auction was for big players only. Only 30 participants entered the auction at the outset, and the numbers dwindled to 18 as the bidding grew richer. Though some licenses in small or remote markets, like American Samoa, sold for less than $1 million, those for big cities all drew high bids and intense competition.
Most of the bidding was in line with expectations. The most expensive license in the country was that covering the region from Los Angeles through San Diego, which was acquired by the Pacific Telesis Group for $493.5 million.
Only one license for that region was available, even though there are two for each region, because the other had been awarded to Cox Enterprises as a result of what the commission deemed its "pioneering" technology development.
A similar situation prevailed in New York, where a small company called Omnipoint Communications had been promised a "pioneer's" license as well. Those companies -- along with American Personal Communications, which won a license for the Washington market -- will pay 85 percent of the average bid for the top 10 markets, based on the amount bid per potential subscriber.
The most hotly contested market was Chicago, because AT&T, the Bell company group, Sprint and the GTE Corporation all sought a license there. AT&T and the Bell group won the two available licenses, paying nearly $400 million each.
The next round of auctions, set to begin in about six weeks, will cover hundreds of licenses that are reserved for small businesses and companies owned by minorities or women. Those licenses will ultimately cover just as much of the radio spectrum as the auction that ended today. But the bids are expected to be far more modest because the licenses cover smaller geographic areas than in the auction that concluded today and the Government is offering substantial discounts and financing preferences.
Predictably, most winners said they were delighted by the outcome and that they had not paid too much. "I said three months ago thaat the bidding would be rational, and that's the what happened," said Gary Foresee, a senior vice president at Sprint who was overseeing that company's bidding.
Sprint, which is aligned with both American Personal Communications and Cox, said it could begin to offer wireless service in Los Angeles and Washington by early next year.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Wireless Auction: Top 10 Winners"
The Federal Communications Commission raised more than $7.7 billion through its auction of 99 licenses to offer wireless personal communications devices, or P.C.S., that transmit voice, data, and images over the air. Two licenses were offered in each of 51 metropolitan areas, In New York, Los Angelas and Washington, one license was not auctioned, but was set aside for one of the companies that pioneered the technology. Pioneers will pay a license fee set at 85 percent of the average price per person bid in the top 10 markets.

HEADLINE: Pressure On All Sides In the Battle Of the Budget

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 13

 BODY:
On the airwaves, in the quiet of lawmakers' offices and in rowdy protests in the halls of the Capitol, the battle has been joined over Gov. George E. Pataki's budget and the deep cuts that it would inflict.
With 19 days until the start of a new fiscal year, when Mr. Pataki says he will virtually shut down the state government if the Legislature has not passed a budget, all sides are feeling the pressure. 
 Opponents of the budget cuts, who range from advocates for welfare mothers to public employee unions, are spending millions of dollars for television, newspaper and radio advertising. In one television spot against the health care cuts, an elderly woman looks frightened as she overhears her daughter saying that she might have to quit work to take care of her.
Nearly every day, a new group of badge-wearing, placard-waving protesters flood in and around the Capitol building. Today, a few hundred screaming state employees who face layoffs rallied outside the Omni Hotel here during a visit by Senator Bob Dole: they knew that Mr. Pataki's strongest ally, Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, would be there.
"We want to let him know we vote, and we want to take an active role in the budget," said Cathy Vallee, 35, a secretary with the state.
For groups that can afford the fees, lobbyists and interest groups are tracing Mr. Pataki's political friendships, working his former colleagues in the Republican-controlled Senate especially hard. One health care group sent out maps to each Senate Republican, showing every hospital and nursing home in the legislator's district and saying how much money would be lost locally.
For his part, Mr. Pataki, with the help of the Republican Party, plans to fire back this week with his own $1 million advertising campaign, apparently the first time that a New York Governor has bought television time to argue for his policies.
So far, he is standing firm on his $32.4 billion fiscal plan, the most severe in a generation. But some Republicans worry that the pitch of opposition has become so great that he is slipping in the all-important battle for public support. They are urging him to step up the fight for the change in state government -- for lower taxes and spending -- that he promised in the campaign.
"I think the administration has to redouble its efforts to get out its message," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican of Kinderhook who oversaw the Pataki transition on budget issues. "When people are aware of the cuts and the magnitude of the deficit the Governor inherited, I think most people will accept the necessity of reductions."
Every year's budget brings its share of opposition, of course, and that was especially true during the recession's darkest years of 1990 and 1991. But lawmakers and lobbyists say this year is even more intense because the cuts are so deep and so wide and because, contrary to the perception under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, people really believe that Mr. Pataki will carry through with his reductions.
His proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning in April represents a cut of $1.1 billion, one of the largest cuts in state history and one that would affect virtually every program around the state.
"The intensity is the kind of intensity that generates marches, picketing on the State Capitol, hundreds and hundreds of people walking the halls because you're going after programs that are really close to people," said Robert J. Malito, a founder of the lobbying firm Davidoff & Malito. "They're far more passionate than in the past."
Mr. Malito, who has strong ties to the Pataki administration and whose business has grown by 50 percent since Election Day, says he is a believer in Mr. Pataki's less-is-more philosophy. Nevertheless, he is plowing ahead with his efforts to restore money to his clients' programs.
For example, a new lobbyist with the firm, Tarky Lombardi Jr., a former Republican senator from Syracuse, has been working on behalf of the Home Care Association of New York to restore what they can of the $48 million long-term home care program, which serves 15,000 mostly elderly people in their homes.
Mr. Lombardi met with key lawmakers to argue the program's merit, and last week Mr. Bruno said he expected some restoration of the program.
For his part, Mr. Pataki has been repeating his mantra that the cuts may be painful, but that they and a $720 million reduction in the state income tax represent the only way to jump-start the state's economic growth and to create jobs. Two weeks ago, he filed amendments to the budget but underscored his commitment to his course by changing relatively little, despite enormous pressure.
"We think our budget is a budget that is extremely beneficial to all New Yorkers," Mr. Pataki said after a recent speech in New York City where he was hooted down by AIDS protesters. "I totally understand the opposition. That's the nature of democracy.
"But we think that by making the tough choices and the right decisions this year we will be able to build for a better future in this state."
Still, protest is everywhere. The Rev. Al Sharpton, for example, has embarked on a 175-mile walk from Harlem to Albany to protest cuts to welfare. Students from the State University of New York, angry at what may be tuition increases of about $1,300 a year, two weeks ago proclaimed the death of public education by heaving two wooden coffins into the Capitol lobby.
Their efforts, though loud, may not be as effective as the campaign waged by SUNY administrators. They have refused to say exactly how they would absorb what amounts to a 33 percent cut in state financing, frustrating lawmakers who want the administrators to show exactly what the cuts would mean for public education. Instead, lawmakers say, the administrators are threatening to close four two-year technical colleges, a move the Republicans vehemently oppose, in part because most SUNY campuses are in Republican districts.
In one of the most visible signs of opposition, the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents 265,000 state workers, is spending $1 million on television, radio and newspaper advertisements. Local 1199 of the National Health and Human Services Union is also spending $1 million.
"People are fighting with intensity right now because what they are doing is harsh, is cruel," said Dennis Rivera, the union's president. "What they are doing is meanspirited."
To counter the attacks, the Republican State Committee is scheduled this week to begin its own statewide television advertisements, stressing tax cuts, reduced state regulation and requiring some welfare recipients to work for their benefits. The party has already begun mailing letters to voters in the districts of 20 upstate Democrats in the Assembly. Upstate residents voted heavily for Mr. Pataki, and the Republican hope is that they will pressure their Assembly members to vote for the Governor's budget.
The question is how much the protests and lobbying will affect Mr. Pataki and lawmakers as budget negotiations begin in earnest. Although the budget is supposed to be passed by April 1 -- it has been late every year for the last decade -- today was the first day that the Governor and legislative leaders met to talk solely about the budget.
"They will realize that this slash-and-burn, scorched-earth approach doesn't even work for them politically," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Democrat from Manhattan.
"I think they felt as long as the cuts were in New York City and to poor people they could just turn a deaf ear," he said. "But the volume is turning up around the state."

HEADLINE: Mexico's New Leader Finds Job Full of Painful Surprises

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 13

 BODY:
Ernesto Zedillo did not expect the presidency of Mexico to be "pleasant," he said today. Nor, he acknowledged, did he fully understand the weaknesses of Mexico's economic strategy, the depth of the demands for reform, or what it might mean to be the first developing country to fall precipitously out of favor with the world financial markets.
"I thought it was going to be rough," Mr. Zedillo said. "But I must be honest -- I never expected anything as complex as what we have lived through over these last three months." 
 After a first 100 days that have destroyed the hopes of Mexicans for new prosperity and shattered their sense of the country's political rules, Mr. Zedillo pointed only one way out of the crisis -- to accept much greater economic hardship in the months ahead and to accelerate the pace of political change.
"I know that this is going to be painful," Mr. Zedillo said in a wide-ranging interview in his office today. "I know that nobody is going to like it. But this is what the country needs. It was said that I am not a good politician to put it that way. But some of the most traumatic experiences that we have had in Mexico around financial crises have to do with the fact that people were not told the truth."
If Mr. Zedillo found any solace in his country's difficult economic straits, the only sign of it was in the warning he offered to others. Mexico was merely the first heavily indebted nation to run afoul of global investors, he said, but unless the world faced up to the risks of its changing financial system, others are likely to follow.
Two days after Mr. Zedillo's predecessor, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, left Mexico for what senior officials described as virtual exile in the United States, the shadow of the former leader seemed at times to dart around the sunlit office he gave up on Dec. 1.
For the record, Mr. Zedillo denied having sent an intermediary to ask Mr. Salinas to leave. Speaking privately, aides to the President did not hesitate to contradict him. They also made a point of saying that while Mr. Salinas had sought repeatedly to meet with his handpicked successor, Mr. Zedillo had declined each time.
Mr. Zedillo did suggest that Mr. Salinas's public criticism of the Government and a strange, two-day hunger strike he began after the arrest on murder charges of his elder brother, Raul, had broken the unwritten rule that calls on retired Mexican leaders to keep silent on political affairs.
"I think there was some sense in the country that he was getting involved not only in things that were strictly private but that his comments were having some political effects," Mr. Zedillo said. "The sense that I had was that he was perhaps sad about Raul's situation and that made him put forward other issues."
Mr. Zedillo may have said as much about his differences with his predecessor simply by the way in which he conducted what turned somewhat unexpectedly into one of the few lengthy interviews he has given since taking office.
The meeting had been intended as a brief, private conversation. But in the middle of the encounter, and apparently to the dismay of some of his aides, Mr. Zedillo agreed to put his remarks on the record. He spoke in English.
Mr. Zedillo appeared not even to have thought about the tiny microphones that Mr. Salinas typically pinned on his visitors to record the interviews for prompt transcription.
There were no official photographers, no aides gliding in with important messages. Mr. Zedillo shunned the blue leather sofas in which Mr. Salinas liked to hold court, speaking to his visitors at a meeting table decorated with nothing more than a neat stack of note paper and a small bouquet of yellow highlighter pens.
Mr. Salinas had seemed to revel in the exercise of power from a position that he had prepared for throughout his adult life. Mr. Zedillo, a 43-year-old economist who stepped suddenly into the governing party candidacy after the assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio last March, said nothing to dispell the notion that he treats the presidency as a duty, even a burden.
"I never thought that life was going to be pleasant at the presidency," he said. "Right now, we are basically in a crisis-management situation. But I think that nothing that has happened should change our long-run view of Mexico. I think that is true in the economic realm; that's also true for the political realm."
Mr. Zedillo's asserted that his biggest surprise was the vulnerability of the Mexican economy. Despite holding a doctorate in economics from Yale University, having worked as a senior economic official for a decade and having had allies inside Mr. Salinas's economic cabinet, Mr. Zedillo said he had not been able to see the seriousness of the huge short-term debts that Mexico was contracting by the issuance of government bonds called tesobonos.
"I was not aware, for one thing, of how fast the structure of the internal debt had changed," he said. "I became aware of the tesobono problem in December."
Wall Street analysts say the problem was evident by last fall, when a devaluation was being actively sought by several senior Government officials, including the man who became Mr. Zedillo's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz. But Mr. Zedillo suggested that even a devaluation at that time would only have postponed a solution to the more fundamental problem of Mexico's dependence on huge flows of short-term foreign capital to finance the shortfall in its current account. The shortfall includes both the country's trade deficit and payments on its debt.
"A few days after we devalued, I became convinced that we did not have a classical, current-account adjustment problem," Mr. Zedillo said. But when the Government's first economic-recovery plan failed to calm the financial markets, he said, he realized that the problem was one that Mexico could not handle alone.
"That's when I called Mr. Clinton and told him that this was a very different ballgame," he said.
In Mr. Zedillo's view, Mexico was merely the first so-called emerging economy to confront the growing power and immediacy of global financial markets.
"It is obvious that the speed at which international financial markets have evolved over the last 25 years has been much faster than the capacity of governments and international organizations to cope," he said. "We have a new, global agreement on trade. But we don't have a new financial arrangement. So there's something missing there, and that's very dangerous for the world. Mexico was the first to pay for this problem."
Mr. Zedillo warmly praised the Clinton Administration for its $20 billion in help with the problem.
"I am surprised at the speed with which the U.S. Government reacted," he said, recalling the long struggle between Latin American debtors and the United States after Mexico led the region into its foreign-debt crisis in the 1980's. Mr. Clinton, he added, "was extremely quick to get it."
In a televised speech on Sunday night, Mr. Zedillo offered Mexicans a bleak economic time in the months ahead, with no more consolation than the assertion that any other policy would have more drastic consequences.
Responding to calls for a moratorium on debt payments from some opposition leaders and others, Mr. Zedillo said that in an economy in which trade represents half of all productive activity, the loss of credit lines would destroy the country's financial system. The cost, he said, would be a disaster in which the economy would contract 20 percent within a year.
"We would be talking about losing not thousands of jobs, but millions of jobs," he said.
Mr. Zedillo declined to discuss why Raul Salinas might have wanted to kill the governing-party leader whose slaying he is accused of having ordered, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu. Nor would he say how he would respond if Carlos Salinas were to be implicated in the cover-up of the case that Mr. Ruiz Massieu's brother, former Deputy Attorney General Mario Ruiz Massieu, is accused of having engineered on Raul Salinas's behalf.
Mr. Zedillo was asked if, after 100 days in power, he had gained a better sense of how to handle the political tumult that he is expected to face in the months ahead, partly as a side effect of the harsh economic remedies he has prescribed. He skipped past what many of his Mexican critics have described as a need for more careful political management and went to a broader point.
"Mexico now needs a high speed of change regarding democracy, regarding the rule of law," he said. "And it is obvious what we have to do to make a better democratic system. We just have to do it."
