HEADLINE: Argentina Announces Financing Package to Bolster Peso and Stabilize Economy

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, March 13

 BODY:
Argentina said today that it had put together a financing package that would give it an extra $11.1 billion to back its economy and bolster the Argentine peso's fixed one-to-one parity with the United States dollar.
The package, announced after high-pressure weekend talks with a visiting International Monetary Fund mission, includes a renewed loan from the I.M.F. for $2 billion and an identical amount pledged by local businessmen and foreign banks, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo told a news conference. 
 Mr. Cavallo, who has vowed never to follow the trail of devaluation blazed by Mexico and Brazil, said that the rest of the money would come from the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank and a planned fiscal surplus of $4.4 billion to be achieved in part through more austerity.
In Washington, the I.M.F. immediately praised the planned moves as proof of Argentina's commitment to price stability -- a key ingredient of what the Government of President Carlos Menem called its "economic miracle" until Mexico's crisis shook Latin America's emerging markets.
"We have an additional $11.1 billion that allow us to ratify convertibility, that is, the backing in gold and foreign currencies of Argentina's money, to insure the timely payment of $5.2 billion in debt maturing in 1995," Mr. Cavallo said.
He said he would disclose on Tuesday a series of tax measures that would help achieve the planned $4.4 billion fiscal surplus.
The planned $4.4 billion fiscal surplus is calculated on the basis of a 1995 growth estimate revised down to 3 percent of gross domestic product from the earlier forecast of 4.5 percent, he added.
"But we believe, however, that this is the most pessimistic hypothesis," Mr. Cavallo said.
Argentina returned to the I.M.F.'s coffers after giving up voluntarily last year the last two parts of an earlier Extended Fund Facility worth a combined $420 million, saying it had full and free access to voluntary capital markets worldwide.
Faced with a $4 billion fall in bank deposits since Mexico's Dec. 20 devaluation and a slump of more than $2 billion in central bank foreign reserves, Mr. Cavallo decided this month to draw down the $420 million after all.
Then last week, faced with an increasing liquidity squeeze that has already caused prices to deflate so far in March, the Government decided to tap the I.M.F. for a more sizable loan.
The tax increases that will help produce the pledged $4.4 billion fiscal surplus come on top of a $3.3 billion austerity package announced last month, which included the unusual step of cutting the salaries of better-off public servants.
Mr. Cavallo said the Government, which faces presidential elections in two months' time, on May 14, would not increase taxes on fuels, cigarettes or alcohol but would instead turn to trade taxes.
Argentine stocks surged today in anticipation of the I.M.F. deal, with the key blue-chip index gaining more than 8 percent. It had risen almost 13 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI IN ACCORD WITH CITY COUNCIL ON X-RATED SHOPS

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council agreed yesterday to a set of strict new zoning rules for X-rated video stores and topless bars that city officials say will drastically reduce the number and concentration of the establishments throughout the city.
The new rules, which officials hope will be put into effect before the end of the year, would prevent sex-related businesses from operating within 500 feet of residences, schools and houses of worship and within 500 feet of one another. 
 Together with other zoning restrictions, the rules will essentially limit such businesses to parts of midtown Manhattan, including Times Square, and isolated manufacturing areas in the boroughs outside Manhattan. But even in Times Square, whose red-light reputation for X-rated entertainment is known worldwide, the changes will be profound.
"This starts a new day," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District. She estimated that the proposed regulations would reduce the number of adult stores in Times Square "from 47 to about 5 or 6."
She added: "This is great news. It can welcome back exciting and appropriate economic development on Eighth Avenue."
The rules come in response to the proliferation of sex-related businesses both in midtown Manhattan and in residential neighborhoods where they had rarely been seen before -- places like Chelsea, the Upper West Side and Forest Hills, Queens. In the last decade, officials say, the number of adult businesses has risen 35 percent, from 131 in 1984 to 177 in December 1993.
Yesterday's agreement represents a sort of compromise between Mr. Giuliani, who last year proposed far stricter regulations that would have effectively banned sex-oriented businesses from all but manufacturing areas outside of Manhattan, and the City Council, whose members worried that his plans would push pornography shops to the fringes of the boroughs outside Manhattan.
But in revising the plan to allow some sex businesses to remain in Manhattan, the Mayor was able to allay the Council's concerns.
The proposal must still be reviewed by the city's 59 community boards and the borough presidents. It must be approved by the City Planning Commission and the City Council, both of which are anticipated to do so. City officials said they hope to have the regulations approved and in place by November, to coincide with the end of a moratorium that the City Council passed last year halting the establishment of any new sex businesses while the zoning rules were being set up.
The agreement defines adult establishments as businesses that have "a substantial portion of their stock in trade or materials characterized by an emphasis on specific anatomical areas or sexual activities." It also includes businesses that regularly feature films "characterized by an emphasis on specified anatomical areas or sexual activities." The proposal does not include art schools and studios. Inspectors from the city's Buildings Department are to determine which businesses fall into these categories.
Several store owners were angered by the agreement. Richard N. Kunis, the owner of Manhattan Video in midtown Manhattan and a founder of the Adult Industry Trade Association, said he and the association would take the matter to court as a First Amendment issue.
"Any time the government is going to limit any kind of expression -- especially pleasurable expression -- you get a censored city," he said.
Arthur N. Eisenberg, the legal director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said the agreement left unaltered his view that the regulations were unconstitutional. "The question is whether the city has created alternative opportunities for these First Amendment enterprises," Mr. Eisenberg said. "We think the city's position is vulnerable to constitutional challenge."
Mayor Giuliani said all of that was taken into account in deliberations with the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and other officials. He said the city wanted to have the "maximum degree of control" over how such businesses operated, but "consistent with the right of free speech."
Mr. Giuliani added that "that's a delicate balance and I believe that we've achieved it."
The proposed zoning regulations retained the bulk of Mr. Giuliani's initial recommendations by prohibiting sex businesses from opening within 500 feet of residences, schools, houses of worship or one another. It permits such businesses to operate chiefly in manufacturing areas, as in the Mayor's proposal.
But the agreement would expand the areas in which such establishments could operate to "commercial zones of high density." They include business areas with high traffic and larger stores, including parts of Seventh Avenue and Broadway from 48th to 55th Streets, parts of Eighth Avenue from 38th to 41st, and parts of Broadway and Avenue of the Americas from 29th to 31st.
"The proposal will have a very significant impact on the concentration, locations and operations of the adult entertainment businesses," Mayor Giuliani said at a press conference in City Hall with Mr. Vallone at his side.
"These businesses have a very devastating impact on the neighborhoods in which they are located," Mr. Giuliani said. "These zoning amendments will leave open only certain areas of the city. Basically light industrial and some high-density commercial zones."
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan borough president, responded cautiously to the new plan. "We need to take a careful look at all the maps to understand exactly what neighborhoods will be impacted," she said. "This is a broader spread than the Mayor presented at first, but I still want to see the impact, so that there are not business neighborhoods with excess concentration."
The agreement also restricts the size of the establishments, prohibiting any from being larger than 10,000 square feet.
Businesses that do not comply with any provision would be required to close within a year. However, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals could extend that period if a business can demonstrate that more time would be needed to recoup its investment.
The administration estimated that in Manhattan alone the effect of the proposed regulations would be to reduce the number of adult-entertainment areas to 45, from 107.
 
 
Areas to Be Zoned for Sex Shops
 Under the Giuliani administration's first proposal last year, adult-entertainment shops would have been restricted to light manufacturing areas in boroughs outside of Manhattan and a few small sections of Manhattan, including Chelsea, parts of TriBeCa and part of SoHo.
Under the new agreement with the City Council, these areas in Manhattan would also be included:
*Block fronts along Seventh Avenue, from 48th to 55th Streets.
*Full blocks between Seventh Avenue and Broadway from 48th to 55th Streets.
*Half blocks west of Broadway from 51st to 55th Streets.
*Block fronts along Eighth Avenue, from 38th to 41st Streets.
*Three blocks north of the Javits Convention Center.
*Parts of the blocks between Broadway and Eighth Avenue between 42d and 44th Streets.
*An area between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas from 29th to 31st Streets.
*An area at the intersection of Thomas and Lafayette Streets in lower Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Welfare and Food Stamp Rolls End Six Years of Increases

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Welfare and food stamp rolls, which increased relentlessly through recession and economic recovery in the last six years, have finally leveled off, new Government data show.
The persistent increases in the rolls had become one of the great puzzles of social welfare policy. 
 The last recession ended in March 1991, according to the arbiter of economic cycles, the National Bureau of Economic Research. But until late last year, the number of people receiving assistance under the two programs kept increasing.
Experts say the increases have now stopped for two reasons.
First, they say, the benefits of the economic recovery have begun to reach some people at the bottom of the income ladder. In addition, they say, in the last year or so, many states have restricted eligibility for welfare, so fewer people are entitled to cash assistance.
Whether the new data will affect the Congressional debate on welfare is unclear. The figures may slightly reduce the political pressure for wholesale changes in the welfare system. But the effort to make such changes is sure to continue because Republicans insist that cash welfare programs, in particular, have been a complete failure.
The food stamp rolls have grown by more than one-third since 1990. More than one-tenth of all Americans now receive the coupons. But in October, November and December of 1994, the program showed a drop in the number of recipients, to an average of 27 million, down 300,000 from the same period in 1993.
A similar pattern is evident in data for the nation's main cash assistance program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children. About 13.9 million people received such aid in November 1994, as against 14.2 million in November 1993.
Melissa T. Skolfield, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, which supervises the cash assistance program, said, "When you look at the most recent data, the caseload has apparently stabilized and the growth in the rolls has apparently stopped."
In the past, the number of food stamp recipients declined when the economy was growing and employment was rising. The latest surge in the food stamp rolls began in 1989, before the recession, and it continued even after unemployment began to decline in the middle of 1992.
"This program has gone up when the economy turns down, as it should," said Representative Pat Roberts, the Kansas Republican who heads the House Agriculture Committee. "But in addition, it has gone up when the economy turns good, in an ever-increasing spiral."
But Ellen Haas, the Under Secretary of Agriculture for Food, Nutrition and Consumer Services, said the food stamp rolls had leveled off. "It reflects the economic upturn, the recovery," she said.
Ms. Haas said the data also showed that the food stamp program, as currently constructed, expands in hard times, when more people need assistance, and can contract when the need abates.
The number of people receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children was remarkably steady, around 11 million, from 1975 through 1989. The recession in the first years of the Reagan Administration, 1981 and 1982, would ordinarily have produced an increase in the rolls, but it coincided with eligibility cutbacks, which prevented such an increase.
The number of welfare recipients shot up after 1989, rising by an average of 659,000 in each of the next five years.
The Federal Government controls the food stamp program, setting uniform national eligibility criteria and benefit levels, and it pays the full cost. By contrast, in Aid to Families With Dependent Children, states have a large degree of discretion.
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said, "Many states have purposely reduced the generosity of their welfare benefits, making them less attractive, or adopted more stringent eligibility criteria, reducing the number of people entitled to benefits."
Why did the welfare and food stamp rolls grow so much more than expected in the last six years?
Long-term demographic trends account for some of the growth. The trends include an increase in births to unmarried women. Many families headed by such women are poor and qualify for welfare.
Demetra Smith Nightingale, director of welfare research at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization, offered several other explanations. State and local government agencies have simplified the procedures used in applying for welfare, food stamps and Medicaid, she said. Many states have tried to identify people who might be eligible and encouraged them to apply. When people seek benefits under one program, some states check automatically to see if they qualify for the others.
Declining rates of unemployment insurance coverage have also contributed to increases in the welfare rolls, said Isaac Shapiro, associate director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research and advocacy group. About 33 percent of jobless workers now receive unemployment insurance, down from an average of more than 50 percent in the 1970's, he said. Those who have no unemployment insurance protection are more likely to qualify for welfare because they have no income from jobless benefits and may exhaust their assets.
Changes in the labor market also contributed to the increase in welfare rolls, making it difficult for people with low skills and little education to find jobs that lift them out of poverty. Low-wage jobs are often temporary, part-time or seasonal, so women who take these jobs often return to the welfare rolls. The same labor market conditions will make it difficult for welfare recipients to comply with work requirements in the welfare bill now moving through the House of Representatives.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Up Again as Traders Doubt Rates Will Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for a third consecutive session as expectations grew that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this month.
Recent reports showing a persistent combination of brisk growth and low inflation have generated optimism among traders and analysts. 
 "We have seen signs of slowing in the economy," said Rob Schumacher, who oversees more than $13 billion at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "They're not flashing red lights, but they're unquestionably amber."
The price of the 30-year bond rose 3/32 , to 1013/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 7.45 percent from 7.46 percent.
Treasury notes, which have a maturity of 10 years or less and are more sensitive than bonds to Fed rate increases, gained even more than bonds. The yield on the two-year note, for example, fell 6 basis points from Friday, to 6.74 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Rates fell at the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. The Treasury sold $12.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.76 percent, down from 5.77 percent last week, and $12.4 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.92 percent, down from 6 percent.
In one sign that the Fed may be finished raising interest rates for the time being, the spread between the 2-year note and 30-year bond widened to 71 basis points, from 66 on Friday.
A slowdown in consumer spending and the prospect that Congress will trim the Federal deficit mean "there's a very real prospect we'll continue downward in rates," Mr. Schumacher said. Bond yields could reach 7 percent by August, he said.
Fed economists associate growth of more than 2.5 percent with rising inflation rates, and last year the economy expanded by 4 percent, creating expectations that inflation would increase from the 2.7 percent recorded at the consumer level during the last two years.
Optimism that the Fed is engineering a soft landing -- controlling inflation without causing the economy to stagnate -- is keeping yields near the six-month low of 7.44 percent set on Feb. 28.
Treasury prices gained on Friday even after the Labor Department reported strong job growth in February. The resilience of Treasury prices after Friday's report suggested that any signs of strong economic growth emerging from this week's reports might not be enough to push yields up, some investors said.
A series of strong reports "could help burst the bubble," said Fabio Salvodelli, who oversees $1.4 billion at SBC Portfolio Management International. "But it's a pretty thick bubble of happiness, and it would take a fair bit of worse-than-consensus news to do that."
Top Fed officials say an economic slowdown is anything but assured. The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Cathy E. Minehan, who is also a voting member of the Fed's policy-making committee, said yesterday that inflation could soon increase.
"Further growth acceleration at this point can lead to inflation, as the demand for goods outstrips our ability to produce them," Ms. Minehan said.
Economic reports this week could help Fed policy makers determine whether to raise interest rates at their next meeting, on March 28.
The week's reports include reports on producer prices tomorrow and consumer prices on Thursday. The Federal Reserve will report on industrial production tomorrow.
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Apartments, and Lives, And an Unsure Future

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
WHEN she thinks hard, Marisol Rivera can recall Charter Oak Terrace as a sweet little village, with the brick houses still young and strong, children doing flips off the playground swings, family barbecues on the front lawns.
"It was nice 30 years ago," Ms. Rivera said, standing on a parking pad littered with broken beer bottles. "It was different." 
 The grass that graced Charter Oak Terrace has long surrendered to neglect. A rusted slide and geodesic dome strangled by weeds are what's left of the playground. The barracks-style buildings, built in the 1940's as temporary housing for defense workers, are falling apart, and the burglar bars make them look like prisons.
Charter Oak Terrace has devolved into one of public housing's worst cases. While it is Hartford's largest housing project, with 980 units, several buildings are boarded up and some 300 units are vacant. Close to 98 percent of its 650 households are headed by single women. About 90 percent of the residents are unemployed. Gangs have divvied up the project into a drug-turf pie.
City officials say Charter Oak Terrace is beyond repair. They are talking about demolishing most of the buildings and relocating tenants into a nearby moderate-income project and scattered apartments. The city and adjoining West Hartford would turn the land into a commercial development park for light industry and give Charter Oak Terrace residents first crack at jobs.
PART of the proposal is an idea gripping public housing authorities across the country -- tear down old, high-density, low-income projects where crime and generational despair have taken hold and relocate residents to mixed neighborhoods. (Under Federal law, the housing authority has to replace housing units that are demolished one for one.) But displacement is a scary word. In Hartford, at least, the idea is making the very residents it is supposed to help scream bloody murder.
Ms. Rivera is one of them. Charter Oak Terrace is no place to boast about, but it's the devil she knows. "I was born and raised here," she said. "My grandmother lived here. I feel it's the best place for me. I say don't kill it; fix it and make it safer."
Nine people were murdered at the project last year, including Ms. Rivera's cousin and uncle. They were shot to death in their apartment the day before New Year's Eve, around the same time that two other residents were found dead in another apartment.
Ms. Rivera pondered the reasons and shrugged. "I keep my eyes open and my mouth shut," she said.
Nilsa Ramos, who has lived in Charter Oak Terrace for 20 years, said that minding your business has become the rule to live by. "Once, I saw a guy delivering Chinese food surrounded when he knocked on a door," she said. She did not stick around to see what became of him.
She is raising three children on public assistance and pays $169 a month for a two-bedroom apartment where the walls seem ready to collapse. She figures she gets what she pays for.
"Not only is the place falling apart," she said. "It has rats. Whenever they put spray for them, it attracts more. That stuff is like food for them."
She said she has requested transfers to other public housing. But now that the city is proposing the idea, she doesn't like it. She is skeptical that another place would be better, or that jobs would come. "What kind of jobs?" she asked. "Where are the guarantees?"
It's a good question. John Wardlaw, the executive director of the Hartford Housing Authority, said part of the concept for Charter Oak Terrace is a job-training program for tenants to prepare them for the companies that would move in to hire them.
"We should be in the business of helping people no longer be poor," said Mr. Wardlaw, who gained some notoriety when he hired a gang member last summer to help quell gang violence.
After spending $34 million on the buildings at Charter Oak Terrace over 17 years, Mr. Wardlaw said he is convinced that the money could have been better spent. He blames politicians who he said have a vested interest in keeping Charter Oak a power base, for scaring residents into believing the proposal is to dump residents into two projects that are almost as bad as Charter Oak Terrace, or worse, leaving them out in the cold.
"Now, as we explain to tenants the entire idea, we're starting to see the community get excited about it," he said.
TO try to dispel fears among Charter Oak Terrace residents, the City Council is expected to pass a resolution promising that under no circumstance would a plan result in displacement or undo hardship of the Charter Oak Terrace community; that residents would be given first preference in jobs created by commercial development; that whatever relocation would vastly improve their living conditions; that they would not be transferred to another project without their express approval, and that they would be part of the process.
"I think if we failed with this attempt, that would be the end of Hartford," Mr. Wardlaw said.
But if Ms. Rivera is any indication, the city has a lot of work ahead. She does not want to think about the end of Charter Oak Terrace. Even its menacing aspects don't faze her.
"For me, it's safe because I've been living here so long," she said. Sure, she said, sometimes she thinks she wants to leave, but the thought never lingers because home is home.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Greenspan Calls for a New Panel To Set Cost-of-Living Adjustments

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Reiterating his belief that the Government's Consumer Price Index overstates inflation, the chairman of the Federal Reserve called today for an independent commission to set new cost-of-living adjustments for income taxes and benefit programs like Social Security that are pegged to the index.
Roughly 30 percent of all Federal spending is pegged to the Consumer Price Index and rises with it. Personal income taxes account for 45 percent of Federal revenues and the brackets for them are also linked to the price index. 
 Because the index appears to exaggerate actual increases in the cost of living in the United States, Mr. Greenspan said, benefit programs like Social Security overcompensate recipients for inflation, while taxes are collected at artificially low rates. "For purposes of indexation of Federal programs, the C.P.I. should be a starting point, but it shouldn't be the end," he added.
The index is calculated by the Labor Department. Mr. Greenspan did not say who should serve on the panel or for how long, but he strongly implied that the commissioners should be experts on prices and that the commission should be permanent. If nothing is done, the loss to the Federal Treasury from overstating inflation could add as much as $150 billion to the Federal budget deficit over the next five years, he said.
Mr. Greenspan's proposal for an independent commission, made this morning before the Senate Finance Committee, comes at a time of intense Republican interest in finding some way to change the cost-of-living index so as to save money, either for tax cuts or to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Mr. Greenspan's proposal offers lawmakers a way to do both, while seeking to divert toward the independent commission any political criticism that may come from affected groups like Social Security beneficiaries.
Senators on the committee generally avoided taking any immediate stance on the question of the independent commission, and expressed concern that powerful lobbyists for the elderly had already misinterpreted Mr. Greenspan's previous remarks. Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is the committee chairman, did not take a personal position on Mr. Greenspan's proposal for an independent commission but said that it might be included in this year's budget legislation.
Senator Packwood emphasized the issue's significance. "We are considering today what is perhaps a more important subject fiscally than almost anything else we will consider this year -- and I think in the public's mind yet it's had relatively little notice -- and this is the Consumer Price Index and the effect that it can have on our policy," he said.
Mr. Greenspan's comments today also set the stage for a new and potentially nasty fight over the extent to which the United States should continue to transfer huge sums of money each year from young people to older people.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican, told Mr. Greenspan that "the senior citizens and their advocacy groups -- that ought to know better -- think you're part of a Republican conspiracy to cut down on Social Security in a way that we don't have guts enough to do it in the Congress, if it should be done."
Perhaps in deference to that, Mr. Greenspan mentioned the possibility that a more generous cost-of-living adjustment could be used for elderly benefits because of the fast-rising medical costs they face.
When Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, walked out of the hearing room and into a corridor, he ostentatiously looked in both directions and began walking sideways toward an elevator, his back pressed against the corridor wall. In response to quizzical reporters, he explained that he was afraid of meeting lobbyists from the American Association of Retired Persons.
Martin A. Corry, the association's director of Federal affairs, later criticized Mr. Greenspan's proposal as unnecessary. Mr. Corry defended the current practice of using the Consumer Price Index, saying that the Labor Department calculated the index impartially and without political pressures. If the index exaggerates inflation then the Labor Department should fix it, he said.
But Mr. Greenspan backed away today from his previous suggestions that the index be recalculated, saying that the index had certain inherent flaws that required broad adjustments. He mentioned that many products, from CAT scanners to power tools, have improved in quality without increasing much in price. The Consumer Price Index has failed to take adequate account of these quality improvements, he said.
"Those who remember with fondness the products of yesteryear are probably suffering from either fading memories or excessive sentimentality," Mr. Greenspan said.
Academic and Government experts who also testified before the Senate Finance Committee today tended to agree with Mr. Greenspan that the price index overstated inflation and added to the budget deficit. "Every year that we wait, Social Security beneficiaries and taxpayers are being compensated for inflation that did not occur," said Robert J. Gordon, the chairman of the economics department at Northwestern University.
Mr. Greenspan said today that the Federal budget deficit would continue to be artificially widened as long as Federal programs and taxes are pegged to the Consumer Price Index. "Left in place over long periods of time, as has now occurred and is envisioned continuing in the future, the discrepancy will compound in a manner that cumulates to a very substantial magnitude," he said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold's Rally Gains Momentum With a Surge to a 4-Month High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices hit a four-month high yesterday as precious metals resumed a rally powered by the weaker dollar and what traders saw as the improbability of higher interest rates.
Rising demand by jewelry makers also underpinned gold's gains, analysts said. 
 In other commodity markets, coffee futures fell sharply and crude oil rebounded. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.03 points, to 235.12.
Gold for March delivery on the Commodity Exchange of New York hit $385.70 an ounce, the highest since Nov. 17. Profit taking cut the closing price to $385, which was $3.20 above Friday's settlement. The more active April contract ended $3 higher at $386.10. March silver rose 12.8 cents, to $4.696 an ounce.
The rally in gold that began last week continues, said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals trading at the New York branch of Credit Suisse. "I think we may well be set for further gains unless something unexpected happens, like the dollar strengthening," he said.
The dollar's renewed weakness against the Japanese yen and German mark sent investors to the perceived safety of gold, analysts said.
Traders also said they were reacting to an article in The New York Times that said four of seven Federal Reserve governors expressed little enthusiasm for further increases in short-term interest rates.
"The Times story definitely had an impact on gold and silver," said James Steel, an analyst for Refco Inc., a large futures brokerage firm. "It's unusual for an article, even in The Times, to carry that much weight in these markets."
Higher interest rates would increase the dollar's appeal to investors, traders say, and would also reduce gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation.
Coffee futures fell sharply on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as traders awaited word on price-support measures being considered at a meeting of coffee producing countries in London. The contract for May deliveries of green arabica coffee beans fell 5.6 cents, to $1.8215 a pound.
Crude oil rebounded from three consecutive days of losses on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders attributed the recovery mainly to technical factors.
Light crude oil for April delivery rose 28 cents, to $18.19 a barrel, and April heating oil rose 0.36 cent, to 45.61 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Slips as Trading Quiets After Volatile Week

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday. Trading was quiet after a volatile week when the dollar slid to record lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark before recovering on Friday.
Currency dealers and analysts said an article in The New York Times yesterday confirmed market expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on March 28. Higher interest rates tend to make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive. 
 The article reported that four of the Federal Reserve Board's seven governors said they thought that economic growth was stabilizing, suggesting that further increases in short-term interest rates would not be needed.
"People are now convinced there will be no move at the March meeting," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at the Standard Chartered Bank.
But speculation that the Fed will not raise rates soon prompted a rally in the United States bond market, which helped pull the dollar up from its lows, particularly against the yen, traders said. To buy bonds, foreign investors must first purchase dollars.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4067 marks from 1.4120 marks on Friday. The dollar slipped to 90.75 yen from 90.90 yen.
After touching record lows of 1.3455 marks and 88.76 yen on Wednesday, the dollar slowly recovered. Now it is in the process of settling into ranges of 1.34 to 1.42 marks and 88 to 92 yen, Mr. Spence of Standard Chartered said.
In other currency trading yesterday, the mark continued to climb against the Italian lira. The German currency reached a record high of 1,211.44 lire, lifted by Italy's political and economic difficulties.
Investor confidence in Italian assets and the lira was further weakened after the governor of the Bank of Italy, Antonio Fazio, said a budget package was "necessary but not sufficient" to bring Italy's large budget deficit under control.
"The lira-denominated market is very nervous about political developments, and Fazio's comments have clearly added to the concerns," said Lorenzo Stanca, currency analyst at Credito Italiano.
The mark was last quoted at 1,194.07 lire, up from 1,182.72 lire late Friday in New York. The dollar stood at 1,680 lire, up from 1.670 lire.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Mexico Without Blinkers

 BODY:
Even close watchers of Mexico have been shaken by the explosive allegations of narco-corruption and murderous intrigue being leveled against former Government officials by the new authorities in Mexico City. Those allegations led former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to flee Mexico over the weekend for a potentially extended exile in the United States.
This is not just the modest settling of scores after a high-profile administration leaves office. President Ernesto Zedillo, who shattered precedent by naming an opposition lawyer to the sensitive post of Attorney General, has now authorized a far-reaching and unflinching inquiry into past misdeeds, mysteries and cover-ups. 
 Particularly disturbing are the new Government's claims, still unproven, that intimate associates of former President Salinas may have been directly involved in skimming millions of dollars of drug profits and even organizing political murders.
The last two Presidents of the United States have embraced Mr. Salinas as the personification of desirable economic and political change in Mexico. Yet American authorities were far more aware than they let on of the close ties between Salinas associates and the Mexican drug cartels now funneling most of the cocaine that reaches the United States.
Their silence was part of a misplaced effort to maintain good relations with the Salinas administration to encourage its policies of economic reform and not spook Congressional passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Salinas economic reforms were real enough. Over Mr. Salinas's six-year term, Mexico sold off hundreds of money-losing state enterprises, substantially lowered tariffs on foreign imports and opened its economy to foreign investment. Grievous mismanagement of the peso during the final months of the Salinas presidency has chased those investors away. But over the longer run, his impressive accomplishment in opening up Mexico's economy to competitive forces should invigorate economic growth.
Washington's downplaying of corruption issues was a costly mistake. United States relations with Mexico are best served by the kind of housecleaning that is now going on. Only by rooting out corrupt links between officials and drug traffickers and ending the ruling party's long immunity from prosecution can economic reform be consolidated and secured.
Congressional critics of Washington's recent loan guarantees to the Zedillo Government may find some rhetorical grist in the latest sensational headlines. But the Zedillo administration's willingness to pursue credible evidence of corruption wherever it leads makes Mexico an even stronger candidate for United States support, and the Clinton Administration is right to encourage Mr. Zedillo in his efforts.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: New York's Desperate Hours

BYLINE: By Carol O'Cleireacain; Carol O'Cleireacain, an economist, was New York City's finance commissioner from 1990 to 1993 and budget director in 1993.

 BODY:
This should have been the fiscal year that New York City turned the corner. After five straight years of severe budget problems, of staggering through an endless cycle of cutting services and stretching out debt, the city got a half-billion-dollar gift: a temporary downturn in debt service payments to the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
It was a rare opportunity -- not only to balance the 1995 budget but to buy time, to start taking long-term measures that wouldn't necessarily pay off this year but would lead to big savings in the future. As the City Council holds hearings into next year's budget -- still severely out of balance despite the deep cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani -- it has become all too clear that the opportunity was wasted. 
 Soon after the council adopted the budget last June, state and city fiscal monitors reported that it was about $1 billion out of balance. Apparently, the Mayor and council had gambled that an improving economy and a friendly administration in Albany would make up any shortfall.
To his credit, Mr. Giuliani put spending controls in place and, in October, presented budget changes to close the billion-dollar gap. But a losing game of catch-up had already begun. A quarter of the fiscal year was over; agencies had begun operating with unbalanced budgets. The Mayor and council spent three months battling over budget authority, and as they did so the city's economy stalled, so tax revenues came up at least $400 million short.
And the city is still scrambling. One-shot deficit-closing actions now come to at least $1.8 billion this year. This is more than two and a half times the average amount of one-shot actions in the past five years of economic downturn.
Some of these measures are defensible, but others seem inspired by sheer desperation. Consider the proposal to sell the state two city-owned jails near the Canadian border. It is hard to know which is the more serious risk to the city's fiscal health: not getting the State Legislature's approval for this sale, or getting it.
The first would create a $120 million hole in the 1995 budget. Under the second, the $120 million from the sale would go entirely toward closing this year's budget gap, while the city would still have to pay off $113 million in bonds it issued in 1988 to build the jails. State Comptroller Carl McCall calls this "capitalizing operating expenses," the same behavior that cut New York City off from the bond market in the mid-1970's. The nontechnical taxpayer will recognize it as comparable to selling the house, blowing the proceeds at the race track and still being stuck with the mortgage.
Whether defensible or not, such one-shot actions have no recurring value. As a result, in 1996 the city faces its largest deficit (at least $2.7 billion, or 13 percent of revenues) in the past 15 years.
And the city still has to get through this fiscal year, which ends June 30. Standard & Poor's has placed the bond ratings of the city and its Health and Hospitals Corporation on a negative credit watch. Though the fiscal monitors say the city can end the year with its budget balanced, there are still considerable risks; the biggest, they say, is at the Board of Education, where a sizable slippage in efforts to close its spending gap illustrates that the longer you wait to solve a problem, the harder it becomes.
While this is the city's worst fiscal plight since the 1970's, it is hardly a new one. In the past five years a sort of equilibrium has set in, with rolling quarterly shortfalls, new spending cuts, one-shot gap-closing measures and refinancing of debt. The focus is short-term in the extreme, the pressure is exhausting for all participants, and the uncertainty about future services punishes every city resident, from schoolchildren to subway riders (and their employers).
The only way to break the cycle is to move toward structural balance -- a situation in which revenue and spending are about the same size and grow at roughly the same rate. And the path is no mystery: it was laid out on Dec. 1, 1993, in a report to Mayor David N. Dinkins by Donald Kummerfeld, a former city budget director; Dall Forsythe, a former state budget director, and William Gray 3d, a former chairman of the Budget Committee of the House of Representatives.
Right now, the growth in spending exceeds the growth in revenue by about 2 percent a year as far as the eye can see. Structural balance, then, means making tough choices that cut the growth of spending and permanently increase revenue. The 1993 report presented a full array of the necessary spending cuts, some of which the city has begun: reducing the number of employees and their compensation; reducing debt service; eliminating certain subsidies and duplicative services, and consolidating agencies.
As for revenues, the Kummerfeld report said bluntly that structural balance could not be achieved by spending cuts alone. Revenues must be raised, the report said, and argued that it could be done in ways that would do the least damage to the economy: delay scheduled tax cuts; introduce a combination of fees and charges for certain basic services, like garbage collection and bridge maintenance.
Most important, they called for reform of the city's largest tax, theproperty tax, which is now skewed in favor of single-family homeowners and against commercial property owners. Such a change is not only a matter of equity; it would help restore the property tax to its historical role as the stabilizer of the revenue side of the budget.
Putting structural balance at the center of the city's budget planning cannot be the responsibility of the Mayor alone. It requires full participation by the City Council, and recognition in Albany that the state has a real stake in the long-term fiscal health of New York City.
Some new budget rules can help, too. The city's financial plan should make structural balance an explicit goal, with the pattern of recurring spending and revenues monitored and reported in the same way as the annual gap-closing program. The city should commit itself to a cap on one-shot actions in any given year. While there is no hard rule on where to set that cap, recent experience suggests that it should not exceed $700 million. Finally, rather than reporting after the fact, the fiscal monitors, or at least the city comptroller, should be required to verify before adoption that the proposed budget deal between the council and the Mayor is in fact a balanced budget.
As desperate as the city's plight looks now, it can get worse. So far the bond markets have accommodated the city. Bondholders are requiring, and the city has been all to happy to pay, a higher rate of interest than is generally appropriate for its investment-grade rating. But the markets can turn.
Changes in securities regulations, interest rates or exchange rates, as well as the national trend toward tax cutting at all levels of government, may lower demand for tax-exempt municipal bonds or generate a flight to higher-quality bonds. City debt service is increasing again, even with a one-third cut in the capital budget. Declines in commercial property values are lowering the ceiling on both the amount of debt the city can issue and the property taxes that can be levied. A national recession would unbalance the budget further. The city could lose its one remaining investment-grade bond rating. That's why it's more urgent than ever to listen to what the Kummerfeld report told us almost a year and a half ago.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Talks Off as N.L.R.B. Summons Parties

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13

 BODY:
First, they disagreed about which day they would meet. Now they're not sure they will meet at all.
The round of talks in the baseball strike that had been scheduled to begin Tuesday or Wednesday was delayed today in the face of a scheduled meeting in Washington Tuesday at which the owners are expected to learn that the National Labor Relations Board will issue a complaint against them. 
 Fred Feinstein, the board's general counsel, has scheduled a morning meeting with the owners' representatives and one in the afternoon with union officials. At the morning session, Feinstein is expected to tell the owners that unless they agree to settle the players' unfair labor practice charge against them, a complaint will be issued and he will ask for board approval to seek an injunction in United States District Court.
Unlike a similar session on Feb. 3, the owners are not expected to agree to settle. The players have said they will return to work if the board gets an injunction forcing the clubs to restore the working terms and conditions that existed before the owners implemented a salary cap last Dec. 23.
The pending board action has prompted a delay in the resumption of talks. The owners' negotiating committee was at a hotel outside Orlando today to discuss a new proposal that the mediator, Bill Usery Jr., has asked it to make. The committee presumably would have made it when talks resumed Tuesday, the date the owners thought had been set, or Wednesday, the date the players thought had been set.
But Usery issued a statement saying, "The clubs have stated that it is not possible to comply with my request that the clubs put forward their best offer until they can receive and assess the decision of the general counsel."
Usery said he was postponing the negotiations, but would remain in contact with the two sides. He said he would decide when the talks should resume "when the situation regarding this matter has been clarified."
Donald Fehr, the union leader, said he hoped the resumption of talks would not be "long delayed."
"No matter how Feinstein rules," he added by telephone from New York, "whether it's for us or the clubs, we should continue to negotiate and try to find a way out."
The owners have called the N.L.R.B. business a distraction, and that's the way they felt today after the members of their negotiating committee all had traveled to Florida. But they didn't dismiss the possibility of meeting with the players' negotiators later this week.
"The clubs continue to believe that the best way to resolve our differences is at the bargaining table," John Harrington, chairman of the negotiating committee, said in a statement. He said the committee would determine how and when to continue negotiations after the Washington meeting.
When asked if the two sides could yet meet this week, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said from Milwaukee, "I think there's a chance."
The charge Feinstein will act on Tuesday arose after the clubs agreed Feb. 3 to restore the conditions prior to Dec. 23 and withdraw their implemented salary cap rather than have an unfair labor practice complaint issued against them.
When the clubs altered the previous working terms and conditions, eliminating salary arbitration among other things, the union filed another unfair labor practice charge with the board. The initial charge stemmed from the clubs' act in declaring an impasse and implementing a new economic system.
In another element of the labor dispute, the clubs have renewed the contracts of more than 800 unsigned players, but the union contended today that the renewals were invalid.
"They are the function of invalidly implemented terms," Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said by telephone from New York. "The clubs haven't restored the status quo in violation of the National Labor Relations Act."
Club management lawyers did not return repeated telephone calls seeking comment on the renewals and the union's position.

HEADLINE: Deadly Nuclear Waste Piles Up With No Clear Solution at Hand

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
INCREASINGLY, the world is awash in plutonium, the deadly gold of the nuclear era, the man-made element that is produced in all nuclear reactors and prized for making atom bombs. And increasingly, no one knows what to do with it, as big nuclear arsenals become passe and as alternative plans for the perilously radioactive stuff lose their luster.
The simplest option is to bury it. But that is now under fire as scientists debate, and Federal agencies study, whether a proposed underground dump in Nevada might eventually blow up in a nuclear explosion fed by waste plutonium. For years the dump has been seen as a crucial solution to the plutonium problem, and its rejection would be an enormous blow to nuclear planning. 
 And globally, plans to burn plutonium in commercial nuclear reactors are floundering for political and economic reasons.
Scientists are proposing many new methods and machines meant to rid the world of surplus plutonium, including new reactors, annihilators and special ways to discard it. But costliness and political inertia have kept these schemes largely in limbo. Meanwhile, the glut of plutonium is growing, stirring fears that sooner or later some will fall into the hands of nuclear terrorists.
"Plutonium is the bottom-line danger because it's always atom-bomb material, even when it's declared for peaceful purposes," said Paul Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute, a trade group based in Washington.
It takes from 2.2 to 17.6 pounds of plutonium to make a bomb, depending on the skill of the designer and the concentration of the 239 isotope, the preferred kind for weapons. A metric ton (2,205 pounds) can make from 125 to 1,000 warheads.
Of the 270 or so metric tons of weapons plutonium in the world, perhaps as many as 200 tons are slated to become surplus in the next few years as nuclear disarmament moves forward. And on the civil side, the stockpile of plutonium, both in nuclear-reactor wastes and isolates from spent fuel, stands at about 930 metric tons and is expected to nearly double in the next decade.
"This is a very serious problem," said Dr. Arjun Makhijani, a nuclear physicist and president of the Institute for Energy and Environmental Research, a private group in Takoma Park, Md. "Every four or five years we're making about as much plutonium in the civil sector as we did during the whole cold war."
Plutonium was discovered in 1940 at the University of California. Made in a cyclotron, the radioactive element was found to be extremely toxic and to have a half-life of 24,360 years. It was soon produced in bulk. Uranium 238, the common isotope of uranium in nature, was bombarded by neutrons in nuclear reactors and almost magically transformed into plutonium 239, which was then extracted to make atomic bombs. In 1945, a plutonium bomb was dropped on the Japanese city of Nagasaki.
The ease of plutonium 239 production made it a bulwark of the cold war. The alternate primary fuel for making nuclear weapons, the rare 235 isotope of uranium, had to be wrung from ore in a costly and laborious process.
As civil reactors for nuclear power multiplied in the 1960's and 1970's, they too began to make large amounts of plutonium, their spent fuel containing up to 1 percent of the element as a byproduct. A civil industry to separate it for powering special reactors quickly rose and fell in the United States, its death prompted by fears that the plutonium would eventually be diverted into making nuclear bombs.
In 1977, President Carter announced an end to the civil separation of plutonium. In its place, spent fuel holding the deadly element was to be buried in underground dumps. Congress began a national search for sites in 1982. When this plan collapsed from political opposition, Washington chose a single site in 1987: Yucca Mountain, a heap of volcanic ash in the Nevada desert. If found suitable, it is to open in 2010.
The rest of the world's civil-reactor work tended to press down the separation path, mainly that of recycling the plutonium from spent fuel for use in breeder reactors. Less richly endowed with energy resources than the United States, countries like Japan, Britain, Germany and France saw plutonium burning as an economic bonanza.
But recycled plutonium fell out of favor over the years, except in Japan, as uranium fuel became cheaper. Many countries are still separating some plutonium, however, in case uranium one day grows scarce and costly. And leftover plutonium in nuclear waste is to be buried in underground dumps, as in America.
Today 438 nuclear power reactors are on line around the world, all producing plutonium in greater or lesser amounts. The Nuclear Energy Institute, a trade group based in Washington, says the total will grow to about 465 reactors by the end of the century.
The plutonium glut has increased with the end of the cold war and the scrapping of thousands of nuclear weapons. In January 1994, the National Academy of Sciences, which advises the Federal Government, suggested that weapons-grade plutonium be mixed with highly radioactive wastes and buried, or burned in reactors and then buried. In either case, some plutonium would end up going underground.
Debate recently broke out among Federal scientists over whether plutonium beneath Yucca Mountain might eventually erupt in a nuclear explosion, scattering radioactivity into the winds and underground water.
While many experts say the thesis is probably wrong, it is being seriously studied at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, by the Energy Department, and by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has responsibility for licensing the proposed dump.
The main proponent of the theory, Dr. Charles D. Bowman, is one of scores of scientists hunting for new ways to rid the world of surplus plutonium. In his plan, big particle accelerators would, by a kind of nuclear alchemy, transmute radioactive wastes and plutonium into more benign elements before they were buried. Waste heat from the process could spin turbines and produce electricity.
"It's a brilliant way of solving the world's most dangerous problem by transforming a liability into an asset," Dr. Carlo Rubbia, the Italian physicist and Nobel laureate, said at a recent meeting. "It means cleaning up at least part of the mess left over from the cold war."
But perfecting the advanced technology might take 15 years and cost $500 million.
Many other ideas for plutonium disposal involve burning it up in special reactors. General Atomics, a San Diego-based company, has joined with Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy to design a meltdown-proof, gas-cooled reactor that would turn the deadly material into electricity. The $535 million reactor would be built in Russia and fueled at least partly by plutonium from Moscow's huge stockpile of scrapped nuclear arms.
The partners recently pledged $2 million to the project's design, which is expected to employ more than 200 Russian scientists.
"It burns about 12 tons of plutonium in 40 years," Dr. Walter A. Simon, a senior vice preside at General Atomics, said in an interview. "Four modules would burn about 50 tons in 40 years."
But the plan has no backing from the Clinton Administration, which in a policy move decided to abandon all work on reactors that would burn plutonium out of fear they would foster global trade in the deadly substance. In a similar vein, the Administration stopped work at the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois on the Integral Fast Reactor, which would have consumed dangerous waste while producing electric power.
Perhaps the least publicly acceptable of all the plutonium proposals is to dump it at sea in missile-like titanium casings that would bury themselves deep into muddy sediments. Although a world moratorium now exists on the ocean dumping of all nuclear waste, the plutonium glut is so great that sub-seabed disposal is again being looked at internationally.
Perhaps the most elegant solution of all would be to pitch excess plutonium into space, firing it into the Sun. But high costs, as well as launching risks, have always conspired to dash such proposals.
Many nuclear experts argue that talk of transmutation and new reactors and exotic solutions only delays work on real disposal, which always seems to come back to permanent burial underground. If dangers of plutonium explosion are found to exist, they say, solutions can also be found.
Dr. Bowman of Los Alamos has suggested making steel canisters smaller and spreading them out over larger areas in underground galleries at Yucca Mountain, expensive steps in a project already expected to cost $15 billion or more. A different precaution would be to dig the deep repository in granite rather than volcanic tuff, lessening the chance that plutonium might eventually migrate into rock and flare up in a nuclear chain reaction.
"You need to dispose of it underground in an irretrievable form," said Mr. Leventhal of the Nuclear Control Institute. "Using reactors to burn it up will take hundreds or thousands of years."
The State of Nevada has seized on the explosion argument to fight the repository project, which it has long and bitterly opposed. And the state has vowed to keep battling it, even if the explosion debate proves groundless or if reasonable solutions to the problem arise. Like many other states and localities, Nevada wants no part of any nuclear dump.
Bucking the trend, the Mescalero Apaches in southern New Mexico voted last Thursday to go ahead with a lucrative plan to store high-level nuclear waste from commercial reactors on their reservation. Some 30 utility companies want to put their mounting piles of spent fuel rods there until a permanent repository is found. But the temporary dump is opposed by the New Mexico Legislature and the state's Congressional delegation, which see it as dangerous.
"Every technically good solution has political sides that are horrible, and every politically good solution tends to be technically shabby," remarked Dr. Makhijani of the Institute for Energy and Environmental Research. "Nobody has any good overall solutions to this mess, including us."


GRAPHIC: Some alternatives to Yucca Mountain for disposing of high-level nuclear waste:
 
Turn waste into a glassy compound and bury it deep underground, in smaller containers, at other sites.
 
Burn plutonium in more efficient reactors.
 
Convert waste into other elements with particle accelerators.
 
Dump waste at sea in missile-like titanium casings that would bury themselves deep in muddy sediments.
 
Fire waste into space.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

President Zedillo of Mexico Sees Crisis in Other Nations
President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico said his country was merely the first emerging economy to confront the growing power and immediacy of the global financial markets. Discussing the vulnerability of Mexico's economy, Mr. Zedillo said international markets were changing faster than governments could cope. His Finance Minister is to meet with bankers in New York today to brief them on the austerity program that Mexico announced last week. [Page A1.] 

Argentina said it had put together a financing package that would give it an extra $11.1 billion to back the Argentine peso's fixed 1-to-1 link to the United States dollar. The package includes a renewed loan from the International Monetary Fund worth $2 billion. [D3.]
Bankers Trust's Stock Plunges
The stock of Bankers Trust plunged 16 percent as employees and industry analysts expressed doubts about its ability to rebound quickly. The company announced Friday that problems in its derivatives business and with Latin American markets would result in a loss of about $125 million in the first quarter. [D5.]
 
USAir Trips Berkshire Hathaway
Berkshire Hathaway wrote down the value of its USAir stock and said its 1994 earnings fell to $494.8 million from $688.1 million. Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire's chairman, and Charles T. Munger, the vice chairman, resigned from the airline's board. [D4.]
 
ompuserve to Buy Spry
Compuserve, the online service subsidiary of H & R Block, will buy Spry Inc. for about $100 million in one of the largest acquisitions of an Internet access provider. [D2.]
 
urmoil at Future Healthcare
Future Healthcare's stock price plunged 70 percent after the company said accounting discrepancies could reduce its earnings for 1994 and previous years. The company's president resigned, and its independent accountant was dismissed. [D10.]
 
tocks Fall 10.38 as Dollar Slips
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 10.38 points, to 4,025.23, after the dollar continued to fall on currency markets. [D12.]
 
.B.M. Rewards Chief Executive
Louis V. Gerstner, the chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., earned $4.6 million in compensation and received additional stock options that would be worth more than $4.9 million if they were exercised today. [D5.]
 
Alcatel Names Interim Chief
Alcatel Alsthom, France's third-biggest industrial group, appointed a top executive to oversee its management and executive committee after its chairman, Pierre Suard, was indicted on fraud charges and banned from running the company. [D7.]
 
I.R.S. Policy Raises Questions
The Justice Department has given copies of individual income tax returns to an Ohio company that is in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over payroll taxes. The action seems certain to arouse new concerns about the confidentiality of tax returns. [D4.]
 
Macintosh Commercial Honored
A commercial introducing the Apple Macintosh during the 1984 Super Bowl was chosen as the best television ad ever.

World's Fair in Cyberspace Backed
Several countries, including the U.S., are backing a plan to create a world's fair in cyberspace. It is intended to demonstrate the power and advance the capabilities of the global information network. [D2.]

Welfare, Food Stamps Level Off
Welfare and food-stamp rolls, after increasing through periods of recession and recovery in the last six years, have now leveled off. Experts say the economic recovery has begun to reach more people, and that fewer are therefore entitled to assistance. [A18.]

HEADLINE: Why Do We Watch Those Awards Shows?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Grumbling Gets Louder Over Voting on Grammys" (Arts pages, March 1): For a time it seemed as if every other night television was spawning another award show; it's noticeable that many have since disappeared, but evenings like the Grammys and Tonys evidently still fascinate people or they'd be history. 
 I still don't understand why I sat through more than one evening of Academy Awards, watching inept thank-yous interspersed with forgettable special material, wooden teleprompter banter delivered in an expensively tacky stage set and clips of increasingly interchangeable films -- but I have, and so presumably have you. Why? Especially if we hadn't seen most of the films?
Ignace Paderewski, the Polish pianist-statesman of 60-odd years ago, wrote of his tour crisscrossing America by railroad. More than once a whole small Middle West town's population would come out to wave as Paderewski sped past, but afterward practically no one ever got in a car or on the next train to go to hear him play. The art itself was not so potentially thrilling as the kick that came from waving at somebody famous.
This may be an American thing: I hear that a novel that wins France's Prix Goncourt enjoys better sales, but no similar phenomenon exists in our own publishing world. Which brings up the question: Do these awards mean anything, even economically?
The composer Charles Ives, on receiving a Pulitzer late in life, felt that prizes were for children. Maybe it's our same inner child, the one who enjoyed attending birthday parties even if they weren't for us. (Maybe that is why so much of our popular entertainment is so puerile.)
Maybe if Americans ever did grow up we could abolish awards for the arts industry, as we insist on calling it, and show our appreciation for art by genuinely paying attention. What I would then like to see, if we in our new enlightenment still needed award shows, is something given to the city that got all its potholes filled first, for example. That might be a lot easier to monitor, and everybody would be happy.
 
WILLIAM BOLCOM
Ann Arbor, Mich., March 6, 1995
 
The writer won the 1988 Pulitzer Prize in music.
