HEADLINE: A Hard Act to Follow? Here Goes.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
"I don't care who writes a nation's laws -- or crafts its advanced treaties -- if I can write its economics textbooks." -- Paul Samuelson
N. Gregory Mankiw, a dweeby 37-year-old economics professor who named his dog Keynes, was not counting on getting rich overnight. Most academics, even at Harvard, don't. But a phone call from a Texas publisher changed all that. 
 Professor Mankiw, who doesn't look a lot older than the freshmen and sophomores he teaches, was offered a $1.4 million advance by Harcourt Brace in Fort Worth to write a basic economics textbook. That's about three times as big as any other in the college textbook market and rivals those of all but a few celebrity authors.
 So what's going on? It's a race among once-stodgy textbook publishers to find the next blockbuster economics textbook, a book that will shape the thinking of the 1.5 million college students who sign up for Econ 101 each year. This introductory course is both the first and the last brush that most educated Americans have with supply and demand, marginal cost, comparative advantage and other first principles of the dismal science.
 Such a book is long overdue. For nearly half a century, students have learned the essentials of economics from Paul Samuelson, now almost 80 years old, and a score of his disciples and imitators. But Professor Samuelson's "Economics" and its many clones reflect the mind-set of a post-Depression generation of scholars who thought they understood the economy well enough to tell Washington how to manage the ups and downs of the business cycle.
 Meanwhile, the world has changed. And so has what most economists believe. A new generation of scholars -- while still respectful of John Maynard Keynes, the British thinker who advocated government borrowing to end the Depression -- are far more skeptical of government fine-tuning. They worry more than their teachers about the economic long term and they focus more on how the United States interacts with the world.
 For all the shifts in thinking, though, previous attempts to sell a mold-breaking economics textbook have wound up costing publishers money. Most college students are learning from books that many in the field view as outdated.
 "We're really not teaching basic economics," said Paul Krugman, an economist at Stanford University who is also writing an introductory textbook. "We're not getting it across at all."
That's where the wooing of Professor Mankiw and other economics superstars of the baby-boom generation comes in. These scholars -- some now writing or thinking about it -- include Professor Krugman, John B. Taylor, Michael J. Boskin and Joseph E. Stiglitz, all from Stanford, and Lawrence H. Summers, formerly at Harvard and now Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs. (Mr. Summers is the latest winner of the John Bates Clark medal as the best economist under 40 and just happens to be Professor Samuelson's nephew.)
Textbook publishers, like other marketers in mature and overcrowded fields, are placing big bets that these people, who are among the closest in their field to brand names, will sell lots of books.
In the past, ambitious young economists like Professor Mankiw (pronounced Man-CUE) left textbook writing to older or less distinguished colleagues. They concentrated instead on the kind of esoteric research that might win them a Nobel Prize. But now some are jumping at the chance to mold the minds of the next generation of political leaders, executives, image makers and other members of the American elite.
"Every economics editor in the business has been looking for the new Samuelson since the 1970's," said Paul Shensa, executive editor at Worth Publishers in New York.
The new stars are seeking not just fame, but fortune. "Even young people at the forefront of research are taking off time to write textbooks," Professor Mankiw said. "The top three or four textbooks, even the top 10, are profitable, wildly profitable."
"Besides," he added with a smile, "economists are proselytizers."
 
The Role Model
A Superstar For Super Sales
 Only one economics superstar, Professor Samuelson, has transformed a new gospel into a category killer. That was in 1948. His reputation as the most brilliant theorist of his generation secure by the time he was 30, the self-confident Professor Samuelson set about writing a textbook that would, as he put it, awaken students like "the kiss of the prince in 'Sleeping Beauty.' "
Without an advance or, for that matter, any publishing deal at all, he labored for three years while teaching at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to turn the novel ideas of Lord Keynes into breezy prose, crystalline examples and simple diagrams. Samuelson, in all its editions, has sold more than three million copies and followers of his approach have sold several times that
But the feat of combining a big name with big sales has never been repeated. Milton Friedman, the great leader of the conservative anti-Keynesian counterrevolution in the 1970's, never did father a successful introductory textbook to hawk his gospel, known as monetarism. Nor did Robert E. Lucas Jr., another University of Chicago economist, or any of the other instigators of an even more anti-interventionist school of the early 1980's known as "rational expectations."
Instead, introductory economics is still dominated by Samuelson emulators. The Samuelson bible, now in its 14th edition, is heavily outsold these days by clever clones and brightly written knock-offs, from Campbell R. McConnell's best-selling "Economics: Principles, Problems and Policies" to Roger LeRoy Miller's "Economics Today" and "Economics: Principles and Policy," by William J. Baumol and Alan S. Blinder of Princeton. (Mr. Blinder is now vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.)
Indeed, as a 1990 study by two economists, William Walstad and Michael Watts, found, all the successful textbooks are remarkably similar in content.
 
The Market
Blockbusters Are Dominant
 The market for introductory economics textbooks, which most publishers peg at $50 million a year, is a lot like the movie business. Thirty to 40 books are typically on the market, but only a handful of blockbusters, selling more than 50,000 copies a year at around $55 each, provide a feast of regular profits, leaving crumbs for everybody else.
Given the chance to hit it big, some outstanding economists -- like movie actors, ballplayers and novelists -- have figured out that they are worth much more in the new superstar market. "Economists are like bassets and beagles," Professor Samuelson said at the weekly departmental lunch at M.I.T. the other day. "They've got no loyalty and they're insatiable."
Before the late 1980's, textbook editors tried to build long-term relationships with authors. Take W.W. Norton & Company's deal with Mr. Stiglitz, the 52-year-old Stanford economist now on President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. Deemed by many the leading all-around theorist, he is certainly one of the most prolific economists. The human equivalent of a multi-tasking Windows software program, he has made major contributions in a dozen or more fields of economics.
In 1986, Mr. Stiglitz signed for a $350,000 advance, a record at the time. Still, it was well within academic tradition, with Mr. Stiglitz making a deal with Norton, the publisher of his earlier public finance book, after its top editors convinced him that they shared his vision of the book he planned to write. It was not that far from Professor Samuelson's decision to choose McGraw-Hill after the publishing company bought the collected papers of his beloved teacher, Joseph A. Schumpeter.
But in 1987, the staid world of academic publishing was jolted by the heretical concept of a bidding war. Two professors, Andrew Abel of the University of Pennsylvania and Ben Bernanke of Princeton, sent what they called a prospectus to eight publishers.
The auction worked brilliantly, from the authors' point of view. It set a new floor of $250,000, which has since escalated to $400,000 to $500,000, for the much smaller intermediate-level textbook market.
Enter Mr. Mankiw, who kept a close eye on such goings on. The son of a northern New Jersey engineer and a hairdresser turned vocational teacher, Mr. Mankiw grew up sailing, raising ducks and collecting campaign buttons. He turned first to economics at Princeton, then law at Harvard and finally earned his Ph.D. in economics at M.I.T. Granted tenure by Harvard at the unusually young age of 29, he won notice not only with his original research but also by publishing a promising, vividly written intermediate textbook.
Scott Stratford, then at McGraw-Hill, began the bidding war for Professor Mankiw's principles text. He offered what he thought was a staggering advance -- $1 million. But Professor Mankiw didn't even blink. "That little money-grubber started shopping the deal," said John Greenman, the longtime economics editor at HarperCollins, which found the price too rarefied to bid.
According to several people familiar with the negotiations, Professor Mankiw's own publisher, Worth, promptly matched McGraw-Hill's offer. Then Harcourt Brace jumped in, offering what amounted to a $400,000 signing bonus on top of the $1 million, plus a 22 percent royalty arrangement. The deal was sealed in December 1992.
"There was no relationship, just money," said Mr. Shensa, Professor Mankiw's previous editor at Worth.
Developing a new economic textbook is an expensive, time-consuming process, but it is also by far the most lucrative part of the textbook publishing business. Still, the landscape is littered with some big-name failures. For instance, the 1,000-page tome by Stanley Fischer and Rudiger Dornbusch of M.I.T., two prominent macroeconomists, sank like so much concrete in the Charles River.
The Stiglitz textbook may be the biggest disappointment of all. While W. Drake McFeely, president of Norton, says the book has sold 60,000 copies, other publishers contend the true figure is closer to 30,000, well below the industry break-even of about 45,000 copies.
In contrast to the 1950's and early 1960's, when the profession wholeheartedly embraced Keynesian economics, there is no consensus today. "Samuelson may be publishing's Holy Grail," said Bruce Kaplan, a senior editor at HarperCollins, "but there can't be a next Samuelson yet because there's no new Keynes. There's just not enough unanimity on a new set of principles."
But that is not stopping publishers from trying to find another Holy Grail.
 
The Holy Grail
Many Have Tried, Many Have Failed
 One hope for publishing stardom is Professor Krugman, 42, the Wunderkind of international economics who recently moved from M.I.T. to Stanford. In 1993, Professor Krugman accepted an advance of half a million dollars from Worth, turning down much bigger offers from competitors because he wanted the freedom not to aim at the biggest possible audience. Nonetheless, he has some established authors worried.
Professor McConnell of the University of Nebraska, whose introductory text is the current best seller, said: "Krugman is an excellent writer. He has strong opinions. If he can keep those out of the way, he could be trouble. I hate these new hotshots coming down the pike."
Some of the hotshots -- like Professor Boskin, who has returned to Stanford after a stint as President George Bush's chief economic adviser, and Mr. Summers -- have only flirted with completing a textbook. And Professor Taylor's new book, while likely to do reasonably well, is not expected to be a barn burner.
That leaves the field open, at least for now, for Professor Mankiw. Cleverly, he expresses relatively modest ambitions for his book's impact. "These things are evolutionary," he said, "not revolutionary."
His boldest thought, perhaps, is to keep it short. He promises to write no more than 650 pages -- close to the original Samuelson length -- rather than let it grow to the 900 to 1,000 pages now standard.
And even though Professor Mankiw shares a number of ideas with the Samuelson emulators, such as the belief that prices and wages do not adjust instantly to changing conditions, he still plans to adopt the more skeptical attitude toward government that pervades modern economics. Earlier scholars, for instance, wrote proudly of the advantages of government borrowing to pull an economy out of recession. But Professor Mankiw will emphasize that deficit spending, while sometimes necessary, can also create significant long-term problems by sapping the savings needed for future investment and productivity growth.
Professor Mankiw's new status as a millionaire has not gone to his head. He still lives in the same comfortable, typically academic house he and his wife, Deborah, have shared for years in the Boston suburb of Wellesley. He is not planning to replace his beat-up 1988 Toyota anytime soon.
And he continues to maintain his quota of two cleanly written pages a day, having already turned in 700 pages. The book should be in classrooms by the fall of 1997.
"He's the best risk for the money," said Mr. Kaplan of HarperCollins. "When I first heard it, I thought Harcourt was crazy. But in the past year I've come to think that the book has a good chance of success."

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
Tokyo Trade Surplus Up 5.3% in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus rose 5.3 percent in February from a year earlier, officials said yesterday, with export volume resuming somewhat as Japanese learned to cope with the effects of Jan. 17 earthquake that halted operations at the port of Kobe.
The increase in the surplus, to $11.46 billion, marked a reversal from January, when the imbalance fell 52.3 percent, in part because no goods could leave the devastated port after the quake. In February, Japanese goods were sent to other ports for shipment. 
 Despite February's increase, economists and Finance Ministry officials said the trade surplus was expected to decline in the long run because consumers were buying less expensive imports. The strong yen makes imports to Japan less expensive in terms of the local currency.
Japan's trade surplus with the United States rose 13 percent in February, to $4.89 billion.

HEADLINE: Salinas, in New York, Denies Being Asked to Quit Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the former President of Mexico who was said to have been forced into virtual exile over the weekend by his successor, popped up on Manhattan's East Side yesterday, eager to dismiss that version of events.
"Can I return to Mexico?" Mr. Salinas said in an interview. "At any moment! Yes!" He paused, then added, "But I don't have plans now to do so." 
 Mr. Salinas phoned The New York Times yesterday, and in a subsequent interview quibbled with the portrait that has been painted of him in Mexico, as a man virtually without a country, asked to leave his homeland by President Ernesto Zedillo, who succeeded him on Dec. 1.
Senior aides to Mr. Zedillo, speaking on condition that they not be identified, have given that version of events since Sunday, after Mr. Salinas boarded a private jet on Friday and flew to Texas and on to New York City the same day. Mr. Salinas had broken a political taboo by quarreling publicly with his successor over who was to blame for the collapse of Mexico's currency and had become a source of concern to the Government after his angry response to the arrest of his brother on murder charges.
In an interview in the elegant five-story brownstone building on East 72d Street that is the official residence of Mexico's representative to the United Nations, Mr. Salinas declined to speak for the record about his country's economic and political crises, saying he feared his comments would undermine what little stability Mr. Zedillo has been able to restore.
"The situation in Mexico is delicate," he said. "It's important not to disturb that."
Because he spoke guardedly, and at times enigmatically, his current status remained a bit of a mystery. But he outlined his immediate intentions in broad strokes, saying he plans to travel indefinitely, contemplating his future role and engaging in "small private dialogues that I've been invited to."
"You could call them speeches," he added.
"I have plans to continue traveling here in the U.S. and abroad, most probably abroad," Mr. Salinas said. "My children continue in school in Mexico City, and my wife is with them."
Dressed in a formal blue double-breasted suit and wingtip shoes, Mr. Salinas appeared relaxed and affable. He spoke in English from the depths of an easy chair, sipping herb tea.
The setting for the interview did little to clarify Mr. Salinas's status.
He said it was only coincidence that he was meeting with reporters in a Mexican Government residence, since he had been having lunch there with an old friend, Manuel Tello, formerly Mr. Salinas's Foreign Minister and now the Mexican delegate to the United Nations
Mr. Tello withdrew from the room for the duration of the interview.
Asked as he ushered the reporters from his home whether Mr. Zedillo was aware that Mr. Salinas was using the official Mexican residence to meet reporters, Mr. Tello said, "He knows he's here."
Mr. Salinas, 46, left office as a highly respected world leader, but has reacted erratically since the Mexican economic crisis that began three weeks later and the arrest of his brother on murder charges last month. He began and then hurriedly ended a hunger strike -- a fast, he preferred to call it -- after he was widely criticized in the country. He demanded that the Zedillo Government exonerate him of any responsibility for its economic woes and for alleged tampering with the investigation into another political slaying last year.
"This has been a difficult 90 days," he said. "A former President of Mexico has to adjust to a different way of life. You have so many duties and responsibilities that end sharply. And that's it."
In an interview in Mexico City on Monday, Mr. Zedillo was asked if there was truth to statements by his senior aides that he sent an intermediary on March 7 to ask Mr. Salinas to leave Mexico.
"No, no," Mr. Zedillo responded, smiling. He said Mr. Salinas's only direct contact with the Government had been with the Agrarian Reform Minister, Arturo Warman, who spoke to Mr. Salinas during the hunger strike. And Mr. Zedillo added: "I know that many people went to him and gave him a lot of advice. I don't know if some of them thought they were going on my behalf or whatever."
Mr. Zedillo was asked, "For the record, you didn't ask him to go?"
"No," he replied.
"But there are people in this building who say you did," a reporter said.
"I don't know," Mr. Zedillo responded. He was still smiling.
A senior Mexican official also said on Monday: "Of course he was told to go. He was inevitably going to be making noise here."
Mr. Salinas declined to speculate about why aides to Mr. Zedillo would be spreading a story he says is false about his having been asked to leave the country. Asked if he was perplexed by this portrait of him as an exile, he screwed up his face into a look of mock puzzlement.
"Do I look perplexed?" he asked.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former President Carlos Salinas of Mexico yesterday at the official Mexican residence in New York. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOUSE COMMITTEE SUPPORTS TAX CUT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today to reduce taxes by almost $200 billion over the next five years, a cornerstone of the Republicans' Contract With America.
But the action was tempered by the first signs of trouble in the Republicans' promise to cut spending to compensate for the loss of tax money. Party leaders had to concede that they were hard pressed to win support for even a modest first round of spending reductions. 
 Republicans have asserted that they will pay for the tax cuts with equivalent cuts in spending so that the deficit will not be worsened, but they have not specified how they will do so.
Opposition to the spending cuts, contained in separate legislation, began to jell as lawmakers realized how their own districts would be affected. The Republicans' problem was compounded by a controversy over abortion, one of the most divisive issues within the party.
The main elements of the tax legislation are a tax reduction of $500 per child for all families except the richest and the poorest, a lower capital gains tax, a tax cut for working couples and several tax breaks for businesses.
Approved by the committee on a party-line vote, the tax bill is almost certain to pass the House intact this spring. But its prospects are in doubt because of strong opposition at the White House and the determination of many senators from both parties to deal with deficit reduction before tax cuts.
Democrats on the committee originally planned to string out consideration of the tax measure by offering dozens of amendments, even though they knew they would fall to the Republican majority.
But today the Democrats saw that Republican leaders were having trouble rounding up votes in their own party for the spending cuts. So the Democrats dropped the tax amendments and let the bill win committee approval before the House began debate on the spending measure on Wednesday. "We wanted to make them face up to where the money was going to come from," said Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington.
For months, Republican leaders have promised to balance the budget by paring Government spending to the bone. The first round was supposed to be a $17 billion cut in programs for the current fiscal year.
These rescissions, in budget terminology, were approved two weeks ago by the House Appropriations Committee. They would fall heaviest on social programs for the poor, including spending for subsidized housing, summer jobs programs for poor teen-agers and helping the elderly pay heating bills. Other aspects would cut money for President Clinton's national service initiative, education programs, AIDS research and public broadcasting.
Fueling the furor over this bill was a proposed amendment to let states deny financing for abortions for poor women who are victims of rape and incest. Many moderate Republicans were angered by this proposal, which would apply to the Medicaid program for the poor, and they sought to have it stricken.
This afternoon, they said their party's leadership was unresponsive. "This is absolutely unacceptable," said Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut. "I will not support it, and there's a lot of Republicans who feel the way I do."
But tonight, to insure the votes of moderate Republicans like Mrs. Johnson, the leadership used its authority to prevent the abortion amendment from being offered.
The sponsor of the amendment, Representative Ernest Jim Istook Jr., Republican of Oklahoma, said, "A small group of Republicans saw that they had a lot of leverage."
The possible defection of Republican moderates meant that party leaders were scrambling to piece together a majority with the votes of conservative Democrats. It also raised the friction level between moderates and conservatives just as the party headed into the most difficult parts of its agenda.
"This is going to be a very demanding bill," Speaker Newt Gingrich conceded today.
Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, pleaded with his colleagues not to break ranks the first time they considered trimming Government.
"Republicans are going to have to ask themselves, do they want to fulfill the contract?" he said at a news conference. "We either fulfill the contract beginning with this bill or we punt and tell the American people we were only kidding them."
Trying to blunt the argument that the bill would cut programs for the poor to pay for tax cuts for those better off, Mr. Gingrich promised today that the spending bill would be amended to include what he called "a lockbox provision" stipulating that none of the spending reductions would be used to offset tax cuts.
That will amount to a bit of budgetary fiction, since the Government's money is not compartmentalized. But Mr. Gingrich seemed to hope that this might give lawmakers the cover they needed to vote for unpopular spending cuts.
Mr. Gingrich continued to argue that the tax bill was to his party's political advantage. "It draws the clear distinction," he declared, "between those of us who believe that we ought to leave the money with the parents so they can pay directly for their children, and the liberals who believe that we ought to make sure we take the money away in taxes so we can then hire a bureaucrat to do for the children what their parents can't do because they don't have the after-tax income."
But the Democrats felt they won the political argument today by standing on the side of deficit reduction and by drawing attention to the extent to which the wealthy would benefit from tax cuts and the poor would be hurt by new limits on spending. The tax bill approved by the committee today would cost $189 billion in lost revenue over the next five years and another $500 billion from 2001 through 2005, according to Treasury Department calculations.
During the committee debate, the Democrats hammered the point that the richest 1 percent of taxpayers -- those with annual incomes over about $200,000 -- would get 20 percent of the tax breaks in the bill. They also complained that a mother working full time at the minimum wage would get no benefit from the $500 per child tax credit.
Republicans responded that the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers paid more than one-fifth of the income taxes, so it was only fair that they got one-fifth of the cuts.
As for poor families not benefiting, Republicans said that this was a tax cut -- not a welfare -- bill, and that people should get an income tax cut only to the extent that they paid income taxes at all. (A single mother with two children earning, say, $20,000 a year would not owe $1,000 in income taxes and thus could not take full advantage of the credit.)
The tax bill closely follows the Republicans' campaign Contract With America. Following are other main elements of the bill:
*A reduction of the top capital gains tax rate to 19.8 percent from 28 percent, and adjustments in some capital gains to offset the effect of inflation.
*A repeal of the alternative minimum tax for businesses, an item in the tax code meant to insure that profitable companies with large write-offs still pay some taxes.
*A new retirement savings account that would allow penalty-free withdrawals for buying a home and some other specific purposes.
*A tax cut of up to $145 for working couples to reduce the additional taxes sometimes owed when two single workers marry.
*Tax breaks for adoption expenses, life insurance distributions to the terminally ill and longterm-care insurance.
*An increase to $30,000 from $11,500 in what people from age 65 through 69 could earn without having their Social Security payments reduced, and a repeal of the higher taxes that were enacted in 1993 on the Social Security benefits of middle- and upper-income retirees.
*More favorable depreciation rules for businesses with capital investments.
*Lower estate and gift taxes.
If all goes according to the Republican plans, the House will vote on the tax bill by April 8.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Asks U.N. to Do More for Women

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 14

 BODY:
Today, for the second time in a week, Hillary Rodham Clinton came to speak to a United Nations gathering, this time about the condition of women's lives within this organization as much as in the world at large.
But this time, invoking the spirit of Eleanor Roosevelt, who was a delegate to the General Assembly, Mrs. Clinton offered the most spirited American defense of the United Nations that this gloomy headquarters has heard from Washington in a long time. Today's conference, "Women and the United Nations," was dedicated to Mrs. Roosevelt's memory. 
 At a time, Mrs. Clinton said, "when full economic, social and political opportunities for women too often remain an elusive goal, we should commend the United Nations for inviting serious discussion of the unique obstacles confronting women in every country, rich and poor."
Mrs. Clinton, who last week spoke at a United Nations conference on world poverty in Copenhagen, leaves next week for a solo trip to South Asia.
There she wants to see projects like the Grameen Bank, which loans money to rural women without collateral in Bangladesh, and other self-help organizations for women in business and crafts. She will also make at least two substantive speeches on social topics, in Pakistan and India, where women face many impediments and traditional prejudices. Sri Lanka and Nepal are also being considered as stops.
In the summer, she will be the honorary chairman of a delegation planning American strategy for the fourth international conference on women, to be held in Beijing in September. Her staff said it is too soon to say whether she will go to Beijing.
The World Summit for Social Development last week made an impression on her, Mrs. Clinton said today.
"I and many others came away from Copenhagen convinced that we must work harder for ways to open opportunities for women," she said. Her overwhelmingly female audience today applauded when she added that United Nations headquarters, where only 15 percent of the officials are women, needed to improve its record.
Mrs. Clinton also drew laughs from the enthusiastic crowd in the Trusteeship Council chamber when she recalled how Mrs. Roosevelt, noting an "obsession with rule-making" among her male peers, would show her displeasure and impatience by knitting in General Assembly sessions.
Mrs. Clinton is not the first President's wife to venture alone into an international arena. Jacqueline Kennedy made a number of trips abroad, also including one to India while her husband was President. Rosalyn Carter still travels with former President Jimmy Carter on his troubleshooting missions from North Korea to Haiti, sometimes in an active advisory role.
At a time when the United Nations is under fire on Capitol Hill, Mrs. Clinton came to the defense of the series of international conferences the organization has been holding, from the Rio Earth Summit in 1992 through Copenhagen.
"With Beijing on the horizon, issues historically dismissed as unimportant may now be understood in a larger context," she said.
"The United Nations must play a leadership role, and must play a role by example," she said. "Every program, policy and decision that emanates from this building directly or indirectly affects women, as they raise their children, manage households or work at their jobs."

HEADLINE: Broad Group Visits President On Affirmative Action's Future

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Hoping for help in defusing a political bomb, President Clinton summoned a bipartisan, interracial group of civil rights leaders and academics to the White House on Monday night, part of the Administration's review of Federal affirmative action programs in the face of Republican demands to scale them back.
In a freewheeling four-and-one-half-hour discussion over dinner in the Green Room, Mr. Clinton sought the advice of about two dozen people with experience on the topic, from the retired Federal appeals judge A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. to the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president emeritus of the University of Notre Dame, to Elliot L. Richardson, an Attorney General in the Nixon Administration. Participants said the President had suggested that he feared that Republicans would use the issue to splinter the country in next year's elections. 
 Since the midterm elections, Republicans have vowed to roll back race- and sex-based preferences in employment and contracting, and to make the subject a major issue in the 1996 Presidential campaign.
"He said his concern was this issue has legs, and how do you convince people who are sort of the white working class that this issue doesn't hurt them," one guest said of the President today, speaking on condition of anonymity. "He said that's the dilemma he faced, and that much of it is driven by the general economic insecurity of the country."
Participants said the President had mostly listened as guests at three round tables stood by turns, some urging him to concentrate on saving programs benefiting blacks, others urging him to focus on programs for women, and still others pleading with him not to pare affirmative action at all.
Senior White House officials described the dinner as private and declined all comment on it. Other participants included Ray Marshall, who was Secretary of Labor in the Carter Administration; Mary Frances Berry, a historian at the University of Pennsylvania; Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, and George Stephanopoulos, senior Presidential adviser.
Mr. Clinton commissioned the Administration's review of Federal affirmative action programs last month, in hope of finding a "third way" between defending the status quo and abolishing all race- and sex-based preferences. But already the review itself looms as a political third rail. Dinner guests said the President had mentioned that he wanted to give a speech on the topic, and last week White House aides suggested that he would make one soon, but they remain unsure just what he should say.
Mr. Clinton has said he wants to retain some preferences where needed to rectify past discrimination, while stressing broader economic assistance programs that benefit needy people regardless of race.
Yet Democrats including prominent blacks like the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the California Assembly Speaker, Willie L. Brown Jr., have warned the White House that Mr. Clinton risks grave peril with his electoral base of core Democrats if he is seen as retreating on the issue. The President's pollster, Stanley B. Greenberg, caused a minor stir last week for merely suggesting that the Democrats' electoral future lay with appealing more broadly to working Americans instead of defending preferences for some groups.
After arriving at the White House with a delegation of California state officials, Mr. Brown met with the President for about half an hour today. Mr. Jackson went to see the President last week. Aides said today that Mr. Clinton planned to consult widely with members of Congress, including members of the Congressional Black Caucus, but was still reviewing just how such meetings should be organized.
Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey, the chairman of the Black Caucus, said he was to meet with the President on Wednesday. Also on Wednesday, a coalition of women's and civil rights groups, including the National Organization for Women and the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, is to march to the White House for a meeting with senior officials.
"We soundly reject the divisive and polarizing tactics of our opponents," one of the coalition's organizers, Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority Foundation, said in a statement. "We are putting elected officials on notice that we will not tolerate sacrificing affirmative action for political expediency."
The Monday dinner was the latest in a series of discussions that top-ranking Administration officials have held on the topic. Vice President Al Gore, who attended the session, has separately held a series of dinners in recent weeks to discuss race relations generally with some of the same people, his aides said.
Participants said the White House session had begun with presentations by Charles Moskos, a military sociologist at Northwestern University, on the armed services' record with affirmative action, and by William Julius Wilson, a University of Chicago sociologist, on the need for economic development to counter high unemployment among black men.
Professor Moskos, who declined to elaborate on other participants' remarks, said he had suggested that by investing in recruitment and special training, the private sector could benefit from the military's example. He said that affirmative action programs had done much to improve morale in the military during the last decade and that the key was the military's aggressive efforts to train all recruits to high standards, then offer extra help to those who needed it.
"One of the points I tried to make was that a level playing field was not enough," Mr. Moskos said. "What drives affirmative action problems is the dearth of qualified minority candidates. What the Army has is a series of uplift and educational programs to bring everybody up to standard." That, together with a heavy concentration of blacks among the ranks, makes the Army "the only place in the world where whites are routinely bossed around by blacks," largely without resentment, he said.

HEADLINE: Investigator Seeks Control of Javits Center Hiring

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
A special investigator is seeking court permission to take control of hiring for the lucrative carpenters' jobs at the Jacobs K. Javits Convention Center and accusing the president of the carpenters' union of allowing organized crime to persist at the center.
Kenneth Conboy, the investigator appointed by a Federal judge to monitor the 30,000-member New York District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, charged in a report yesterday that the union's president, Frederick W. Devine, had ignored a court order that requires him to stop the awarding of jobs to mob-connected union members and make them available to all members. 
 The report said Mr. Devine, who represents union members from southern New Jersey to Albany, was violating a consent decree issued last year to settle civil racketeering charges brought against the union. At that time, Mr. Conboy, a former Federal judge, was appointed to investigate and monitor activities of the union.
For the second time in recent months, Mr. Conboy submitted evidence linking the union's chief at the Javits Center, Anthony D. Fiorino, to organized crime. Mr. Fiorino is in charge of hiring carpenters to assemble and tear down exhibits at the center, the city's primary trade show venue. In administrative charges filed in December, Mr. Conboy said that Mr. Fiorino gave trade center jobs only to people in a special pool of about 100, many of them attached to the mob. Yesterday's filing includes sworn statements from admitted members of crime families identifying Mr. Fiorino as an associate of the Genovese crime family.
Mr. Devine, president of the union since 1991, appointed Mr. Fiorino last April to serve as steward at the Javits Center, a post that pays more than $100,000. Mr. Conboy charged yesterday that by refusing to dismiss Mr. Fiorino, Mr. Devine was in effect aiding criminal activity at the center.
In yesterday's report filed with the court, a copy of which was sent to Mr. Devine's Manhattan office, Mr. Conboy demanded the immediate dismissal of Mr. Fiorino. And in an open letter to rank-and-file members, Mr. Conboy said the union's job referral system "facilitates racketeering control of the center by the Genovese organized crime family."
"We have learned through law enforcement sources, and by taking depositions of over 30 of these favored 'carpenters,' that a large number of these 'pool list' members have some connection to organized crime," Mr. Conboy wrote.
Neither Mr. Devine or Mr. Fiorino could be reached for comment. Phone calls to Bernard Cohen, the labor union's general counsel, were not returned.
Mr. Conboy's request to take control of the hiring of carpenters for the Javits Center will be considered by Judge Charles S. Haight of Federal District Court, who approved last year's settlement between the union and the Justice Department.
Trade show exhibitors have long complained about shakedowns and excessive labor costs in dealing with carpenters and other unions at the state-run convention center.
Carpenters union members who were on the Javits Center preferred list made far more than those who were not, Mr. Conboy said. According to his report, for the first seven months of 1994, employees on the list earned median wages of about $25,000, while union members who were not on the list and did not have steady work earned a median total of about $510 for the same period.
Mr. Conboy's report came a week after another independent report charged that the Teamsters local at the center -- which has been plagued by allegations of corruption since it opened in 1986 -- was also tainted by organized crime.
By the end of last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani publicly requested that the center be turned over to the city, and Gov. George E. Pataki then raised the ante, threatening to shut the center down and demanding the immediate resignation of its 13-member governing board. At the same time, the State Senate announced investigative hearings.
"It's obvious to the Governor's people that they are taking over a hot potato," said Fabian Palomino, who resigned in January from his post as president and chief executive officer of the center. Governor Pataki, he said, "has to act because he sees the Mayor, and the Mayor sincerely believes that he can do a better job than anyone else."
City planners and private developers in recent months have lobbied government officials, urging them to focus on tourism as a means of economic development. A vibrant Javits Center, free of crime and exorbitant costs, would help create jobs and growth throughout the city, they assert. At a conference on the city's economy last month, Jonathan M. Tisch, president and chief executive officer of Loews Hotels, appealed to the public officials and private executives in attendance. "The most important issue is what do we do with the Javits Center," he said.
A civil hearing for Mr. Fiorino is scheduled for Monday. Mr. Conboy will act as a prosecutor, and the charges will be heard by a three-member panel, named by Judge Haight. The most severe penalty the panel can impose is the expulsion of Mr. Fiorino from the union. An expulsion by the panel can be appealed to Judge Haight.
Even with the imminent hearing date, Mr. Conboy is indicating that he may take similar action against Mr. Devine. In a letter sent to Mr. Devine yesterday, the investigator threatened, "If you continue to fail to act against Mr. Fiorino, I will be compelled to proceed against you for breaching your fiduciary duty to the union."

HEADLINE: OIL CONCERN ENDS A DEAL WITH IRAN AS PRESIDENT ACTS

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
A big American oil company said today that it would not proceed with its agreement to develop two large offshore oilfields for Iran after the White House announced that President Clinton would issue a directive barring all such transactions.
The step by Conoco Inc. ended an energy deal that would have been the first involving Iran and the United States since Washington severed relations with Teheran in 1980. It came after eight days of debate within the Administration about how and whether to block an agreement that top deputies to Mr. Clinton acknowledged was legal but said could undermine American efforts to isolate Iran. 
 In announcing Mr. Clinton's decision this morning to block such oil-development agreements, the White House said the President was trying to set an example for American allies and was also trying to prevent Iran from accumulating wealth that could make it more dangerous to its neighbors.
"We need to send a clear and unequivocal message," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said. "There cannot be normal relations until Iran's unacceptable behavior changes."
One reason, perhaps, that Conoco misjudged the suitability of its Iranian deal was that the Administration had been sending American business a clear message: Join the age of "economic engagement," by helping the United States win over governments through greater access to American capital and investment. That was the case in China, North Korea and Vietnam. But in pursuing a policy of economic containment in Iran, one Administration official said, "We draw the line in countries with policies that are beyond the pale." [News analysis, page D5.]
The Administration was surprised by the deal between Conoco and Iran, which some analysts valued at $1 billion, and its initial complaints were dismissed by the company, a Houston-based subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Conoco emphasized that it was operating within the law.
But after senior Administration officials objected strongly in meetings with top Conoco executives, the company's chief executive, Constantine Nicandros, indicated that he would end the controversial deal if the President made clear that it violated United States policy, aides to Mr. Clinton said today.
At the same time, three powerful members of the Du Pont board, members of the Bronfman family, had been expected to vote against the accord, and a statement issued by Conoco today suggested that their opposition played an important role in the company's decision. Edgar M. Bronfman, Charles R. Bronfman and Edgar Bronfman Jr. are top officers of the Seagram Company, which owns 24.2 percent of Du Pont. They are also active in Jewish organizations that support the Administration's policy on Iran.
"Conoco's agreement with the National Iranian Oil Company was contingent on Du Pont board approval," the company said. "Du Pont's board of directors' approval would not be given if the U.S. Government opposed the agreement."
In prohibiting Americans from developing oil and gas for Iran, the White House said that Mr. Clinton was using the authority given to him under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, which allows him to block commerce for national security reasons.
Even under Mr. Clinton's directive, American companies would still be permitted to buy oil from Iran and to resell it to third countries, a practice that accounts for one-fourth of the oil sold by Iran. The White House said that it was reviewing whether to close those and other exceptions to its policy of isolating Iran, which is being criticized as too weak by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, and by others on Capitol Hill.
But Administration officials said that by blocking the Conoco deal the Administration had taken an important step. They said that to allow the agreement to stand would have invited Russia, China and the European allies to proceed with nuclear and commercial accords with Iran that the Administration was determined to prevent.
To allow Conoco to develop the vast oilfields in the Persian Gulf, Mr. McCurry said, would have "dangerously added to the Iranian capacity to do the things that we regard as most dangerous in the international community."
As examples, the White House pointed specifically today to what it said was the continued support of terrorism by Iran, its efforts to undermine the Middle East peace process and its quest to obtain weapons of mass destruction.
But in shaping a decision on the proposed oil deal, Administration officials said they wanted most immediately to send a signal to Russia, which the United States is trying to persuade to break off an agreement to complete construction of two nuclear reactors for Iran. The Administration has said the deal could help Iran build nuclear weapons, and officials said today that they hoped Moscow would see an example in American forbearance.
"We're giving up something for a greater good," one Administration official said of Mr. Clinton's decision to block an accord that could have produced millions of dollars in revenues for an American company. "We're hoping that others will be willing to do the same."
Under the deal, Conoco Iran N.V., a Netherlands-based affiliate of Conoco, was to have been the contractor to develop two offshore fields close to Sirri Island in the Persian Gulf about 80 miles from Iran. A Conoco spokesman had said that the two fields were expected to produce more than 120,000 barrels a day in two years.
Among the European oil companies that competed with Conoco for the project were Elf Aquitaine S.A. and Total, both of France. Administration officials said today that they hoped that France would prevent those companies from taking part in the deal, but indicated they were not optimistic that Paris would agree.
Even the White House was initially tepid in its criticism of the Conoco agreement, saying as it became public last week that the accord "was not a helpful development." But the Administration's stance grew harder in large part at the urging of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who has led the Administration's drive to isolate Iran and who criticized the oil deal from the Middle East last week as "inconsistent with the containment policy that we have carried forward."
Mr. Christopher later withdrew from policy discussions about the oil deal because his former law firm represented Conoco. But Administration officials said today that a group including Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser; Bill White, the Deputy Energy Secretary, and Peter Tarnoff, an Under Secretary of State, had worked intensively in recent days to settle on the course that Mr. Clinton embraced today.
A senior Administration official said that Mr. White raised strong objections to the deal in a preliminary meeting with senior Conoco executives last Thursday, and that both he and Mr. Tarnoff repeated those objections the next day in discussions here with Mr. Nicandros of Conoco.
After Conoco released its statement today, the company's chief spokesman did not return a telephone call to his Houston office. But Mr. White said in an interview that Mr. Nicandros had indicated with some reluctance even on Friday that the company would not resist if the Administration scuttled the deal.
Mr. White said that Mr. Nicandros told him in response to a question that Conoco "would be willing to comply with a clear Administration policy."

HEADLINE: February Retail Sales Had Surprising Slide

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The Government reported today that retail sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent in February, a surprising decline that was the first in almost a year.
"Consumers are keeping their wallets shut," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch. "The retail sales report provides more evidence to support our view that the economy is slowing significantly." 
 Indeed, almost every category of merchant suffered, from car dealerships and furniture stores to grocery and department stores, the Commerce Department found.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the economy -- with half of the money pushed across retail counters and the other half going for items like car insurance, rent and dental bills. Business and government spend the remaining one-third.
The drop in retail sales appears to make it even more unlikely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its March 28 policy meeting. The Fed has been raising interest rates for more than a year to keep inflation in check. But each fresh sign of slackening from the economy's rapid 4 percent growth last year provides more evidence for most economists that the rate increase on Feb. 1 was the last for a while.
The central bank will be "very reluctant" to move in the current climate, contended Paul L. Kasriel, economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Yet some analysts were skeptical about the report of lower retail sales, which they said might reflect little more than new anti-fraud procedures at the Internal Revenue Service that have delayed tax refunds and sharply curtailed loans using expected refunds as collateral.
"There's a $6 billion shortfall" of refund money so far this year, said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson Associates, a consultant on the bond market. Over all, Mr. Crandall said about $2 billion of retail sales was lost last month, roughly the difference between the reported February decline and a gain of that size, which most analysts expected.
Mr. Crandall predicted a moderate sales rise in March and a strong rebound in April.
Darwin L. Beck, economist at CS First Boston, agreed that slower tax refunds were a factor last month. "Consumer spending probably has slowed somewhat," Mr. Beck said, "but I'm not sure the economy will drift down to that magic 2.5 percent that the Federal Reserve seems to want."
Another reason for minimizing the February decline was that sales for January were revised upward to show a six-tenths of 1 percent advance instead of the two-tenths of 1 percent rise initially reported.
Still, lower sales were a widespread reality for merchants last month as durable goods, which have not advanced since November, fell six-tenths of 1 percent, while sales of nondurables skidded into decline after posting steady increases since last May.
"Seven interest rate hikes in a year were bound to have an effect sooner or later," said Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, the largest industry trade group. "Increased payments for adjustable-rate mortgages and credit cards have sapped consumers' discretionary income."
Automotive dealers experienced a 1 percent sales decline last month while sales of furniture and other equipment for the home slumped 1.2 percent. Stores selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes took in five-tenths of 1 percent less money.
Among nondurables, sales were down 1.1 percent at stores selling general merchandise, 1.2 percent for apparel and accessory stores, six-tenths of 1 percent for food stores, four-tenths of 1 percent at drugstores and two-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars. The only increase was that for gasoline service stations, one-tenth of 1 percent.
Total sales last month were $192.85 billion, or 6 percent above the February 1994 level, with no adjustment for inflation. Sales for December through February were 7.1 percent ahead of the period a year earlier, the Commerce Department's report also showed.

HEADLINE: Weak Retail Sales Cheer Markets, Sending Stocks Up

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
It was a surprisingly good day on Wall Street yesterday, although the dollar remained under pressure.
The spark came from the new report on retail sales, which declined in February for the first time in almost a year. The five-tenths of 1 percent drop signaled that the economy might be slowing, thus encouraging traders and investors into believing that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates soon. [Page D2.] 
 Stock traders bid prices up to record levels. Bond traders sent prices up for a fifth consecutive session, as the yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 7.36 percent, its lowest since June 2. But the dollar rose only slightly against both the Japanese yen and the German mark, as rumors that could hurt the dollar continued to circulate among currency traders.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed to a record 4,048.75, up 23.52 points, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also hit a record 492.89, up 2.84 points.
The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, tracking the performance of 4,930 companies, gave the strongest performance, closing at a record 808.24, up 5.93 points -- at last surging past its March 1994 record of 803.93.
On the New York Stock Exchange, almost two stocks advanced for every one that declined. New highs were set for 105 stocks and new lows for only 25. Volume was heavy at 346.2 million shares.
The dollar affects the stock and bond markets because a declining dollar lowers the value of stocks and bonds for foreign investors, who are an increasingly important source of investment capital.
In the first week of March, the dollar plunged more than 6 percent against the German mark. But since then it has gained back about half of its value, or three percent. But the dollar continues to be down about 6 percent against the yen.
Yesterday, the dollar closed at 90.85 yen, up from 90.75 yen, and ended at 1.4140 German marks, up from 1.4067 marks.
Currency traders said the dollar may be rising for short-term speculative reasons rather than any permanent strengthening.
For example, there were rumors that the Bundesbank, the German counterpart to the Federal Reserve, would cut German interest rates soon, thus making German marks less valuable compared with dollars. That may have led to short-term buying of dollars.
But developments in the rest of Europe could just as easily send the dollar down further. There were rumors that the Italian Chamber of Deputies may delay a key vote on the Government's budget. And Credit Lyonnais, the troubled French bank, was reported to be considering a multibillion-dollar charge against earnings.
Both developments could prompt currency traders to dump French francs and Italian lire to buy German marks, raising the value of the mark and thus encouraging traders to dump dollars.
David De Rosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at Swiss Bank, said the stock and bond markets might be setting themselves up for a fall if they were reading too much into the recent stability of the dollar.
"Let's be realistic," he said. "In the next two days, there are going to be a ton of economic reports that could contain surprises." The February Producer Price Index is due this morning and the Consumer Price Index is due tomorrow.
Indeed, one bond trader at a major investment house, who asked not to be named, said, "We're incredibly vulnerable to bad news."
Nonetheless, the financial markets have been coming to the most optimistic conclusions about recent economic data. A stronger-than-expected jobs report last Friday reassured stock traders worried about an economic slowdown and a drop in corporate profits. Slow growth in wages and salaries, which was reflected in the same report, reassured bond traders worried about inflation.
The Dow surged 52 points to a record 4,035.61 last Friday, but the S.& P. and Nasdaq indexes failed to break records then.
Yesterday, however, a seemingly contradictory report on retail sales reassured both stock and bond traders.
Bond prices rose sharply immediately after the 8:30 A.M. report, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond closing at 7.36 percent, down from 7.45 percent. Stock prices soared an hour later, when the equity markets opened.
Stock traders were skeptical about the dollar, too, but nonetheless optimistic about stocks. "The market is gaining momentum and people are getting comfortable with a Dow above 4,000," said Paul Hennessey, chief stock trader at the Boston Company. "People are looking for a Producer Price Index and a Consumer Price Index to be within expectations" of moderate inflation.
Donald Fine, chief bond market analyst for Chase Securities, did not minimize the dollar's problems but noted that the dollar has been falling for years and had not contributed greatly to inflation in the United States.
Mr. Fine said that the stock and bond markets reacted so positively to the retail sales data because the numbers told more about future economic performance than did job-creation or unemployment figures.
"A lot of people were unconvinced that the economy is slowing and the retail sales numbers convinced them," Mr. Fine said.
A wide range of stocks rose, including local telephone companies like GTE, long-distance carriers like AT&T and health-care-related companies like American Home Products. Among blue-chip stocks, Boeing gained 2 1/4, to 49, after winning a $1.2 billion aircraft order. And Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing rose 1 3/4, to 57 5/8.
Dart Group surged 14 3/4, to 89 3/4, after news that company directors are considering a large stock buyback or special dividend. Leaseway Transportation advanced 625/32 , to 1923/32 , after it agreed to be bought by Penske Truck Leasing for $200 million.
Sports and Recreation fell 7 3/4, to 10 3/4, after the specialty retailer announced disappointing fourth-quarter earnings. And Apple Computer slid 3 1/8, to 35, because the computer maker announced slowing sales of its hot-selling Power Macintosh related to production and supply shortages.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.36 points, to 266.53; the American Stock Exchange market value index gained 0.85 point, to 453.91.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL NEWS;
Big Investor Relations Task: Selling Mexico to Wall St.

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Mexico, the prodigal son of the financial markets, has a lot to do if it is to repair its credibility with Wall Street and international investors, who poured billions of dollars into Mexico and were badly scalded by the recent 48 percent devaluation of the Mexican peso.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz came to New York again yesterday to explain Mexico's second economic plan and to tackle this huge investor relations task. With the skill of the quintessential technocrat and Stanford-trained economist that he is, Mr. Ortiz smoothly rattled off projections and answers to journalists and investors in back-to-back meetings at the St. Regis Hotel. At times, though, he looked nervous as he tried to convince wary listeners that this time Mexico had hit on a workable plan. Indeed, the Mexican Government's confidence, even arrogance, of a year ago has turned to anxiety. 
At best, though, Mr. Ortiz's Wall Street audience was muted and cautiously optimistic after his presentation of the plan. That package includes a 50 percent increase in value-added taxes, Government spending cuts, increases in gasoline and electricity prices and proposals to shore up Mexico's banking system. The nation's gross domestic product is expected to contract by 1 percent this year, the minister said.
A spokeswoman for J. P. Morgan & Company -- which is advising Mexico on its financing strategy and which arranged yesterday's meetings -- said the 70 or 80 Wall Street financiers who attended yesterday's meeting represented those with substantial Mexican investments.
"The country's new macroeconomic program is clearly a step forward," said Lawrence Goodman, a vice president of Salomon Brothers who listened to Mr. Ortiz's remarks by telephone and who met with him later in the day. But, he added, Salomon would be following "quite closely" how Mexico handles the amortization of its short-term debts, which include short-term Treasury notes known as tesobonos.
"Tesobonos, bank certificates of deposit and interbank lines: until there's a formulation for addressing all those, one of the risks is heightened pressure on the currency," Mr. Goodman added. The Mexican peso has slid badly in recent weeks, ending the day today at 6.635 pesos to the dollar in New York trading.
Mr. Ortiz's audience listened with the respect and wariness of those who have suffered. He fielded a series of questions after his presentation that gave a sense of the financial markets' concerns about Mexico. There was anxiety -- even suspicion -- about how the country would manage its short-term debt.
"Isn't that double-counting," one investor questioned as Mr. Ortiz tried to explain how the Government would amortize tesobonos.
"Why not establish a fixed exchange rate?" asked another financier, who has watched the peso deteriorate to current levels, from an exchange rate of 3.465 to the dollar before devaluation on Dec. 20.
A fixed exchange rate would be unrealistic, Mr. Ortiz answered, adding later that he and his colleagues thought that the Mexican currency was now "grossly undervalued."
At least some of the concerns about Mexico's short-term debt were exaggerated, Mr. Ortiz argued. The country has the capital to meet its short-term payments, he said. And Mexico plans to refinance some of its short-term notes with international banks, but Mr. Ortiz cautioned that the country had to have its whole package in place before it could do that. To be sure, Mr. Ortiz does not have great expectations for big flows of foreign capital anytime soon. An increase in domestic savings and tough Government belt-tightening will have to do the trick, he says.
But at least some of those listening to Mr. Ortiz's remarks needed more assurance. An investment banker from Goldman, Sachs approached the minister after his remarks, seeking confirmation of what loans Mexico was currently drawing on from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Those leaving Mr. Ortiz's presentation to bankers and investors generally preferred not to be identified by name. "There was nothing much new," said one investment banker who declined to be identified. "It's going to take time to rebuild trust with investors."
A colleague, however, disagreed, maintaining that Mr. Ortiz had provided new information about how Mexico's bigger companies would be aided by the Government in dealing with their foreign-currency debts.
Mexico, realizing that it has a crisis of confidence on its hands, wants to keep its international investors informed. "I hope to come again in April to report to you," Mr. Ortiz told his audience at the St. Regis.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz of Mexico met with bankers and investors yesterday in Manhattan. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
As U.S. hotel companies rush to get ready to enter Cuba, Days Inns appears to be a step ahead.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AMERICAN hotel companies have made no secret of their intention to expand into Cuba if and when Washington lifts its economic embargo, but the company that appears positioned to move the quickest boasts neither luxury resorts nor a reputation as a hotel for business travelers. It is Days Inns of America Inc., a chain of 1,600 economy hotels.
"We've identified about 12 properties we consider suitable to carry our banner," said John Russell, president of Days Inns, "and once relations are normalized between the U.S. and Cuba we'd be ready to go." 
 Without commenting on the fate of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, Mr. Russell predicted that "normalization" would occur "within a year."
In preparation, Days Inns, based in Valhalla, N.Y., recently signed an option agreement with the Realstar Group of Toronto, which has 45 Days Inns franchises in Canada. A subsidiary of Realstar, Delta Hotels and Resorts, manages seven Government-owned properties in Cuba, and Delta officials helped Days Inns find the properties that the American chain considered suitable.
While the option agreement does not specify the countries in which the development will occur, Days Inns has applied to the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control for the right to include Cuba in the agreement.
"We're hedging our bets," Mr. Russell said. "While 60 percent of our guests are leisure travelers, in about 500 of our properties at least 65 percent of them are business travelers. So when the surge of American visitors hits Cuba, many businessmen will choose to stay at properties they're familiar with, namely Days Inns."
And when Cuban-Americans return to visit, Mr. Russell added, "if their relatives' houses can't accommodate them, they'll stay with us, because they know us."
 
Support for T.W.A. at Home
 In an unusual demonstration of civic support, Civic Progress, an organization of the chief executives of the leading companies based in St. Louis, said yesterday that its members would purchase up to six months of travel on Trans World Airlines to demonstrate their confidence in the future of the troubled hometown carrier.
The advance-ticket purchase plan, devised after a review of the airline's operations and finances, "is a demonstration of our confidence in T.W.A.'s new management team as it continues to complete its long-term financial restructuring," said Andrew E. Newman, president of Civic Progress and chairman of Edison Brothers Stores. The other companies involved are Anheuser-Busch, Monsanto, Emerson Electric, McDonnell Douglas, Ralston Purina and the May Department Stores.
While declining to discuss the value of the commitment, which will represent about 110,000 round trips, John McDonald, a spokesman for T.W.A., said it represented "roughly five days' worth" of the traffic of the airline at Lambert International Airport, its St. Louis hub.
 
American Express in France
 The 100-year-old American Express office on Rue Scribe in Paris has played an important role in the life of expatriate writers, painters and jazz musicians. They used it as a home away from home to pick up mail, change currency and cash traveler's checks. So it is natural to assume that American Express has long been a big factor in France's travel industry.
Not so, and especially not in business travel. In fact, earlier this year a French businessman who is a rival of American Express taunted the company as being a distant fourth in the French travel market.
To remedy that, American Express recently joined with Havas Voyages, the biggest travel agency in France, to create a joint subsidiary that will combine the business travel operations of both companies. Bearing the unwieldy name of Havas Voyages American Express, the new company will begin operating next Jan. 1.
Havas Voyages, which had sales of about $820 million last year, will own about 80 percent of the operation, while American Express, with $220 million in business travel sales in France in 1994, will own the rest. The new company is expected to operate more than 180 business travel offices and employ about 1,200 people.
 
New Hilton Checkout Plan
 Express check-in and checkout are features at many hotels, but Hilton Hotels hopes to leave the competition in the starting blocks with what it calls Tableside Zipout Check-Out -- checkout at the breakfast table. Upon request, guests will be given printouts of their bills, including their breakfast checks if the meals are charged to their rooms. After eating, they can bypass the front desk and will not have to return to their rooms.
After initial tests at airports in Chicago and San Francisco, Hilton plans to expand the test this year to many of its 34 other airport hotels. What could be next? Presenting guests with their bills at check-in?

HEADLINE: Boeing Is Victor In S.A.S. Deal With a Value Of $1.16 Billion

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
In a big victory for the Boeing Company and a serious setback for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Scandinavian Airlines System said today that it would purchase 35 new Boeing 737 jetliners, valued at $1.16 billion, and take options on another 35 planes.
McDonnell Douglas had been counting on S.A.S., the flagship carrier of Sweden, Norway and Denmark, to be the so-called launching customer that would justify beginning production of the company's new 100-seat MD-95 aircraft. 
 Without this sale, the introduction of the MD-95 will be delayed, and it could be scuttled if McDonnell Douglas receives no suitably large orders for the plane in the near future.
S.A.S. will now be the launching customer for the Boeing 737-600, a 100-seat version of the venerable 737, with improved electronics and quieter engines with fewer emissions. The Boeing victory is all the more impressive because the company also beat competing bids from the leading European aircraft manufacturers, including Airbus, British Aerospace and Fokker.
"If you look at Boeing in the last three and a half years of this recession, they've rejuvenated the product line, upgraded the manufacturing base -- productivity is significantly improved as are profit margins -- and at this point it looks like their marketing is becoming more aggressive," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities. "That's a world-beating combination, and they took on the world in this transaction and won."
Shares of Boeing, which is based in Seattle, rose $2.25, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, while shares of McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, fell $1.50, to $55.625.
"It's a disappointment," said John Thom, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas in Long Beach, Calif. "We thought we had the right plane for S.A.S., and they made a different choice. The effect is probably going to be a later launch than we had anticipated."
Mr. Thom said several other airlines were considering the MD-95, which has a price in the mid-$20 million range, and the first deliveries could occur in late 1998.
S.A.S. said it had selected the 737-600 because it was modern, cost-effective and had good environmental properties.
In addition, "S.A.S. has had the advantage in that the market currently offers very favorable terms, and we have been able to choose from a number of very good alternatives," the president and chief executive of S.A.S., Jan Stenberg, said in a statement yesterday. "Our selection of Boeing was based on such deciding factors as flexibility, environmental considerations, economics and the fact that Boeing is a very professional and solid supplier."
Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the sale was particularly damaging to McDonnell Douglas because S.A.S. was traditionally a strong customer for the company. "More than 70 percent of S.A.S.'s current fleet is Douglas," Mr. Rubel said. "This was the cornerstone of Douglas's MD-95 strategy."
Mr. Rubel said the common cockpit design of different 737's and the high residual value of the planes might have influenced the S.A.S. decision.
But in the current market, favorable financing terms and flexibility often play roles as great as or greater than those played by the relative merits of competing airplanes. By most measures the MD-95, which combines the modern cockpit of the McDonnell Douglas MD-90 with the slim fuselage and wing of the company's older, smaller DC-9, is comparable to the new 737, and the prices quoted are similar.
The actual prices, however, are not disclosed, and Boeing has shown that it can be very accommodating on the financing side to close a big deal. Mr. Demisch of BT Securities said that in a previous large sale to Finn Air, the other large Scandinavian carrier, Boeing agreed to accept the airline's existing fleet of older DC-9's and DC-10's as a down payment on new 737's and 767's.
Though no such arrangement was announced in the sale yesterday, Mr. Demisch said it was not unreasonable to assume that similar terms were offered.
Though McDonnell Douglas has less flexibility because of its smaller size, Mr. Demisch said it was too soon to dismiss the ability of the company to introduce the MD-95 and benefit from a worldwide recovery in commercial aircraft sales. "There is going to be significant improvement over the next two years in jetliner demand," he said, "and some of the worries about McDonnell Douglas will fade as the business volume picks up."
Boeing said its first deliveries to S.A.S. were scheduled for the second half of 1998. The 737-600's will become the backbone of the S.A.S. short-haul fleet, serving Scandinavia and Eastern and Western Europe. They will replace McDonnell Douglas DC-9's and Fokker F-28's. The S.A.S. long-haul fleet currently includes Boeing 767's.
Separately, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said that Japan Airlines had ordered four Boeing 737-400's, an older version of the small jetliner, in a deal valued at about $180 million. The first of the planes will be delivered in May, and will be used to help expand the domestic services of the airline in conjunction with Japan Trans Ocean Air, of which Japan Airlines owns 51 percent, Boeing said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boeing has won a $1.16 billion order from S.A.S. The airline's president, Jan Stenberg, discussed the deal in Stockholm yesterday, saying, "We have been able to choose from a number of very good alternatives." (Associated Press) (pg. D4)
