HEADLINE: Filipinos Protest Singapore Death Sentence

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: MANILA, March 15

 BODY:
The Government of Singapore, which has tried to portray the debate over its draconian legal system as a clash between Asian and Western values, now finds its courts under attack by fellow Asians who are campaigning to prevent the execution of a Philippine woman this week.
Leading Philippine politicians, human rights groups and church leaders are demanding that Singapore stay the execution of Flor Contemplacion, a Philippine maid who is scheduled to be hanged on Friday for the deaths of another maid and a 4-year-old Singaporean boy in 1991. 
 President Fidel V. Ramos has joined in the appeals, asking that Singaporean prosecutors reopen the case because of new testimony suggesting that Mrs. Contemplacion was framed, and that the other Philippine maid was actually killed by her vengeful Singaporean employer after the boy had accidentally drowned.
The testimony is coming from a third maid, Emilia Frenilla, who has since returned home to the Philippines. Mrs. Frenilla has said that the boy drowned in a bathtub after suffering an epileptic fit, and that the boy's outraged father then killed the maid, Della Maga, who was supposed to be caring for the child.
According to her testimony, Mrs. Frenilla eavesdropped on members of the boy's family as they decided to pin both deaths on Mrs. Contemplacion, who was a friend of Mrs. Maga.
Jaime Cardinal Sin, the head of the Roman Catholic Church in this devoutly Catholic country, has said he will ask Pope John Paul II to intervene with the Singaporean Government to save Mrs. Contemplacion from the gallows.
The case has made for banner headlines in newspapers in Manila for weeks, turning this into the Philippine equivalent of last year's furor over the flogging of an American teenager, Michael P. Fay, who pleaded guilty to vandalism in Singapore.
At the time of the Fay case, Singaporean officials argued that their critics in the United States and elsewhere in the West did not understand Asian values, which, the Singaporeans say, demand strict law enforcement and a preference for the rights of society over the rights of an individual.
But the reaction in the Philippines to the prosecution of Mrs. Contemplacion suggests that Singapore's concept of Asian values is not one shared by all of its Asian neighbors.
For many Filipinos, Mrs. Contemplacion has come to symbolize the plight of millions of Filipinos who are forced by the poverty of their homeland to work abroad, most of them as household servants or construction workers elsewhere in Asia or in the Middle East.
"Every new revelation in the Contemplacion case seems to point at a frame-up and a miscarriage of justice," the Philippine Daily Inquirer said in an editorial this week. "It's no longer Singapore's good will and compassion that are being put to a test here. What's on trial is its system of justice."
The Singaporean Embassy in Manila, which has been the target this week of telephoned bomb threats and of several noisy protests by supporters of Mrs. Contemplacion, did not respond to written questions about the case. In turning down earlier appeals for clemency, Singapore's Government has said she received a fair trial.
Mrs. Contemplacion, 42, worked as a maid in Singapore to support her unemployed husband and their four children back in the Philippines. The children, who had not seen their mother in four years, were allowed to travel to Singapore this month for a final reunion.
Mrs. Contemplacion was arrested in the two deaths in 1991.
Philippine officials say Mrs. Contemplacion initially pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity on the advice of her Singaporean lawyers. Her lawyers said she suffered a type of epilepsy that limited her responsibility for her actions.
But the court rejected the plea and sentenced Mrs. Contemplacion to death. News reports here have suggested that Mrs. Contemplacion had nothing to do with the crime but claimed mental illness on the advice of the lawyers, in hopes of a lesser sentence should she be found guilty.
The uproar over Mrs. Contemplacion followed a furor here in January over the execution of three Filipino contract workers in Saudi Arabia. They were beheaded after they were accused of holding an influential Arab family hostage and then killing four of them. Details of the case were never made public by Saudi officials, although news accounts here have suggested that the Saudi police were responsible for the deaths in a shootout.

HEADLINE: Dollar Falls Sharply Despite U.S. Growth

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday to near-record lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark, despite signs of robust growth in the American economy that could lead to higher interest rates. Still, the stock and bond markets largely shrugged off the fall in the dollar.
The Government said that industrial production and factory capacity rose in February to new 15-year highs and that producer prices rose by three-tenths of 1 percent. In the past, such reports have bolstered the dollar by raising the prospect that the Federal Reserve might increase rates to keep inflation in check. Instead, the dollar continued on its downward course of recent weeks. 
 Financial analysts warned that stocks and bonds might not be able to withstand the impact of a falling dollar for long.
Business Day, page D1.

HEADLINE: In French Presidential Race, Lagging Neo-Gaullist Hustles on the Hustings

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: MONTPELLIER, France, March 14

 BODY:
Once the front-runner and now the underdog in the race for the French presidency, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur is trying to regain the lead with a new campaign full of hustle and hoopla.
With just five weeks to go before the April 23 vote, and polls showing that close to 50 percent of the voters have not made up their minds, Mr. Balladur clearly hopes to beat the odds by replacing his aloof, stiff image with something a little more hot-blooded. 
 He played openly to the French patriotic pride of about 2,500 people who came to see him in a hangar-size exhibition hall here in the south of France on Tuesday. They blasted air horns and chanted "E-douard! E-douard!" in a kind of noisy delirium that had been notably absent from his campaign until now.
The reaction apparently excited the reserved, gray-haired 65-year- old Prime Minister so much that he jumped up onto a chair and clasped hands in a victory salute, though he never loosened his gray three-button suit.
"I want this to be a dignified campaign," he told the throng, "but we are on earth; we're not angels."
That didn't mean the other candidates should behave diabolically, Mr. Balladur warned in his only allusion to published insinuations that he had cut corners financially and connived to thwart investigations of corruption in his neo-Gaullist conservative party, the Rally for the Republic.
But he conceded that with his earlier strategy of remaining far above the fray, his campaign had gone through "a difficult passage." The Prime Minister now trails his fellow conservative, Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, and the Socialist candidate, Lionel Jospin, in the public opinion polls.
The latest, a Harris survey published on Tuesday, the day Mr. Balladur was here, predicted 18 percent of the vote for Mr. Balladur in the first round of the two-stage presidential election on April 23, with 21 percent for Mr. Jospin and 28 percent for Mr. Chirac. The winner is likely to be determined in a runoff on May 7.
Mr. Balladur has begun a new campaign that is almost American in flavor. Here he had campaign workers passing out red baseball hats and T-shirts, and he made his entrance to the swelling strains of music made popular by a Gerard Depardieu movie.
Try to picture Bill Clinton getting cheers at a shrimp creole dinner in Louisiana by claiming triumph in the negotiations on the global trade agreement that was concluded two years ago. Mr. Balladur did, saying he had put backbone into his fellow Europeans to fight President Clinton on American attempts to outlaw protectionist measures for movies, audiovisual programming and agriculture.
"We need a stronger France, more confident of itself and of its future," Mr. Balladur said. "Europe, properly recognized and used well, is a source of increased strength for France."
It would be easy to picture the uproar in France if Chancellor Helmut Kohl had said anything like that in his campaign for re-election in Germany last October. Mr. Balladur's platform describes French-German relations as the pivot of European union, but he wants to update the 35-year-old friendship treaty to take account of German unification.
He also said again here that he would push for a common European currency as early as 1997 to eliminate the strains placed on the French economy by the German mark, which has surged recently against the franc and other European currencies as it rose against the dollar.
Mr. Balladur, a conservative who has been Prime Minister for the last two years under the Socialist he hopes to succeed, Francois Mitterrand, has a hard job representing continuity and change simultaneously at a time when people seem to want change, but only if it doesn't hurt them.
So he tried hard to be folksy, gracefully accepting a chocolate-covered coffee bean during a visit to an agricultural research center, and then picking the pieces endlessly out of his teeth with a white handkerchief. But he never lost his smile.
On national television on Sunday night, Mr. Balladur conceded that unlike Mr. Chirac, a veteran of previous French presidential election campaigns, he had perhaps been unprepared for their rigors.
"I am in training," said Mr. Balladur, a former Finance Minister and businessman. "But I am learning to fight back."
Last week, after an anti-establishment newspaper, Le Canard Enchaine, reported that he had made millions of francs through stock options and consultancy fees awarded him by G.S.I., the French computer company of which he had been chief executive from 1977 to 1986, Mr. Balladur took the unusual step of disclosing some of his finances.
He said he had made a total of $550,000 in profits from the perfectly legal sale of company stock when he left the company to go into government, and had been paid $20,000 a month as a consultant to the company from 1988 to 1993, when he became Prime Minister. French news organizations calculated his current net worth at about $4.2 million, triple Mr. Chirac's and several times that of Mr. Jospin.
Mr. Balladur told the television audience that he was a free man who owed nothing to anybody, financially or politically.
Many of the people who turn out for him appear to be on the comfortable side of the French income curve, and the other side of middle age. But Mr. Balladur, like the two other main candidates, says that his first actions as President would be aimed at reducing France's unemployment rate, now above 12 percent.
He said the first thing he would do is legislate a reduction of government-imposed health insurance charges on companies that hire the long-term unemployed by $800 a year per person, with a five-year goal of finding jobs for one million.
On March 25, thousands of supporters from around the country will converge on Le Bourget, north of Paris, for what is intended to be a demonstration of mass popularity. "Free transportation in special high-speed train," announced fliers for that rally. Everybody who came to the dinner here got one.
"France has become a raw and difficult society in which too many people have lost out," Mr. Balladur said. "I don't promise, 'Vote for me and in six months everything will be better'; it will take years of hard work," he said. "I want France to be better off, and the French to be happier than they are now."

HEADLINE: Mideast Goal Of Clinton And Hassan

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
With Israel and Syria set to resume direct talks soon, President Clinton and King Hassan II of Morocco called today for speeding up the quest for Middle East peace.
After a White House meeting with the Moroccan leader, Mr. Clinton spoke of renewed hope and urged the parties to seize what he said was now a real opportunity to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict. King Hassan, who is beginning a state visit to the United States, said it was crucial that the tempo of talks between Palestinians and Israelis be quickened. 
 "This newborn peace appears to be threatened by dangers because it's not a full-fledged peace," the Moroccan King warned on the South Lawn of the White House.
The meeting between the two leaders came as Secretary of State Warren Christopher returned from the Middle East with an agreement between Israel and Syria to resume their discussions early next week in Washington. Mr. Christopher told reporters aboard his plane that the United States would play a central role in pressing for progress as the two sides try to work out an agreement on the future of the Golan Heights, and Mr. Clinton called the accord on new talks "a very encouraging development."
At a Rose Garden news conference after their 90-minute meeting, King Hassan praised Mr. Clinton for his "relentless efforts" on behalf of Middle East peace. But the Moroccan leader's comments also underscored the priority that both men said must still be accorded to talks between Israel and the Palestinians, which remain contentious even 18 months after the handshake and agreement between Yasir Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin.
The King suggested that "signs of good will" in the Arab-Israeli peace effort could persuade members of the Arab League to lift their economic boycott of Israel. But while the Moroccan King has been active in encouraging other Arab leaders to make openings toward Israel, he would not say today whether he believed it was time for the boycott to be lifted.
Asked today what the White House could do to speed up the Israel-Syria talks, Mr. Clinton said, "We cannot make a peace for the parties." But other Administration officials said an active part would be played by Dennis Ross, Mr. Christopher's Middle East coordinator, who will travel to the region at the end of the month to try to push the discussions to a higher diplomatic level.
In their first stage, the principal negotiators will be the Israeli Ambassador, Itamar Rabinovich, and the Syrian Ambassador, Walid Moallem. But part of Mr. Ross's job during the meetings and on his trip to the region will be to make suggestions about the status of the Golan Heights and other issues that the two countries have been unable to solve since they began direct discussions in October 1991.
As he takes over the next round of shuttle diplomacy in the region, Mr. Ross will be seeking enough common ground to enlist the Israeli and Syrian military commanders in the Washington talks.

HEADLINE: Crackdown on Job-Injury Costs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Willie Brown, one of the most powerful politicians in California, recently found himself on the other side of the fence from the working people whose causes he likes to champion.
Shortly after Mr. Brown, the Assembly Speaker for California, invested in an Oakland radio station, almost all the employees filed claims seeking workers' compensation for the stress they felt about the changes the owners were making. "At that moment," Mr. Brown told an appreciative audience of insurance executives in New York late last year, "you could be sure that elimination of stress claims was No. 1 on the agenda." 
 With the support of Mr. Brown, California overhauled its workers' compensation system in 1993. One change required that the workplace be the predominant cause of the stress cited in a disability claim, not just a contributing factor of 10 percent or more.
Mr. Brown did not return three telephone calls seeking comment, but such a restriction would have made it much more difficult for the workers at his station to prove that they deserved compensation.
California is not alone. Pushed by businesses and insurers, most state legislatures around the country are reining in growth in the cost of job injuries, now $70 billion a year. They are tightening the eligibility rules for collecting disability benefits, limiting recourse to the courts, attacking fraud, making the workplace safer and in some states cutting benefits.
The new vigilance in workers' compensation coincides with a broader effort in the country to free businesses from expensive lawsuits through tort reforms.
Some people wonder whether the crackdown in workers' compensation has gone too far by denying benefits on technical grounds to workers with real injuries. Already, horror stories are emerging of disabled workers stuck with huge, unpaid medical bills.
But employers, who pay the bills, and insurers are pleased with the changes. Last year, for the first time since 1970, insurers spent less on claims and other costs for workers' compensation policies than they collected in premiums -- 99 cents on the dollar, down from $1.21 two years earlier. When combined with interest and investment gains, workers' compensation profits have grown enough for insurers to cut prices in many states and compete for business they once shunned.
As for employers, the growth of workers' compensation costs has slowed, giving them relief from a financial burden that averages 3 percent of wages but can range as high as 20 percent for workers in high-risk occupations.
These are among the changes that have produced striking results:
*Connecticut no longer awards disability benefits for mental or psychological disorders unless they are the result of an injury. It has eliminated cost-of-living adjustments on disability benefits and has cut some benefits by a third. Insurance premiums in the state have fallen 24 percent in the last two years.
*Texas tightened the eligibility for temporary income benefits. For severely injured workers, it instituted guidelines designed by the American Medical Association to measure the extent of a disability. As a result, even though the number of injuries rose to 283,000 in 1993 from 251,000 in 1991, the number of workers with severe injuries who qualified for special supplemental payments plummeted to 39 from 1,055. Texas also restricted legal appeals by workers of rulings by compensation boards.
*Arkansas required workers to identify the day and time of injuries, a simple measure that state officials say has reduced fraudulent claims. "Before that, workers could just say they got hurt on the job and that was the end of it," said Lee Douglass, the Arkansas insurance commissioner. The state also adopted a medical-fee schedule and mandated a safety program for employers. In January insurance rates fell by more than 12 percent. And 40 insurance companies are doing business in the state, up from six before the reforms.
*California set up a fund, financed by employers, that pays for special teams to go after fraud. Job-injury claims declined to 8.4 for every 100 workers last year, from nearly 10 in 1992.
For many business people, the changes legislated by the states could not come too soon. Karen Keiko White, president of Summit Installation in Gardena, Calif., said she "seriously considered leaving the state" a few years ago, when her business got an insurance bill for $338,000 for 25 workers.
Ms. White had just doubled her work force to install shelves in the Los Angeles library, which had been damaged by fire. But because of a serious injury to one worker a year earlier and a history of other claims she regarded as fraudulent, the insurance cost for each worker had more than doubled.
Her workers' compensation bill, for which she later negotiated a reduction of $100,000, has come down further -- she would not say by how much -- since the California overhaul in 1993. "I haven't seen a fraudulent claim in two years," she said, adding that the company had also hired an adviser to improve safety standards.
But organized labor argues that many of the new state provisions unfairly punish the entire work force for the misdeeds of a few. "The publicity generated by the companies and insurers about fraud has put a stigma on workers' compensation," said James Ellenberger, assistant director for safety and health at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Thomas Sheehan, a former administrative law judge in the Texas workers' compensation system and now a lawyer in Amarillo, Tex., said most cases were settled fairly. "But you still see cases where people are victimized by insurance companies that are too zealous in fighting claims," he said.
Mr. Sheehan cited a client who suffered permanent hearing loss in both ears in an explosion. The client was denied supplemental benefits on a technicality, Mr. Sheehan said: The new Texas standards for measuring a hearing disability compare the hearing in one ear with the hearing in the other. "That case could perhaps be overturned in an appeal," Mr. Sheehan said, "but that costs money."
Another case shows the vulnerability of workers in states in which insurers and employers delay settlements. Loretta C. Shelton, a new worker at a cardboard-cutting factory in Axton, Va., accidentally activated a cutting machine while reaching into it to move a piece of cardboard, amputating her right hand, government records show.
The owner of the plant, Brown Products Inc., a packaging concern in Atlanta, and its insurance company, Zurich Insurance, successfully fought her claims for nearly two years on the ground that Ms. Shelton was guilty of "willful misconduct" for ignoring previous safety warnings, the records show. By the time Zurich agreed to pay the medical bills and disability compensation, Ms. Shelton had to forgo crucial treatment and therapy for her reattached hand.
Mr. Ellenberger of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. complained that state legislatures and regulators were not showing the same zeal in pursuing "the greatest problems with fraud, which are at the companies and insurers." Companies, for example, might hire workers off the books, with no compensation insurance, or misclassify them in low-risk occupations that are less expensive to insure, he said.
Richard D. Levy, staff counsel for the Texas branch of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the efforts in Texas to reduce the involvement of lawyers in the system, while laudatory on the surface, tipped the balance too much in favor of industry.
"The new system is easy for insurance companies to manipulate," Mr. Levy said. In Texas, insurance companies are more than twice as likely as workers to take lawyers with them to hearings, he said. "It's not fair to have an injured worker go up against insurance company lawyers," he said.
Geoff Smith, a vice president at the insurer ITT Hartford, said he did not buy that argument. He said that reducing the role of lawyers was important to assure fairness; in some cases that have gone to juries, he said, lawyers had pocketed big fees, while "some severely injured people were not getting adequate compensation or care, while many people with injuries of low severity were getting more than they should have."
Even some people in the insurance industry's camp question some recent changes. John D. Copeland, a lawyer in Fayetteville, Ark., who often represents insurers, wrote in the Arkansas Law Review last year that in reaction to abuses by some workers, "the pendulum has now swung too far in favor of employers."
In an interview, Mr. Copeland warned that employers might have gone so far in curtailing disability benefits that they might be setting themselves up for a new generation of tort claims through the courts that could be much more expensive than settlements through the workers' compensation system.
But cutting benefits is not the only way to reduce the costs of workers' compensation. Employers are making accident prevention a big part of their efforts to cuts costs, often with a push from state legislators. In some states, like Oregon, in which the number of injured workers has declined even as the work force has grown, companies are required to create safety committees. There is also increasing surveillance by the state-run occupational safety boards.
Employers have an interest in keeping injuries to a minimum, because their safety records help to determine the size of their premiums.
Companies are also reducing costs by getting more involved in the handling of workers after injuries, demanding a say in the medical treatment, rehabilitation and return to work. For example, Ryder System Inc., the truck-leasing company based in Miami, hired nurses to work as case managers and monitor the treatment of injured workers. The claims department at the company is expected to treat injured workers as courteously "as if they were customers," said Tad G. DeOrio, a vice president at Ryder. The hope, he said, is that "workers are not confused and do not feel the need for a lawyer."
Ryder has also worked to promote safety. The upshot: The number of workers' compensation claims at Ryder has fallen by half since 1990.
Despite the big changes in much of the country, many populous states, like New York and New Jersey, have yet to take strong action. In New York, for example, insurers are lobbying for the State Assembly to weaken a law that allows workers to sue the makers of machinery that injures them on the job. Such lawsuits in the last 11 years have accounted for about a half of 1 percent of all workers' compensation cases, but have resulted in more than 11 percent of workers' compensation costs, or $1.8 billion.
William D. Hager, president of the National Council on Compensation Insurance in Boca Raton, Fla., said the reforms in some states were reminding others that "their economic development hinges on keeping the workers' compensation system healthy."
Recently, he noted, legislators in Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee asked his group for recommendations. He said he had told them all the same thing: Reduce the incentives for lawsuits, use objective standards for measuring the extent of disabilities and control medical costs.

Texas Simplified Appeals . . .
 
OLD SYSTEM
 An injured worker dissatisfied with a ruling of the compensation board could appeal in the courts and repeat the process of gathering evidence -- witness statements, medical tests -- favorable to the worker's claim.
 
NEW SYSTEM
 The compensation board makes its rulings within stricter guidelines. Appeals go to a hearing before a judge, not to a full jury trial. The judge reviews the same evidence the board used.

HEADLINE: Some Drugs Rise in Price At Fast Pace

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Pharmaceutical companies have increased the pace of price increases on many of their best-selling drugs since the collapse of the Clinton Administration's health care proposal last year.
During the battle over health care, drug companies promised to rein in their price rises, keeping them at or below the increase in the Consumer Price Index. That promise, made in an effort to ward off legislated price controls, has almost been kept over all, with drug prices rising 3 percent last year. 
 That pledge, however, has not prevented the drug makers from trying to maximize their profits by pushing up the prices of most of their 20 top-selling drugs.
According to health economists who surveyed drug prices for Families USA, a consumer group based in Washington, the prices of the 20 top drugs jumped 3.6 percent in the last 12 months. The price of Zantac, for example, the No. 1 ulcer treatment, rose 3.7 percent.
And this year it appears that the increases might be getting larger. In January, the price of Mevacor, the most commonly used treatment to lower blood cholesterol levels, went up 4.4 percent and Premarin, a big-selling estrogen product used by women after menopause, jumped 6.4 percent
The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group in Washington, said the list prices that were used in the Families USA survey were misleading because they overstated the price increases by half a percentage point.
Wall Street analysts have welcomed the price breakthroughs as harbingers of higher profits for the companies. But consumer advocates and their allies in Congress say the increases are painful for millions of low-income people, especially those living on Social Security. The Medicare program for the elderly does not cover retail drug purchases.
It is not clear yet what response there will be in Washington if the price increases continue, in part because the rises still seem low compared with those of recent years; just three years ago, the overall annual increase in drug prices was 6.1 percent.
Still, the change in pricing is getting attention. "Although the increases in drug prices have slowed down over the past year, prices on the drugs older Americans use most continue to rise," said Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, who is chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging.
Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, was blunt. "My sense is," he said, "that some of these big drug companies are saying that the heat's off now. They're saying that Congress didn't pass a health care bill last session; they've got a lot of new allies in the Congress, and they can get away with more than they could before."
Joseph P. Riccardo, a drug analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company, said "posted price increases in the U.S. retail market have edged up 4 percent to 5 percent" in the first weeks of 1995. He said worldwide price increases for pharmaceuticals were expected to be at a faster pace this year than in the preceding four years.
Prescription drug prices over all increased 3 percent in 1994, slightly faster than the 2.7 percent general inflation rate, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Through January, the latest available data, overall drug prices and the Consumer Price Index were rising at a 2.8 percent rate.
But prices of the 20 largest-selling drugs, according to economists with Families USA, rose 3.6 percent last year and 3.6 percent during the 12 months that ended on Feb. 28. The Families USA study monitored changes in the manufacturers' list prices to distributors, which reflect changes paid at retail pharmacists by people who do not have drug coverage in their health insurance. Such buying makes up about 44 percent of all drug purchases, according to Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a University of Minnesota economist who helped prepare the survey. Most of the rest is sold through hospitals, health insurance plans and state Medicaid programs.
The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association said the prices that "pharmacies actually paid" for the 20 top-selling drugs increased only 3.1 percent. That included purchases paid by insurers, which often get discounts from both pharmacies and manufacturers. The Families USA survey was of buyers who do not get discounts.
Max Duink, a retired sheet metal worker in Frewsburg, N.Y., in the western part of the state, said he spent $385 a month for heart, asthma and diabetes medicines for his wife. "A year ago it was about $320," he said. "It's going up faster than our Social Security."
A spokesman for Merck & Company which makes Mevacor, said the price increase when averaged for all of Merck's products was 1 percent, well under the inflation rate. Gary Lachow, the spokesman, said prices of some individual products had been raised by the projected inflation rate plus 1 percent. In raising Mevacor by 4.4 percent, Merck projected that the Consumer Price Index would rise 3.4 percent in 1995.
While the prices of most of the top-selling drugs rose faster than general inflation, prices of many others did not, which kept the overall increase at 3 percent last year. And in the face of market competition, some prices were lowered. For example, the price of Prilosec, an ulcer treatment made by Astra Merck, a joint venture company with the Swedish company Astra A.B., recently went down 2.1 percent.
Audrey Ashby, a spokeswoman for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, which makes Premarin, said it was still a low-cost drug, only about 40 cents a day. She said the company, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, raised the price after Premarin received Federal approval for use as a treatment for osteoporosis as well as for menopause symptoms. She added that the company had committed $200 million to research on possible other uses of Premarin.
Nancy Petarek, a spokeswoman for Glaxo P.L.C., which makes Zantac, said its overall price increases were also no greater than the Consumer Price Index.
John Coster, an economist who worked on the Families USA survey at the University of Minnesota, said some drug makers were raising retail prices of popular drugs to make up for discounts they have to provide on the big purchases made by providers of managed health care.

LENGTH: 965 words

HEADLINE: Senate to Begin Hearings on Operation of Javits Center

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
At a conference on the city's economy last month, Jonathan M. Tisch, president and chief executive officer of Loews Hotels, appealed to public officials and private executives to focus on cleaning up the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
"The most important issue is what do we do with the Javits Center," he said. 
 The call echoed a decade of warnings about the extent of corruption at the center. But only in the last two weeks has a deluge of public attention been focused on the problem, putting the onus on public officials to make good on their promises to rid New York's premiere convention center of corruption.
Today, the State Senate is to begin hearings into the management and operation of the mammoth structure on Manhattan's West Side. The hearings follow comments by Gov. George E. Pataki that he is dedicated to rooting out corruption there, and his call for the replacement of the center's board of directors.
Aides to Governor Pataki said the Governor had been committed to cleaning up corruption at the Javits Center since the beginning of his term and was not being driven to act merely by the recent bad publicity and calls by the city for state action. After he took office in January, aides said, the Governor assigned a team to examine operations at the center, which was built with state financing and operates as an autonomous public benefits corporation. That team, led by Robert Boyle, recently reported to the Governor that there was an "alarming and immediate need" to address the situation at the center, said the Governor's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha.
Mr. Boyle, a former chairman of the board of the Hudson Valley Hospital Center, , will be nominated by the Governor today to be chief executive of the Javits Center, sources close to the Governor said. Mr. Boyle, who was the Governor's campaign treasurer, would replace Fabian Palomino, an appointee of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo who resigned in January.
But today's hearings were called by Republican legislative leaders only last week, after an independent board issued a review of mob activity at the center. And the hearings are expected to focus primarily on problems at the center under a Democratic Governor, Mr. Cuomo.
Before the panel gets an opportunity to question the exhibitors, union leaders and others who have direct knowledge of how the Javits Center operates, members will hear from a parade of Republican officials, including Governor Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco.
Mayor Giuliani was thrust into the issue last week when his Deputy Mayor, John S. Dyson, suggested that the state turn the operation of the center over to the city. Mayoral aides said Mr. Dyson made the comments because many business people have been appealing to Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dyson to take action that would make it easier to do business at the convention center.
Forrest Taylor, a spokesman for the Mayor, said: "The Mayor recognizes that the Javits Center is an asset and wants to make sure that asset is fully exploited."
Indeed, as economic developers and city planners focus on the need to create jobs to replace dying sectors of the economy in the city, tourism is increasingly mentioned as one area with the potential for growth. Officials say a thriving Javits Center is essential to drawing visitors.
The sudden attention on the center also stems from the fact that, as a huge public operation that creates jobs, contracts and prestigious board appointments, it offers significant patronage and power to the person who receives credit for rooting out corruption there.
"The convention center is the type of thing you will see political television commercials about in the future, either as a plus for the Mayor or Governor for having cleaned it up, or from their opponents because it's still a mess," said Hank Morris, a Democratic media consultant.
The list of people expected to testify before the Senate panel includes Mark Schienberg, the executive vice president of the Greater New York Automobile Dealers Association, which represents 500 new-car dealers. The group's auto show has been held at the Javits Center each year since it opened in 1986.
Where to hold the 1996 show is in question, Mr. Schienberg said, because costs continue to rise and the Javits Center management has trimmed the number of setup days allotted for the show, to 4 from 10.
"That will call for workers to do double time, and that will double our cost," Mr. Schienberg said.
For this year's show, scheduled for April, the Ford Motor Company is spending about $1.6 million. For the same show in Chicago, Ford is spending about $1 million, he said.
If given the chance, Mr. Schienberg said, he might tell the committee of a meeting he had last year with Mr. Palomino, shortly after the auto show's costs for some services were increased by Javits officials.
"There were about seven people in the room, and I was standing up with blueprints in my hand, giving a presentation," Mr. Schienberg recalled. "Palomino fell asleep. I didn't know what to do. I rattled the blueprints to try to wake him up."
Mr. Palomino, who ran the convention center from 1991 until January, has come under fire in recent days for his management of it. In his defense, Mr. Palomino has characterized the problems as intractable. He has said that he and his inspector general, Sebastian Pepitone, were being unfairly singled out for failing to transform an ingrained culture that existed long before they were around. Both men are expected to testify before the Senate panel, a hybrid drawn from the Finance, Labor and Tourism committees.
Although the panel has invited representatives from the convention center's major labor unions to appear, it is not clear whether they will.


GRAPHIC: At the outset, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was billed as the centerpiece for the renaissance of midtown's West Side. Optimistic New York City and state official predicted that the center would quickly attract major conventions and exhibitions that would directly and indirectly generate $2.3 billion a year in spending and more than 30,000 new jobs.
Chronology: "The Javits Center: A History of Trouble"
Those rosy projections were made in 1979 when the Legislature approved the construction and the issuance of $375 million in state bonds for building costs. But none of those hopes has been fulfilled, and from its inception the center been beset by bid-rigging, organized-crime infiltration, labor-racketeering abuses and financial woes. SELWYN RAAB
 
October 1980 -- First major construction contract for $30 million given to Julius Nasso Concrete Company and S.A. Concrete Company. Anthony Salerno, the underboss of the Genovese crime family and several other mobsters are convicted in 1987 on Federal charges of rigging the concrete bids for the center and inflating costs by about $12 million.
 
April 1984 -- Planned opening date for center postponed because of cost overruns and by problems of manufacturing novel "nodes" or "rods" for glass superstructure.
 
November-December 1985 -- A 13-member board that sets policy for the center appoints John D. Feerick, the dean of the Fordham University School of Law, as impartial arbitrator or "labor czar" to resolve union jurisdictional disputes and prevent work stoppages. Unions representing employees at the center agree to prohibit strikes and featherbedding -- the hiring of unneeded workers for trade shows and meetings.
 
PUB-DATE: April 3, 1986
 
February 1987 -- After one year, trade show exhibitors say that center is plagued by power failures, poor cleaning and maintenance, labor slowdowns and inadequate space for major shows.
 
1989 -- Alair A. Townsend, then a Deputy Mayor in the Administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, says exhibitors are complaining about high costs, no-show jobs and demands for bribes by employees who set up and dismantle displays. Ms. Townsend says complaints were turned over to Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau after center officials failed to take action.
 
Sept. 6, 1990 -- Federal prosecutors in Manhattan file a civil racketeering suit against one of the major unions that dispense jobs at the center, the District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. The suit asserts that the union used the center as hiring hall for mobsters.
 
January 1991 -- Exhibitors and trade show organizers say in interviews that they are being victimized by excessive costs and thefts. The exhibitors maintain that costs in center are 50 percent higher than in other cities. Most frequent complaints are about unneeded overtime and work rules requiring $80 for an electrician to plug in a lamp, featherbedding by electricians and carpenters and demands by teamsters and laborers for bribes to expedite loading and unloading of materials. The Police Department reports that between $500,000 and $1 million in supplies and equipment are stolen each year from exhibitors.
 
Feb. 5 1992 -- Twenty seven men, including officials of three unions and two former state police officers, are indicted in Manhattan on state charges of extortion, theft and violence in connection with operations at the center. The charges result in guilty pleas by 24 defendants with most receiving sentences of less than one year in prison or probation. Three defendants were cleared. Prosecutors said the cases were compromised by a former state police officer who leaked information to targets of the investigation. Four unions -- carpenters, electricians, teamsters and laborers, agree to new work rules intended to lower costs. Exhibitors will be allowed to screw in a light bulb without having to pay an electrician and to carry packages into the center.
 
PUB-DATE: March 7, 1994
 
October-December 1994 -- Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge appointed to investigate misconduct in the carpenters union, reports that two union officials who control jobs at the center are linked to the Genovese family. Most of the carpenters who work at the center, Mr. Conboy charges, are mobsters or ex-convicts.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Prudential Is Putting Its Home Mortgage Business Up for Sale

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it wanted to sell its home mortgage business, one of the largest in the country.
The sale, which analysts said could fetch as much as $1 billion, comes at a time when rising interest rates have caused mortgage lending to drop by more than 50 percent from 1993. The decline has led to big losses at many companies and a flurry of sales, as some have abandoned the business. The Prudential mortgage business, for example, lost $119 million last year, after earning about $150 million in 1993. 
 The withdrawal from the mortgage business, in which profits have fluctuated widely in recent years, is the first big change at Prudential under Arthur F. Ryan, the new chief executive. Mr. Ryan, previously the No. 2 executive at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said when he arrived at Prudential late last year that he would review the Prudential strategy, adopted in the 1980's, of expanding into many different financial businesses.
Mr. Ryan has said that one of his objectives is to reduce the swings in the earnings of the insurance company, a move that would help attract more customers and perhaps restore the top-notch credit ratings that it lost recently. Earlier this month, Prudential reported a loss of $907 million for 1994, and said that its capital base had been reduced by $1.2 billion, to $9.5 billion.
In addition to its core life and health insurance businesses, Prudential also owns Prudential Securities, the fifth-largest securities firm in the country, a property and liability insurance company, a re-insurance company and a credit card business. Its other businesses related to home mortgages -- Prudential Real Estate Associates, with a network of 5,000 brokers, and Prudential Resources Management, which specializes in the purchase and sale of the homes of workers who have been transferred -- are not for sale, Mr. Ryan told Prudential's employees yesterday.
Speculation that Prudential may sell its securities subsidiary, which lost more than $800 million last year, has been a perennial topic on Wall Street. The losses last year were mostly a result of fines and legal expenses of $1.4 billion arising from improper sales of limited partnerships. But Mr. Ryan has previously said the securities business is not for sale, at least for now.
Stan Strachan, editor and publisher of National Mortgage News, a newspaper based in New York, said enough companies were interested in expanding their mortgage business that "Prudential can cash in readily, earn a big profit and increase its capital." He estimated that the Prudential mortgage business could be valued at $1 billion. It includes the servicing or record-keeping for $75 billion of loans, and it issued $24 billion of new loans last year.
Prudential has valued the businesses to be sold at $175 million on its own books, so a sale for $1 billion would produce a pretax profit of $825 million.
Whatever the exact price, analysts said it would not be out of reach for many of the largest companies in the business, including GE Capital, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, Countrywide Credit, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the BankAmerica Corporation and Nationsbank.
"It's a high quality company, and I expect it will end up owned by a large bank," said Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst at Smith Barney.
Prudential tried to keep apace of the contraction in the industry last year by cutting about 1,200 jobs, or a quarter of its work force. Still, Mr. Ryan said yesterday, the giant insurance company "needs to better focus its resources."

HEADLINE: State Leaders Agree on Revenue Estimate

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 15

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and the state's legislative leaders passed the first milestone on the path to enacting a state budget by agreeing today on how much money they will have available to spend.
Aides to Mr. Pataki had warned only a week ago against the dangers of unjustifiable increases in state revenue estimates. But today, the Governor agreed to raise his previous projection of $33.88 billion by $300 million. That figure, which is for the fiscal year that starts on April 1, fell between the Senate Republicans' estimate that state taxes and fees would generate an additional $214 million and the Assembly Democrats' estimate of $549 million. 
 The leaders may raise their revenue estimates even further because they have yet to agree on a projection of how much will be generated next year by the lottery. The Governor's estimate on the lottery's revenue is $91 million below that of the Assembly.
It is a time-honored practice in Albany to begin budget negotiations with what amounts to an instant discovery of cash. The Governor and Legislature declare that the state can anticipate more revenue than they previously thought and then spend the year hoping that their optimism will not leave them with a deficit the next year.
Mr. Pataki's budget division believes that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature overestimated this year's revenues by almost $1 billion. Some independent fiscal analysts believe that today's agreement may leave the state in a similar hole at the end of the year.
"A sound justification for raising these estimates has not yet been presented," said Cynthia B. Green, vice president for state studies at the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization. "Certainly, raising revenue estimates to accommodate spending desires has happened in the past, and under this practice, we increase the risk that even larger spending cuts will be needed next December."
Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders, Speaker of the Assembly Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, each said today that the new projections were based on new information about improving sales tax revenues and economic growth indicators.
"We think that's a real number based on the changing economic forecasts that have come out," Mr. Pataki told reporters after meeting with Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno.
The leaders said they had made little headway in deciding how to construct the budget. Both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican, said they were interested in using the additional money to pay for cuts in business taxes, like the gross receipts tax on utility revenues, or to expand the state's credit for property-tax payers who spend a large share of their income on real estate taxes. They also said they would like to soften some of the spending cuts proposed by Mr. Pataki to close a budget gap of more than $4 billion and to pay for proposed tax cuts of $720 million.
Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said significant changes must be made in Mr. Pataki's proposed budget, starting with the Governor's cuts in funding for the state and city university systems, in welfare programs for the elderly and disabled, and in Medicaid coverage for home health care.
Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno have met each day this week to negotiate the budget, and will meet again on Thursday.
Mr. Pataki has threatened to shut down state government if a budget is not passed on time, except for functions essential to the health and safety of New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mixed Economic Signals Leave Long Bond Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the dollar remained weak and reports of strong growth in the economy countered a Federal Reserve report that suggested that inflation was unlikely to accelerate.
The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 1036/32 for a yield of 7.36 percent, with rates on shorter-maturity bills slightly lower. 
 Bond prices fell nearly half a point in early trading after the Labor Department reported that wholesale prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said, "It wasn't so much the slight three-tenths percent uptick in the headline data that spooked the market, but rather the sharp 1.5 percent rise in crude goods and the nine-tenths percent rise in the intermediate goods that got under traders' skin."
The latter figures implied an increase in inflationary pressures, which would cut the value of fixed-income investments.
"With the 30-year bond down through 7.50 percent, the two-year more than a half-point over the Federal funds rate, and the three-month bill trading 25 basis points under," Mr. Hamilton said, "you almost need a Fed easing to justify these levels -- all representative of an overextended market."
The dollar was another big factor in the market's weakness yesterday. Foreign exchange traders in Europe, Mr. Hamilton said, were buying German marks in a flight to quality ahead of the political uncertainty expected from the vote set for today in Italy's Parliament on a resolution of no confidence in the Government.
The market pace picked up in the afternoon as some traders with short positions -- bets that bond prices would drop -- began buying bonds to give themselves some protection against having made the wrong bet. The buying trend was aided by the release of the Federal Reserve's beige book report, which showed considerable slowdowns in both the retail and housing sectors. It also stated that there were few signs that wage and production-capacity pressures would find their way into the prices of finished goods.
In addition, Janet Yellen, a Fed governor, said the increases in interest rates engineered by the central bank during the last year stood a good chance of keeping consumer prices in check; those prices have risen 2.7 percent during each of the last two years.
The pace of buying quickened further after reports that some foreign central banks were purchasing Treasury securities with short maturities, regarded as a safe haven for investing.
In the municipal bond market, investors continued to show strong demand for new securities, traders said. Investors have been paying higher-than-expected prices for some new issues, as offerings so far this year have been down about 60 percent from last year's pace.
Among corporate issuers, the MBNA Corporation sold $526.1 million of floating-rate securities. The securities of MBNA, a bank holding company based in Newark, Del., are backed by credit card debt and were sold in two parts through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.
The securities were sold through specially formed MBNA Master Credit Card Trust 1995-A, with $500 million of a senior class A issue with a maturity of 9.4 years priced to yield 27 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate. The issue had no cap at the top.
In the second part, consisting of $25.9 million of subordinated class B securities, the maturity was 9.48 years and the yield about 45 basis points over the one-month London rate. It also had no cap.
The one-month London interbank offered rate, which is the rate that international banks charge one another for loans, was at 6.125 percent late yesterday.
According to John H. Nash, an analyst with MCM/CorporateWatch, this is the longest maturity ever for a floating-rate issue backed by credit card debt. Previously, seven years had been the maximum.
Traders said that the senior debt was rated triple A by the major rating agencies and that the subordinated debt was rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service, AA- by Standard & Poor's and AA by Duff & Phelps Credit and Fitch Investors Service.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Greatest Auction Ever

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
They all laughed at the economist Milton Friedman when he suggested a generation ago that the Federal Government auction off broadcast licenses, instead of giving them away to political favorites.
The last laugh is his; last week, in the greatest auction in history, bidders for wireless places on a tiny fragment of the broadband spectrum committed nearly $8 billion to the U.S. Treasury. 
 And that's only the beginning of the taxpayers' bonanza in the sale of our valuable thin air.
Remember all the talk, eight years ago, of high-definition television, the Japanese invention that was supposed to force us all to replace our 200 million TV sets? U.S. manufacturers, with antitrusters' blessing, formed a "Grand Alliance" to match the Japanese advance.
Along came an unexpected scientific breakthrough. We leapfrogged the analog (feh!) competition into the brave new digital world. This not only produces a knock-your-socks-off picture but expands each TV channel into five or six wireless channels for video, audio, computer data transmission, telephones and every form of communication short of mental telepathy.
Broadcasters smacked their lips at the bonanza. "Advanced television is not just about pretty pictures anymore," F.C.C. chairman Reed Hundt told Edmund Andrews of The Times, one of the few reporters on top of this story. "It's about the digitization of television and a huge range of new services."
It's as if one old oil well gave birth to six new gushers. Broadcasting lobbyists have descended on Congress and the F.C.C. to insure "flexibility" -- that is, to exploit exclusively all the new technology, and to charge viewers for the "ancillary and supplementary" services.
Even if accompanied by payment of rent to the Government, the exclusive arrangement sought by broadcasters would be an outrageous taxpayer ripoff.
What is the digitized, divisible channel worth? Senate Commerce Committee Chairman Larry Pressler gave a hint in an op-ed piece last week, suggesting that noncommercial licensees had a huge hidden asset: "Public broadcasting stations could rent, sell or make use of the additional channels for other telecommunications and information services."
Based only on current uses, which are primitive, the market value of the VHF, UHF, cellular, broadband and narrowband spectrum ranges around $120 billion.
But in the near future, your television set will combine with your computers and telephone and fax machine into a single unit you can hang on the wall or fold up in your pocket. That's soon -- possibly in the next Presidential term.
I've seen not-for-attribution estimates that the market value of the digitized spectrum in that onrushing era will be -- hold your breath -- a half-trillion dollars, give or take a hundred billion.
Before rushing into any giveaway, or any long-term exclusive rent away, we need extended, wide-open, thoroughly debated hearings to make certain of three outcomes:
First, we want a guarantee of spectrum competition. The criterion to determine competition must be scrupulously economic, not jiggered by the Government to introduce sexual or racial or ethnic or ideological favoritism. An appeals court yesterday stayed the F.C.C. from holding auctions that favored minority fronts.
Next, we want a holdback of certain rights. For example, we can solve the campaign finance dilemma justlikethat by putting a right-of-way in the deed setting aside air time, on-line time and direct E-mail advertising for candidates, which could be used or traded or sold by them in election campaigns.
Finally, we want top dollar for our public property. That means a series of Friedman-style auctions. After the purchases, sophisticated risk-takers and their banking backers can enhance the value of their property at no cost to the taxpayer and with great benefit to the consumer.
Where should the spectrum-sale money go? Toward reduction of the crushing national debt. By recognizing our hidden asset of the spectrum, Americans can ride the wave of the future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: U.S. Steel Plans to Increase Its Prices on Sheet Products

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The nation's newly prosperous basic steel industry appears on its way to even more prosperity by raising prices for the second time this year on the sheet products that go into automobiles, appliances and a broad variety of consumer and industrial products.
A spokesman for the largest domestic steelmaker, the United States Steel subsidiary of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that the company had notified its customers that it planned to raise prices by an average of 3.5 percent effective July 2. The increases would total $15 a ton for hot-rolled steel, $20 a ton for higher-quality cold-rolled steel and $30 a ton for steel with an additional coating like zinc galvanizing. 
 The proposed price increase comes shortly after the No. 2 company, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced an increase of 2 percent, or $15 a ton, on galvanized sheet, also effective July 2.
The stocks of steel companies were up broadly yesterday after the disclosure of the price increase. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of USX rose $1.50, to $32.50; Bethlehem rose 50 cents, to $15.75; the LTV Corporation rose 25 cents, to $15; the Inland Steel Company rose $1.375, to $26.375, and the National Steel Corporation rose 75 cents, to $17.50.
Analysts said the demand for steel continued to be strong, and they expected other companies to follow quickly with price increases.
If it holds, the increase would be the second of the year for the integrated steel companies, most of which returned to solid profitability last year, after several years of losses. Most of the industry raised prices by $30 a ton on Jan. 1, and the increase appears to have held, despite some reports of resistance from buyers.
But some industry specialists questioned whether USX and the other companies would be successful in raising prices in all grades of sheet steel.
"This looks like the last gasp at the end of a pricing cycle," said John E. Jacobson of Jacobson & Associates, a steel consulting firm in Swarthmore, Pa. "The increases might hold in coated and other high- value products, but the hot-rolled situation is unclear."
He said the Nucor Corporation and other so-called mini-mills were moving into the hot-rolled market and, with their low costs, would likely be the price leaders. "U.S. Steel does not have the clout to move the market as it once did," he said.
But Charles A. Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities, said the weak dollar was likely to reduce steel imports by making them even more expensive than domestic steel. As such, he said, companies would have little choice but to pay higher prices for domestic sheet steel.
"Imports are coming down big time this year," he said. "Given the value of the currency, this is just not a very attractive market." He said the prices for coated steel had risen sharply in Europe, making it uneconomical for steel users to seek alternatives there. Similarly, imports from Japan have declined.
Mr. Bradford said steel users were accepting the price increases of the last two years as necessary to get needed raw material. "I've talked to big steel service centers and they say they are paying the January increase and their customers are paying them," he said.
Steel service centers buy large lots of steel from the mills and break them down into smaller quantities for sale to manufacturers.
The pared-down domestic steel industry has been running nearly flat out for the last two years to meet the demand of an economy that some analysts say is hungrier for steel than in the past. The industry has invested heavily in equipment that has improved the quality of steel and lowered the cost of making it.
Meanwhile, the mini-mills, which rely on scrap rather than iron ore, have begun moving into flat-rolled steel, the last stronghold of the integrated producers.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL NEWS;
Austerity and Rates of 92% Fail to Perk Up the Peso

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 15

 BODY:
A tough new economic plan and interest rates of more than 90 percent were not enough to rekindle much confidence in Mexico today as the peso tumbled an additional 5 percent and investors expressed worry that the country's problems would continue to worsen.
The peso closed at an exchange rate of 6.95 to the dollar, which means that one peso now equals little more than 14 cents, compared with almost 29 cents before the Government first devalued last December. 
 The austere new recovery plan has proved hard to sell to skeptical investors who have seen earlier plans crumble. The initial enthusiasm shown after the latest plan was announced last week seems to have faded quickly.
"Most people have taken a wait-and-see attitude with Mexico," said Brian M. Barish, vice president for emerging markets at Lazard Freres & Company in New York. "The new plan might work, but nobody is really willing to commit meaningful amounts of money to see if in fact it will."
In the measures introduced last week, taxes are increased sharply, the prices of state-produced goods like gasoline rise by a third and Government spending is cut 10 percent. Officials vow to stick to a tight monetary policy that will reduce the supply of pesos in the economy and eventually lead to a stabilization of the exchange rate, even if there is no formal method for controlling the currency.
For the first time since 1989, the Government sold two-week treasury certificates. The annual rate for them was 92.5 percent, the highest in seven years. The issuance of high-yield, two-week certificates was seen as indication of the Government's hope that conditions will improve in the third quarter of 1995.
Rates were set at 82 percent for one-month certificates and 85 percent for three-month certificates. The Government did not issue its usual six-month and one-year certificates.
However, even in the short term, such sky-high rates will strangle an already badly weakened economy. For example, the interbank rate, which is used as a guide for many consumer and business loans, nearly reached 110 percent.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz was in New York for a second day selling the new plan to Wall Street investors, who for the most part said they were willing to give the plan a chance even though they harbored doubts that it would succeed.
The Mexican stock exchange received a modest boost, closing at nearly 1,612, an increase of 1.3 percent, largely on the belief that for foreign investors, stock values in Mexico rise when the peso weakens and a dollar buys more.
Some financial analysts here thought the peso had weakened in anticipation of more than $700 million in Government bonds that mature this week. The bonds, called tesobonos, are pegged to dollars but are paid out in pesos. Investors who redeem their maturing bonds take the pesos into the market looking for dollars, creating a demand for dollars and an oversupply of pesos.
Jonathan E. Heath, an independent economist in Mexico City, said few buyers or sellers were still active in Mexico's currency market. "If you have very few buyers going to the market where there are no sellers, the rate goes up," Mr. Heath said. "I wouldn't be surprised if every once in a while you see the peso bouncing up to the same level again."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Gasoline Rises Sharply On Signs of Tightening Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices surged yesterday after Government reports showed supplies were tightening for the first time in weeks. Other energy prices also gained.
On other commodity markets, lumber prices plunged and soybeans were sharply higher. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.97 point, to 236.64. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for April delivery rose 1.25 cents, to 54.04 cents a gallon.
Gasoline prices had been sinking as many states balked at using a reformulated grade of gasoline that is less polluting. The reformulated grade that is traded on the exchange contains an ether additive, which raised health concerns among officials of some states.
Analysts speculated yesterday that many refiners halted gasoline production in the face of the sinking prices prompted by the uncertainties around the reformulated grade. That cutback was reflected in the American Petroleum Institute's regular weekly report on inventories, which was released after the market closed on Tuesday.
The institute's report showed that refinery production over all climbed to 91.7 percent of capacity last week but that gasoline production fell.
Unleaded gasoline output fell 3.5 percent, to 7.1 million barrels a day, and production of the reformulated gasoline fell nearly 6 percent, the report said.
"The refinery runs are very high, but the production of gasoline and reformulated gasoline did not increase," said Tom Bentz, director of the energy division for ING Derivatives Clearing Inc. in New York.
With many refineries likely to be shut soon for routine seasonal maintenance work, there could be an increased chance of shortages during the peak driving season, Mr. Bentz said.
The rise in gasoline prices lifted other energy contracts. Crude oil for April delivery rose 17 cents, to $18.11 a barrel, and the April natural gas contract rose 3.6 cents, to $1.506 for 1,000 cubic feet.
The expiring March contract for lumber fell $8.40, to $272.20 for 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. May lumber fell $7, to $292 for 1,000 board feet.
Investors were squaring their positions in advance of tomorrow's report by the Commerce Department on housing starts in February.
Lumber traders are betting that rising interest rates have led to a decline in housing starts of as much as 2 percent, analysts said.
Soybean prices rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade on an increase in optimism about export prospects. March soybeans rose 8 cents, to $5.7650 a bushel.
The rally was mostly technically driven, with investors viewing the weaker dollar as a sign that exports would increase. A weak dollar makes American commodities cheaper for foreign buyers.
Soybean prices also gained as investors began to adjust their positions for the seasonal shift to summer trading, said Steve Freed, director of research for ADM Investor Services Inc. in Chicago.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The dollar also rises, but not so much lately. Why is that?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE weighty dollar, anchor to the world's monetary system, has once again torn loose in turbulent financial seas.
Why did it happen now, even as the Federal Reserve was being congratulated for navigating so cleverly between the Scylla of inflation and the Charybdis of recession? Was this just a preview of worse to come? 
 Surjit Bhalla, a currency strategist for the Deutsche Bank, answers with candor uncharacteristic of his profession. "I just don't know," he says. "At times, economists ought to be humble."
But never fear: there is more to this column than nautical metaphors. Try these ideas on for size.
 
THE CRASH WASN'T AS BAD AS IT LOOKED Yes, the dollar is down by roughly a fifth against the German mark, Swiss franc and Japanese yen, compared with its peak over the last year. But the dollar is up substantially against the currencies of two of its largest trading partners, Canada and Mexico. J. P. Morgan's trade-weighted index of the value of the dollar against 19 currencies is down only 4 percent since the beginning of 1995 -- and only 2 percent since the last time the dollar got mugged, in October.
Robert Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, adds that this asymmetry may even offer Americans an unexpected bonus. Since Germany and Japan are America's major competitors in third markets, the appreciation of the mark and the yen are good news for American exporters, like Caterpillar, Citibank and Motorola, whose costs are largely denominated in dollars.
But by the same token, Mr. Lawrence suggests, the dollar's appreciation against the Mexican peso and the Canadian dollar has softened the blow for American consumers, who will benefit from improved terms of trade with these two neighbors. And it will reduce the lingering pressure on the Federal Reserve to push interest rates higher as a damper against import-led inflation.
 
OR YOU WERE LOOKING IN THE WRONG PLACE While the phenomenon was little noted in America, Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, says that the latest plunge of the dollar is part of a broader flight by cash holders toward the perceived safety of the yen and the mark. Portugal and Spain, questionably managed economies whose exchange rates fluctuate within predetermined bands, were both forced to devalue.
Spain and Portugal are minor players in the European currency game, but Italy, Sweden and Britain are not. And while all three managed to keep their currencies within target ranges against the German mark, the drama exacerbated Europe's continuing difficulties in making the transition to monetary union. In a world of highly integrated capital markets, it has become all too clear that events in Mexico or Indonesia can affect exchange rates between France and Austria.
 
WHERE THE DOLLAR GOES, IRONY FOLLOWS Since the 1970's, economists and statesmen have been fretting over the lack of will in the advanced industrial nations to coordinate their economic policies. But Mr. Hormats of Goldman Sachs suggests that the explosive growth of capital mobility in the last few years may accomplish what high-minded pleas to serve the commonweal could not. After all, the price of not keeping one's financial house in order these days is often a noisy and costly currency crisis.
 
GOOD NEWS IT WASN'T The dollar rises and falls -- but more often the latter. In 1986, a dollar bought 2.2 marks and 170 yen; today those figures are down to 1.3895 marks and 89.50 yen. Even adjusting for relative rates of inflation and the shift in American trade toward Asian and Latin countries with weaker currencies, the effective exchange rate of the dollar has decreased by about 20 percent.
Mr. Lawrence worries that this reflects a decline in the "competitiveness" of the American economy in the sense that only economists take seriously: Foreigners are now demanding more of our stuff in return for less of theirs. He speculates that this reflects improvements in the relative quality and reputation of products made elsewhere.
That is not so terrible; indeed, it meshes with the prediction that free market economies will sooner or later converge in their capacities to innovate and grow. But an alternative explanation, offered by Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, is unambiguously grim. "To understand the long-term decline of the dollar," he says, "look at America's low savings rate."
For more than a decade, America has sustained its living standard with a lot of help from its creditors. Should it really come as a surprise that as the foreign debt mounts it takes ever more dollars to induce foreigners to sustain the binge?
