HEADLINE: Education Transfers, and Stops;
Public Schools Are Struggling With High Student Turnover

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
It is March, and Marie Pompeo-Melone, the nurse at Public School 8, is still registering new students -- 25 in the first eight days of the month alone.
The students keep coming, but the seams of the school do not burst because others are leaving just as fast. In 1993, the school had a mobility rate of 89 percent, according to the State Education Department, meaning that 89 percent of the children spent part of the year elsewhere. Ms. Pompeo-Melone's file cabinets are crammed with their transfer papers, and her head swims with their faces and names. 
 "I can't tell you the last time there was a day when I had no transfers," Ms. Pompeo-Melone said. "It's just all the time. Words cannot describe how mobile it's become."
P.S. 8 is not alone. Throughout the country, especially in poor areas, schools are struggling with student turnover rates of 70, 80 and 90 percent. A 1994 report by the General Accounting Office found that nationwide, 17 percent of third graders had attended three or more schools since first grade. At many urban schools, that third-grade percentage is often double.
The consequences can be troubling for both schools and students. Children who move often are more likely to fail a grade and to have behavioral problems than those who do not, according to a 1993 study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Even a short move is often stressful, said David Wood, an author of the study and a pediatrician at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
Lillian Soto was in first grade in Puerto Rico, split the second grade between schools in Hoboken and Jersey City, attended P.S. 8 for third, fourth and fifth grades, transferred to another Jersey City school for sixth grade and now, as an eighth grader, is back at P.S. 8. Lillian said she did not know why her family had moved so much. But recently, she said, her mother has been thinking about returning to Puerto Rico. Lillian, 13, said her brothers all wanted to go. But she will resist.
"She didn't want to let me finish the eighth grade," she said. "I don't want to keep moving to different places. I'm tired already."
The question, educational experts say, is this: Can any effort to improve public schools succeed if the schoolhouse door is a turnstile?
"Do we really have a prayer of educating these kids?" said L. Scott Miller, author of a study of student mobility for the Council for Aid to Education. "I say no."
Education experts say they have only started examining the problem in recent years, and as a result there are few data, making it difficult to know if the mobility rate is growing worse. But at P.S. 8, the teachers have no doubt.
"Years ago I could see a little kid in the first grade and that kid was here at graduation," said Linda Herman, who has taught at P.S. 8 for 30 years. "That was most. Now, it's a handful. Everything has just changed so."
For some families, moving means enhanced fortunes as a parent takes a better job or buys a larger home. But among the nation's most transient families, it is often poverty and its complications that lead to a change in address. A parent loses a job and is evicted. An unemployed mother bounces from the house of one relative to another. An immigrant gives up on his dreams and returns to his homeland.
Poor families move twice as often as those that are not poor, according to a report by the Bureau of the Census. A study by the Council for the Aid to Education linked frequent moving to unemployment, immigrant status, the shortage of low-income housing and problems like drug use, violence and child neglect.
"Mobility is both a cause and a symptom," said Mr. Miller, author of the study.
The stress of mobility weighs most heavily on the student. But a fluctuating population can also paralyze the school. Teachers find it hard to maintain lesson schedules and get to know children and parents. Paperwork overwhelms everyone, from the principal to the nurse.
Each new student disrupts the class and sidetracks the teacher as she tries to figure out where, educationally, the new child stands, said Linda Stokes, a second-grade teacher at P.S. 8.
"If the kid is behind, that's a problem," she said. "If the kid is ahead, it's a problem. Either way, now you have to accommodate the kid, but meanwhile you still have the children that have been there."
Teachers and administrators say it is unfair to judge them by the standardized test scores of students they have not taught -- students who may fare well but are more likely to score poorly on such tests. At P.S. 8, a student from California arrived early this month and took the state's Early Warning Test five days later.
"It's a big issue," said Linnea Weiland, director of urban education for the State Education Department. "The urban districts complain that the suburban districts don't have these problems and that it skews the results."
P.S. 8's working-class neighborhood seems too solid to produce such migratory children. Its modest houses look out on clean sidewalks. A few blocks away, elderly women push carts through the Central Avenue shopping district. Teachers and students said they felt safe on the neighborhood streets.
Because Jersey City does not have middle schools, its elementary schools are large. With more than 1,350 students in kindergarten through grade eight, P.S. 8 is the city's largest elementary school. The three-story, brown-brick building looks like a high school. The halls are so long teachers sometimes walk them in sneakers for exercise.
New Jersey's mobility figures may be higher than other states' because they include students who transfer in or out during the first few weeks of school. (The rate is calculated by dividing the number of students who transferred in or out by the number of students present for any part of the year.)
New York City, for instance, does not count students who transfer until Oct. 1, after schools have been in session for several weeks, and that lowers the rate compared with those in New Jersey districts.
In New York City, the mobility rate for elementary and middle schools in 1993-94 was 27 percent, according to the Board of Education. The New Jersey Education Department does not compile a statewide mobility figure.
However the calculation is done, P.S. 8 educators say the crisis is real. "It's unbelievable," said Pat Farrell, the guidance counselor. "Sometimes a second grader will have eight different past addresses."
Ms. Farrell said the school's proximity to Union City, Hoboken, Bayonne and New York might contribute to its high turnover.
The district is predominately Hispanic, and many students were born in Ecuador, Mexico, El Salvador or Puerto Rico. Every April brings a large influx of Spanish-speaking students into Joanna Veloz's bilingual third-grade class.
"That's when a lot of the Spanish countries finish school, and the parents decide to come on over," Ms. Veloz said.
Linda Herman, an eighth-grade teacher, said the spring also brings a group of eighth graders who are in danger of failing at their old schools.
"A lot of them think the records aren't going to catch up, and that they'll be able to come here and graduate and be promoted," she said.
Ms. Pompeo-Melone said she knew of several cases in which children left P.S. 8 after teachers suggested they be tested for learning disabilities. In one case, officials at the child's new school called, and Ms. Pompeo-Melone told them of the plan to test for a learning problem.
"They said, 'O.K., we'll continue that here,' and the child picked up and left again," she said. "It's a form of running away for a lot of these parents."
The children themselves often have only a vague understanding of why their families must move.
"We just move a lot to different housing projects," Lillian said.
Stephanie Nazario, 13, has attended P.S. 8 since kindergarten. But last year, her best friend of many years transferred to P.S. 28.
"Sometimes people move because their father lost a job," she said.
Lillian said, "Maybe it's because they get tired of the place they're in."
Latasha Foster said, "Grown-ups -- that's their favorite thing, moving." She added, "They just want to move around and around. They want to see different places."
Latasha, 13, went to school in New York until the third grade, then attended P.S. 8 for two years. But during the summer before her fifth-grade year, her mother moved the family to Washington. Latasha said she was academically ahead of her classmates in Washington. Still, she did not like the school or the city.
"It was different -- the way people go about themselves and talk," she said. "It was countrylike."
Norma Reynoso, 11, attended Catholic schools until the third grade, then transferred to one public school for fourth grade, and to P.S. 6 for fifth grade. She entered P.S. 8 in September, after her family moved into the neighborhood.
"I didn't want to come here," she said. "I still feel like I want to go back. A lot of people liked me at Number Six. I used to make a lot of friends."
There are some grass-roots efforts to address the problem. In 1988, a group of landlords in Rochester started a program to educate parents about high mobility, said David Schuler, president of the Apartment Owners Association. Members intervened in housing problems and helped change the way the county pays the rent of welfare recipients, a method that Mr. Schuler said had encouraged people to move often.
The group also tried to build community support for School 9, one of Rochester's largest schools. Its mobility rate has dropped from 73 percent in 1988 to 48 percent in 1993, the last year for which figures were available, district officials said.
Latasha Foster said her mother was planning to move again once Latasha completed eighth grade. But Latasha's acceptance into Jersey City's academic high school changed her mind.
"I don't think your parents know what you go through," Latasha said. "My mother lived in the same neighborhood growing up. She doesn't understand. They think kids can make friends really quickly. But some people can't."

HEADLINE: Whitman Bond-Recycling Plan Would Provide $500 Million to Stimulate Housing

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 15

 BODY:
By recycling state mortgage bonds and refining construction rules, New Jersey housing agencies will put more than $500 million into urban and suburban low- to medium-income housing in the next nine months.
The program announced today by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will promote home ownership in cities, where ownership rates are low, and smooth the way for apartment construction in the suburbs, where rental units are scarce. The Governor said one part of the program would produce at least 1,500 city homes. 
 The housing plan follows the pattern of past ventures of a Republican administration with an active social imagination but with no cash to spare for new projects. Rather than seeking new money, the plan relies on recycling a modest increase in borrowing from the state mortgage agency to multiply, or leverage, in Mrs. Whitman's favorite term, limited resources to multiple uses.
State officials pointedly offered several urban elements in today's proposal as a rebuttal to criticism leveled at the self-help urban agenda announced by the Governor last week, which had neither a timetable nor specific improvement plans.
In contrast, most of the money raised for the housing program will be directed to urban home-ownership programs or the rehabilitation of city dwellings. "When you encourage ownership, the owner has a commitment not only to the four walls of that particular property, but to the community at large," Mrs. Whitman said.
Home ownership rates in New Jersey's cities are below 30 percent, in contrast to ownership rates above 70 percent in the suburbs -- statistics that Democrats turned against the Governor's proposal.
"This plan's focus on home buying rather than affordable rental units shuts out a large segment of our urban population, perhaps 7 out of 10 urban residents, who need rental housing before they can dream of owning a home," said Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Hoboken Democrat and a party spokesman on housing issues.
The plan rests on exploiting $150 million in unused bonding capacity by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, a state agency that acts like a nonprofit bank, selling bonds, lending the proceeds to first-time home buyers and repaying the bonds from the buyers' monthly mortgage payments.
Using a change in the rules authorized by the State Attorney General, the mortgage agency will lend the new bond funds twice, first as construction loans to builders, then as mortgages to buyers of the builders' houses as they are completed.
In that way, according to the plan's logic, $150 million becomes $300 million but does not become new debt for the taxpayers, the state emphasized, since mortgage agency borrowing is separate from state obligations.
The Division of Community Affairs, which oversees the mortgage agency and will be in charge of today's program, took pains after Mrs. Whitman's announcement to say that the Governor was not increasing the state's indebtedness.
The program lets builders raise construction cash by selling Federal tax deductions to investors. And by making builders use more of their own money to qualify for the credits, the state expects to turn $14 million in Federal tax credits into $70 million worth of housing investment.

HEADLINE: Strong Yen Aids Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your front-page article March 8 on the dollar's continuing fall states that a "7 percent rise in the value of the yen in recent days will cost Japanese companies billions in lost products on exports." The yen has risen approximately 10 percent in the last two months, which means that all the food and fuel Japan eats and burns will be bought 10 percent cheaper in world markets. 
 Japan will purchase all the materials for exports 10 percent cheaper than the equivalent cost for American industrial companies. Japan controls its internal labor costs. Since Japan can now buy all its materials at 10 percent cheaper, because raw materials are traded in dollars, it can buy 10 percent more.
Another way of looking at it would be that exclusive of labor, 1 in 10 Japanese autos would cost nothing versus dollar-based American companies.
 
GEORGE D. F. LAMBORN
Chairman, Lamborn Securities Inc.
New York, March 9, 1995

HEADLINE: In Jersey City, It's Earning by Learning

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Paying Children to Read Isn't Cheap, or Right" (letter, March 9) attacked Newt Gingrich and his Learning by Earning program. 
 Here in Jersey City, we are well under way on our first Earning by Learning program. The fourth graders of Public School 5 have read their way into the second half of the initial effort. Mayor Bret Schundler and I intend to spread the program all across the city.
The program is based on the premise that children don't read well because they don't read often,
and they don't read often because they don't read well. Reading all too often is a chore to the young. Unfortunately, this happens where socioeconomic conditions preclude broad reading opportunities. Since today's society is heavily motivated by economics, can we not use those economics as a valid motivational tool when the end result is improved reading skills and greater appreciation of reading? Academic success is based on the ability to read well and to comprehend.
Our program begins with school reading specialists and classroom teachers. It involves library personnel, parents and college students as facilitators and monitors. Where these programs have been implemented, there have been increased and improved reading practices among children.
In Jersey City, the child is not handed $2. There is discussion of the child's plans for his or her money with a direct point to educating the child about financial planning, saving and more.
We encourage the child's opening of a bank account, and we involve the local bank and banker in the process. We also urge the bank to match the dollar amount the child deposits or to match the amount in the form of a donation or a gift to the child's class or school.
The National Westminster Bank Corporation presented its annual community spirit award to Jersey City for this program, and the attendant cash prize went directly into the program. We intend to reach out to more members of the corporate, business and banking community for involvement.
 
THOMAS HART
Director, Recreation and Cultural
Affairs, City of Jersey City
Jersey City, March 10, 1995

HEADLINE: Economy Shows Some Signs of Strength, but Dollar Falls Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Even as consumer spending appears to be tailing off, American industry pushed solidly ahead in February and prices obtained by producers showed signs of acceleration, according to Government figures released today.
While the latest reports added to anxiety over inflation, the Federal Reserve helped calm them with fresh evidence from its regional banks around the nation that the economy was slowing to a more sustainable pace. 
 Production at factories, mines and utilities climbed five-tenths of 1 percent, somewhat more than expected by most economists, with their combined operating rate moving up two-tenths of a point, to 85.7 percent of capacity. That pushed the operating rate of American industry to another 15-year peak, the highest level since 1979.
"The data so far for the first quarter suggests a dramatic slowing in the consumer sector while the industrial sector continues to run in high gear," Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis economic consultant, said today.
Partly as a consequence, the accumulation of inventories on store shelves and in warehouses during January posted its biggest increase since August.
Prices received by producers of finished goods rose by three-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month in February. The so-called core rate of inflation that excludes food and energy moved up a bit faster than in January, or three-tenths of 1 percent.
The Labor Department's report also showed that the prices of products at earlier stages of production rocketed ahead, with intermediate goods climbing by nine-tenths of 1 percent and crude goods by 1.5 percent.
Analysts and policy makers have been wondering for months when at least part of this pressure would begin to emerge from the end of the pipeline and affect finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final business or individual user.
Today, Janet L. Yellen, a Federal Reserve governor, said she was still somewhat surprised that "we have thus far seen so little pass-through of higher raw and intermediate materials prices into the Consumer Price Index."
The consumer prices report for February is to be issued on Thursday.
Early in the day, the tentative evidence in the Labor Department report that the pass-through process may be under way unnerved the bond market and pushed interest rates up. But that move was largely offset later by a contradictory assessment in the Fed's periodic survey of business conditions throughout the country.
"Although commodity prices continued to rise, several districts note that the rate of increase has decelerated," the survey, known as the beige book, stated in its summary of the anecdotal findings from its 12 districts. "There is little evidence that strength in labor markets or increases in commodity prices have spilled over into wages or prices of finished goods."
Over all, the report -- compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York based on information collected through March 5 -- suggested that "the pace of the economic expansion has moderated over the past two months." Half the districts found activity slower and the rest described them as "mixed."
The economic strength indicated by the reports on producer prices and factory capacity may somewhat increase the chances that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its March 28 policy meeting to keep inflation in check. Still, the dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen and the German mark, even though hints of higher rates would normally serve to lift it.
Indeed, in recent days, four of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board expressed little enthusiasm for raising rates further, despite the decline in the dollar and some other signs of economic growth. The four governors said the economy was still slowing to a point of steady, sustainable growth with moderate inflation.
February's rise in industrial production -- about twice the January growth but half that in December, after offsetting revisions -- reflected increases in light trucks and business equipment and from a 2.6 percent surge in utility output that reflected winter temperatures.
Factory output rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to a level 6.9 percent above that of February 1994, the Fed's report also showed, while the operating rate for factories was unchanged at 85.1 percent. Motor vehicle assembly was at an annual rate of 13 million, compared with 12.9 million in January.
The beige book, which is part of the preparation by the Fed for meetings of its Open Market Committee, stated that the dive in the value of the Mexican peso had hurt retail sales all along the border and, according to one respondent, "throughout Texas."
But capital goods industries have been "particularly robust," with the Cleveland district reporting heavy export demand. With plants running flat out and the dollar down, said L. Douglas Lee, economist at NatWest Washington Analysis, inflation pressures could emerge from "two sources -- from both imported and exported goods."
Unlike January, when food prices fell and energy soared, these items both rose moderately last month while prices for prescription drugs jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent and over-the-counter drugs jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Intermediate-stage goods, which advanced 1 percent for the second straight month when food and energy are excluded, included a 1.3 percent surge for metals and other durables used in manufacturing that followed a 1.8 percent leap in January. Aluminum mill shapes rose 6.4 percent and cold rolled steel sheet rose 4.2 percent, increases partly offset by declines for copper and brass mill shapes.
Nondurable materials used in factories surged another 1.7 percent, with alkalies and chlorine up 10.6 percent and medicinal and botanical chemicals up 2.6 percent. Primary organic chemicals, however, turned lower by nine-tenths of 1 percent and inedible fats and oil and paint materials also fell after rising in January.
The price of containers accelerated to a 3.9 percent increase last month from 1.9 percent, with aluminum cans soaring 19.6 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1995, Friday

HEADLINE: In Los Angeles, A Time for Planting

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
ON a desolate corner of Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard in the South-Central neighborhood recently, a group of fidgety fifth- and seventh-grade students from two local schools were being taught a lesson in urban renewal, environmental conservation and civic responsibility.
The only tools of learning they needed were a square of barren earth, a shovel and gardening gloves. 
 "How do trees help us?" asked Andy Lipkis, the founder of Treepeople, a California environmental, educational and training organization, as he handed Ana Reyes, 9, a Canary Islands pine seedling, one of 30 for the neighborhood.
"They give us water and make the air cleaner," she answered, and smiled proudly as Mr. Lipkis nodded.
The newly planted trees will also beautify a community in which empty lots from burned-out businesses stand as drab reminders of the riots that erupted in 1992 after four white police officers were acquitted of assault in the videotaped beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King.
Mr. Lipkis's largely volunteer, nonprofit organization, has used the simple act of planting trees not only to educate the young and to enhance this city's esthetic landscape, but also to bridge the chasm between the city's wealthy enclaves and its low-income communities. Both have endured painful wounds recently.
Since 1977, the group's 18,000 members, 1,000 trained volunteers, and neighborhood residents have planted an estimated 1.5 million trees citywide. In 1986, with the help of Pan American World Airways, Treepeople airlifted thousands of fruit trees to Africa, where they helped train groups to plant and maintain them.
Through its planting programs, the group has taken youths who had never seen beyond the worn, cracked sidewalks of South-Central Los Angeles and shown them the wild hills of Malibu. And it has taken rich children from privileged havens like Malibu, Pacific Palisades and Bel Air to the streets of South-Central and to nearby Pico-Union -- neighborhoods where the average lives of the trees, at 40 years, will be longer than the lives of many young black and Hispanic men living nearby.
"The plantings brought together young people from two culturally and economically disparate sections of the Los Angeles area and allowed them to interact with one another as partners of the same extended community," Mr. Lipkis said as he guided a visitor through the Baldwin Hills and South-Central sections to show off young, healthy pine and magnolia trees. "It's also a vehicle to help remove stereotypes and fears."
The trees are also helping to restore natural beauty to a city that has been plagued by disasters from earthquakes to fires, droughts to floods.
"The public perception is that this place is dying, and without having to go through more disasters, we have the ability to sow seeds of a whole new city," Mr. Lipkis said. "The city can have an environmental rebirth, which in turns means an economic rebirth."
Like a latter-day Johnny Appleseed, Mr. Lipkis has expanded Treepeople's mandate beyond planting to include a citizen forestry program that trains local residents to care for trees, an environmental education program that shows children how to recycle and a proposed watershed-management project. In 1993 alone, Treepeople distributed 3,000 fruit trees -- apricots, peaches, pears, figs and apples -- to residents of low-income areas.
Rather than have the organization do the planting, Mr. Lipkis encourages residents to put their hands in the soil and by doing so to help improve their communities.
Eudora Russell of Baldwin Hills discovered a novel way to reduce graffiti in her neighborhood: cover the walls with vines. Delores Reese turned an abandoned, weedy, trash-filled lot on South Fairfax Avenue into an urban forest of Bradford pear trees. Emboldened by that effort, she formed her own nonprofit urban forestry group, called Green Islands in the City.
In some parts of South-Central, however, residents appreciated the beauty of trees and took good care of those on their own properties, but they were reluctant to have trees planted on the streets for fear they would attract beer-drinking loiterers or drug dealers.
Over time, Treepeople has managed to assuage such doubts.
After the riots of 1992, Treepeople organized its largest single urban planting, seven miles of trees in one day -- 300 in all -- along Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard. Scores of residents helped in the planting; others agreed to keep watch over the trees. For the last two years, Treepeople has marked Martin Luther King Jr. Day by planting more trees in South-Central and areas nearby.
Mr. Lipkis's involvement in conservation began 25 years ago when as a 14-year-old camper he learned that smog from Los Angeles was killing the trees in his summer camp in the San Bernardino National Forest. He spent three weeks working with two dozen other campers to revive the dying forest by planting smog-tolerant seedlings obtained from the California forestry division and private nurseries. When still in high school, he organized volunteers to plant and adopt trees, an effort that resulted in the founding of Treepeople in 1973.
Today, Treepeople has a staff of 34 and a budget of $2 million, which comes from private contributions and grants from the city, corporations and foundations. It members, who include Hollywood celebrities like Gregory Peck and the producer David Zucker, pay $25 a year and often make additional donations.
Even now, at 39, Mr. Lipkis still exudes a dogged youthful idealism.
He has been able to persuade tree farmers to turn over their surplus plants. He pestered city officials until they turned over an abandoned fire station situated on 45 acres on Mulholland Drive, near Coldwater Canyon, for the group to use for its headquarters, tree nursery and environmental education center for the more than 75,000 schoolchildren who visit each year.
He used the riots to create good will, taking youths from Malibu to South-Central to help with the cleanup. Some of those same youths returned a few months later to plant trees along streets lined with forlorn rectangles of dirt. In 1993, when fires charred the hills of Malibu, destroying acres of vegetation, young people from South-Central returned the favor. They were among hundreds of volunteers involved in restoration planting.
Mr. Lipkis's passion for the cause persuaded Katie Irving, a young woman he met on a speaking engagement in Melbourne, Australia, to leave her job as a copy writer for an advertising agency and write press releases and reports for Treepeople. In 1983, they were married.
Now, Mr. Lipkis is twisting city officials' arms to grant the group a permanent occupancy permit so they can renovate the Coldwater Canyon site. Treepeople has been operating under a 30-day revocable lease for the last 10 years.
After the fifth and seventh graders from Edison Middle School and Wadsworth Elementary School had secured their seedling between the stakes, making sure they were far enough apart to allow it to sway in the wind and develop its trunk, they formed a circle, held hands and offered a blessing for it.
To give people a sense of ownership of the trees they've planted, Treepeople encourages naming. The students were about to divulge the name they had chosen when an older man who had been standing nearby quietly watching the planting spoke up.
"Can I offer a suggestion for a name?" he asked. The children, who had already chosen the name Charles Drew, listened. "Fatiha," he said. "It's Arabic for first growth or new growth."
With that, the tree was christened Charles Fatiha Drew. "I hope to come back here some day, when I'm older, and show my son our tree," said Jose Castillo, 13. He said he was sure the tree would still be standing, "because I'm not going to let anybody mess with it."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 8, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Home Section on March 16 about Treepeople, a Los Angeles environmental group that plants trees in low-income communities, misstated the year of its largest single planting. It was 1990, not 1992.

HEADLINE: Clinton Meets With Bosnian and Croatian Chiefs

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
President Clinton met today with Bosnian and Croatian leaders in an effort to give new life to a languishing political federation that his Administration says is vital to helping Muslims and Croats stand up to their joint enemy, the Serbs.
Administration officials acknowledge that the agreement that formed the federation of Muslims and Croats in Bosnia, signed a year ago in Washington, had accomplished virtually nothing beyond getting the two groups to stop fighting each other. 
 Tensions between the two sides remain high, and they have done little to forge effective political or military links that would deter the Bosnian Serbs from fighting.
To mark the first anniversary of the agreement, President Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher met with President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia; Kresimir Zubak, the Bosnian Croat who is president of the federation; and Ejup Ganic, the Vice President of Bosnia. Alija Izetbegovic, President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, was unable to attend because of a meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany.
The United States pledged $30 million in economic aid to the federation, while the European Union promised about $120 million. Including pledges from Pakistan, Indonesia, Malaysia, Turkey and other Muslim nations, aid promised to help the Muslim-Croat alliance now exceeds $300 million.
The United States has also promised to provide the Muslims and Croats with a few military advisers to help them coordinate their armies, a move that American officials say is intended to deter future Serbian aggression.
For their part, leaders of Bosnia's Muslims and Croats vowed to set up joint governments at the canton and town level. They also promised to restart efforts to create an integrated police force in Mostar, in the southwest, and to allow displaced Muslims and Croats to return to their homes there.
"The federation is the way to build Bosnia and Herzegovina from the inside," said Vice President Ganic. Up to now, he said, "We have succeeded in building the federation house from the roof; we have built less on the ground."
While many of the steps pledged today are small, the officials said those efforts would be crucial to healing ethnic tensions between the two groups and restoring peace and a sense of community to the 30 percent of Bosnia controlled by Muslims and Croats.
"The federation one year later is a fragile vessel at best, and it needs revitalization," said Richard C. Holbrooke, an Assistant Secretary of State.
Mr. Holbrooke showed little optimism about persuading Bosnia's Serbs, who control about 70 percent of Bosnia, to make peace with the country's Muslim-dominated Government. He again urged the Serbs to accept an international peace plan under which they would reduce their holdings to 49 percent.
President Tudjman said President Clinton told him today that the United States would back Croatia's application to join the Partnership for Peace, a group of former Soviet-bloc nations that cooperate politically and militarily with NATO. Admitting Croatia to the partnership would be unusual because almost one-third of his country is occupied by rebel Serbs.
Mr. Tudjman said he had asked Vice President Al Gore for such support last Saturday in Copenhagen before he announced that he would allow a scaled-down United Nations force in Croatia.
President Tudjman also complained about the disappearance of Gen. Vlado Santic, a Bosnian Croat commander who Croats say was kidnapped by members of Bosnia's mostly Muslim army.
 
Disappearance Sows Tension
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 16 (Reuters) -- The disappearance of a Bosnian Croat officer is sowing tensions between the Croats and the Bosnian Government, a Government official said today.
Bosnian Croats have accused elements of the Government army of kidnapping the officer, Gen. Vlado Santic, on March 8. But a Government official said today that General Santic had vanished and was "most probably was killed" after a brawl erupted at a private party in the Bihac region, in northwestern Bosnia.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Republicans Use Weight To Approve $17 Billion Cut
 House Republicans used their superior numbers to cut $17 billion from the current budget. The bill would end scores of Federal programs, including summer jobs for youths, and would cut $7.3 billion from low-income housing programs. A1. 
 Republicans on the House Budget Committee voted to cut $100 billion from future Federal budgets to pay for some of the tax cuts they promised in the Contract With America. A18.
 
Conoco Told White House About Iran Deal Four Years Ago
 The Administration acknowledged that Conoco had told American officials repeatedly over the last four years that it was negotiating with Iran to develop a $1 billion oilfield. A1.
 
Slowdown Eases Inflation Fears
 Retail prices climbed 0.3 percent, housing starts declined 2.6 percent and weekly claims for unemployment insurance increased, providing evidence that an economic slowdown is helping moderate inflation. D2.
 
Nine West's Deal With U.S. Shoe
 United States Shoe agreed to sell its footwear division to Nine West for $600 million, rejecting a $1.1 billion bid for the entire company from the Italian eyewear company, Luxottica. Analysts expect a battle. D3.
 
Pfizer Increases Research Budget
 Pfizer plans to spend $1.4 billion on research this year, a surge of 20 percent, which analysts said would move Pfizer past Merck in total research spending. D5.
 
Pollution Credits Expanded
 The Administration said it would allow industry to cut costs by trading smog- and water pollution credits, a novelty now mainly restricted to an acid rain pollutant. A20..
 
Bank to Form Annuity Sales Force
 First Union of North Carolina plans to license 800 employees to sell annuities, further weakening the barriers between banks and insurance companies. D2.
 
Orange County Seeks a Deferral
 Orange County, Calif., asked its creditors to delay the repayment of $975 million of county debt due this summer until 1996 to give it time to rebuild its strained finances. D16.
 
No Merger for Duff & Phelps
 Govett and Duff & Phelps terminated their $230 million merger agreement. Analysts said Duff & Phelps was now likely to receive offers from other investment firms. D3.
 
The Options for Viacom
 Wall Street still expects Viacom to find a way to structure a sale of its cable systems without a large tax liability, although Congress appears to have blocked the company's plans to sell the systems to a minority-led group. D5.
 
Mexico Crisis Hangs Over ING
 The biggest question mark hanging over ING of the Netherlands may not be its purchase of Barings, but the effects of the Mexican peso crisis on its earnings. Market Place. D6.
 
U.A.W. Threatened With Strike Today
 Clerical and maintenance workers employed by the U.A.W at dozens of union offices around the country are threatening to strike this morning over job security and workplace quality issues. D2.
 
Charges Against Tax Preparers
 H & R Block and two other tax preparers were charged by New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs with deceptive advertising and misleading the public about their electronic filing and rapid refund services. B3.
Saatchi Shareholders Get Their Say
Saatchi & Saatchi shareholders voted to change the company's name to Cordiant, but not before railing about the rancorous departures of the Saatchi brothers and big account losses. Advertising. D5.

HEADLINE: New York City Watershed Purchases in Danger

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, March 16

 BODY:
In a move that could hinder New York City's plans to protect its upstate watersheds from development it considers harmful, the state has proposed new restrictions on the city's ability to buy land in those watersheds.
City officials said the restrictions would be so burdensome that they could force the city to drop plans to buy 80,000 acres of watershed property and instead turn to a much more expensive alternative for insuring the purity of its water: an $8 billion water filtration system. 
 "With conditions like that, we would never be able to buy an acre of land in the Catskills," said Marilyn Gelber, Commissioner of the City Department of Environmental Protection.
But while Ms. Gelber called the proposed restrictions "onerous" and "impossible to meet," upstate officials praised them, saying they would encourage the economic development the region needs to provide jobs for its residents.
"Buying that land is going to create problems and make it a zero-growth area," said Anthony Bucca, the Supervisor of Hunter, N.Y., in the Catskills. "Nobody will want to live here."
Under the proposal, towns in the watershed would have 60 days to review any proposed land purchases by the city and the right to appeal any purchases to the state environmental agency, which could block the sales. Environmentalists and city officials say that the delays and uncertainties of that process would make it virtually impossible to strike deals with individual property owners.
The rules, while only preliminary, could be the first signal that the city will get little help from the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki in its efforts to limit development in the watershed.
Although the Governor said on Wednesday that he had not seen the regulations yet or evaluated them, in the past he has been a voting ally of upstate senators who oppose such city land purchases.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on Wednesday expressed the hope that the state would give the city what it needed to acquire and protect the watershed lands.
"No final decision has been made yet," Mr. Giuliani said. "I'm pretty certain that we will have the scope to accomplish what we have to accomplish."
Land acquisition is a major element in a broad plan the city has worked out with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to protect the watershed and avoid building a filtration plant. There are more than 150 other elements, including upgrading sewage treatment plants and reducing runoff from farms.
The state restrictions on land purchase were proposed on March 6 by the staff of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which must issue permits governing the acquisition of watershed land.
The city's water, once world famous for its quality, has come under increasing scrutiny in recent decades because of the booming development of northern Westchester and lower Putnam counties, home of the southernmost of the city's three water systems, the Croton.
Development around the Croton system has resulted in increases in bacteria and chemicals, and the city has committed itself to building a $600 million filtration plant for the system.
To avoid building a more expensive filtration plant for the more pristine waters of the city's Catskills and Delaware reservoir systems, the city decided to spend $200 million to acquire 80,000 acres around those reservoirs and dampen further development. Under an agreement with the Federal Government, Ms. Gelber said, the city must acquire the first 10,000 acres by June 30.
Land acquisition has become a political quagmire because of opposition from most of the towns around the Catskills and Delaware watersheds, 35 of which have banded together as the Coalition of Watershed Towns. More than 90 percent of the city's water comes from the Catskills and Delaware watersheds.
The coalition towns, said the group's lawyer, Jeffrey S. Baker, fear that substantial city land purchases would throttle development. They have proposed that the city instead spend $450 million to replace old septic tanks and build new sewage systems in the watershed communities and for loans and grant programs to foster development that would not damage the environment.
The group's intervention forced the matter of land acquisition before an administrative law judge, Robert P. O'Connor, at the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Unable to resolve the matter amicably between the city and the coalition, the department's associate counsel, Glenn Bruening, on March 6 sent Mr. O'Connor the draft of a seven-page set of conditions governing land acquisition.
While the city would prefer to buy land outright from individual owners, the permit conditions require it to allow the coalition and individual towns 60 days to comment about the acquisition of even a single parcel. If the city rejects a town's viewpoint, that town or the coalition has the right to appeal the matter to Mr. O'Connor, who would make the final decision.
The city must also pay each town $20,000 to compensate it for the costs of studying and analyzing the city's plans.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer at the Pace University Law School here, said that informing the towns about which parcels the city intended to buy would make those parcels prohibitively expensive. "It telescopes the city's intentions and doesn't allow the city to walk away from the deal," he said.
He said he was not sure whether the new regulations were "an attack by Pataki on the city or a mistake by the staff."
Ms. Gelber, facing a June 30 deadline for initial land acquisition, said that the hurdles created by the new permit conditions would make it unlikely that any significant portion of the 10,000 acres could be bought in time.

HEADLINE: Conoco Told U.S. Years Ago Of Oil Negotiations With Iran

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
A senior Administration official acknowledged today that Conoco Inc. had repeatedly told American officials over the last four years that they were negotiating with Iran on the development of a $1 billion oilfield, but that the Government focused on the issue -- and decided to block it -- only after the deal was reached earlier this month.
The official, Peter Tarnoff, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, insisted that lower-level officials of the Clinton and Bush Administrations had told Conoco that "this kind of a deal was not consistent with American policy toward Iran," although it was legal under the rules that prevailed until President Clinton said he would bar the transaction on national security grounds earlier this week. 
 But Mr. Tarnoff's testimony painted a picture of an Administration still struggling to pull together a coherent strategy in its effort to isolate Iran, loath to offer it financial support but unwilling to bar American companies from billions of dollars in lucrative business that would be snapped up by Japanese and European competitors.
For example, in his testimony today before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Tarnoff said that while the United States barred the Conoco deal because it would directly help the Iranian Government, it was still unwilling -- after several years of debate -- to prohibit American companies from buying Iranian oil and selling it to third countries. Petroleum industry experts estimate that those purchases amounted to about $3.5 billion last year.
Mr. Tarnoff said the Administration feared that such a ban would lead to "prolonged litigation and controversy," and would ultimately be futile, because it was "unlikely there would be cooperation" from America's major allies in Asia or Europe.
Japan is Iran's biggest customer for crude oil, and Japanese officials have repeatedly made clear that they will not participate in American efforts to isolate the country economically.
Mr. Tarnoff did not explain why it took so long for the State Department and other Government agencies to wake up to the details of the Conoco deal. A vice president at Conoco, Michael Stinson, said the
company was never told to halt its negotiations.
Although the issue was never discussed at the hearing today, other Administration officials have said in recent days that Japan's close relationship with Iran played a significant role in the Administration's move on Tuesday to block the Conoco project, which would have been the first involving Iran and the United States since Washington severed relations with Teheran in 1980.
For years Japan has been supporting the construction in Iran of a giant hydroelectric dam on the Karun River costing hundreds of millions of dollars. Tokyo has slipped past the deadline for announcing the second installment of its support for the dam, a loan of $450 million, because of heavy behind-the-scenes pressure from Washington.
While the two Governments have avoided public recriminations over the project, the issue has taken such a high priority that President Clinton raised it directly with Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama.
The Administration feared that if the Conoco deal went ahead, it would be impossible to insist to the Japanese that they cancel their loans and effectively kill the project, in which Japanese and European companies are deeply involved. Japan has still not indicated what it will do, but it recently sent Nobuo Matsunaga, a former ambassador to the United States, to meet Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani. Mr. Rafsanjani told Mr. Matsunaga, according to Japanese officials, that Iran was not supporting international terrorism or blocking the Middle East peace process.
Mr. Stinson, the Conoco executive, told the committee that his company thought the deal would be workable because American policy was "vague." He said that the company met regularly with State Department officials in Washington and at the embassies in Dubai, Kuwait and London.
"Until recent weeks," he said, "the typical response was: The United States would prefer that you not do this deal, but it's clearly legal."
In opposing the Conoco deal, Washington also feared that Russia and China would use it as a pretext to move ahead with several nuclear power plant projects and other commercial deals.
The hearings today were prompted by legislation introduced recently by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, to ban all financial transactions between Iran and American companies, including their foreign subsidiaries. The Iranian deal would have been conducted by Conoco's Dutch subsidiary; Conoco itself is a Houston-based subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.
"Either we have an embargo on dealing with and taking -- particularly in this case, Iranian oil -- or we should call it off, it's a myth," Mr. D'Amato said today. "We are saying to the Iranians on the one hand that you're going to pay a price for being an outlaw nation," he said, but the world would not take the policy seriously if Washington is "facilitating Iran with U.S. companies."
But Mr. Tarnoff suggested that a ban on dealings with American companies would not deprive Iran of revenue, it would only deprive American companies of profit.
As many State Department officials are quick to acknowledge, however, that is probably exactly what will happen in the case of the project that Conoco abandoned under pressure, not only from the Government but also from members of Du Pont's board. Two French companies, Total and Elf Aquitaine, were negotiating for the same project and seem likely to strike a deal, American officials say.
Mr. Tarnoff said, however, that many American allies "have been looking to see what the United States would do on Conoco by means of a political signal," and that they should realize that proceeding with deals of their own would undercut "the solidarity that many of them at least express rhetorically about Iran."

HEADLINE: Hundreds Turn Out to Seek Jobs That Have No Future

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, March 16

 BODY:
When Jeanene Wright got to the Labor Department office here at 7 this morning, the line already stretched for more than two blocks and the jostling for position was so fierce that police barricades were soon thrown up to keep everyone calm.
Like the nearly 900 other people who gathered here today, Ms. Wright was hoping to secure one of the hundreds of temporary jobs that General Motors Corporation will soon begin offering on the assembly line at its North Tarrytown plant. 
 And like the rest in line, Ms. Wright, a nurse's aide from Yonkers, said she was drawn by the salary: $12.90 an hour, with a work week of more than 40 hours likely. Never mind, she said, that the jobs carry no benefits and are not expected to last past the fall of 1996, when G.M. plans to close its North Tarrytown plant for good.
"This is still better than standing on the welfare line," she said.
They came from as far as away as Manhattan, Poughkeepsie and Teaneck, N.J., all hoping to get an interview for a job with no future. Most of them were black or Hispanic. General Motors officials said they would use the temporary hires to replace as many as 1,500 permanent union assembly-line workers. Under an agreement with the United Auto Workers, the regular union employees are being offered transfers to other G.M. plants as the Tarrytown operation scales down over the next 18 months.
New York State reported an unemployment rate of 6.7 percent in January that was lower than any previous January since 1990, but for minorities the rate is twice that high. And so, today, the people began lining up as early as 4 A.M.
"General Motors is prestige," said Darrell Mollette, 32, a carpenter from the Bronx. "There are not that many jobs available. When a good job like this comes along, you got to make sacrifices to get it."
Many of the applicants said they had high hopes that the plant would remain open past 1996 or that they, too, would be transferred elsewhere someday. But company officials said emphatically that neither possibility was realistic. And Donald C. Martino, the president of Local 664 of the United Auto Workers, said that the decision to hire temporary workers dashed any last hopes he had that the plant, which manufactures minivans, might somehow be saved.
"I hate to say it, because I'm the last one here who stayed optimistic, but I'm finally seeing the light," said Mr. Martino, who first worked at the plant, the company's oldest, 30 years ago. "I don't think we have a chance."
As they waited in line many of the black and Hispanic men and women said that today's hiring represented an opportunity for union-quality work that might not have come their way under other circumstances. Indeed, a majority of the plant's current work force -- about 60 percent -- is white, union officials said.
What transpired today was only the first round in the hiring process. State labor officials assisting General Motors screened all the applicants for proof that they spoke English, had finished high school and are American citizens. If they cleared those hurdles, they were given appointments for 15-minute interviews with company officials sometime in the next six weeks. After that, they will be given physical examinations and drug tests.
In brief seminars for 30 people at a time, labor officials made sure that the applicants knew what would be expected of them if they were hired.
"You have to be available to be in Tarrytown at 6 A.M.," said Patricia Patrick, a state labor department service representative, during one presentation. "You have to have good hand-eye coordination and you have to be able to lift 40 pounds."
Company officials made it clear that the jobs were physically demanding, whether they entailed installing wiring or bolting down doors or priming van bodies for painting. But none of that fazed Cynthia Smith, 36, an unemployed mother of five who used to work as a nurse's aide.
"If I can lift a 250-pound person," she said, "I can lift a 50-pound piece of equipment."
As in other G.M. plants where temporary workers have been hired, the union is being permitted to charge a $20 initiation fee for temporary union membership and two hours' salary each month as union dues, said Mr. Martino, the president of the local. Typically, the new workers will earn salaries that are $6 less an hour than those of the workers they are replacing, G.M. officials said.
Nevertheless, many applicants said that if they were lucky enough to be hired, their wages at G.M. would still be double the going rate at many other companies seeking unskilled labor in the metropolitan New York region.
"Having a benefit package would be nice -- that's why I'm applying to other places," said Ernest Sneed, 49, who is seeking to supplement the income he earns managing two apartment buildings in Elmsford. "But this is a job paying somewhere in the neighborhood of $12 an hour. I'll get what I can get."

HEADLINE: YELTSIN TO ALTER PARADE ON V-E DAY TO DRAW CLINTON

BYLINE: By BERNARD GWERTZMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 16

 BODY:
In a fresh effort to persuade President Clinton to come to Moscow for the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would tailor the Red Square military parade on May 9 to avoid embarrassing the American leader.
"He wants to come," Mr. Yeltsin said of Mr. Clinton, but is "a bit concerned about the whole scenario." He said that to make it easier for Mr. Clinton to come for the celebration, the parade in Red Square would be limited to veterans of World War II and no military equipment would be included. 
 The Russian leader, speaking in his usual mixture of seriousness and occasional bluster, has been pressing Mr. Clinton to join other Western leaders in Moscow on V-E Day, and then to extend the visit into a summit meeting with Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Clinton, worried about the Russian offensive in Chechnya and fearing the consequences if a summit meeting produces no concrete results, has not said yes or no to the May invitation, although he has said he would like to meet sometime this year.
Speaking in an interview with foreign editors, Mr. Yeltsin confirmed that the United States and Russia were drafting an exchange of letters between him and Mr. Clinton over NATO expansion, letters that are aimed at meeting some Russian concerns over having NATO move closer to its borders. The United States wants Russia to join the so-called Partnership for Peace, a form of association with NATO falling short of membership.
Mr. Yeltsin said the press had "overdramatized" his concerns about NATO, but he expressed irritation on the issue. His voice rising and speaking with intensity, he criticized what he called "forcing the pace of NATO expansion."
"What's happening is that we have just recently abandoned the bloc divisions," he said. "Now assume that some East European and Central European countries would join NATO and the border would move immediately closer to Russia, so the situation would appear to suggest that we would again have a bloc situation with NATO."
"Is it really consistent with all-European security?" he asked. "No, it is not. The situation will not be calm."
These are essentially the same arguments Mr. Yeltsin made, also with some vigor, at a conference on European security held in Budapest last fall. He has been concerned for some time over accusations by Russian nationalists and hard-line Communists that Russian foreign policy has been too accommodating to Washington's interests at the expense of Moscow's.
Another major problem for Mr. Clinton as he considers whether to come to Moscow is the continuing Russian military action against separatist guerrillas in Chechnya. In the interview, Mr. Yeltsin gave no sign that he was interested in reaching a political settlement with the leader of the Chechen rebels, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev.
"I am not going to meet with him," Mr. Yeltsin said of Mr. Dudayev. "He is a gangster. He is a bandit. He should be tried for having killed so many of his own people."
Speaking in Russian to the small group of foreign editors who had been invited for the session, Mr. Yeltsin said Mr. Clinton had passed the word that although he would like to make the trip in May, he did not want to be seen and photographed with the kind of modern Russian military equipment that is being used in Chechnya.
Saying he was addressing Mr. Clinton's concerns, Mr. Yeltsin said, "We want to arrange a program so that in Red Square, there will be a military parade, but without any military equipment." He said there would be speeches by him and by veterans.
"To put it in a nutshell, we shall meet the conditions," he said.
Other Russian officials said the Red Square parade would consist of some 2,500 World War II veterans, and would be preceded by religious ceremonies. Another parade, including modern arms and soldiers, is being planned for Poklonnaya Hill in northern Moscow, some distance from Red Square, and Mr. Clinton would not be asked to visit that parade.
Of the World War II allies, only President Francois Mitterrand of France has said he would be in Moscow on May 9. In the United States and Western Europe, V-E Day is celebrated on May 8, and Mr. Clinton has reportedly been pondering whether to hold a ceremony in Washington on May 8 or whether to attend similar ceremonies in London and Paris on that date.
There has been no word from the British on their plans, Russian officials said. The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, has reportedly also been invited, and Mr. Yeltsin said during the meeting that he has become closer to Mr. Kohl than to any other Western leader.
"I can also add that it is with Helmut Kohl of all the world leaders that we have the most frequent telephone conversations," he said. "Hardly a week passes without my calling him or his calling me. I believe this is very helpful, and we compare notes. We have very good relations with him, and very good contacts. We are real friends."
The interview, in a Kremlin conference room, lasted nearly an hour, and was Mr. Yeltsin's first extended meeting with the news media in some time. He looked fit and spoke firmly and clearly. On a trip to Kazakhstan five weeks ago, Mr. Yeltsin seemed unable to walk without assistance, and he has been rumored to drink heavily and to need medication for back pain.
Today he seemed in a good mood, and often reacted vigorously when he disagreed with a question. He was most angered when he was told that many in the West wondered who was directing Russia's economic policy.
"The most important decisions are made by the President," he said, speaking sharply and emphasizing every word.
The editors -- two from Britain and one each from the United States, France, Italy, Germany, Egypt and Japan -- had been invited specifically to receive briefings on Chechnya, where fighting continues, but at a less ferocious pace than a month ago when Russian troops battled hard for control of Grozny, the capital.
But little was said about Chechnya that was new, either by Mr. Yeltsin or at a larger symposium the night before in which officials from several ministries took part.
Although Washington has been somewhat critical of the use of force in Chechnya, it has supported Moscow's right to quell secessionist movements, and Mr. Yeltsin seemed appreciative of the American attitude.
"The United States and President Clinton were very restrained and quiet in assessing the situation in Chechnya," he said, "and President Clinton on many occasions, including news conferences, was very firm in asserting that he firmly supports President Yeltsin."
Mr. Yeltsin said that although he would not deal with Mr. Dudayev, the Chechen leader, Russian officials were still trying to negotiate with others.
"I believe at this time they are moving on more energetically than in the past," he said of these contacts. "We are talking with the elders, district representatives, city representatives and leaders. We have already set up the government of Chechnya, and are looking forward to organizing elections to the Chechen parliament." He was referring to the Russian effort to create a rival government to Mr. Dudayev's.
But he acknowledged that his Government's efforts had so far not won much Western support.
"We realize that until such democratic elections are held, we will be unable to convince the world that the situation in Chechnya is really positive, really democratic and there are no human rights violations," he said.
In his opening remarks, he gave a fairly optimistic appraisal of Russian society. He said that this year, the pace of economic reform was better than last year, with February's inflation about 11 percent a month, as against 17 percent in January 1994.
He said that 50 percent of the industries were reporting growth, and that companies responsible for 60 percent of the country's gross national product had been privatized. And he said the goal was to reduce inflation to between one and two percent a month by the end of the year.
"But the most important thing we have been able to achieve is the fact that the people who have been for 75 years living under a totalitarian regime, and knew nothing about private property, they are now beginning to understand what is a market," he said.

HEADLINE: In Power Industry, Changes Batter Independents

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
For Charles F. Goff, the president and chief executive of Destec Energy, the solution to a bad turn in his business is tantalizingly close: the distance he can drive a golf ball.
The Lyondell electric plant of Destec, an independent power company, sits a little more than 200 yards from a complex of chemical and oil refineries near Houston, most of which would gladly buy the inexpensive power produced by the plant. 
 But the distance that this eager golfer could have easily nailed off the tee might as well have been hundreds of miles away. The transmission system from the plant is controlled by the Houston Lighting and Power Company, the regulated utility that has long served those industrial customers. And unless it is pressed by the Texas Public Utility Commission, the utility is not about to let its own transmission lines be used to help a competitor lure its customers away.
The plight of Destec is similar to that of hundreds of independent power companies around the country. Federal law once required utilities to buy the power produced by independents like Destec. But late last month the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ruled that two California utilities might be able to walk away from the high-priced deals they had struck with several independent producers. Independents now fear that the agency will let other utilities out of their contracts as they expire.
What is worse, as far as the independent power producers are concerned, existing long-term contracts could be put in jeopardy, too.
This week the New York State Public Service Commission, in a big shift of policy, asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to allow New York State Electric and Gas, a large upstate utility, to break its 15-year contracts with two independent power producers so the utility could renegotiate the pacts and bring down the cost.
And just as independents are on the verge of losing their best customers, they are finding it difficult to get around barriers that make it tough for them to find new ones. Independents in states like California, Maine and New York, where many of the plants are situated, all face similar struggles.
It is an important issue not only to the independents, but also to the large industries that want to lower their electric bills. Most independents can produce electricity more cheaply than the regulated utilities can, and if the independents were free to sell their power to all comers, industry experts say, the resulting competition would lower electric rates around the country.
"The availability of alternative sources of cheaper power will force down rates and bring change," said David T. Flanagan, president and chief executive of Central Maine Power, a utility in Maine, where large amounts of power are also set to come onto the market as contracts run out.
But Houston Lighting and Power, a subsidiary of Houston Industries, worries that increased competition would make it much more difficult to keep power flowing at reasonable costs to its 1.3 million customers, maintain the transmission system and provide backup services.
"Just to let someone like Destec to basically hook up into the transmission system without bearing any part of the cost creates some major problems," said William Carter, a Republican Representative in the Texas Legislature. "We're going to be looking for some equitable way for this to happen."
Despite intense lobbying, Destec has largely been left to fend for itself. The company has been unable to find a state legislator to sponsor a bill providing it with more access to customers.
The quandary faced by Destec is most clearly shown by its Lyondell plant near Houston, which was built in 1985 as a co-generation plant that supplies steam and power to the ARCO Chemical Company. The plant, which is connected directly to the ARCO plant, can generate 465 megawatts of power, but supplies ARCO with only 66 megawatts.
The surplus power of the plant was sold under a 10-year contract for 6 cents a kilowatt-hour to Houston Lighting and Power, which serves Houston and a 5,000-square-mile area along the Texas gulf coast. The contract generated about $1.48 billion.
Even though Houston Lighting and Power thought the price was too high, it and other utilities were mandated by the state to sign many such long-term contracts under the provisions of a 1978 Federal law that encouraged the building of small co-generation plants. The plants were seen as better alternatives, because of the expense and risk of building big coal and nuclear power plants to replace generators that were dependent on imported oil. Independents now generate 6 percent of the power in the United States.
The law required utilities to buy the power at a rate equal to that which the utilities would have spent to generate it themselves. Many states set rates based in part on estimates of future oil prices, which were expected to soar to $70 a barrel by the 1990's. Oil is currently trading for about $18 a barrel.
 Meanwhile, utilities in Texas were in the middle of their own building boom, putting up huge coal-fired and nuclear plants. "There was a need for power," said Dan Bulla, who is in charge of investor relations at Houston Lighting and Power. "We spent about $1 billion a year for a decade to keep up."
Then the bottom fell out of the Texas economy, and the state ended up swimming in surplus power.
Founded by the Dow Chemical Company in 1989, Destec still prospered because the Texas utilities were locked into their long-term contracts for its gas-fired plants. Growing revenues and profits made the company popular on Wall Street. When it went public in March 1991, the stock sold for $20 a share. Yesterday shares of Destec closed at $9.875, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Last year, however, Destec went from feast to famine as it became one of the first independents in the country to lose a big long-term contract. Without its deal with the utility, Destec has been forced to run some of its plants below capacity. Its Lyondell plant, which can produce 465 megawatts, is generating about 250 megawatts, most of it fed into the grid system of the regulated utilities at less than than 3 cents a kilowatt-hour.
Destec is feeling the pinch. In its fourth quarter, revenues fell 14 percent, to $206.4 million. Analysts predict that its earnings will fall to about 40 to 50 cents a share this year, from $1.84 a share in 1994.
The management of Destec has been able to sell power temporarily to some municipal utilities, like San Antonio's, which the regulated utilities are required to carry, for a fee, over their transmission lines.
But Mr. Goff is after bigger game. Rick Zalesky, the manager of energy services for the Chevron Corporation, which has a large petrochemical plant near the Lyondell plant, said his company was eager to buy power from Destec.
"It's really hurting Destec and it could really help us," he said. "Destec has power that they would love to sell to us, but the regulators won't allow that. That's crazy."
The regulated utilities like Houston Lighting and Power have argued that the independents should not be allowed to raid their biggest industrial customers. "They want to cherry-pick the most profitable customers," Mr. Bulla said. "The result would be an increase in the cost of power to the smaller residential and commercial customers."
Mr. Goff of Destec predicted that the pressure on the utilities would grow as states sought to attract new industry and keep existing ones by making cheaper power more available.
"There is a consumer-driven movement that is sweeping the country demanding cheap power," he said. "That movement is the same one that has led to the ability to select long-distance telephone suppliers. That movement will lead to competition in the utility industry in the not too distant future."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles F. Goff, president and chief executive of Destec Energy, at the company's Lyondell plant near Houston. It was built in 1985 as a co-generation plant to supply steam and power to ARCO Chemical. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times) (pg. D4)
 
Diagram: "Independent Power"
 A Federal law has required utilities to buy power from independent producers at higher-than-market rates. That, in part, has helped the independents claim a significant share of the total output in Texas and across the country.
 But as the long-term, high-priced contracts expire, the independents are left to scramble for customers and fight with he utilities about access to the distribution grid.
